HEADLINE: Anti-Business Chickens Are Coming Home to Roost 

 BODY:
Long Island lost hundreds of people when the World Trade Center collapsed. It also seems to have lost its way.
 New Jersey is quietly moving to accommodate hundreds of companies made homeless by the attack. New Jersey officials recognize that corporations are now embracing decentralization so that any future attacks cannot wreak the type of strategic damage done on Sept. 11. Stephan Schultz of the Jersey City Economic Development Commission told a recent edition of The Financial Post, "It will change the skyline of New Jersey." 
 In contrast, Long Island is silent in the wake of this economic transfer of power "Displaced Companies Call, but Few Sign Leases," L.I.@Work, Sept. 30 . 
Regional business organizations are stymied in making the case for Long Island because there is little leverage they can offer in an environment where local zoning laws throttle orderly economic growth and new commercial construction. In towns like Oyster Bay, the Town Board actually delights in railroading new projects. In Garden City, once the retail hub of the county, village fathers are preventing the construction of a simple parking lot to serve rehabilitated office space. Meanwhile, leadership from Nassau is in the deep-freeze, awaiting the swearing-in of a new county executive in January. 
Oyster Bay and similar communities hostile to business should expect these reactionary policies to come back and haunt them as a stinging recession saps economic growth, destroys tax revenues and erodes new investment. Even sales taxes are expected to take a pounding. Other townships that have a record of partnering with business, like Hempstead and North Hempstead, should stretch their vision and consider what roles they can play in the Long Island leadership vacuum that has developed in a post-W.T.C. environment. Similarly, a public-private task force should be created immediately for the express purpose of determining how Long Island should navigate now that major corporations are pondering their options for space, location and manpower.

DESMOND RYAN
Executive Director
Association for a Better
Long Island
Hauppauge

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
The Bear Choice: Big Lure, Big Risk

BYLINE:  By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:
A HANDFUL of mutual funds chalked up spectacular returns in the third quarter -- a couple of them even doubled their investors' money -- in stark contrast to the average diversified mutual fund, which had negative total returns of more than 16 percent.
 Did the winning managers know of wonder stocks that were overlooked by their competitors? No. Their portfolios, known as bear funds, are set up to have opposite performances from market indexes like the Nasdaq 100 or the Standard & Poor's 500. The funds accomplish this not by putting money into stocks, but by investing principally in futures contracts, options contracts, swaps and other financial instruments and by engaging in short sales -- in other words, the same instruments and techniques that many institutional investors use to hedge their portfolios. 
 The two leaders of the last quarter, Rydex Venture 100, which climbed 116.97 percent, and ProFunds UltraShort OTC, which surged 116.92 percent, seek to provide daily returns that are double the inverse performance of the Nasdaq 100. 
Gazing at the recent returns of these funds, many investors may find them alluring, but many investment advisers and fund managers are offering advice that makes them sound a bit like park rangers: Don't feed the bears.
"One of the problems with the whole fund industry is that people buy into the last quarter's or last year's hottest performers," said Charles Creighton, a financial planner at Equity Services Inc. in Broomall, Pa. "Many of these funds use aggressive leveraging techniques. There is a lot of risk attached. That does not mean there aren't people who can't use them and get that return, but they're not for the Main Street investor. They're for the aggressive investor."
Dan Rivera, head of global equities at American Express, said that while anyone who bought into a bear market fund in early 2000 could now reap profits, "to commit to the funds at this point is to fight the Fed."
"Monetary and fiscal policy are both stimulative," he said, and "the biggest determinant of equity prices is interest rates, not earnings."
The stock market could drop an additional 10 percent or 15 percent, he said, but "I would argue that at some point, and my view is sooner rather than later," it will turn back up, possibly suddenly and steeply. Under those circumstances, the bear funds would all plunge.
Companies that manage these funds contend that they are offering individual investors a valuable tool for ironing out risk in their investing, but they do not view them as the place to invest an entire portfolio.
Michael L. Sapir, chairman and chief executive of ProFund Advisors in Bethesda, Md., said: "We have 26 bullish funds and three bearish funds. We're not intrinsically bearish."
"The bearish funds are intended to be short term -- to allow you to hedge a portfolio," he added, just as institutional investors and professional portfolio managers do. 
"Most people don't know how to use futures or options, so this allows individual investors to do something they know how to do -- buy a mutual fund," to offset the risk in their traditional stock funds, Mr. Sapir said. "It's for the middle-tier investor," he added, not for beginners.
The funds are also for investors who think that the market will fall, he said. If you want to short the market, even for just a week or a month, the funds can provide a convenient way to do so, he said, because "there is no entry fee, no exit fee and no restriction on how long you have to hold."
Charles J. Tennes, a senior portfolio manager at Rydex Funds, said the funds could be used to mold a portfolio and to lower its overall level of risk. "Investors don't focus enough on risk-adjusted return," he added.
Mr. Tennes said an investor might sell 20 percent of a long portfolio and put half the proceeds into Rydex Venture 100 and the other half into cash or short-term Treasuries. That would result in only 60 percent as much risk as in the original portfolio, he said, and the cash position would mean added flexibility.
"I wouldn't recommend anyone go all short," he said.
A LONG-TERM investor who did focus his holdings on a bear fund would have had substantial losses. ProFunds, for example, reports on its Web site that a $10,000 investment in the UltraShort OTC fund at its inception in June 1998 would have fallen to just $385 by March 31, 2000. But it would have climbed back to $1,279 by Sept. 30 this year.
Some investment professionals say the high volatility contributes to their skepticism that using such funds to fine-tune a portfolio will work as well in practice as in theory. Hedging limits a portfolio's upside potential, as well as its downside, they add.
Michael Stolper, an independent investment adviser whose firm, Stolper & Company of San Diego, works with institutions and affluent individuals, said the bear funds "are trying to straddle the fence to limit damage, but short-selling is one of those activities that is very difficult to get right."
He advises people to put their money into cash, bonds and stocks, either directly or through mutual funds, rather than into short positions. 
Peter Cundill, president of Cundill & Associates in Vancouver, British Columbia, and portfolio manager of the Ivy Cundill Global Value fund, had a similar view. "Common stocks wisely chosen have done well over a period of time," he said, "and I suspect that will be true of the future." 
Mr. Cundill, who has 30 years of experience and manages $1.8 billion in assets for institutional and individual investors, offered another argument against taking a bearish position: "If you can borrow money, then over time markets will be all right," he said, and credit is readily available now. "It's only periods like 1974 that you cannot borrow that markets are hazardous to your health," he added. 
Another value manager who is skeptical of bear funds is John C. Holden, vice president and senior portfolio manager at Fort Washington Investment Advisors in Cincinnati and manager of the Touchstone Value Plus fund. Because of the market's plunge after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, investors may well be tempted to go into a bear market fund, he said, but "that is an emotional response to an external shock to the financial system."
"America is a very resilient country," he said "We will get out of this."
History is on his side. Richard J. Nash, chief market strategist at Victory Capital Management, a unit of KeyCorp of Cleveland, said that research has shown that the market usually rebounds within six months of a crisis.
The terrorist attacks have pushed "economic recovery farther out into the future," Mr. Nash said, but he expects strong growth by mid-2002. And he expects markets to anticipate that growth, recovering early in the year. 
Investors in bear funds, of course, risk losses when the market turns back up, Mr. Holden said. "It is impossible to be agile enough to time the top or the bottom," he added. 
The money needed to invest in the funds could be a barrier for some individual investors. ProFunds has a $15,000 minimum for self-directed individual accounts. Rydex has a $25,000 minimum for individual investors; the minimum applies to an overall account, however, not necessarily to individual funds. Smaller investments may be possible through investment advisers and some brokers.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael L. Sapir of ProFund Advisors says the firm's bearish funds are intended for short-term investing. (Marty Katz for The New York Times) Graph: "Feeding the Bears"Bear market funds, intended to have opposite performance from market indexes, soared in the last quarter. Grap shows the weekly performance through Sept. 28 for the ProFunds UltraShort OTC, a leading bear fund and the Nasdaq 100 index. (Source: Morningstar Inc., Bloomberg Financial Markets)

HEADLINE: Office-Building Plans Come Off the Shelf 

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
THE need for prime office space as a result of the destruction of 13 million square feet of office space and damage to 16.5 million more square feet in the attack on the World Trade Center has caused developers and brokers to focus attention on long-dormant development projects in Midtown and elsewhere.
 Douglas Durst, president of the privately owned Durst Organization, said he intended to proceed with a 2-million-square-foot 50-story tower at the northwest corner of 42nd Street and the Avenue of the Americas starting next year, even though he does not yet own all the land at the site. Because the site is diagonally across from Bryant Park, Mr. Durst is calling the proposed building One Bryant Park. 
 Charles A. Gargano, the chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, said he is eager to see a 1.1-million-square-foot office tower rise over the Port Authority Bus Terminal at 42nd Street and Eighth Avenue. Since he is also vice chairman of the Port Authority's board, he is in a position to help make this happen, although he said he cannot make the private sector developers build before they have signed an anchor tenant. 
Other building sites identified by real estate executives as receiving renewed interest include one at the intersection of Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street and a parking lot on the eastern side of Eighth Avenue between 41st and 42nd Streets.
Immediately to the south of the parking lot, The New York Times Company has recently reaffirmed plans, first announced last year, to build a new headquarters facing the bus terminal between 40th and 41st Streets. If the necessary agreements to proceed with construction are obtained, The Times would occupy about half of the 1.37 million square feet of space, with the rest available for commercial rent by The Times's development partner, the Forest City Ratner Companies.
But some real estate executives say there is a lot of office space coming back to the market as companies shrink their operations, and they say a wave of new building may not be justified. "Anyone drawing long-term conclusions from short-term shortages of space is making a mistake," said Michael T. Cohen, the president of Williams Real Estate, a brokerage and services company.
He said a lot of space has flooded onto the market since Sept. 11 as companies that had been thinking of subletting unneeded space suddenly decided the time was right. According to an analysis by Williams of information provided by CoStar Realty Information, which tracks market data, a total of about 850,000 square feet of space in Manhattan was on the market two weeks before the attack. Two weeks afterward, the amount of space available ballooned to more than 6 million square feet, and the amount continues to remain high, company officials said.
"The next 12 months are absolutely predictable -- the feeding frenzy will continue," Mr. Cohen said. "But it is an artificial period that does not tell you what will happen later." The loss of the World Trade Center buildings would suggest that new construction is justified. But, he said, if the economy continues to weaken, enough sublet space may pour on to the market to satisfy continuing demand. In addition, real estate executives say, much of the damaged space near the Trade Center is likely to be repaired and available for use within three to six months -- well before any new construction could be completed.
Lenders are likely to discipline overeager developers by requiring that they have creditworthy tenants signed up before providing construction loans, said Peter Pattison, a real estate consultant. "I don't see speculative development in the short term," he said. "Very few lenders want to fund speculative projects. What they want to see is buildings packaged with tenants."
The city is likely to see a flurry of what Mr. Pattison calls "cheap development." He said developers will announce projects, complete with building plans and renderings, and start through the city's laborious approval process, hoping to sign up an anchor tenant before the moment of truth arrives for the actual decision to build.
He said a well-financed developer could afford to put a few million dollars into design and permitting before facing the hundreds of millions it costs to build a skyscraper. And doing this preliminary work reduces the time between when tenants sign leases and when they can actually move into a completed structure.
Not all of the attention is focused on New York. Jersey City has been established as an alternative to downtown Manhattan, and building projects there may get under way if tenants commit to the location. Developers like Mack-Cali and Hartz Mountain and the securities firm Goldman Sachs have sites on or near the waterfront that could be developed as well.
One of the first buildings to come out of the ground in Manhattan is likely to be a boutique office building at 505 Fifth Avenue, at the northeast corner of Fifth and 42nd street, said Mary Ann Tighe, vice chairman of Insignia/ESG, the brokerage and services company. "That site can be cleared fast -- there's nobody in those buildings," she said of the site, partly occupied by a one-story former bazaar-like shopping complex.
The building would be of modest size by New York standards, with 275,000 square feet in a slender building rising 25 or 26 stories. Kurt Eichler, executive vice president of the developer, LCOR, which is based in suburban Philadelphia, said he expected to sign a principal tenant before commencing construction.
The company is also involved in a commercial project in Queens West where as much as 5 million square feet of office space could be built near the East River facing the United Nations. LCOR has also been designated as the developer of the 300,000-square-foot Air Train building in downtown Jamaica, Queens. About half the building will be occupied by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Mr. Eichler said, with tenants needing easy access to Kennedy Airport the likely candidates for the rest of the space. No starting date has been set for that project. 
Mr. Eichler said companies displaced from the Trade Center area had for the most part solved the problem of finding temporary space to stay in business. He said now they are considering more long-range questions, such as whether it makes sense to concentrate all their operations in one location.
He said development in Manhattan and other boroughs will give companies "an opportunity to diversify their assets, yet keep their people in the city."
One significant consideration is that most of the buildings destroyed at the Trade Center were modern and up to date technically, said Bruce Mosler, president of United States operations at Cushman & Wakefield, the brokerage and services company.
In real estate circles, the most modern and efficiently laid out buildings are termed Class A, while older and less efficient buildings fall into the Class B or C categories. Companies displaced by the attack may have settled for Class B or C space as an emergency measure but may want to find a Class A space for a more permanent home, Mr. Mosler said.
"Forty-four percent of the space that was destroyed was Class A, which means we have a shortage of Class A space in Manhattan," Mr. Mosler said. "With very little Class A space available, there is a need for development, although it should be done on a selective basis." 
Barry Gosin, the chief executive of Newmark & Company Real Estate, a brokerage and management company, said the destruction in the Trade Center area would increase "pressure for development." Although there has been discussion about rebuilding the center, city officials have said it will take up to a year just to clear the site of the rubble from the collapsed buildings.
Since nothing is likely to be built there for a while, Mr. Gosin said, there is increased attention on the few sites in Manhattan that are well located and can be easily cleared for new construction. He said the most likely development prospects were the proposed 37-story tower over part of the Port Authority Bus Terminal on the west side of Eighth Avenue between 40th and 42nd Streets and a parking lot owned by members of the Milstein family on the east side of Eighth Avenue between 41st and 42nd Streets, directly north of the New York Times site. Since the Times Company will be the principal occupant of its building, it is not usually included on lists of possible development projects seeking an anchor tenant.
THE best site of all, Mr. Gosin said, is the Durst site on the eastern section of the block bordered by 42nd and 43rd Streets and Broadway and Avenue of the Americas, whose western end is now occupied by a 1.6-million-square-foot-tower, 4 Times Square, that was developed by Durst.
Mr. Durst's plans are important because, real estate executives say, he is one of the few developers in the city who can finance a building project with internal funds and without securing an anchor tenant in advance. Indeed, 4 Times Square was begun as a speculative building, although an anchor tenant, the Conde Nast publishing group, signed on shortly after work began. 
Mr. Durst's family owns most of the site, which is about two-thirds of the block. But he does not own three parcels. One, owned by the Maidman family, is the site of a largely abandoned 22-story brick office tower, now said by the Maidmans to be undergoing conversion for residential use.
Another, an L-shaped tract facing both the Avenue of the Americas and 42nd Street is owned by the brothers Joseph and Ralph Bernstein, who have had a long and complicated relationship with Mr. Durst and his late father, Seymour. Mr. Durst has said he expects to work out a deal for the third parcel, on the corner of the block, with its owners, the Rosenberg family.
Mr. Durst said he expected to begin demolition of the buildings he owns late next spring or early in the summer and said he was "pretty confident we will have most of the block." He said he had discussed with Mr. Gargano the possibility of using the state's power to condemn property as a way of assembling the block and said the response was "very receptive." He said he expected special legislation to be passed next year to waive the state's environmental quality review, "which causes big delays in condemnation."
For his part, Mr. Gargano said he had talked to Mr. Durst but would say only that Empire State Development "will explore ways to streamline the development process" for the Durst project.
But he added that the state agency would focus "on those projects already in the design process or where ground has been broken already." He said it was important to get companies now in temporary space into permanent locations in the city.
Mitchell Maidman said the building his family owns on the site that is largely surrounded by Durst holdings "is under development." He added, "We plan to capitalize on the great opportunity in Times Square."
As for Mr. Durst's suggestion that condemnation might, subject to legislative action by Albany, be possible, he said: "It will be interesting to see how the months play out. What process is there for condemning our site? It is outside the Times Square development district."
Joseph Bernstein said he believed Mr. Durst was "using muscle" to try to build the largest possible building. As it is, he said, "he could build a pretty big building without going all the way to Sixth Avenue."
Nevertheless, he offered to "sit down with Mr. Gargano and Durst to work things out for the benefit of New York." A real estate executive said Mr. Durst could build a 1.8-million-square-foot structure on the land he currently owns; to get to 2 million square feet he would need the additional parcels.
The proposed Durst building may have special appeal to state and city officials eager to keep financial-industry companies in the city. Mr. Durst said the lower floors of One Bryant Park would have large spaces, suitable to replace some of the trading floors lost at the Trade Center. "We are looking for a financial institution as an anchor tenant," he said.
MR. DURST said he also intends to press ahead with plans for a site he has leased between 57th and 58th Streets, 11th and 12th Avenues. The first phase of the project is a six-story, 500,000-square-foot building in the middle of the block that would be a data center, housing computers and telecommunications switching equipment.
Although demand for these facilities has dropped recently, Mr. Durst said he believed the building will be attractive because it will have its own gas-fired electrical generating equipment and will be independent of the Con Ed grid. This, he said, will eliminate the need for backup generators and fuel tanks to assure continuity of operations.
Mr. Durst said he may proceed later with an office building on 11th Avenue and said he has had discussions with city officials about building a light rail line along the avenue to provide mass transportation for what he said was a developing office corridor.
Another developer said that he could, once an anchor tenant is obtained, be under way within two months. The site is 9 Metrotech South, the last building in the 5.3-million-square-foot Metrotech complex in downtown Brooklyn.
"Our plan is to start the new building within 60 days," said Bruce Ratner of the Forest City Ratner Companies, the developer of Metrotech. "We will be the first building out of the ground since the disaster."
He said that the original plan for 9 Metrotech South was for a 500,000-square-foot building but that he would seek approval for a 700,000-square-foot structure because of an anticipated increase in demand. He said work would start upon the signing of a large tenant while seeking approval for the taller structure. City officials have promised to expedite the often-convoluted process, he added. 
Mr. Ratner said he doubted there would be much new construction in Manhattan without what he called "deep incentives" from the city. He said land costs, construction costs, taxes and other expenses mean a developer has to charge annual rents of $70 to $80 a square foot to justify a project. "A lot of the people who were displaced from the World Trade Center," he said, "are not in the $70 to $80 category."
He said incentives offered to companies that move employees from Manhattan or out of state to designated locations like downtown Brooklyn are worth $15 to $20 a square foot. This effectively cuts the cost of Class A space there 60 percent below comparable space in Manhattan.
But, he said, development sites are difficult to find or assemble and executing projects is difficult. "It is very hard to do a building if you haven't done it before," Mr. Ratner said.
Ms. Tighe said that the difficulties of replacing the office space lost at the Trade Center are real and that state and city officials will have to lend assistance to private developers if they want the new space built quickly in New York.
She said the state needs to use its power to take land to help to complete the assembly of building sites. The city needs to establish ways to get construction material into the city and particularly Manhattan. Concrete cannot currently be delivered to Manhattan because inspections of the delivery trucks outlast the useful life of the product.
"The other big issue is real estate taxes, which are extremely daunting," Ms. Tighe said. "Only two or three projects in recent years have been built without some kind of tax break."

SECTION: Section 3; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 1162 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
Opening A Road Others Avoided

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH HARRIS

 BODY:
DONALD H. MUHLENKAMP stands apart from the Wall Street crowd. To develop his own investment style, "I had to step outside of Wall Street language," Mr. Muhlenkamp said. 
 Shareholders have benefited from his idiosyncratic approach. Mr. Muhlenkamp's $400 million portfolio, called the Muhlenkamp Fund, has gained 11.33 percent a year, on average, over the three years through Sept. 30, according to Morningstar Inc., compared with an annualized gain of 2.04 percent for the Standard and Poor's 500-stock index. The fund was down 8.57 percent for the 12 months through Sept. 30, compared with a decline of 26.61 percent for the S.& P. 
 Mr. Muhlenkamp, who works from Wexford, Pa., a suburb of Pittsburgh, has distanced himself from the financial district both in personal style and in his approach to investing. At 57, he rides a 1984 Harley-Davidson with noise and power that remind him of the tractors on his father's farm in western Ohio. Mr. Muhlenkamp said his investing reflected the lessons he learned there: Crops do not grow every month. Not every seed sprouts. Weed early.
Not all of Mr. Muhlenkamp's training, however, was in farming. He received an engineering degree from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and an M.B.A. from Harvard Business School. He got his start as an analyst in 1968, when classmates from Harvard asked him to join their investment firm, Berkley Dean & Company, in New York City.
In 1970, he moved to the Integon Corporation, an insurance holding company in Winston-Salem, N.C. At the time, many money managers discounted inflation, calling it an economic problem of the past. Speaking of his experience from 1968 through much of the 1970's, he said he had to set his own standards for what companies are worth in various market climates.
HE also drew upon his education as an engineer, which taught him that when the basics are understood, everything else falls into place. "In the late 1960's," he said, "business spoke a different language than Wall Street." While business looked at return on equity, for example, Wall Street focused on growth, he said. 
Mr. Muhlenkamp has honed his investing style by managing private accounts for individuals and institutions since founding Muhlenkamp & Company in 1977; the firm started the mutual fund in 1988.
Like other value investors, he focuses on finding good companies at reasonable prices. Unlike some of his peers, however, who may rely mainly on low price-to-earnings or price-to-book ratios in companies, Mr. Muhlenkamp demands above-average returns on equity; these days, that means greater than 14 percent annually. But in the current climate, he also looks for a price-to-earnings ratio that is below the percentage figure for return on equity. Consumer cyclical and financial stocks have filled that bill lately.
Return on equity reflects a company's strength and potential for growth, he said. If the return is higher than the growth rate as measured by sales and earnings, free cash flow is more likely. "When I try to translate this for people, we tell them we want to buy Pontiacs and Buicks when they go on sale," he said. "We'd like to buy Cadillacs, but they don't go on sale very often." 
Mr. Muhlenkamp resists labels that categorize his fund by style or market capitalization (Morningstar, for example, calls it a mid-cap value fund.) Unlike fund groups that let shareholders slice and dice their investments in a broad range of narrowly defined funds, Muhlenkamp & Company runs just this single fund -- and it may hold companies of any market capitalization.
He also bucks the trend by refusing to organize stocks into generally accepted sectors. For instance, he does not group computers or telecommunications infrastructure stocks in the technology sector. Instead, he considers them capital goods stocks, which lag behind the market because their purchase depends on corporate management decisions, he said. 
"You learn more if you ignore those labels," he said. "We found out a long time ago that if you use different language, that it's easier to think of things in different terms than the crowd."
Mr. Muhlenkamp also incorporates macroeconomic indicators into his investment decisions. He looks for changes in the public mood, sometimes polling his own shareholders to gauge consumer attitudes. "Every once in a while, you have to review the big picture -- we call it the climate," he said. "Every once in a while the climate changes, and when that happens it overwhelms the business cycle."
These days, Mr. Muhlenkamp's analysis points to a business-cycle slowdown that has been worsened by the terrorist attacks last month. But he said the factors that pushed the United States economy into a depression in the 1930's -- rising interest rates, taxes and tariffs -- were absent now.
Bill C. Nygren, who runs the Oakmark and Oakmark Select funds for Harris Associates, an investment management firm in Chicago, said he and many other value managers used indicators like return on equity to evaluate funds, just as Mr. Muhlenkamp does. But Mr. Nygren does not incorporate macroeconomics into his analysis because he does not believe that he has any special skills that let him predict the future better than other investors can. 
"Even though that's not how we invest," Mr. Nygren said of Mr. Muhlenkamp's approach, "certainly we accept the point of view that that's a valid way of investing."
Mr. Muhlenkamp imparts his views to shareholders regularly -- at seminars and in newsletters. That frequent communication and his straightforward manner helped to attract one investor, William F. Gilfillan Jr., 20 years ago, before Mr. Muhlenkamp started his mutual fund. Mr. Gilfillan, now 76, and his wife, Carol K., 74, hired him to manage their portfolios. 
Mr. Gilfillan, who lives in Bethel Park, Pa., said he was satisfied with his Mr. Muhlenkamp's investment performance and strategy. And he likes the direct-from-the-horse's-mouth style of providing information. "That's a key factor of why we're with him," Mr. Gilfillan said, praising Mr. Muhlenkamp for his "accountability" to clients.
After the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, Mr. Muhlenkamp was quick to update the firm's Web site (www.muhlenkamp.com) for shareholders, telling them that he saw no reason to shift his investments significantly. Through the end of August, the portfolio held its largest stakes, about 20 percent each, in consumer cyclical and financial stocks, which offset each other, he said. If consumers do not spend freely, then interest rates should decline, benefiting financial stocks, he said. "We think having a leg in each camp gives us a little bit of a hedge," he said.
That is an example of another element of Mr. Muhlenkamp's investing style: not relying 100 percent on any single factor. "You have to make sure whatever the hell happens -- whether it's markets going irrational, whatever -- that you're still around to survive it," he said. "So we don't go all the way out on a limb."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
Amid Uncertainty, A Junk-Bond Divide

BYLINE:  By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:
HIGH-YIELD bond prices fell sharply in the third quarter as investors fled risky investments. And the drop in price pushed up yields to unusually high levels compared with those of Treasury securities. 
 Even so, advisers and fixed-income portfolio managers are divided over whether investors should put money into mutual funds of high-yield, or junk, bonds, particularly in such uncertain times. 
 Because junk bonds are considered risky -- they are loans to companies and municipalities that have the least likelihood of repaying them -- the sector has been hit hard by the market decline and the shaky economy. 
In recent weeks, prices of junk bonds have fallen as yields have soared above 13 percent. As a group, high-yield funds have been the only one of 11 taxable fixed-income categories tracked by Morningstar to have a negative performance for the 12 months ended Sept. 30, declining 9.7 percent.
Still, some experts say investors who can stand the risk should not abandon the category. "The economy at the moment is not a pinnacle of perfection, and there are going to be defaults," said M. John Sterba, chairman of Investment Management Advisors Inc. of New York. "But markets tend to overreact, and yields are attractive now. I would encourage investors not to give up and hide money under a mattress."
Junk bonds are those rated Ba1 and below by Moody's Investors Service or BB+ and below by Standard & Poor's. Most high-yield funds concentrate their holdings in securities rated B or BB, but some go as high as AAA, while others go as low as securities with no rating.
Mr. Sterba says he does not recommend high-yield funds for every client. But for those who can tolerate risk, he suggests investing 5 percent to 10 percent of a long-term portfolio in such funds. Even then, he says he prefers "fairly conservative" funds with "higher credit quality," like the Vanguard High Yield fund.
Prescott B. Crocker, manager of the Sentinel High Yield Bond fund in Boston, was more bullish. "The high-yield market is extremely attractive at this point," he said.
Mr. Crocker pointed to yields that were more than double those of 10-year Treasuries, now yielding about 4.5 percent, and to the efforts of the Federal Reserve to stimulate the economy by lowering interest rates, making credit more available to corporations.
ON the other hand, Mark Vaselkiv, president and portfolio manager of the T. Rowe Price High-Yield fund in Baltimore, said: "At this stage, to be intellectually honest, I have to be cautious. The market is increasingly fragile." 
It had begun to recover from "an ill-timed bet on telecom," Mr. Vaselkiv said, but "Sept. 11 changed everything." He said he would not recommend that long-term investors sell high-yield funds, and he would advise people considering such a fund to "wait and be cautious." 
Pointing to "a strong correlation with the stock market," which plunged after Sept. 11, he said that "if the economy and the military issues resolve quickly, I would be more confident." He would guide new investors, meanwhile, toward "a high-quality bond fund" like T. Rowe Price New Income.
Connie J. Plaehn, a managing director of J. P. Morgan Fleming Asset Management in New York, steers a middle course. Ms. Plaehn, as senior fixed-income portfolio manager for mutual funds, pension and other institutional clients, is responsible for managing more than $73 billion and can cross the credit spectrum.
"We are upgrading the junk bonds we have in our portfolio," she said, "holding our high-yield allocation steadily but moving to higher quality." The allocation may be 3 percent for a conservative client, she said, ranging up to more than 20 percent for an aggressive investor.
"Certainly, in our view, we cannot avoid a recession," Ms. Plaehn said, noting that the economy had been slowing even before Sept. 11 and that the possibility of military action had made the outlook for all investments uncertain. Still, short-term corporate debt securities -- especially those rated B and BB, at the high end of the junk category -- are attractive relative to Treasuries, she said. 
"We don't do much in distressed sectors," she added.
Brendan M. White, manager of the Touchstone High Yield fund and senior portfolio manager at Fort Washington Investment Advisors in Cincinnati, says he expects a "reasonably tough market going forward" and predicts that "defaults will increase in the near future." As a result, he said, his portfolio's "risk-return profile is more aligned to the higher end of the market."
Mr. White suggested that potential investors study a fund's portfolio, checking the credit quality of its holdings, its volatility and total return and whether it is in battered sectors like telecommunications. (Such information is available at www.morningstar.com and from the funds.) Bonds with low credit ratings may signal problems, he said. Many CCC-rated bonds "can mean aggressive, equity-like risk," he said.
"Yield has become something of an unfulfilled hope," he added.
Kurt Brouwer of Brouwer & Janachowski, an investment adviser in Tiburon, Calif., said, "We have never used a pure high-yield bond fund." Stronger total returns, he said, have generally been available in funds with higher credit quality, like Pimco Total Return.
Still, Mr. Brouwer said, he is beginning to look at some high-yield funds, including those offered by Pimco, Vanguard and T. Rowe Price. 
"High yield is an opportunistic area," he said. "Your timing has to be good. Going into a recession is not a good time. When the recession is deepest and darkest is probably the best time."
Of course, market timing is difficult, even for the professionals. Mr. Brouwer advises that only investors who have well-diversified portfolios go into such funds, and "only if you can hold a few years."

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY; 
It's Time for Terror-Proof Markets

BYLINE:  By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst's column tilts at conventional business wisdom and appears the first Sunday of each month.E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
NEVER again. 
 That should be the motto of our financial markets in the wake of Sept. 11. Never again shall we let the forces of evil shut us down. Never again will we hand our enemies the power to paralyze our business lives. Never again will we make ourselves so vulnerable. 
 Now is the time to resolve that no person or thing will be allowed to close American financial markets unless the exchanges themselves and their government overseers believe that doing so is in the best interests of the nation and its economy. That means markets cannot be closed because the phones are not working, or because we feel bad, or because employees cannot reach their posts. 
Just as the nation is embarked on a campaign to increase security against terrorist attacks, so the securities industry and its regulators must embark on a drive to build attack-proof markets. We can easily achieve this goal with the proven electronic trading technology already in use by Nasdaq and others. 
That will mean jettisoning our sentimental attachment to the sporting spectacle that the New York Stock Exchange offers today. We can debate forever the virtues of open-outcry trading, but henceforth it will always be antiquated and vulnerable, a tourist attraction more than a sensible modern way to buy and sell securities. Open outcry is theme-park capitalism, colorful, to be sure, but best left to Disneyland or Las Vegas. If necessary, people dressed like traders can shout harmlessly at one another every day on the current site of the New York Stock Exchange, in a latter-day version of colonial Williamsburg. That's entertainment. But what the world economy needs are bulletproof financial markets immune to everything short of nuclear holocaust. 
But it's not just the markets that must pursue business as usual when terrorism strikes. Next time around, all of us will have to do our part. If you felt helpless watching those horrible images on television, know that you can, in fact, do something. You can get back to work and at least deprive our attackers of the ability to decide what we do -- and how prosperous we should be.
For that to happen, we need to confront an unfortunate side effect of our remarkable prosperity: shame. Chronic guilt over the almost unimaginable wealth of American life seemed an inevitable by-product of our affluence, like traffic jams or lawyers, though it hasn't stopped many of us from buying nice cars or second houses. 
It is time to get over it, and we may yet thank our attackers for helping us to do so. If you are ashamed of what you do and how you live, change your life. Otherwise, no more squeamishness. We cannot let every crackpot with a grievance bring the economy screeching to a halt. Besides, getting back to work doesn't dishonor the dead, and walking away from the job next time around will bring comfort only to those whose mindless assault on progress and modernity has our paralysis as its aim. 
It's time to grow up about this: not only is making money nothing to be embarrassed about, it's also at the core of our civilization. Prosperity underwrites our freedoms, our universities, our advances against pollution and disease and discrimination. The values of pluralism and individual rights are bound up with the free markets and financial wherewithal that were one of the main targets on Sept. 11. 
It would be nice to say "never again" to terrorist attacks. Unfortunately, in the 21st century that may not be possible for a long, long time. We must do everything we can to thwart them, but the sad reality is that, someday, somewhere, terrorist violence against innocent Americans will recur. And our impulse after the recent attacks to stop everything (and plunge our economy into recession) will only encourage the enemies of decency and progress.
We cannot give them the satisfaction. Next time, however much it hurts, we should make sure it is business as usual, especially in the financial markets.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT: STRATEGIES; 
Is Gold Relevant? Quiet, Please!

BYLINE:  By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Annandale, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THE debate over the role of gold in investment portfolios may boil down to just a few percentage points. But you would never know that by listening to the fervor with which the two sides disagree.
 In one corner are those who say gold funds should play a permanent part in diversifying a portfolio, despite gold's 21-year-long bear market. 
 That viewpoint received a lift when gold for December delivery rose to $294 an ounce by Sept. 30, from $273.70 before the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. 
The price spike helped to make precious-metal funds the top performer of any domestic or international equity category in the third quarter. As a group, the funds rose 3.18 percent, compared with a decline of 14.7 percent on a total return basis for the Standard & Poor's 500.
In the opposite corner are investment professionals and finance professors who deride these arguments as the delusions of what they call "gold bugs" -- people who cling to an outdated notion of gold as an eternal store of value. 
Relatively little research has been done on the investment role of gold. While many market debates can be decided by the historical record, this one quickly dissolves into a dispute over which periods, if any, are relevant.
Those who shun gold tend to concentrate on the last two decades, when gold has performed poorly. But is such a limited focus justified? While many researchers concede that it would be better to analyze more than two decades, they say that in the case of gold, the data before 1980 is of limited relevance. 
From the end of World War II until 1971, the price of gold was fixed at $35 an ounce. As a result, these researchers say, nothing can be learned about gold's role as a portfolio diversifier by studying that period. Even gold's behavior in the 1970's is suspect, because at least part of its impressive rise in that decade might have been caused by a delayed reaction to inflation in the previous years. 
Another factor might have been pent-up demand from individual investors in the United States; until then, it was illegal for them to invest in gold.
Even when analyzed with a limited, two-decade focus, gold still earns a passing grade for reducing risk. That is because bullion tends to zig when stocks zag and, as a result, a portfolio that includes gold will be less risky than one that is invested in stocks alone. Since 1980, an equity portfolio with a 10 percent allocation to gold would have had its volatility reduced by 9.6 percent.
Foes of gold, however, say it deserves no permanent place in a portfolio because it forfeits too much performance as it cuts volatility. Since 1980, an investor would have made more money, with less risk, by substituting 90-day Treasury bills for gold.
So how do gold's defenders answer that? They disagree less with this analysis than with the historical period to which it is applied. Of course, they say, investors should not buy gold if they assume that the future will be like the last two decades -- characterized by relative geopolitical calm, robust economic growth and low inflation. But what if the future is less rosy? What if the war against terrorism takes longer or is less than successful? 
This attitude toward recent decades leads to defining risk over much longer periods. Unlike some analysts, whose risk models use a year or two of data to define the relationships among various assets, gold's advocates tend to focus on events that occur rarely but are extremely significant when they do.
Certainly, gold excels as a hedge against rare events. Those who say gold has a permanent role in an investment portfolio refuse to dismiss the 1970's, because that decade offered the best modern example of financial distress. The 70's contained America's exit from the Vietnam War, the resignation of a president, an oil embargo, high inflation and sluggish economic growth. Gold's advocates say these factors, not the deregulation of the gold market, caused bullion to skyrocket to more than $800 an ounce, from $35.
The battle of precedents goes on and on. Must you resolve it before deciding on your asset allocation? Given the volume of the two camps' arguments, you might think so. But there may be a way to sidestep the debate.
On one practical level, the two sides are not so far apart as their arguments would suggest. Consider first the gold allocation recommended by academicians who do not like gold as an investment.
That allocation -- while small -- is not zero. And it derives from a prevailing academic theory of efficient and rational markets. Implicit in that theory is the idea that an investor's allocation to an industry should not deviate from its proportional weight in the overall market. If the auto industry represents 10 percent of the market's capitalization, for example, investors should allocate 10 percent of their portfolios to auto companies' stocks.
According to Wilshire Associates, United States companies involved in gold and related precious-metals mining have a combined market capitalization of about one-half of 1 percent of the total U.S. stock market. So even ardent believers in efficient markets do not object in principle to allocating at least this much of an equity portfolio to gold and precious metals. And because most of the world's leading gold-mining companies are not based in the United States, the number probably understates the industry's market weight globally.
NOW consider the asset allocation recommendation of the World Gold Council, a trade association of the world's leading gold mining companies whose goal is "stimulating and maximizing the demand and holding of gold." 
The council commissioned a study simulating thousands of situations involving alternating periods of financial calm and distress. Researchers built portfolios with the best risk-reward characteristics, combining large- and small-capitalization stocks, Treasury bills, long-term Treasury bonds and gold. 
Even assuming that periods of financial distress like the 1970's are as likely to occur as periods of calm like the 1990's -- an idea that is favorable to coming up with a high gold allocation -- the study concluded that the optimal allocation is 6 percent of investable assets.
So the debate that seems so intractable on a theoretical level boils down in practical terms to a difference between a small number and a very small number. Though that range is not insignificant, it is far less momentous than many investors might think.
Where you fall within this range depends on how much you want to hedge your portfolio against terrorism and war. If you believe that the world never can return to the relative innocence that prevailed before Sept. 11, you might favor a gold allocation toward the higher end of that range. If you think normalcy will return quickly and remain for a sustained period, then that allocation should be much smaller -- but not zero.

HEADLINE: Business; 
In a Chorus of Caution, Some Still Chant Boldness

BYLINE:  By REED ABELSON

 BODY:
DECIDING to open stores. Buying a company. Proceeding with plans to make significant investments in business. Offering stock to the public for the first time.
 While none of these moves would have seemed particularly aggressive a few months ago, the current business environment has convinced many executives that the wisest course for the foreseeable future is to do as little as possible. Many are choosing to retrench, slash expenses, lay off thousands of employees and postpone major projects. 
 "I don't think people are thinking long term," said Jerry J. Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers in Washington. "They're thinking short term."
The possibility of another terrorist attack, the outbreak of war or a prolonged economic and stock market slump has convinced many executives that they cannot predict the future, said Ronald L. Nicol, a senior vice president at the Boston Consulting Group. "What they realize is that they're driving on a curvy road in the fog, and it's scary," he said. 
Adding to the uncertainty, oddly, is the proposed $75 billion federal package of tax cuts and spending measures to stimulate the economy, advanced last week by President Bush. Because the package could include specific measures to encourage businesses to invest in new factories, computers and other equipment, some companies may now wait to make spending decisions to take advantage of the tax breaks.
But a few executives are plunging ahead, betting that the future may not be so vastly different and wanting to take advantage of the environment to get ahead of rivals.
"Being bold, on strategy, is the right move," said Stratton D. Sclavos, chief executive of VeriSign Inc., who decided to proceed with a $1.2 billion merger less than two weeks after Sept. 11. VeriSign, which provides Internet security services, agreed to buy Illuminet Holdings, which provides services to telecommunications companies.
Mr. Sclavos was undeterred by warnings from investment bankers that investors might react poorly to the deal and send the stocks of both companies down. He was convinced, he said, that it was as much a mistake for businesses to time the market as it was for investors. "It's not something we've ever done," he said.
Because Illuminet is profitable and well run, the combination with VeriSign will generate additional profits, he said, and let VeriSign explore new business areas. "Waiting also delays the benefits," he said.
A scattering of other mergers and acquisitions have been announced, including Deutsche Bank's planned purchase of Zurich Scudder Investments, a deal valued at about $2.5 billion in cash and assets. The purchase of Scudder, which has $278 billion in assets under management, thrusts Deutsche Bank into a much larger role as a money manager.
Other companies are choosing to expand. Last week, Wal-Mart Stores, for example, said it planned to spend nearly $10 billion next year to expand its network of stores. The retailer, already the nation's largest, said it would open about 230 stores as well as 50 Sam's Club stores in the United States and 125 overseas. 
Even some executives who are resigned to an unpredictable future have chosen to act. Hilton Hotels has decided to go ahead with the renovation of hotels in San Francisco, New Orleans and elsewhere. While Hilton has cut some jobs at many hotels, it plans no corporate-wide layoffs.
Hilton management decided that it needed to make some guesses about the economy, even if they proved wrong. "We felt immediately after the act on Sept. 11 that we needed to have a theory about how the business would recover," said Stephen F. Bollenbach, the company's chief executive. While acknowledging that Hilton did not have "better insight than anyone else," its management decided to bet on a quick recovery within the next 8 to 12 weeks, returning business activity to the levels last seen in the late 1990's. 
"It lets you answer those questions" about whether to continue spending or start significant layoffs, Mr. Bollenbach said.
While Hilton's management had discussed what to do if the recovery is three to six months off, the executives decided that it would not significantly affect costs if they were more optimistic, Mr. Bollenbach said. The difference in Hilton's expenses, regardless of when a recovery takes hold, he said, was "not a big deal."
The company is also expecting to expand its system at low cost by selling the Hilton franchise to owners of 200 hotels. The overall industry is suffering low occupancy rates because of the slow economy and fears about travel, and Mr. Bollenbach said some hotel owners were more willing to convert to a nationally recognized brand like Hilton.
"We believe the world has not fundamentally changed but that this is a short-term crisis," he added.
And by refusing to make drastic cutbacks in jobs, Hilton may better keep itself ready for an improvement in the industry. "Let's not worry so much about short-term profits," Mr. Bollenbach said.
Of course, some companies are choosing to continue with their plans because their businesses have not been significantly affected by the turmoil. Because Walgreen, the drugstore chain, has historically been immune to economic cycles, "we try to take that long-term focus," said David W. Bernauer, the Walgreen president, who takes over next year as chief executive. Over the last 27 years, growth "is a pretty steady curve," he said.
The company expects to spend about $1.3 billion on projects, including the addition of 475 stores. That is a slight increase from this year's capital spending. "We are going to continue to push that along," he said.
AND despite the virtual standstill in initial public offerings, there are some signs of life. Given Imaging, an Israeli medical device company, went public last week on Nasdaq, raising $60 million in the first such offering since mid-August. Others are at least contemplating going public. PayPal Inc., a small company in Palo Alto, Calif., filed a registration statement in late September for a possible offering. The company allows people, like those using eBay, to send payments via e-mail; it says it has 10 million users.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Tosha Wilkes, Dwayne Andrews

 BODY:
Tosha Nicole Wilkes, a daughter of Sharon and William Wilkes of Oakland, Calif., was married yesterday to Dwayne McDonald Andrews, the son of Joy and James Andrews of Cambria Heights, Queens. The Rev. 
Xavier Lavagetto performed the ceremony at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in San Francisco.
 Mrs. Andrews, 29, is the vice president of the Business Council for International Understanding, a nonprofit organization in Manhattan that seeks to foster foreign trade. She graduated from Pomona College and received a master's degree in international economics and Japanese studies from Johns Hopkins University. Her parents work in Oakland, where her mother is an appraiser of commercial property for Alameda County and her father is a freelance photographer. 
 Mr. Andrews, 31, is an assistant general counsel for Edison Schools, the private manager of public schools, based in Manhattan. He graduated from York College and received a law degree from Georgetown University. His parents are retired nurses who worked in Brooklyn. His mother was with the pediatric intensive care unit at Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center; his father worked in the general surgery unit of Maimonides Medical Center.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: CAREER ARC; 
When the Work Path Turns, Can a Guide Help?

BYLINE:  By BARBARA WHITAKER

 BODY:
MANASSAH BRADLEY knows what it is like to rethink a career. Since graduating from Northeastern University in 1985 with an economics degree, Mr. Bradley has made more changes than many other working people make in a lifetime.
 He started as a customer service representative at Fidelity Investments, but was laid off after the stock market crash of 1987. After traveling and working several odd jobs at investment firms, he was hired by Kidder Peabody to sell fixed-income securities, only to be laid off again in the mid-1990's when the company was acquired by PaineWebber. 
 Disenchanted with Wall Street, Mr. Bradley returned to school and received an M.B.A. in entrepreneurship in May 2000. He wanted to "make lots and lots of money while doing social work," he said. He landed a high-paying job with UPromise Inc., a company that helps create college savings plans; that lasted until he was laid off one year and 12 days later. 
There may be more career changes ahead. But this time, Mr. Bradley has taken a new approach -- hiring Suzanne Blake, a career coach with offices in the Boston area, to help guide him. "I'm hoping she can clarify for me how I can reach my goal of being that six-figure social worker or at least say to me, 'You're never going to get that; here's what you can do in the interim,' " said Mr. Bradley, 39, who lives in Franklin, Mass., a Boston suburb.
Many other working Americans are doing the same. Huge corporate layoffs -- affecting more than 1.5 million so far this year -- along with the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, have caused many people to re-evaluate their lives and careers. "People are coming for very practical, pragmatic reasons," said Judith F. Feld, president-elect of the International Coach Federation, a 6,000-member professional association based in Washington, and owner of CoachNet in Dallas.
Responding to the financial problems in the airline industry, federation officials say they are developing a plan for members to offer free coaching services to airline workers laid off since the Sept. 11 attacks.
Career coaches are part cheerleader, part guidance counselor and part sounding board. They can help clients clarify their goals, hone their talents and develop job-search and interview skills. Most also try to match clients' objectives with their personalities and how they live -- maybe suggesting ways for people to lighten their workloads while maintaining their income levels.
There are about 10,000 full-time professional coaches of all types (excluding sports) nationwide, and that number is expected to grow. Thomas Leonard, a pioneer of the profession and a founder of Coach U in Colorado Springs, one of the largest training schools for personal and business coaches, predicted that "it will be as common to have a coach as it now is to have a personal fitness trainer."
But choosing the right career coach can be a challenge in itself. How much should you pay? How long should a coach be retained? What results should you expect?
While there are few exact statistics for gauging success, people in the business have several suggestions. First, they say, check credentials. Random searches on the Internet show a variety of sources for training and credentialing -- some offer certification after just a three-day course -- but the experts recommend certification by the International Coach Federation. The group, which has a set of standards and a code of ethics for its members, offers certification for those who have graduated from an accredited coach-training program and have met other requirements, including completing a minimum of 750 hours of coaching. It lists 10 accredited schools on its Web site (www.coachfederation.org), many with training programs lasting several months.
People should also consider the coach's communications skills, education and experience, as well as his or her own job background. Experts recommend interviewing several candidates before hiring one.
"The client has to feel the coach understands the world they live in; there needs to be good chemistry and good communication," Ms. Feld said.
Rich Feller, a counseling and career development professor at Colorado State University, said career coaches "seem to work best with self-directed people who have few barriers holding them back." Mr. Feller also serves on the board of the National Career Development Association, a professional group in Tulsa, Okla.
According to the coach federation, most career coaches charge by the month and require a minimum of at least three months. The average monthly fee is $500, but may be as low as $250. Coaching fees for corporate executives tend to be higher.
Most coaching sessions, excluding those for top-level executives, are conducted over the telephone or on the Internet. Once hired, a coach assesses a client's skills, personality, lifestyle and goals.
Lori Sallet, 37, hired Ms. Feld after leaving MCI in 1999 after it was acquired by WorldCom. She had worked there for 12 years.
"Then I was faced with 'Where do I go next?' " said Ms. Sallet, who was also re-evaluating her life in Washington, where she was living at the time.
With a background in marketing, she briefly considered becoming a career coach herself. But as she worked with Ms. Feld as a mentor, she examined her options and started a consulting business -- Project Management L.L.C. -- which helps corporations manage change in situations like mergers, restructurings or downsizings.
Ms. Feld also helped Ms. Sallet change the way she approached her work life. Rather than being driven by a checklist detailing all she had to do, she began looking at the type of work she was drawn to, isolating what she valued in her life. As a result, she and her husband, Jonathan Sallet, 49, once the chief lawyer advising MCI on policy issues and now a business consultant, moved to Centreville, Md., on the Eastern Shore, and scaled back the number of hours they worked.
But Ms. Sallet's work with Ms. Feld did not end there. She continues to consult with her coach almost every week and has used the relationship to help her build her business and draw boundaries. For example, she said, Ms. Feld helped her to develop standards, work practices and fee schedules. When a client was too demanding, she turned to her coach to find the strength to say "no" and then came up with acceptable alternatives. She declined to disclose her income, but said that it was about the same as at MCI and that her workweek had been scaled down to three days. That means she and her husband can take their boat out for a spin on many afternoons on Chesapeake Bay.
"I'm very happy," she said. "First of all she's helped me make my business very successful, and successful on my own terms." 
While such stories abound, some experts in career counseling and job transition question the value of career coaches. 
"I have trouble getting my hands around what a career coach is," said Robert K. Otterbourg, author of "Switching Careers" (Kiplinger Books, $17.95).
Mr. Otterbourg's book, published this year, details how and why dozens of people switch careers, and it suggests that those looking for a change can easily handle it themselves, saving a lot of money in the process.
"You can do an awful lot of investigation yourself," he said, noting various sources available in publications or over the Internet. Many universities and community colleges also offer skills assessments, he added.
"If your goal is to be a minister, go see a minister," Mr. Otterbourg said.
Most important, he said, is to "do something you love" and not to try to second-guess the job market. After all, the hot jobs of two years ago, like those at dot-coms, are among the least attractive today.
COACHES and their clients, however, say the do-it-yourself method does not always work. It is sometimes hard, they said, for workers to be objective about their own skills and talents, particularly when going through a rough patch like a layoff, which can be demoralizing.
"First, you're shocked, then you're disappointed," Mr. Bradley said. "Then it's, 'How are you going to pay your bills? Can you make it?' Then you have to deal with the three R's -- reality, responsibility and redirection."
Ms. Blake, his coach, has helped him through that self-searching period. Mr. Bradley recently completed the first of a three-month contract, at $350 a month. And he has come up with a plan to do decorative painting, paying about $25 an hour, while he develops his next career as -- you guessed it, a career coach.
"For me the value of having a coach is keeping me focused on my goal," he said. "I just need somebody to be in my corner saying, 'go for it.' "

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
How the Growl Became a Roar

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
FOR most mutual fund investors, about the only nice thing that can be said about the summer of 2001 is that it ended. 
 What began as a quarter of worry over a wobbly economy and rocky corporate earnings ended with 99 percent of equity funds in the red. 
 "The last three months have been some of the most difficult conditions I have experienced in managing money in the last 20 years," said Thomas F. Marsico, portfolio manager and president of Marsico Funds, with $11 billion under management. 
Major stock market indexes were down before terrorists attacked the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, and so were equity funds: the average stock market mutual fund was down nearly 12 percent from the end of June through Sept. 10.
The selling after Sept. 11 made matters much worse. For the quarter, the average diversified mutual fund fell 16.22 percent, according to Morningstar Inc. It was the biggest three-month decline since the fall of 1987. 
Perhaps more important, the decline meant that diversified equity mutual fund values have now fallen in four of the last five quarters. The last period of comparable contraction was in 1983-84, according to Lipper Inc., the research firm.
The market's free fall left few stocks unscathed. Only bear funds, which short the market, and precious-metals funds, which rose 3.18 percent, showed an increase. 
Science and technology funds, which have been falling since March 2000, when the Nasdaq composite index peaked, had their worst quarter ever, falling nearly 39 percent, according to Morningstar. Growth funds fell 22.9 percent, on average, with value funds down 12.4 percent. 
Confronted with uncertainty and loss, many investors chose not to panic and run for the exits, but to seek safety and stability.
Extrapolating weekly fund flow numbers from AMG Data Services, Thomas McManus, chief investment strategist at Banc of America Securities, estimated late last month that net redemptions from domestic equity funds totaled $21 billion in the third quarter, the first negative quarter since the summer of 1990, when Iraq invaded Kuwait. 
While that $21 billion is significant Mr. McManus said, it needs to be put in context. 
"In 1990, net outflows from domestic equity mutual funds totaled $4 billion," he said. "But assets back then were $196 billion. At the end of August there was nearly $2.9 trillion in all domestic equity funds." 
Money coming out of equity funds was redirected into bond funds and money market funds. In August alone, bond funds had inflows of $15 billion; an additional $24 billion went into money market funds, according to Lipper.
"Investors are deciding to reallocate, and not exit the financial system," said Robert Adler, president of AMG Data Services. 
At the Vanguard Group, the mutual fund company with $530 billion in assets, net outflows from equity funds in September totaled $1.3 billion, said Brian Mattes, a spokesman. But Vanguard had net inflows of $2.3 billion in the first two months of the quarter. 
Last month, Vanguard bond funds had $1.8 billion in inflows, Mr. Mattes said, on top of $5.1 billion in inflows in July and August.
Helped by the continued decline in interest rates, bond funds eked out positive returns for the quarter. The average taxable bond fund was up 1.6 percent for the last three months, according to Morningstar, while municipal bond funds gained 2.57 percent, on average. 
The enduring popularity of bond and money market funds, however, is in doubt. With short-term interest rates now at 40-year lows, investors may soon look elsewhere. In large measure, future flows will depend on how long it takes to restore confidence and stability in the market.
"Investors are doing what they have always done," said Geoff Bobroff, president of Bobroff Consulting, a mutual fund consulting firm in East Greenwich, R. I. "Once equity returns are restored, they will move as quickly as you can blink an eye out of fixed income." 
Russell Kinnel, Morningstar's director of fund analysis, said a reversal, if it comes, may not be abrupt. "I don't expect fund investors to make big moves into stock funds in the near term," he said.
"Fund flows are generally very much a lagging indicator," Mr. Kinnel said. "Some improvement in the economy or the market will reverse the trend. But even a nice rally will produce a much more sober investor. People were getting carried away with the allocation to equities."
Stock markets declined around the world during the quarter. The average international stock fund fell 15.8 percent, Morningstar said. It was the fifth decline for such funds in the last six quarters. 
Of the bear funds that had a feast in the quarter, none fared better than Rydex Venture 100, a fund whose results inversely correlate to the Nasdaq 100 index. The fund gained 116.97 percent during the quarter.
"Bear and contrarian funds were the ones making money in the quarter," said Andrew Clark, a research analyst at Lipper.
Conrad B. Herrmann, director of equity research at Franklin Advisors in San Mateo, Calif., and manager of its $1.6 billion California Growth fund, had a rocky ride in the third quarter. 
"I have been with Franklin since 1989, and this was one of the most challenging periods on record," he said. 
Mr. Herrmann, whose fund lost 21.3 percent of its value in the three months, said the selling after the Sept. 11 attacks reached irrational proportions. 
"The market on Sept. 21 indicated major panic psychology, suggesting we have reached a bottoming process," he said. "But I try and keep an optimistic outlook on things." 
On Friday, Sept. 21, the Dow Jones industrial average, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Nasdaq composite closed at their lowest levels so far this year. The selling that day was the finishing touch on one of the stock market's worst weeks ever. 
"There has not been a bear market this bad since 1973 to 1974," Mr. Kinnel said. "It's a pretty severe loss, one I don't think people are used to."
In depth and duration, the current slide in the stock market is the worst since the steep drop in the mid-1970's, when a sharp spike in oil prices sent the economy into a tailspin. 
The losses of the last three months have only worsened what was already a bad year. 
Coupled with the declines in the first quarter, some famous fund names are down sharply for 2001. Vanguard 500 Index is down 20.5 percent; Fidelity Magellan, 20.5 percent; and American Funds' Growth Fund of America, 25 percent.
October has seldom been a good month for stock investors, and there are ample reasons for caution: The length and depth of what looks certain to be a recession are unknown; the United States, in concert with its allies, has yet to respond to the Sept. 11 attacks; and the threat of further terrorist activity is real.
Still, as the third quarter was ending, some people were deciding to start buying.
Mr. Marsico, whose funds concentrate on growth stocks, said the steep price declines after Sept. 11 had pushed many of the stocks he prefers into the value category.
Stocks are deemed to be a value when their prices fall below the underlying value of their assets. 
"Going into the 11th, our cash positions were relatively high, at between 15 percent and 18 percent," he said. 
In the last two weeks of September, "we did quite a bit of buying," he said, adding to positions in Citigroup and buying shares in General Electric and Home Depot.
By the end of the quarter, Mr. Marsico's funds had lowered their cash holdings to between just over 2 percent and 6 percent of their portfolios. 
"I am feeling more confident about investing money at these levels than I have in the last five years," he said.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
The Outlook For Recovery: Three Factors To Watch

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
THERE is almost no end to the uncertainty about the economy. Here are three questions whose answers could go a long way toward clarifying the outlook.
 Can the productivity miracle continue? 
 The foundation of the prosperity that the United States enjoyed in the 1990's was the resurgence in the nation's ability to produce more for less. After languishing for decades, the growth rate of productivity, or output per hour worked, took off in the middle of the last decade, creating conditions under which both workers and companies could earn more without generating inflation. 
The improvement was driven largely by advances in technology. But it also reflected a pervasive economic and cultural push, prompted by intense international competition and pressure from Wall Street for consistent earnings improvement, to make companies and the economy more efficient. 
Technology is likely to remain a powerfully positive economic force. Although companies have cut back substantially on capital spending, they are only beginning to reap the benefits of advances in automation, communications and data analysis.
But the flexible, cost-squeezing nature of the economy is giving way to something more hardened and expensive.
Companies in many industries are facing higher insurance costs and are devoting large amounts of money to security and backing up computer operations. Banks are likely to face increased costs as the government cracks down on money laundering and closely monitors international money flows.
Moving goods and people around has become more time-consuming and expensive. The border with Canada, for example, has gone from being all but invisible to being a bottleneck for automobiles and parts going back and forth between the two countries. The New York-Washington shuttle flights started again last week, but the days of showing up at the airport at the last minute and hopping aboard are over.
None of these things by themselves are enough to alter the course of an economy as big and resilient as this one. Still, the cumulative effect could be a gradual erosion in productivity improvements. 
If the erosion is permanent, many of the assumptions about the vibrancy and potential of the new economy will be called into question. If it is temporary, the long-term outlook will remain bright.
What will happen to long-term interest rates?
The sagging stock market has eaten into the wealth of many households. But for most people, the prime repository of net worth is their home. So far, housing prices have held up fairly well. More important, low and declining rates this year have allowed more homeowners to refinance their mortgages.
In the process, many people have reduced their monthly payments, freeing cash to spend on other things. Some people have chosen to use equity from their homes in lump sums to buy a car, take a vacation or put aside for a rainy day.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, often points out that the stimulative effect on the housing market of low interest rates has been important in keeping the economy from weakening even more than it has. And as he has counseled Congress about an economic recovery package of tax cuts and new spending, Mr. Greenspan has warned against busting the budget to the degree that investors will be alarmed and long-term interest rates will climb.
There is already some sign of upward pressure on long-term rates, even though the Fed has cut short-term rates aggressively. If rates begin rising for mortgages, as well as corporate bonds and other types of longer-term borrowing, the prospects for a rapid recovery would dim.
Will Japan and Europe stabilize their economies?
There is no realistic prospect that the United States will get any economic help from abroad during this business cycle. But it is still not clear whether deteriorating economic conditions in Japan and Europe will prove to be merely unhelpful or actively harmful.
The new European Central Bank has been slow to cut interest rates this year despite the weakening of national economies across the Continent. Its focus appears to have been more on building its credibility in fighting inflation than on trying to encourage an economic turnaround. Should it remain stingy with rate reductions, the weakness in Europe could linger for some time.
The Bank of Japan has been ineffectual for years in ending Japan's decadelong slump. There are signs that it may finally be learning its lesson. But the banking system in Japan is extremely rickety, and a financial meltdown there would have global repercussions.
