HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
A Fund Firm Adjusts, Within Boundaries

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: BERWYN, Pa. 

 BODY:
WHEN stock prices slide, ordinary investors suffer varying degrees of distress and may look for someone to blame for their losses. But they typically have the option of moving into less risky securities or even to the sidelines.
 Professionals generally enjoy less flexibility, especially those who manage publicly traded mutual funds. Consider Robert E. Turner and his colleagues at Turner Investment Partners, a growth-oriented firm that manages $7.6 billion, roughly half in funds and half in private accounts for pension funds and other institutions. The firm lives by some of the more rigid restrictions in the industry. 
 "We're always fully invested," Mr. Turner said. Under the self-imposed restrictions, Turner Investment never moves significant amounts into cash -- it keeps no more than it needs to meet redemptions -- because clients pay it to pick stocks, not time the market, the firm says. It also hews to a policy of investing the same proportion of assets in each industry as a portfolio's benchmark. The policy is to replicate the industry weightings in a particular benchmark, like the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, but not necessarily to buy the individual stocks.
The sector neutrality means, for example, that even if retail stocks are likely to be weak -- as was expected after the attacks on Sept. 11 -- managers must still find stocks within that group in which to invest.
Nonetheless, the Turner operation, which was founded in 1990, the year when Iraq invaded Kuwait and when the last recession began, adjusted its portfolios as soon as trading resumed on Sept. 17, six days after the attacks. The firm substituted stocks within the same sectors.
"We looked at our portfolios, went one by one, and asked ourselves, 'Will this company be damaged?' " said Y. David Kovacs, a senior portfolio manager and Turner's quantitative analyst. "We identified those that were at risk and should be sold as soon as the market reopened."
Abandoned or reduced were stakes in travel-related companies like American Express, Carnival, Cendant, Starwood Hotels and Resorts, AMR (parent of American Airlines), Southwest Airlines and Continental Airlines; retailers like Tiffany and manufacturing companies like Lam Research and SPX.
Replacements included shares of military contractors like L-3 Communications and TRW; technology companies like EMC; retailers like Wal-Mart Stores and Walgreen; energy companies like Calpine and PG&E; as well as P.F. Chang's, Johnson & Johnson and Harley-Davidson.
Despite these shifts, the company's growth strategy produced some dismal results. Its Midcap Growth Fund, for example, lost 32 percent of its value in the last quarter, and was down 59 percent for the 12 months ending Sept. 30. 
Turner's response to the attacks was broad. After determining that its 89 employees and their family members were safe, though some who were traveling were stranded, the firm tried to reassure customers not only that it was able to do business but also that it would not deviate from its investment principles.
"Our financial system has weathered tragic events in the past, and it will do so again now," Turner said in an e-mail message to its 4,900 clients and industry colleagues on Sept. 12. "Our offices will remain open."
The basic message to clients, Mr. Turner said, was "Don't bail out."
PARTICULAR attention was given to consultants, those whose advice helps decide where institutions place their money.
"We wanted clients to know we're here -- and what's going on," said Stephen J. Kneeley, president of Turner and one of four main shareholders in the firm, which is privately held.
While the markets were closed, employees attended daily, often emotional, staff meetings, said Doff Meyer, the chief marketing officer. 
They were urged to focus on their work. "We cannot leave a basis point of alpha on the table," said Mr. Kneeley, referring to the slimmest unit of market-beating performance. "Some of our competitors are not going to be standing at the end of this. We are."
To accommodate small investors with patriotic fervor, Turner reduced its $2,500 investment limit to $25 for the first two weeks after the markets reopened. And it canceled a reception it had planned in San Francisco as part of the annual meeting of the International Foundation of Employee Benefit Plans, donating the money instead to the American Red Cross.
Many of the portfolio shifts that Turner made were obvious, selling shares in industries like airlines, hotels and insurance and investing in industries that could benefit like military suppliers and companies that make travel less necessary. One stock it added, Polycom, is a maker of audioconferencing equipment.
But the firm's analysts, several of whom double as portfolio managers, dug a bit deeper in search of other investment possibilities.
Frank L. Sustersic, the health care specialist, warmed to pharmaceuticals stocks, figuring that price limitations and a patients' bill of rights would be less likely to be enacted by a government whose attention had been diverted to issues of national security.
"From a political standpoint, the events were perversely positive," Mr. Sustersic said. He also spent some time considering the question of which stocks might suffer if foreign insurers, facing large claims, were forced to sell shares.
William C. McVail, who oversees consumer products, suggested that a rise in the "nesting" impulse would make eBay and Barnes & Noble more appealing, and he contended that a recession would put a premium on job-related education, which led Turner to add to its holdings of the Apollo Group, parent of the online University of Phoenix. 
And he found that Stanley Works, the tool maker, was in line to sell more products to Wal-Mart. As for the advertising business, Mr. McVail said, the best indicator -- "the canary in the coal mine" -- is the spending of car dealers and other merchants on radio stations in major markets.
"We're sector neutral, so you can't not own consumer stocks," Mr. McVail said. "That's the challenge, to find the exposure."
But Turner, whipsawed when it became bullish on semiconductor capital equipment in late summer, continues to stress growth despite the sour investment climate.
"There's a tendency to become value oriented" and abandon a time-tested and widely broadcast growth style, Mr. Turner said, who told clients that the attacks "will certainly" push the economy into a recession.
"It would be easy to throw in the towel and buy more conservative stocks that on a near-term basis may be better relative performers," Turner told clients on Sept. 19, the middle of stocks' worst week since the Depression, as gauged by the Dow Jones industrials. But those stocks will lag behind when the market turns up, it said, adding, "We are growth stock managers and when growth re-emerges, we will be there."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Bolstered by Rate Cuts, S.& L.'s Are on the Rise

BYLINE:  By CAROLINE WAXLER

 BODY:
DECLINING short-term interest rates and strengthening balance sheets have bolstered the shares of savings and loan associations, and some analysts say the stocks continue to be good values.
 "The bottom line is that I don't think these stocks are very expensive," said Jeff Runnfeldt, senior analyst at Montgomery Asset Management in San Francisco. The stocks have an average trailing price-to-earnings ratio of 13.8, versus 20 for the Standard & Poor's 500. He said these companies had fairly stable earnings and had benefited from falling short-term interest rates. 
 David Ellison, portfolio manager at FBR Fund Advisors in Boston, said he thought the current environment was good for the savings institutions, including companies like Astoria Financial, Charter One Financial, Golden State Bancorp, Golden West Financial and Washington Mutual.
Savings and loan associations lend money to homeowners through mortgages, financings and home equity loans -- on a fixed-rate or adjustable-rate basis. They typically sell off the fixed-rate loans but keep the adjustable ones on the balance sheet as assets. They profit from the difference between the yield on their loans and their cost of deposits; during the last 18 months, that gap has grown larger. Primarily because of the short-term rate cuts, Mr. Ellison said, earnings in the fourth quarter could be even higher than expected.
Still, long-term interest rates have been dropping, too, posing a risk for the savings institutions. If rates become too low, consumers will probably lock in the lower fixed-rate mortgages instead of turning toward the adjustable-rate mortgages, which are crucial for balance sheet growth. Mr. Ellison said that if long-term rates fell too far, margins would shrink. The average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage, according to Freddie Mac, declined to 6.64 percent last week, to the lowest level since 1998. Mortgage refinancings this year are estimated to reach $890 billion, the highest level ever. 
Another danger is found in the economic slowdown. If the downturn persists, lending will slow, and consumer defaults will rise.
Savings and loans have not always been the safest places to invest. In the industry crisis of the 1980's, questionable loans led to rampant bankruptcies as the economy faltered. Today, Mr. Ellison said, the industry is more strictly regulated, and problems should not be as severe. "This is a cleaned-up industry which is very conservatively run," he said. 
Many companies have capital ratios -- equity as a percentage of assets -- of 6 to 7 percent. In the mid-1980's, 2 to 3 percent was not unusual. 
Thomas O'Donnell, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said he thought that in the short term, institutions that do more adjustable-rate mortgage lending, like Washington Mutual and Golden West, should benefit most from the wider gap between short- and long-term interest rates.
Washington Mutual, based in Seattle, is the largest savings and loan in the country, with with $229 billion in assets, and is acquiring Dime Bancorp of New York. "Lower rates are helpful to us." said Kerry Killinger, Washington Mutual's chief executive. It earned $2.36 a share last year, and the forecast for this year, according to Thomson Financial/First Call, is $3.56 a share. Its stock now trades at $38.49.
Golden West, based in Oakland, Calif., is the third-largest in the country, with $57 billion in assets. For its 2000 fiscal year, it earned $3.41 a share, but expects to earn $5.01 a share this year. It trades at $57.10.
Its expenses are less than 1 percent of assets, versus 2 percent for a typical savings and loan. Herbert Sandler, the co-chairman and co-chief executive, said, "We're not smart enough to forecast the direction of interest rates," but, he added, "We have a terrific productivity and cost effectiveness." He said the company's earnings per share had grown at an average annual rate of 17 percent for the last 30 years; the average over five years has been 21 percent. 
MR. ELLISON recommended Astoria Financial, based in Lake Success, N.Y., because it has an expense ratio of less than 1 percent and high business volume in each branch. Its location is a benefit, he said. "This is a densely populated blue-collar area, which is a perfect banking market," he said.
With $22.5 billion in assets, the company is the second-largest savings and loan in New York and the sixth largest in the country. Astoria earned $4.32 a share last year, and analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/ First Call expect that to rise to $4.77 a share this year; the stock now trades at $58.44. "There is a lot of safety in the typical thrift business," said George L. Engelke Jr., chairman and chief executive of Astoria. "The last thing anybody wants to lose is a place to live. They would eat less or have less fun rather than not make their mortgage payments."

SECTION: Section 14; Column 2; The City Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

HEADLINE: New York's True Heart 

BYLINE:  By BILL McKIBBEN; Bill McKibben is the author of "The End of Nature" and other books about the environment. His latest book is "Long Distance: A Year of Living Strenuously," about cross-country skiing. He is a visiting scholar at Middlebury College in Vermont.

 BODY:
ONE of the myths Manhattan likes to tell about itself is that it runs on ideas alone. 
 It's true that this rather unremarkable island managed to turn itself into the most important place on earth through sheer brainpower. The ability to juggle words and numbers and images and emotions made it the publishing and financial and communications and advertising center of the globe, gradually replacing, in the last century, the manufacturing and the shipping and the actual doing that underpin most economies. 
 But it's true as well that at the bottom of all that virtuality there always remained a physical city. Its typical dramas are usually well hidden -- there's no Dow Jones Index of Water Main Breaks -- but in the days after the World Trade Center attack, that infrastructure literally burst out into the open. 
To stuff it back inside there just as suddenly appeared swarms of men and women, the incredibly competent overseers of this submerged world. You were suddenly reminded that for every Master of the Universe trading bonds in the clouds, there was a Master of the Underworld, who knew how to splice cable back together. 
Everyone has focused, understandably, on the heroics of the fire and rescue crews sifting through the rubble at the site of the attack. 
But consider the subtler feats of magic and grit worked in the course of the first few weeks:
Con Ed, with some 850 workers out in the streets, managed in eight days to cut and isolate the circuits around the twin towers and a pair of destroyed substations, lay 33 miles of new cable, and restore service to virtually all the 12,000 commercial and residential buildings without electricity and the 1,400 without gas. 
Verizon managed to restore two-thirds of the 300,000 voice lines served by its West Street switching center, even though many of its manholes were deep under the debris, and flooding and falling debris destroyed parts of the underground cable vault.
City workers somehow got subways rerouted and stations reopened, even though the tunnel for the No. 1 and No. 9 trains was crushed, the No. 2 and 3 tube was partly flooded, and stairways to the N and the R were filled with rubble. 
There have been, of course, grumbles that it took too long (as good a sign as any of New York returning to "normal"). But when you stop to think about what lies at the real heart of the city, it's almost unbelievable that the recovery has been so swift.
At the very bottom, almost completely obscured, lies the natural Manhattan that the first settlers found: bedrock, fault lines, even stream beds. Sometimes, when the water department finds flooding in a basement but can't easily trace the source of the leak, an inspector will pull out a map drawn by Egbert L. Viele in 1865, a map that shows the island's original shoreline and its active creeks: Saw Kill Stream, Smit's Vly, and so on, a gazetteer of the vanished, all obliterated beneath fill and foundation. But not totally obliterated. Sometimes, water pouring out of a main will find one of the old stream beds and follow it blocks uptown or down, and if you have the map you can puzzle it out.
ABOVE that is a spaghetti bowl of pipes, wires, cables, mains, all of it forgotten, except when those swirls of steam come wafting up from beneath Times Square. But even in the best of times, it's under severe stress. 
Say a gas main crosses a water pipe. Every time something presses down on the gas main, it chisels away at the pipe. What could press down on a gas main? Years ago, in a more innocent time, I asked that question of the chief of repair for the Bureau of Water Supply. "Say you get some clown hightailing down Canal Street to the Holland Tunnel at 3 a.m. in his moving van," he said, "hitting all the valve boxes and the potholes and, oh, boy, those pipes will just crack."
Or say you get a building hurtling down through space, millions of tons of debris crashing in a few square acres. Crashing hard enough, for instance, to crumple the I-beams that vault the subway tunnels, which in some cases run just five feet below the surface of the street. Because of the curious history of the subways -- they were built by competing private firms, each wanting a piece of the lucrative Lower Manhattan traffic -- the lines all converge on the crowded ground near the Battery. Ground that, incidentally, must also be protected from the water of the harbor. A retaining wall performs that job, a retaining wall that almost miraculously appears intact.
In other words, the heavy-yielding trees of commerce that blossom all across the island, and grow thickest at its tip, are rooted in an ungodly tangle below the ground. That tangle twists beneath every inch of the city. There are still wooden pipes down there, bypassed now, that once carried water or factory gas. Nothing is clean, simple, easy to unknot. It's a splay that forever defies rationalization, one jury-rigged from the technologies of three centuries.
Repairing it requires the skills of those different eras, too. I've watched Con Ed splicers repair a cable shorted by hungry rats who relish the insulation, watched as a worker climbed down a manhole, pulled the line through till he found the hole, replaced the wire cover with a lead sleeve, and then heated lead solder till it was 900 degrees. 
Wearing cotton work gloves, he poured the lead from a ladle over the cable, and caught the excess in another ladle beneath, then held the molten lead in place with a square of cotton ticking into which he had spit. Grease would work better than spit, he said, except that when it heated up it drew new rats at a run.
Now, down in the subway tunnels, other workers are simultaneously shoring up damaged arches with the wooden pillars that miners have used for eons, and monitoring the most high-tech inclinometers to see if the ground is still shifting. Some parts of the tunnels are so precarious that they'll need to be literally filled with concrete to keep them from collapsing under the weight of the recovery machinery operating on the streets above. And when the time comes, subway workers will then have to tunnel right through that concrete to build a new line. 
The kind of expertise that allows the city even to begin to cope with such disasters doesn't come quickly. You can't wait until a crisis and then start thinking about what you're going to do. 
Imagine a day in 1940, when New York City's Water Board, looking for engineers, offered a Civil Service exam. It gave the test simultaneously in New York, Boston, Denver, where many of the best employees of the Federal Bureau of Reclamation were located; and in Knoxville, Tenn., trying to lure engineers from the Tennessee Valley Authority. 
Ten thousand took the test, 20 were offered jobs, and many of those began early in their careers to plot the course of the third tunnel, a vast excavating job still under way. 
It was needed to bring water to the fast-growing areas of Brooklyn and Queens. But even more it was needed because there was no way to shut down and fix the city's two existing water tunnels, which dated from the first part of the century. Everyone feared -- still fears -- that if their gate valves were closed so the huge pipes could be inspected, they might stick shut, drying up the city. Through such forethought comes the kind of redundancy that makes it possible to imagine surviving an attack like last month's.
IT'S not just forethought, either, but a kind of persnickety fussiness as well. Perhaps you've noticed, on streets around the city, gray boxes that look as if they house the controls for traffic lights. In fact, some of them house spigots so that water from any neighborhood can be drawn for testing: run through infrared spectrometers, checked for acidity, alkalinity, bacteria, temperature, fluoride, conductivity, odor. Even for taste. 
So while armed guards patrol the upstate reservoirs to make sure terrorists aren't adding chemicals or poisons, there's also a standing army of lab techs making sure the water is still clear. 
The point is that any city, and especially a city with supply lines as long as New York's, has its own ecology. Its enterprises may seem to respond to consumer confidence or to interest rates, but they are exquisitely sensitive to the physical world as well. Droughts, shifts in environmental laws, changes in energy prices and supplies all work their way through the system, requiring constant adjustment. The Clean Air Act means Con Ed must stop burning coal, and then search the world for low-sulfur oil, for high-grade uranium, for electricity from distant dams. Reservoir levels fall on the headwaters of the Delaware and workers need to dust off giant emergency pumps for sucking water from the Hudson. 
All of this just happens, year in and year out, without the cacophony that accompanies any move in the above-ground Manhattan. In that world, squads of analysts make fortunes, and great names, tracking telecom stocks, but their every move relies on similar squads of people who have built up an expertise in actual telecom equipment. People who know the Esperanto not of money but of gear, who are intimate with the enormous, spidery walls of switches and relays and contacts that make broadband, not to mention dial tone, actual possibilities.
A horror like Sept. 11 explodes our ingrained image for a little while, both literally and in the way that engineers speak of an "exploded diagram." For a little while, one can see the sinews of the city, raw and exposed. 
Right now, in the streets around ground zero, the electric lines run through cables lying on the curb. Soon enough they'll be buried again, made invisible as part of the healing process.
The people who make that system work are usually invisible too. They don't live in Manhattan; for the most part these are bridge-and-tunnel, Island-and-Jersey jobs, often pretty well paid, but never compensated with the kind of glamour that attaches to even the most ephemeral of Manhattan's knowledge industry occupations. 
For the moment, there's an unusual solidarity between New Yorkers of every address and pay grade. Just as surely, that fellow feeling will fade over time, as the city of hype and flash rebuilds its self-confidence, convinces itself once more that it needs nothing from the outside save capital, assures itself that its cloud of hot air keeps Manhattan gloriously afloat. Which it does, but not without a lot of people just as savvy down in the basement bailing hard.

HEADLINE: New York Fiscal Crisis 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "A Looming New York Fiscal Crisis" (editorial, Oct. 3) understates the problems facing New York State. According to the governor's pre-Sept. 11 projections, New York would have faced deficits of $1.2 billion in the 2001-2002 fiscal year, and $2.6 billion in 2002-2003. 
Since Sept. 11, the projected deficit has skyrocketed. 
 It will be difficult for New York City to find relief in Albany. The challenge to our next mayor will be to develop creative and aggressive economic growth programs and shepherd them through Washington's perilous political process. Hard as it may be, our political leaders need to move beyond comforting the immediate victims of the Sept. 11 atrocity and begin to address the needs of the indirect victims of the terrorists, including tens of thousands of laid-off workers and our 1.1 million schoolchildren, whose needs must not be forgotten.

ERIC T. SCHNEIDERMAN
State Senator, 30th District
New York, Oct. 3, 2001

HEADLINE: Private Skies Of the Very Rich 

BYLINE:  By ALEX KUCZYNSKI

 BODY:
AT a small dinner party in New York last weekend, the conversation among the well-to-do guests turned to vacation plans. The diners -- husbands in custom-made shirts, wives with dewy, laser-blasted faces -- spoke of the potential strain of commercial air travel and the special frustrations this holiday season will surely hold. 
 They spoke of their fear in the lingering shadow of terrorism, and, of course, of the wait in long security lines -- only to have your $42 Tweezerman cuticle nippers taken away from you, one diner complained. 
 Another woman turned to the table and asked, "But how are we going to get to Vail?" 
The answer, everyone agreed, was aboard your own plane -- by booking a charter, buying a time-share or hopping a ride with a friendly mogul. 
In the last decade, the lure of private aviation has saturated the ranks of America's wealthy. And since Sept. 11, as Americans have become more cautious about flying and first-class passengers accustomed to whisking past the economy classes blanch at the thought of long lines, requests for chartered flights have surged. In addition, aviation companies that in the last 10 years have introduced shared ownership programs for private planes (think of a shared Hamptons beach house, but with flight attendants) have in recent weeks expanded their programs to be more affordable.
The wealthy and merely well-to-do -- the A-type moguls, society divas and spoiled venture capitalists, the people whose loafers are never penny, but Belgian or Gucci, the movie stars and society interior decorators -- are all jostling for a seat on a Gulfstream, which sometimes means simply asking, May I hitch a ride with you? 
"I have offered rides to people, sure," said Felix Dennis, the publisher of Maxim and other magazines, who flies to his homes in Mustique, New York and London on chartered jets. "I can understand why there is more interest in flying private. I cannot stand to wait for anything, and most of my friends can't either." Mr. Dennis said that the inconvenience of extra security, not safety, is the issue in his circle. He has offered lifts to friends for a December pilgrimage to Mustique. 
Hollywood, the land of pampered egos and paranoia, has also been making an end run around the airline industry. NBC hired a private jet to bring Reese Witherspoon across the country to host "Saturday Night Live" on Sept. 29. Last week, John Cusack flew on a Disney corporate jet from Los Angeles to New York to promote his movie "Serendipity"; in normal times, a producer said, he might have flown first class.
Even for those Americans unlikely ever to be guests of morning television, the private plane is emerging as a way to skip the frustration of long lines at airports. An investment banker in his early 30's at Credit Suisse First Boston, who described himself last week as "the farthest thing from a mogul you can imagine," said that he and his wife are trying to put together a group of fliers to go to Vail at Christmas at a cost of about $2,625 a person one way, roughly the cost of a first-class ticket. 
"The airports are going to be crowded, I don't want to wait with my gear in a line a hundred miles long, and I guess I have this residual bad feeling about flying," he said. 
Mario Buatta, the interior decorator, said that although he has always been afraid of flying, he must travel for work, and clients have offered in the last few weeks to fly him privately. "They want to send a plane for me," he said. "Oklahoma or Texas, for example. It is very thoughtful." 
Decorators flying in private jets? What's next, Madonna's manicurist? If the number of private airplanes is any indication, the answer is yes. Since 1991, the number of private planes used by corporations has increased to 14,000, a 47 percent rise, the National Business Aviation Association said; many of those planes are also used by business owners and executives for personal travel. 
And since the soul-chilling disasters of Sept. 11, charter companies, which make planes available to anyone with a telephone and a platinum card, report huge new interest. According to Air Charter Guide, a directory of the 20,000 commercially licensed charter aircraft in the United States, 80 percent of surveyed charter companies report an increase in bookings since Sept. 11. Meara McLaughlin, a spokeswoman for the directory, said that many of the companies had reported interest from people who want to split a plane with friends, colleagues or family. 
"Now they call up and ask, 'Hey, what would it cost for me and three of my friends to fly to Sun Valley?' or, 'Hey, I'm about to drop $2,200 on a first-class ticket, and I wonder if it might be cheaper to charter,' " Ms. McLaughlin said. 
The flowering of options means that a personal jet is no longer an anomaly akin to Hugh Hefner's big purple bunny plane in the sky. You can still buy your own Gulfstream V for about $45 million, plus millions more annually for insurance, housing, maintenance, pilots' fees and fuel. But there are also less expensive alternatives -- chartering a plane for between $2,000 and $5,000 an hour; and various aircraft time-shares, known as fractional ownership plans, which run from around $110,000 into the millions 
Kevin Russell, senior vice president at Executive Jet, a corporate aircraft operator owned by Warren Buffet, the billionaire investor, said that the company's fractional owner service has been generating more attention in recent weeks, for price, convenience and safety. 
He said preflight inspections include the exterior, the baggage compartment and the cabin. The planes are locked down when not in the air. Baggage is not X-rayed, because not all of the 3,300 airports that the jets fly to have X-ray machines, but baggage is hand-checked. 
Passengers do not go through metal detectors, for the same reason, but Mr. Russell said the passengers are generally known to the crew. Passengers must supply a manifest before the trip, and must provide identification before boarding the plane. Weapons are not allowed. 
John Nance, a pilot, author and aviation analyst for ABC News, said that corporate jets are not impervious to attack. 
Companies that operate chartered planes must be extra diligent, he said.
"Anyone could charter the plane and kill the pilot," he said. "You had better identify your charterers and make darn sure you get the F.B.I. in on the equation if you have any doubts about them." 
The other issue, he said, is that not all planes are secured at night. 
"Right now, we have thousands of small and large planes sitting with marginal security every night. That is an uncovered area that is being addressed, and it is a vulnerability." 
Executive Jet's fractional ownership program, Net Jets, is still not for weekend excursions. Ownership contracts for the smallest plane, the Citation V Ultra, begin with an upfront price of $375,000 for a one-sixteenth interest in the plane. Above that, the annual fee is $135,000, which buys 50 hours of flying time per year. 
Last week Net Jet announced a program that makes it even cheaper: in partnership with Marquis Jet Partners, buyers can purchase fractional ownership for one year, instead of the normal commitment of five years. Twenty-five hours of flight time begins at $109,000 for a Citation V.
Alan Clingman, the chief executive of Marquis, said the company has signed up celebrities, including the rap group Run DMC and the professional golfer Jim Furyk. But its clients are also families and groups of friends. Regular folks, but rich regular folks. 
"Three guys might fly together with their wives and split the bill, just as if they were at a restaurant," Mr. Clingman said. 
Todd Rome, the president of Blue Star Jets in New York, a year-old agency that matches charters with customers, said that he has made more arrangements for mid-level executives in the last three weeks. 
"You're getting not just the high-level executives, but you're getting someone who wants to spend Thanksgiving with his grandmother in Boca," he said. 
In an odd situation that must make the merely rich folks giggle, it is the superwealthy Gulfstream V owners who have special problems right now. Teterboro Airport in Teterboro, N.J., long a favorite with the private-jet crowd for its proximity to Manhattan, was as late as Friday shut to private jets -- classified by the F.A.A. as "owner-operated, not for hire" aircraft -- and only charter flights or fractionally owned planes could use the runways. 
Theodore J. Forstmann, the New York financier who resuscitated the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation a decade ago, said that the Federal Aviation Administration's no-fly policy for some private airports was a royal pain. 
"Teterboro is closed, so you have to go White Plains," he said. "But everyone's going to White Plains. Which means you have these long waits on the ground. So then we try Morristown, but that's a long drive. But you get off the ground a lot easier." 
And there are other kinds of drawbacks. Mr. Buatta, for instance, said that he would probably take up one of his clients' offers to fly out on a private aircraft. 
"But the worst part," he said, "is that I'll probably have to get a flight back on my own."

HEADLINE: Companies' Big Debts Now Carry Big Risks 

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
FOLLOW the money. In the harsh, new world after Sept. 11, that axiom applies more than ever.
 The United States is almost certainly in a recession, and many companies and their investors now face a stark future. Even companies whose operations were humming in early September are vulnerable to what may become a protracted slump. 
 Those with the shakiest prospects became obvious immediately -- travel and entertainment companies, for example. And as trading in the bond market slowed to a crawl in recent days, all kinds of companies in need of cash to keep operating found themselves out of luck. Much of corporate America is overextended. 
During the boom, "things were so good that a lot of folks loaded up on debt and on employees," said David Trone, senior regional bank stock analyst at Prudential Securities. "Now it has quickly unraveled. You have a whole lot of industries with overcapacity." 
Many heavy borrowers, Mr. Trone said, are at great risk.
Last week, Polaroid, in default on nearly $1 billion in debt and with little excess income, seemed to be on its way to filing for bankruptcy protection -- and it is by no means alone. 
Renaissance Cruises, a privately held operator of cruises, shut down and filed for bankruptcy protection on Sept. 25. A lawyer for the company said it had failed because it could no longer finance its operations, and negotiations with prospective lenders and investors had broken down after the terrorist attacks. 
Even companies that are not as close to the edge as Renaissance are imperiled by a nation of newly parsimonious consumers. At risk are department stores, like Nordstrom; furniture manufacturers, like Ethan Allen Interiors; and consumer electronics and personal computer companies, like Gateway. Until last month, ebullient American shoppers had kept the economy out of recession, but this crucial source of revenue and profits is largely gone. 
Like sand in the gears of a well-oiled machine, these financial stresses impede the economy's ability to rev up and exit the downturn. 
"You had a number of things aligning," said Stuart C. Gilson, professor of corporate restructuring at the Harvard Business School. "Excessive confidence among consumers and companies and easy access to debt capital meant banks made a lot of bad loans, and a lot of high-yield bond issues were made to companies facing extreme risks. This one's going to take a little longer to work through the system."
INVESTORS may be especially unprepared for the wringing out of these risks. In recent years, Wall Street has largely ignored the high levels of debt lurking on the balance sheets of many companies. Instead, analysts obsessed over revenue growth and earnings, if companies had any. 
But bond investors, the professional worriers of the financial markets, closely monitor debt loads and a company's ability to pay interest obligations. The actions of those investors can tip off others to problems that more freewheeling and forgiving stockholders ignore. 
In recent weeks, bond investors have had a lot to worry about. Corporate debt has not reached dangerous levels across every industry, but overall debt has risen substantially in the last five years. As a percent of net worth, corporate debt has risen to 77 percent last year, from 73 percent in 1995, according to the Federal Reserve. 
Not surprisingly, many companies have run short of cash and have simply stopped paying their obligations. Default rates on corporate bonds have already zoomed past the levels seen in the last recession, in 1990. By August, even before Sept. 11, default rates on high-yield bonds had reached 9.6 percent, above the 8.7 percent peak of 1990, according to Fitch Inc., a credit rating agency. Almost $56 billion in debt was in default as August began, roughly double the amount of defaults in all of 2000.
Rising defaults, along with other evidence of credit problems in corporate America, have been percolating through the economy for some time. As early as the third quarter of 1998, the number of debt downgrades began exceeding upgrades, said Diane Vazza, head of global fixed-income research at Standard & Poor's. They have done so ever since -- for 13 consecutive quarters. That is well beyond the 11 consecutive quarters of higher downgrades around the recession of the early 1990's.
"We've been in a manufacturing recession," Ms. Vazza said. "Certainly consumer confidence was shaken enough by the events of Sept. 11 that it shoved us into recession." In the three weeks after Sept. 11, S. & P. downgraded $162 billion in debt issued by 45 companies, but upgraded only $44 billion issued by 9 companies.
Until now, the credit problem has generally been limited to a handful of industries -- manufacturers and, most notably, telecommunications companies. Investors who dreamed of endless demand for broadband, wireless and other communication technologies are now haunted by telecom companies' debt binge from 1997 to 1999. Of the $74 billion in debt that has defaulted this year, $31 billion was by telecom companies. 
Now the weakness is spreading, striking companies that, until recently, had been enjoying hefty profits, courtesy of spendthrift consumers. 
No more. Richard D. Hastings, a research fellow at the Credit Research Foundation and credit economist at Cyber Business Credit in New York, said a new hesitation among consumers about spending money poses the gravest threat to the world economy. 
"Consumers will postpone purchases of anything that is postponable," Mr. Hastings said. "As demand suddenly drops, already overinventoried positions in many suppliers will result in weaker prices as firms attempt to raise cash quickly and maintain competitive positions."
Personal spending, which grew almost 4 percent in the fourth quarter of 1999 over the same period a year earlier, has been steadily dropping since. Mr. Hastings estimated that in the third quarter, these expenditures grew 1 percent to 1.35 percent, dealing a blow to companies dependent on free-spending Americans. 
Feeling flush, consumers have for years spent more than they have made, and they, too, are entering this recession with heavy debt and no cushion. Consumer debt was $1.6 trillion in July, more than double $783the billion 10 years ago, according to the Federal Reserve. This year, households are using 14.35 cents of every dollar of their disposable income to pay interest, compared with 12.35 cents in 1995. 
That burden becomes only heavier when rising layoffs are added to the mix. Companies cut almost 200,000 jobs in September, the biggest decline in a decade. On Wednesday, the Ford Motor Company, one of the nation's largest employers, warned that plants could be closed if its manufacturing costs did not come down quickly.
For many companies, the problem is just that: high fixed costs, some of which are interest payments, set against declining revenue. The nine reductions in interest rates by the Fed this year will not help some companies that need to refinance their debt. For them, the capital markets are either closed or still asking rates that are out of their reach. 
The picture is not bleak for every company. Many took advantage of the incendiary stock market of the late 1990's and raised money there, rather than in debt markets. As a result, said Sam DeRosa-Farag, director of global leverage finance at Credit Suisse First Boston, most companies have more conservative capital structures today than they did 10 years ago. 
"In 1988, the average debt was 90 percent of capitalization and equity was 10 percent," Mr. DeRosa-Farag said. "Today, debt is 60 percent and equity is 40." (Conservatives, though small in number, would say that anything over 40 percent debt is risky.)
THIS time, some sectors that were hammered in the last recession are in stronger condition, at least for now. Retailers, for example, were the casualties in the 1990's, thanks to leveraged buyouts that loaded them with debt. These days, retailers are in much better shape, Ms. Verde of Fitch said. Less than one-third of the retailers that have issued high-yield bonds are in the two lowest credit rankings: B or CCC. 
"That's not to say they won't deteriorate," she said. "But it would be much more troubling if they had a greater percentage of lower-rated bonds." 
On another positive note, the mix in the overall high-yield bond market -- which includes riskier companies -- is skewed more toward higher-quality issues today than it was going into the last recession. Martin S. Fridson, chief high-yield strategist at Merrill Lynch, said that at the end of 1989, only 30.5 percent of the junk bond market was made up of the highest-rated securities -- those rated BB -- while 55.7 percent was of lesser-quality, B-rated securities and 13.8 percent were CCC. 
Today, however, securities rated BB dominate the market -- a 47.5 percent share. B-rated debt is 39.3 percent and CCC-rated bonds are 13.2 percent.
But even if the recession is not long, or deep, many companies have amassed large debts and are watching nervously as their revenue shrinks. The Sept. 11 attacks, Mr. DeRosa-Farag said, sharply increased the chances of defaults.
Not surprisingly, from Sept. 6 to Sept. 20, the probability of defaults rose significantly for aerospace companies, whose airline customers are wobbling with cash problems of their own. And default probabilities also jumped in the telecommunications sector during that time, to 44.4 percent from 42.6 percent. 
More surprising, information technology has also been hit, with default probabilities rising to 12.3 percent from 6.9 percent. Among cable and wireless video companies, Mr. DeRosa-Farag said, that number rose to 17 percent from 13 percent. Others with increased default probabilities were wireless communications companies, chemical makers and forest product and container companies.
Of telecom and cable companies, Mr. DeRosa-Farag said: "These credits are highly dependent on the availability of credit. There is a whole crop of companies that are going to miss the availability-of-credit window."
LOOKING at industry trends, Mr. DeRosa-Farag has broken down vulnerability to the current slowdown into three categories. 
Those industries that should not be badly hurt include food companies, health care providers, broadcasters and, at least in the short term, energy companies. Those that will be sensitive to the downturn, he said, include automotive suppliers, gambling operations, homebuilders, media companies, paper manufacturers, metals concerns, technology and wireless telecommunications companies.
Industries most likely to be hurt, he said, are chemical companies, lodging and leisure companies, retailers and clothing makers, the transportation sector and telecommunications.
Bond investors, attuned to changes in companies' financial footing, reacted quickly after Sept. 11, selling securities of companies whose prospects had dimmed. As bond prices fell, yields increased. Yields on bonds issued by textile and apparel companies, for example, jumped to more than 22 percent in mid-September from about 19 percent in mid-August. For makers of cars and car parts, bond yields climbed to 26 percent from 19 percent, and for restaurants, to 14 percent from 13 percent.
Yields on some bonds issued by Tricon Global Restaurants, owner and franchiser of 30,000 Pizza Hut, Taco Bell and Kentucky Fried Chicken eateries, had risen to 11.75 percent by mid-September from 7.92 percent, and those of Pep Boys, an auto parts retailer, rose to 10.89 percent from 8.14 percent. 
"There's not a lot of bottom-fishing going on," Mr. Fridson said. "People are getting out of downgrades before they happen or they're trying to upgrade in quality." 
Bond investors may have backed away from these companies, but stockholders have not abandoned many of them. While a bond of the Dana Corporation, a maker of components for cars and trucks, fell to $905 in mid-September, from $960 in mid-August, its shares are not cheap, trading at 24 times current earnings and two times sales.
At Hasbro, the toymaker, the yield of one bond rose to 12.5 percent from 9.7 percent, but its shares are trading at 38 times its estimated earnings versus 21 times for Mattel.
Investors also appear to think that regional banks will emerge unscathed from a recession, because the Fed is lowering interest rates so aggressively and they are not exposed to the telecommunications meltdown. 
But that view is wrongheaded, said Mr. Trone at Prudential Securities. "All industries are under pressure, but we would certainly expect the banks to underperform," he said. "We're not talking about an insolvency issue, like the 1990's. We're talking about earnings risk."
Mr. Trone says the Pacific Century Financial Corporation, a regional financial services holding company with operations in Hawaii, Asia and the South Pacific, is particularly vulnerable. The company is heavily dependent on the isolated and tourism-reliant economy of Hawaii. A slowdown in Japanese tourism has now been exacerbated by a dearth of American visitors. 
"This will have a substantial impact on the middle-market companies they lend to and the real estate companies," Mr. Trone said. 
Nevertheless, the stock, which he rates a sell, closed at $20.65, up 16.8 percent for the year to date. It is trading at more than one and a half times its earnings growth rate and 14 times its expected earnings. 
Even healthy banks that do not rely on tourism will be hurt by a recession; Mr. Trone pointed to Cullen/Frost Bankers Inc. The company has a conservative management team and operates in Texas, where the economy had remained strong. But on Sept. 28, its shares fell 27 percent when it said its 2001 profit would be less than expected, in part because of an increase in loan loss reserves. 
"If this can happen to Cullen/ Frost," Mr. Trone said, "this can happen to anyone."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 7, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in Money & Business on Oct. 7 headlined "Companies' Big Debts Now Carry Big Risks" discussed the falloff in consumer spending since Sept. 11. The article cited a cruise operator that had filed for bankruptcy protection, and then said that even companies that were not close to the edge were imperiled by consumers' cutback in spending. That passage gave several examples, including Ethan Allen Interiors. 
The mention of Ethan Allen in a discussion of indebted companies was not warranted. Ethan Allen executives say the company is "virtually debt-free."

HEADLINE: Making Sure the Rich Stay Rich, Even in Crisis 

BYLINE:  By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
MARIA ELENA LAGOMASINO was giving a speech to private bankers in Geneva last month when she was interrupted with the news that hijacked jetliners had plowed into the World Trade Center. As soon as she learned of the terrorist attack, Ms. Lagomasino, chairwoman of the J. P. Morgan Private Bank, raced to Morgan's office to check on colleagues in New York, then started calling her wealthy clients there and in Hong Kong, Buenos Aires and elsewhere around the world. The clients -- individuals and families worth $100 million, on average -- rely on Morgan to help them manage and protect their fortunes.
 "We felt it was important to force the issue and to think about what would happen," Ms. Lagomasino, a petite and elegantly tailored woman, said in an interview last week. "We wanted them to think about how this would affect the economy and the market. 
 "Since our clients were rich, our No. 1 concern was their staying rich," she said. "We wanted to make sure we put in place whatever defensive actions they need to do that." 
Ms. Lagomasino knows her territory. Her charges are people and families with net worths of at least $25 million, and they include more than one-third of the people on Forbes magazine's list of the 400 wealthiest in the world. The private bank, a part of J. P. Morgan Chase that oversees $300 billion in assets, is the largest such institution in the United States and second in the world only to UBS Warburg Private Banking. 
J. P. Morgan is a mainstay of the rapidly growing industry of advising the superwealthy -- a group whose purchasing power has been known to inflate overall consumer spending, a significant part of the economy -- and Ms. Lagomasino is perhaps the most visible of the world's growing ranks of private bankers.
"What you want from a banker is pure, unadulterated, honest opinions," and she is "an honest broker," said Gary Winnick, the embattled chairman of Global Crossing, who is both a client and a friend of Ms. Lagomasino. Earlier this year, he asked her to join the board of Global Crossing.
Private banking was once denigrated as "walking the dog," or "taking care of people with inherited wealth who don't have the capability to do anything themselves," as one banking executive put it recently.
But during the 1990's, as the world's wealth soared, J. P. Morgan and other top banks pushed to attract the growing number of multimillionaires as clients, especially those who own their own businesses, have sold businesses or run big public companies.
There are 60,000 families worldwide with net worths of $30 million or more, according to a report released in May by Cap Gemini Ernst & Young, a consulting firm. At the time, the number of superrich people was growing 5.8 percent annually, although recent market declines may have slowed or even reversed that rate.
Even if the number of very wealthy families does not grow as rapidly as it did in the 1990's, private banking will remain attractive because banks can earn returns of 20 to 25 percent on their investments in the business, according to a person close to the J. P. Morgan Private Bank.
Both Chase Manhattan and J. P. Morgan were active in private banking before their merger last year, and the combined operation became even more of a powerhouse. In August, Ms. Lagomasino inherited sole control of the private bank after her co-head, James E. Staley, who had run J. P. Morgan's private banking operation before the merger, was made head of the combined bank's private banking and investment management operations. Ms. Lagomasino reports to him.
She says roughly 70 percent of the Morgan bank's clients made their own fortunes, rather than inheriting them. In some cases, that has presented special problems because the World Trade Center tragedy increased the risk of extending and deepening stock-market declines. A number of Morgan's customers had taken loans against their stock holdings, and a precipitous market decline could set off margin calls.
"You have business people who have borrowed from their personal wealth to fund business investments," she said, her soft voice suffused with a slight accent reflecting her childhood in Cuba. "When the market looks good, they say: 'I will take stock and borrow against it for business.' " For some of these clients, she added, there could be "a problem with liabilities."
AFTER 25 years in the private banking business, Ms. Lagomasino can talk at length about such transactions.
Ms. Lagomasino was born in Havana in 1949 and emigrated to the United States with her family when she was 11, to escape the revolution led by Fidel Castro. Her family left behind her parents' properties and her grandparents' cigar and cigarette business. "We went first to Connecticut, and we were the only Cubans," she said. "It was difficult but wonderful."
Business was not an obvious career choice, but after majoring in French at Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y., and working in the library at the United Nations, she took an aptitude test that suggested she had business skills. Friends got her an interview at Citibank, where, after being hired, she was intrigued by private banking. "My clients were like my family," she said. "I always felt that if my grandfather, who lost his money, had had a private banker like me, somebody would have protected him."
Ms. Lagomasino, who eventually earned an M.B.A. at Fordham University, was running a Citibank private banking operation in southern Latin America in 1983 when she left to join Chase Manhattan. At Chase, she rose to become managing director and then the executive in charge of global private banking by the time Chase merged with J. P. Morgan.
Though Ms. Lagomasino is extremely secretive about her client list, it is said to range from prominent heads of public companies to families that control privately owned businesses. The private bank says it has clients in 36 countries; about 30 percent of Ms. Lagomasino's clients live outside the United States.
That means she has a heavy travel and social schedule, here and abroad. Mr. Winnick recalled that he met Ms. Lagomasino over dinner with David Rockefeller, the retired chairman of Chase, at Le Bernardin in Midtown Manhattan.
"I was impressed with her from Day 1," Mr. Winnick said. "She is the personification of what makes America great. She was an immigrant and rose through the system to the chairmanship of Chase private bank, working against whatever obstacles to succeed."
She also has the experience to help Mr. Winnick protect his fortune, which is still tens of millions of dollars even after his Global Crossing holdings have fallen to 83 cents a share, from a peak of $64.25 in May 1999.
"I wanted to talk to someone who was smart and understood it from a generational perspective," he said. "For me, I wasn't looking for a money manager. It was a person to tell you what other families were thinking: how they were doing things.
"It's like having a shrink," he said. "You don't have to give them the keys to your house, but you have to know they will give you advice based on your needs, not their needs."
In 1999, when Mr. Winnick was host for a dinner at the Claridges Hotel in London for a who's who of Britain's social and business elite, including Margaret Thatcher, King Constantine of Greece and Lord Saatchi among others, he seated Ms. Lagomasino next to him.
Some private banking clients turn over their investing decisions to J. P. Morgan. Others, including Mr. Winnick, do not. Mary Erdoes, a Morgan managing director at the private bank, said that of the $300 billion under supervision, the bank makes investment decisions on about $160 billion. For the balance, it helps advise the clients Its overall track record is almost impossible to evaluate because the bank releases no performance numbers. Some money is managed in-house, and some is delegated to outside managers.
The performance in various asset categories varies greatly. The bank's equity fund, for example, is off about 18 percent so far this year. "The fund is geared to outperform the public equity markets, and both have continued to do so," Ms. Erdoes said, citing the 19 percent decline in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
Wealthy families, however, want services beyond straight money management. Sometimes they want help for their businesses, too. For example, J. P. Morgan does not handle Mr. Winnick's investments, but Mr. Winnick's investment company, Pacific Capital, was part of the restructuring group led by the Softbank Corporation that acquired the Japanese bank Nippon Credit.
"Pacific Capital paid in dollars but it was a yen company," a person close to Mr. Winnick said. "That is fine if the yen and dollar remain in place. But his private bank would come back and say, 'You should provide some type of hedge against your yen exposure.' " This person recalled adding that Mr. Winnick "made as much money in the yen hedge as he made in the investment." Chase had arranged the hedge for Mr. Winnick, borrowing yen in an amount equal to what he had invested in the Japanese company, then selling them immediately for dollars. When the yen weakened, the bank bought back the currency at the lower exchange rate, and Mr. Winnick pocketed the difference.
Another client "wanted a Jack Kerouac manuscript more than anything," Ms. Lagomasino recalled. "We helped him figure out what it was worth, and we bid on it for him, although he didn't get it," she said. The bank also makes loans against art collections and private jets.
The bank also provides myriad other services. For instance, Morgan has worked with William Zabel, a trusts and estates lawyer at Shulte Roth & Zabel, to create charitable lead trusts. These allow clients to leave "a huge amount of assets to children without triggering a gift or estate tax," Mr. Zabel said.
AT the same time, Morgan is ready to offer traditional advice about asset allocations. Here, even before the World Trade Center disaster, Ms. Lagomasino had been pushing clients to take a more conservative stance in United States equities by shifting from small caps to blue-chips. Afterward, she pushed even harder. "Our clients are very successful people, and they want to be sure that they feel smart and feel they are in control," Ms. Lagomasino said. "We had conversations with clients who wanted to do things to protect themselves."
Clients with a lot of their wealth in cash were cautioned against rushing back into the equity markets. Other clients who had large positions in a single stock and had borrowed against them were advised to protect themselves.
"Several clients who had loans that were collateralized by stock put collars on the stock they had so they could protect themselves against margin calls," said Cornelia Spring, Morgan's product manager for derivatives. A collar involves a set of transactions that lets a stockholder protect the value of his stock, so that even if it declines, he or she does not face margin calls. After the World Trade Center catastrophe, clients "put on collars in spades," she said.
Thomas H. Lee, who heads the leveraged-buyout fund that bears his name and is a J.P. Morgan Chase national advisory board, said he believed that after the stock market rout of 1987 and the market turmoil caused by the collapse of the Long-Term Capital Management hedge fund in 1998, rich people became more cautious about equities and diversified into alternative investments like hedge funds.
"Those were really shots across a lot of people's bows," he said. "I think people are more diversified."
Even so, Ms. Lagomasino is still cautioning her clients to diversify and warning them that the rapid growth of the 1990's is over. But the most important message has been about when to act and when to wait. "We wanted them to understand how this would affect every piece of what they did," she said.

HEADLINE: After the Shock: Is This the Bottom? 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
THE hijackers brought down the World Trade Center and traumatized a nation. But it is not as clear that the economic damage they wrought will be long lasting.
 The immediate economic impact was devastating. Consumers seemed to go on strike. Retail sales plunged; so did auto sales. The airlines shut down for days, then opened with so little business that Congress quickly approved a bailout. 
 But the picture has brightened a bit. The industries most sensitive to lower interest rates -- cars and housing -- have bounced back more than people expected. 
"There was an initial shock impact," said Henry Kaufman, the economist and money manager. "The shock impact is moderating, but how much is not clear."
Nearly all economists think the economy is contracting now, and most think the contraction will last long enough to go down in the books as the first recession since 1990-1991, thus ending the longest period of expansion in American history.
Retailers' statistics show business is up from the immediate aftermath, when Americans were glued to television sets, but is still below normal. At Home Depot, said Robert L. Nardelli, the president and chief executive, sales began to pick up the weekend after the attack. "Based on a depressed economy, we're back to normal," he said.
In other times, a depressed economy would deeply alarm investors. But the stock market rebounded enough to erase most of the plunge that occurred in the week after trading resumed on Sept. 17. That reaction may, however, only show that everything is relative: Parents might view a report card filled with C's and D's as good news if they had expected the child to flunk out of school.
It is not the same as making the dean's list, of course, and the continuing surge of layoff announcements makes it clear that many companies are deeply worried about their businesses. Indicators like weekly steel production, which reflect the pace of the industrial economy, show no signs of improvement.
The tourism industry suffered immediately. Just before the attack, the number of passengers carried by 11 top airlines was running about 1.2 percent above year-earlier levels, said David Swierenga, chief economist of the Air Transport Association, a trade group.
For a few days after planes resumed flying, the volume of passengers was down by more than 50 percent from the levels of last fall, but that has improved until the comparable figure was off just 29 percent on Thursday, the latest data available.
THAT decline is not being caused just by skittish consumers worried about terrorism. Businesses, responding to the slow economy, were also cutting back even before the attack, and have cut back more since.
In the spring, the Cintas Corporation, a Cincinnati-based maker of corporate uniforms, told its executives to drive rather than fly if the trip was fewer than 200 miles. After the attack, said Robert J. Kohlhepp, the chief executive, that limit was raised to 300 miles.
For the airlines, a 30 percent fall in traffic would be bad enough; the revenue implications are worse. Fares were already lower than in the previous year, and now carriers are cutting them aggressively.
Even before Sept. 11, the American economy was probably in recession. The September employment report, released on Friday, showed a loss of 199,000 jobs during the month, the largest decline in more than a decade. Almost none of that reflects activity after the attack, and there has been a surge of layoff announcements since then.
"We now have a more dramatic pace of firing, and that is what is going to weigh on consumer spending," said Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company. "It is not a loss of nerve. It is lost paychecks."
EVEN Warren E. Buffett, the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway and a man not usually given to fear-mongering, sees no easy way out of the current economic problems. "I'm sure we are in a recession, probably a relatively deep and extended one," he said in a memo to employees of his company a week ago.
This recession was shaping up as a very unusual one in any case. In the usual American recession, rising interest rates brought on as the Federal Reserve tightens monetary policy cause consumers to cut back spending, and the housing and auto industries are the most drastically affected. Only after that impact is felt does industrial production begin to slide.
But this downturn was looking like a backward one even before the attack. September will go down as the 12th consecutive month of declining industrial production, tying a record set just after World War II, when the economy was winding down from war production.
The slowdown had been preceded by an incredible boom in corporate investment, largely in the technology and telecommunications industries. That boom had both contributed to and been enhanced by the stock market bubble, which sent stocks of such companies to dizzying heights and gave them all the money they could use for investment. But the bubble burst in the spring of 2000, leading to the slowdown in investment.
Some economists had thought they saw signs that the industrial part of the economy was no longer getting worse. "In the nontech sector, there were signs of a bottom," said Ian Shepardson, chief United States economist for High Frequency Economics, a research firm.
Postwar recessions have lasted from 6 to 16 months. They usually end after substantial Fed interest rate cuts, which make cars and houses more affordable and unleash pent-up demand, creating a surge of growth.
This recession, however, has yet to see the housing market plunge, and nonresidential construction had held up surprisingly well until it began to soften this summer. The automobile industry has been hurt, but it has done far better than its executives expected. The Fed's aggressive easing has helped those industries, though it has also made it less likely that they will be able to lead the economy out of the recession, simply because there is less scope for rapid growth in demand. And no one thinks that the pace of investment spending in technology will soon recover to its previous pace.
Just what the engine of growth will be is not clear. The longest postwar recession, which lasted 16 months, occurred in from 1973-1975. That was also the last time the major world economies -- those of the United States, Western Europe and Japan -- were in recession at the same time, as they may soon be if the current slowdown in Europe continues to worsen.
Then, the first oil shock had devastated all developed economies. Now the reasons are more varied, but the result could be the same. With no major economy in a position to lead, it could take a while for the economic stimulus efforts to have an impact.
The bear market that accompanied the 1973-1975 turndown was the worst since the Great Depression, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falling 48.2 percent before it bottomed out in October 1974, five months before the recession ended. At its closing low on Sept. 21, the S.& P. 500 had declined 36.8 percent, making it the second-biggest drop since the Depression.
For investors who grew accustomed to big profits during the 1990's, the current investment scene presents difficult choices. An investor who wants absolute safety must settle for returns of less than 3 percent on short-term government securities. But buying stocks seems like a greater risk than it used to.
Mutual fund investors moved out of stock funds during the first two weeks after the attack, but came back in the week ended Wednesday. Clearly, many hope that the recession will be a short one, and that last month's lows will not be breached.
Those who are betting on a mild recession are hoping that the Fed's continued easing of credit and a stimulative fiscal policy will get the economy moving. Washington politicians -- who were trapped in a debate about Social Security lockboxes before the attack -- now are arguing about the best way to put together a stimulus package. Since tax cuts may be saved by the recipient, public spending probably has more recession-fighting firepower.
Perhaps the largest uncertainty is how Americans will respond to the continuing bad news on the economic front -- not to mention to the possibility of further terrorist attacks or to military actions by the United States. Those who are most pessimistic about the next six months assume that consumers will cut back and increase savings, worried that the next round of layoffs might touch them personally.
Every post-World War II recession, except for the most recent one, in 1990-1991, had at least one quarter in which the economy fell by at least 4 percent. The current quarter is the one most likely to be that bad, particularly if the effects of the attack linger. Such a fall might leave the economy ready to rebound, but it might also alarm consumers and delay a recovery.
But perhaps that will not be the case. For the last decade, it has been the optimists who turned out to be right. Already, applications for mortgages to buy homes have rebounded to nearly their pre-Sept. 11 level, even as unemployment rolls have hit levels not seen since 1991.
That deep optimism among Americans helped keep the economy growing even as industrial production plunged over the last year, and may have contributed to the rebound in sales seen in the last couple of weeks. It won't keep corporate profits in many industries from being devastated, and it won't keep overextended companies from being forced into bankruptcy. But it might make this recession milder and shorter than it otherwise would have been.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Fuzzy Math Returns

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN

 BODY:
Post-terror nerves aside, what mainly ails the U.S. economy is too much of a good thing. During the bubble years businesses overspent on capital equipment; the resulting overhang of excess capacity is a drag on investment, and hence a drag on the economy as a whole.
 In time this overhang will be worked off. Meanwhile, economic policy should encourage other spending to offset the temporary slump in business investment. Low interest rates, which promote spending on housing and other durable goods, are the main answer. But it seems inevitable that there will also be a fiscal stimulus package. 
 That package should include only measures that really will promote spending now, when the economy needs it. It shouldn't include anything that worsens the long-run budget position more than is necessary, or anything that looks like "hitchhiking," exploiting the short-run difficulties of the economy to pursue unrelated long-run goals.
Unfortunately, the Bush administration has just taken a big step away from those principles.
Until late last week it looked as if much of any stimulus package would consist of increased government spending to rebuild New York, to pay for military operations and to provide unemployment benefits. This would put money into the economy in a clearly temporary way.
Giving money to lower-income families would also be sensible. The problem with temporary tax breaks is that you can't be sure people will spend them; in fact, the much-vaunted rebate seems to have gone mainly into the bank rather than the economy. The chances are better if the money goes to poorer people, whose spending is often constrained by simple lack of cash.
But the big-ticket items in the stimulus proposal sketched out by administration officials on Thursday, and reaffirmed by George W. Bush after a meeting with Congressional hard-liners, are thoroughly wrongheaded -- and they suggest that bipartisanship is over, that we're back to the cynical budget politics of the past.
One key proposal is a permanent new tax break for business investment. This violates the basic principle that stimulus proposals should be only short-term. Furthermore, it would probably have only a modest effect on business investment now, when there is excess capacity; but it would increase long-term interest rates, by increasing both future deficits and future business borrowing. And since long-term interest rates are what matter for housing, on balance this measure might well delay recovery instead of promoting it.
Another key administration proposal is an acceleration of tax cuts for higher income brackets that under current law are not scheduled to happen for several years. On the face of it this idea seems bizarre: it gives money to precisely the people who are least likely to spend it. Is this just a case of knee-jerk conservatism, of the belief that tax cuts for the affluent are the answer to all problems?
Alas, no: it's worse than that. The real reason to accelerate the Bush tax cut is surely to forestall the growing likelihood that part of that tax cut will eventually be rescinded.
Over the last couple of months the long-run budget outlook has darkened dramatically; we've gone from arguments about whether the Social Security surplus would be raided to the prospect of deficits plain and simple as far as the eye can see. A natural response, once the slowdown is over, would be to cancel some or all of the tax cuts, mainly for upper brackets, that are scheduled to happen in 2004 and beyond. As a political matter, that will be much harder to do if the cuts have already gone into effect. 
And that, surely, is why the administration wants to accelerate the tax cut. It's being billed as a short-run stimulus proposal, but it's really a case of covert hitchhiking. 
To add to the insult, a preliminary analysis of the numbers suggests that fuzzy math is back: the administration appears to be greatly understating the true budget cost of its proposals and pretending that a package that consists overwhelmingly of tax cuts is evenly split between tax cuts and spending. 
As far as one can tell, the ultimate shape of the fiscal stimulus package is still fluid. The package that eventually emerges could be genuinely designed to help the economy, or it could be mainly a vehicle for political opportunism. Sadly, the latter possibility has just become much more likely.

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
A Rally Spurred by Technology Buying

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY

 BODY:
As the horrific memories of Sept. 11 dimmed slightly, technology stocks dominated the market last week, snapped up by investors who decided to take a chance on the sector, which had long been battered. Their buying on Wednesday strengthened the Nasdaq market by nearly 6 percent, its biggest one-day gain in more than five months. 
 Despite earnings warnings from several companies, including MGM Mirage, Jack in the Box and Sun Microsystems, the market was upbeat for most of the week. 
 Investor sentiment was helped, in part, by earnings affirmations from the technology bellwethers Dell Computer and Cisco Systems and by the Federal Reserve, which on Tuesday cut its benchmark interest rate to 2.5 percent, its lowest level since the Kennedy administration. On Wednesday, President Bush proposed $75 billion in government spending and tax breaks to help revive the sluggish economy.
 For the week, the Dow Jones industrials rose 272.21 points, or 3.1 percent, to 9,119.77. The Nasdaq composite index gained 106.50 points, or 7.1 percent, to 1,498.80. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 30.44 points, or 2.9 percent, to 1,071.38. SHERRI DAY

HEADLINE: The Right Stimulus For the Economy 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 We agree with Robert E. Rubin (Op-Ed, Sept. 30) that the Sept. 11 attacks increase the likelihood of a more prolonged economic downturn, but his reluctance to embrace corporate tax cuts as part of an economic stimulus package is unwise. 
 Mr. 
Rubin overstates the cost of reducing the corporate tax rate. A cut of five percentage points would cost about $19 billion a year -- reducing federal receipts by less than 1 percent annually -- a very modest item in a $2 trillion federal budget.
A stimulus package must be highly visible and broad-based if it is to boost both consumer and business confidence. Cutting the corporate tax rate, accelerating individual rate reductions already enacted and repealing the alternative minimum tax will achieve that without undue impact on the budget. But moving quickly is more important than our specific proposals.

JERRY JASINOWSKI
President, National
Association of Manufacturers
Washington, Oct. 2, 2001

HEADLINE: INVESTING: DIARY; 
New York City May Issue More Notes, Mayor Says

BYLINE:  Compiled by Jeff Sommer

 BODY:
The $1 billion in one-year notes that New York City sold last week to help finance recovery from the attack on the World Trade Center may be just the beginning.
 Individual investors bought more than one-third -- or $387 million -- of the securities, roughly double the normal proportion, said city officials and bond traders, who attributed the interest to popular desire to help the city rebuild. 
Issued by the New York City Transitional Finance Authority, the notes were oversubscribed within two hours. 
 People were eager to "make a statement that they support New York," Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said.
"We were oversubscribed by four times," he said. "That means we had $4 billion offered for $1 billion worth of bonds, so we should go out and get the other $3 billion."
For New York residents, the securities were exempt from city, state and federal tax. Yields were 2.13 percent. By contrast, taxable one-year Treasuries were yielding 2.43 percent on Tuesday, when Bear Stearns the managing underwriter of the municipal notes, priced them.
Proceeds will pay for expenses related to the attack, like unemployment insurance premiums, overtime, contractors' charges for removing debris and costs of housing and feeding rescue workers.

HEADLINE: Public Investment, Reborn 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 In "Priorities in the Wake of a Shattered Taboo" (Economic View, Sept. 23) Louis Uchitelle observed that the events of Sept. 11 would almost certainly shatter a nearly quarter-century of de-emphasis of government spending. 
 I agree with him that child care would be one good beneficiary of increased public spending, but I would also propose a national rail system. 
If recent events did not do enough to highlight the airlines' vulnerability, the necessity of increased security will certainly put a significant drag on any rebound they have. 
If we created a national system of tracks and licensed private companies to operate on it (with government operating or subsidizing less profitable runs), our transportation situation would be vastly improved. Other countries have high-speed passenger trains; why can't we? 
The railroads were once an engine of American economic growth. In an era when we must deal with declining oil supplies, global warming and issues of national security, there is no reason that railroads can't assume that role again. 

JIM WALTERS
Iowa City, Iowa, Sept. 24

HEADLINE: Public Investment, Reborn 

 BODY:
To the Editor: 
 The United States now needs public investment more than tax cuts, and not only because of the new spending required for security. Yes, we also need improvements in education (including early childhood education and child care), health care, surface transportation and technology for state and local governments. We also need to extend unemployment pay. Such investment can stimulate the economy at least as well as tax cuts -- and result in greater fairness and a stronger future.

WILLIAM B. SHORE
Tarrytown, N.Y., Sept. 24
