HEADLINE: Ideal Farms vs. Industrial Farms 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER

 BODY:
No matter what their stand in the muddled debate last week over billions of dollars in subsidies to America's largest farmers, all sides promoted the family farmer, a position rooted in the Jeffersonian ideal that "those who labor in the earth are the chosen people of God."
 But Jefferson's yeoman farmer was a straw man: the real issues were 21st-century questions of corporate interests, the environment, global trade and budget constraints. 
 The traditionalists in the House who want to save commodity subsidies won the first round on Thursday in what is becoming a rare public battle to reshape farm policy, normally left to the agriculture committees. They beat back an effort to redirect billions of dollars in farm aid into environmental programs and won passage of their version of the farm bill, 291 to 120. 
Instead of trimming subsidies, as the Bush administration had hoped, the House bill increases them.
Now the $171 billion, 10-year farm measure faces review by Senate leaders and the administration officials who have said they are determined to transform 21st-century farming policy. Their goal, they say, is to puncture myths about rural America and bring farm policy in line with international trade agreements and modern agricultural economics, which they say will help all the farmers left behind. 
House members who want to preserve the current system of underwriting production of certain commodities leaned on the romance of the farmer in debate last week. 
Congress was reminded of dairy farmers rising at dawn to make sure city mothers have fresh milk for their children. Grain farmers were praised for providing Americans with the safest and least expensive food in the world. 
Yet the vast majority of farmers, the men and women who fit the Jeffersonian image, are ineligible for the big commodity subsidies. 
Representative Marion Berry, a Democrat from Arkansas who receives hundreds of thousands of dollars in farm subsidies, said he would hate to see the United States as dependent on foreign food as it is on foreign oil in time of war.
For most agricultural economists, these arguments are as dated as Walker Evans's photographs of sharecroppers in the Depression.
"Our problem is surplus food, not scarcity," said Prof. Bruce Gardner of the University of Maryland. "Commodity prices are so low that we wouldn't see surplus without subsidies, but there is always a question of how much of a safety net do we need. It's really high now and this House bill makes it even higher." 
Unlike in previous debates, urban lawmakers asked why $171 billion was being set aside for farmers in a program that favors the largest farmers, who never have to prove they need the money.
"Are farmers more noble than plumbers, or the welfare mother who has to go back to work and isn't qualified for a dime?" asked Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts. "This is a debate about corporate welfare for farmers that is finally boiling over."
The Bush administration addressed the issue last month in a 120-page farm policy meant to coax Congress away from these commodity payments and toward programs that favor global trade, the environment and all of rural America, not just the larger farmers. 
Administration officials also claimed the mantle of Jefferson.
Secretary of Agriculture Ann M. Veneman went on Agrinet, the farm radio network, last week to promote the Bush plan -- and criticize the House farm bill -- using appeals to the little farmer and rural values.
"We believe a farm bill needs to help all of rural America, not just the few farmers who receive commodity payments," she said. 
Instead of those huge payments, she said, large farmers must find profits in the global marketplace, and learn to respect trade agreements. 
In farm policy, at least, the World Trade Organization is proving to be the strongest bond between free-traders and the environmental movement. The commodity payments in the House bill could break the trade limits, while conservation programs not only keep more farmers on the land, they comply with international trade agreements.
Because farmers and ranchers own half the land in the continental United States, countless environmental groups are sounding Jeffersonian as well, championing these smaller farmers in the belief that they will determine the fate of countless species of wildlife, of open spaces and of clean air and water.

HEADLINE: Legal Residency Hopes of Millions Dashed 

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6 

 BODY:
In the summer, a bolt of hope shot through this city as the Bush administration edged toward granting legal residency to millions of illegal immigrants from Mexico and perhaps other countries.
 When the movement seemed to slow, President Vicente Fox of Mexico, in talks at the White House, sought to rebuild momentum for the proposal that would give individuals and families the prospect of moving out of the shadows and into mainstream working-class life. 
 But that momentum has died. Not only has the plan been abandoned since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, but the White House and Congress are moving rapidly toward making the immigration laws even tighter, out of fear of terrorist attacks. 
Maria Blanco, national senior counsel for the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, said the crisis had sent a chill through both legal and illegal Hispanic immigrants because the message coming from Washington now is that the greatest threats to the country may be coming from foreigners.
"People are very disappointed that, so soon after the debate seemed to be moving forward on immigration, it has taken a few steps backwards," Ms. Blanco said. "Latinos don't want to be tainted by this broad brush."
What is particularly disappointing to some advocates for undocumented immigrants, they say, is that few groups have demonstrated more support for the United States during the crisis, often donating time and money at churches and organizations.
"Yes, people want to stay out of the way more and lie low now," said Mario Matute, the executive director of the Pacoima Workforce Initiative, a job training program in a San Fernando Valley neighborhood known as a gateway for illegal immigrants. "But you know what's interesting is that they talk more about being concerned about the attacks and the pain they feel for the victims. They're responding like other Americans, even if they may have more problems now."
For the immigrants, the sudden shift has pushed them back into lives that are an often clumsy balance of dreams and dreams denied, of an eagerness to join in and the pressures that keep them on the fringes.
In recent interviews in the Los Angeles area, a number of immigrants who have lived illegally in the country for years described how they have to navigate between an open society and the underground economy.
The lives they described are surprisingly close to the mainstream but that leave many basics, like health insurance or a bank account, out of their reach. They improvise, realizing that even the things they do have could be lost in a moment of carelessness, or bad luck. All the immigrants spoke on condition that their full names not be used.
Maria, a 17-year-old high school student who is an illegal immigrant from Mexico, spoke in an emotional interview of all the things she says she is forced to remain silent about when she talks with her friends: why she cannot get her driver's license, or go on a class trip to Acapulco, or attend her dream college, the University of California at Santa Barbara, despite her excellent grades.
Maria's life is one of concealment and anxiety as about whether she will end up working in garment factories like her parents or realize her dream of earning a degree in psychology and achieve her ultimate goal, running for office.
Rocio came to Los Angeles from Mexico 10 years ago, crossing the border in the trunk of a smuggler's car. After working in garment sweat shops, she discovered her talent, sales. She said she now works in telemarketing, selling cosmetics, jewelry and clothing by telephone.
But her dreams are hampered by her illegal status. She could not open a bank account or sign up for utilities at her rented home -- or sign a lease -- without a Social Security card. So, she said, she paid several hundred dollars for a bogus Social Security card, which she bought at MacArthur Park near downtown, where there is an open market in the phony numbers. But every time she uses it, she said, she worries that she will be caught.
She and her husband are still trying to create a normal family. Her daughter is now in the third grade and attends a public elementary school, where she is eligible for free meals. But the family has no health insurance, and even minor illnesses are a constant worry.
Rodolfo, 36, moved here three years ago from Mexico and lives with his mother, who is a legal resident. He said he gets many of his jobs standing on street corners and frequently works at construction sites. One of his greatest concerns is that if his boss decides not to pay him at the end of the day, which he said had happened several times, he has no recourse.
"All I want is to get what I'm owed," Rodolfo said, sitting next to the giant television and the new stereo in his mother's handsome rented apartment here.
Maria has ridden an emotional roller coaster many times. Recently, California instituted a program under which all students who graduate in the top 4 percent of their high school classes are guaranteed entry to state colleges. Maria said her expectations soared, until she realized that she was ineligible for financial aid and inexpensive in-state tuition rates.
"So now, when my friends talk about college, I get kind of silent and just listen to them," she said. "I take A.P. classes like the rest of them," she said, referring to the more difficult advanced placement courses some students take. "I get good grades like them. They'll go to their dream schools. I know I can't."
Carlos came here from Peru. He was a member of the city council of his medium-sized town, he said, and he had a grocery wholesale business. He came here a year ago to live with a sister, who has legal status, after the Peruvian economy sank and his businesses crumbled.
Since arriving and overstaying his tourist visa, he said, he has taken some odd jobs, including work as a security guard. But his real love, he said, is telemarketing, and he is setting up his own business. He found a bank that allowed him to open an account. He talked his way into getting a driver's license, and he bought a car with cash, though he has no insurance.
Another one of his sisters, Haydee, came here illegally three years ago. Though she said she had a university degree from Peru in social work she works in a hospital kitchen but fewer hours than she would like. She said she had lost one car after being pulled over by the police. She had no license and the car was impounded. She did not dare try to get it back.
"I gave up some things leaving Peru, and you have to give up things here, too," Haydee said. "I worry about what I may have to give up next if something happens. That's what you think about. What you want to work for but what you could lose any time."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Haydee, who came to the United States illegally three years ago, says she earned a university degree in her native Peru but now works in the kitchen of a Los Angeles hospital. A brother is also in this country illegally. (Monica Almeida/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Unemployed Struggle to Make Do in Difficult Economic Times; 
Computer Expert Turns to Odd Jobs To Help Pay Bills

BYLINE:  By PAM BELLUCK

DATELINE: GREENFIELD, N.H., Oct. 3 

 BODY:
 If the United States was teetering on the edge of recession before Sept. 11, the terrorist attacks were a decisive shove over the edge. The number of workers filing for first-time state unemployment benefits has soared to a nine-year high. "This is just the initial wave of layoffs due to the attacks," Steven Wood, an economist, said. "There's another wave behind it." 
 Workers have confronted the same difficult task: absorbing the shock of unemployment and figuring out what to do next.
The last year or so has been full of watersheds for Dario Carrara. He married. He bought a rustic house in this out-of-the-way town down a dirt road shaded by poplar and pine. And, six months ago, he lost his job.
A computer engineer who specializes in telephone networking, Mr. Carrara, 35, fell victim to the general softening of the economy and, more specifically, the tanking of the technology industry. His employer, Tellabs, a maker of communications equipment, canceled the product line Mr. Carrara was working on when it cut 6 percent of its work force, or about 550 people, in April.
The job prospects were not great for Mr. Carrara before Sept. 11. He had had no luck with a handful of interviews over the summer. But the terror attacks have made things even harder, he said, so much so that he has pretty much given up hope of finding a job in his field soon.
"Things were getting worse with the economy, and now this," said Mr. Carrara, sitting on the red stone patio he built with his newfound free time. "We're just now starting to see the ripple effect, first with the airlines. It doesn't take much and companies go from wanting to hire to not wanting to hire."
Three headhunters have been working on his behalf, but since Sept. 11, his telephone has been decidedly silent.
"The way you judge a headhunter's attitude about your prospects is how often they call you," Mr. Carrara said. "They've just been calling me less and less, and now I call them."
Over the last few months, Mr. Carrara, who did construction work in college, has done odd jobs for relatives and friends: helping an uncle put in storm windows, splitting wood and rototilling the lawn for a neighbor. He works Sundays at a garden shop in nearby Peterboro.
He has busied himself with home projects, building a stone wall around the front flower beds and rebuilding a good part of the house's back porch. He has taken to making wreaths from soft green princess pine fronds, and is hoping the garden store will sell a few of them at Christmastime.
Mr. Carrara is helped by the fact that his expenses are low. He and his wife, Melissa, 40, rent out part of their home to a tenant, and share the rest only with a pale yellow cockatiel named Harley, who camps out on a perch in the kitchen, near a wood-burning stove the Carraras call on for heat during the frequent winter power disruptions in this remote neck of the woods. Their mortgage, about $650 a month, health insurance and land taxes are their primary expenses.
Ms. Carrara, a former schoolteacher, now makes about $20,000 a year selling women's clothes at a store in Peterboro.
Still for a man used to earning more than $80,000 a year, being jobless has been tough.
"I've been a little depressed," he said. "My wife has noticed, she has told me, I'm more irritable. You start to second-guess yourself." Among other things, Mr. Carrara feels whiplashed by the free fall his industry seems to have taken. Other people he knows in the field have resigned themselves to being out of work for a while.
Mr. Carrara's job search is further hampered by his desire to commute no more than 75 minutes each way from his house, which is about 90 minutes northwest of Boston. Bordering on the lush 600-acre Greenfield State Park, it is so serene that except for the large American flag draped on his house, it seems one of the few places where there is virtually no hint of the devastating terrorist attacks.
Mr. Carrara said he was planning to wait another couple of weeks, but if nothing turned up in his field, he would have no choice but to look for other employment, maybe working for a friend's company, measuring fences.
"The weather's going to get cold and the days are going to get short and I'm going to get some sort of full-time job just to bring in money," he said. "I'm really one of those people that needs to do something productive."

GRAPHIC: Photo: LOW-TECH BACKUP -- Besides doing odd jobs, Dario Carrara, 35, an unemployed computer engineer, makes wreaths from pine fronds and hopes to sell a few at Christmastime. (C. J. Gunther for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Unemployed Struggle to Make Do in Difficult Economic Times; 
A Time for Reflection and Perfecting the Chicken Fricassee

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 5 

 BODY:
 If the United States was teetering on the edge of recession before Sept. 11, the terrorist attacks were a decisive shove over the edge. The number of workers filing for first-time state unemployment benefits has soared to a nine-year high. "This is just the initial wave of layoffs due to the attacks," Steven Wood, an economist, said. "There's another wave behind it." 
 Workers have confronted the same difficult task: absorbing the shock of unemployment and figuring out what to do next.
As a managing director at Charles Schwab, the company synonymous with do-it-yourself online trading, Norman Rosenblatt worked in the trenches of the California boom economy. He joined the company -- was it only last year? -- in a hiring blitz reflective of the crazed optimism that infused San Francisco. It seems almost quaint now, he says.
"The word of the day was don't let the system go down, don't let anything stand in the way of a customer and a trade," said Mr. Rosenblatt, 56, who lost his job in the technology services division Sept. 25, one of 1,600 to 1,900 employees to be laid off in the second round of major cuts that, combined with attrition, will reduce Schwab's work force by 25 percent by the end of the year.
Mr. Rosenblatt, who grew up in Mount Vernon, N.Y., and lives in Oakland, was laid off the day before the Jewish holiday Yom Kippur. "That was the day I was theoretically supposed to be reflecting on my life," he observed, with deadpan humor.
The latest layoffs were announced more than a month ago, the result of the stock market downturn and the steep drop in trading. But it was not until last week that employees found out who would be cut. The mood was edgy. Mr. Rosenblatt, the father of three girls, had a gut feeling that his job, which involved tracking proprietary technology projects within the company, was vulnerable. "It was a background task, never part of the limelight," he said. "I kept thinking like Groucho Marx: If I were them, would I keep me?"
He says he has never defined himself solely by his job. He remains a bit of a "60's person," unenamored of corporate America until he joined Schwab, a company he still considers humane, he says. He worked for 3 years at Bank of America and then for 13 as an independent contractor. He went to college and business school at New York University and has always gravitated toward statistics and computer programming.
His first foray into the work world was in the garment district of Manhattan with his late father, Jacob, an accountant, "sitting on piles of zippers with a ledger book on my knee."
The company has given him a generous severance deal -- he would not give details -- which has staved off "utter panic," he said. After working 35 years and never taking time out, part of him welcomes the opportunity to reassess his priorities. He is permitting himself a couple of weeks of "heavy introspection." But there are realities to consider, most notably his wife, Lorraine, who has multiple sclerosis and whose treatment was largely covered under the corporate health plan.
He has been thinking about past roads not taken. He mulled over a longtime fantasy of becoming a chef -- briefly. "You have to chop carrots for years," he said. "By the time I got to sauces I'd probably be ready to retire."
He has used his enforced vacation to perfect his mother's chicken fricassee recipe. He is considering going back to the technical side of computers, which is "more sanity provoking" than being a manager. "I'd like to have a product I can point to, to recapture the tangible," he said.
He said he had no illusions about what lay ahead. "I'm not optimistic," he said. "It isn't pretty out there."
As a native New Yorker, he said, it has been difficult for him to separate the gloom of the terrorist attacks from the dread and unease of his job loss. "I don't want to call myself a victim, because we're all victims," he said.
He would consider "repatriating" to New York. He has a deep sense of forboding about the economy, predicting that the upheaval at Schwab, combined with the dotcom bust, will prompt a major exodus from the Bay Area. "It's hard to consider myself Tom Joad," he said. "But maybe I am."

GRAPHIC: Photo: AVOIDING PANIC -- A generous severance deal eased the pain of Norman Rosenblatt's layoff as a managing director at Charles Schwab. (Thor Swift for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Unemployed Struggle to Make Do in Difficult Economic Times; 
Necessities Suddenly Become Luxuries

BYLINE:  By DANA CANEDY

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Oct. 5 

 BODY:
 If the United States was teetering on the edge of recession before Sept. 11, the terrorist attacks were a decisive shove over the edge. The number of workers filing for first-time state unemployment benefits has soared to a nine-year high. "This is just the initial wave of layoffs due to the attacks," Steven Wood, an economist, said. "There's another wave behind it." 
 Workers have confronted the same difficult task: absorbing the shock of unemployment and figuring out what to do next.
Exactly two weeks after the terrorist attacks, Renaissance Cruises went out of business and Deirdre Phillips found herself out of work. She immediately went into survival mode.
A single mother who had worked in the accounts receivable department of Renaissance Cruises, which is based in this tourist city, Ms. Phillips had to decide what bills she could delay paying. Things she had considered necessities just weeks ago suddenly became luxuries that had to go.
"I used to go to the supermarket every two weeks," said Ms. Phillips who is 41 and lives with her two sons, ages 11 and 17. "I didn't go to the supermarket this time. We're trying to stretch things."
She immediately began looking for a new job, but with every day that she returned home without one, she wondered when things will start running out.
"I waste gas going around filling out job applications and I just wonder what will happen when this tank runs out," she said. "I used to have my hair done, pedicure and manicure every two weeks. I've had to cancel that. I usually rent movies on Fridays. I haven't been able to do that."
"I usually order pizza on Fridays," Ms. Phillips added. "Not anymore. I've been in the kitchen cooking lately and trying to cook enough that it will last. I cooked yesterday and you bet that's the same thing we'll be eating today." She made beef steak with gravy and onions served over white rice.
Now, though, maybe Ms. Phillips can afford a few more pizzas. Late this evening Renaissance Cruises called her back to work temporarily to help close its books.
A high school graduate, Ms. Phillips has worked for Renaissance Cruises for five and half years. When she lost her job she was making $12.75 an hour.
Until this evening, Ms. Phillips had mentally prepared to get by on about $1,000 a month in unemployment checks, which is about $400 less than her take-home pay. She also receives $500 a month in child support from the father of one of her sons, and expects to receive about $3,000 from a 401(k) account after paying penalties for withdrawing the money early.
Suddenly, though, there were new decision to make. Should she leave the money in the 401(k), and could she afford to turn down temporary work to stay the course on her search for a permanent job?
With expenses that include $675 in rent and a $342 car payment that she is behind on, Ms. Phillips decided to go back to Renaissance until the work runs out. "This way I'll still be making my full pay," she reasoned. "I can hold on a little longer, but who knows what could happen tomorrow."
Renaissance Cruises, after all, shook her sense of security earlier this month, saying it would cease operating because of an unexpected drop in business after the terrorist attacks. 
Now, Ms. Phillips said, the call from her old boss will provide an unexpected break that she realizes other people who are out of work will not likely receive. She is angry about the disruption of so many lives and livelihoods.
A Bronx native, Ms. Phillips realizes that her hardship does not compare with the losses that others have endured. "At least I'm still here," she said. "It may be rough right now but I still have my life."

HEADLINE: Unemployed Struggle to Make Do in Difficult Economic Times; 
Grounded on High-Flying Dream Job

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN

DATELINE: EAST BETHEL, Minn., Oct. 2 

 BODY:
 If the United States was teetering on the edge of recession before Sept. 11, the terrorist attacks were a decisive shove over the edge. The number of workers filing for first-time state unemployment benefits has soared to a nine-year high. "This is just the initial wave of layoffs due to the attacks," Steven Wood, an economist, said. "There's another wave behind it." 
 Workers have confronted the same difficult task: absorbing the shock of unemployment and figuring out what to do next.
The brass and glass lampshade got a round blue sticker: sell. The good Christmas ornaments got orange: keep. Patio furniture, from back when she had a deck: blue. Same for the dried flowers from her long-ago garden, the door wreaths, the end tables, two televisions, a wooden birdhouse. But when Penny Bloomquist picked up the off-white vase with the pink ceramic flowers sticking out, her hazel eyes began to spill tears again.
"This can't go," said Ms. Bloomquist, 41, who was just laid off from her dream job as a flight attendant for Northwest Airlines. "I know it's kind of gaudy, but it's a vase that my grandma had. She was the flower nut, like me."
The garage sale Ms. Bloomquist is planning for next weekend in this small town an hour north of Minneapolis is just another droplet in the ripple effect from the Sept. 11 attacks. In March, she leased out her five-bedroom house and put a life's worth of stuff in storage so she could attend Northwest's six-week training program. Now she can no longer afford the $95-a-month rent on bin 430 at Storage World off Highway 65.
"It's not even the right time of the year to have a garage sale," she said, sighing as she sorted. 
Northwest expects to cut 10,000 jobs, nearly half of them at its Minneapolis hub. About 2,400 flight attendants with at least six years of experience accepted voluntary furloughs; for 312 it was involuntary. Ms. Bloomquist's seniority number, 11,370, was below the cutoff.
Today, she sat at the dining room table in the home of a friend where she is renting a room for $250 a month, sifting through an application for unemployment benefits; financial aid forms for her 19-year-old son, who hopes to attend school in Houston to learn about race cars; and the photographs of her two boys and her boyfriend that she carried on every flight.
She hopes a small airline, like Minneapolis-based Sun Country, might have jobs, or that Northwest will rehire. Maybe, she said, after 10 years of being divorced and 7 dating another man, it is time to marry again. For now, she is focused on the garage sale -- one step at a time.
"I've had a lot of tears because I'm feeling sorry for myself," said Ms. Bloomquist, whose gross August pay was $2,109.58. "Then I feel bad for feeling bad because other people have it so much worse."
After quitting high school and getting her G.E.D., Ms. Bloomquist met and married an older man, and had children. She worked as a medical assistant, tended bar, did nails and sold flowers. But since age 14 she had admired her mother's friend Carla, a flight attendant for the old Braniff Air.
So last spring, she sent her younger son, Jacob, now 15, to live with his aunt, gave away her beloved cat, Sam, and enrolled in Northwest's six-day-a-week training program. Once she got her wings, she flew for five months, to Jackson, Miss., Sioux Falls, S.D., Bismarck, N.D., and Anchorage and Nashville and Memphis.
"The last couple months, I had to almost pinch myself because I was so happy," she said. "I feel like a bird when I'm in the air."
As she left the storage locker this afternoon, Ms. Bloomquist popped Martina McBride into the CD player in her white Grand Am, to play the song that had motivated her through flight attendant school.
With a broken wing, she still sings,
She keeps an eye on the sky.
With a broken wing, she carries her dreams,
You ought to see her fly.
"I still have my dreams," Ms. Bloomquist said. "My dream is just to be back in a safer world, maybe."

HEADLINE: More Bad Economic News For Faltering Caribbean 

BYLINE:  By DAVID GONZALEZ

DATELINE: NASSAU, the Bahamas, Oct. 5 

 BODY:
The suicide attacks that reduced the World Trade Center and part of the Pentagon to rubble have also shaken economies throughout the Caribbean, with island after island facing drastic reductions in American tourists and their dollars. 
 Arrivals at most hotels and resorts in the region are about half of what they should be, a slight rebound from the days after the attack when nervous travelers canceled as much as 80 percent of bookings for September and October. 
 Already injured by the sluggish United States economy, owners had to confront cancellations and reduced airline flights, forcing them to lay off staff and close some restaurants and attractions, or halve the workweek and paychecks. 
Government ministers have met almost daily since Sept. 11 to consider requests from business owners for a moratorium on duties, payroll taxes and utility surcharges, or help with covering loan payments. 
Caribbean heads of state will convene on Thursday in the Bahamas to coordinate a regional response to the emergency while tourism officials rethink their marketing campaigns. 
Leaders have already begun to warn residents that a sustained military escalation in Afghanistan could deal a devastating economic blow and lead to cutbacks in public spending and perhaps even rationing of basic goods to conserve dwindling foreign exchange reserves.
While future reservations, especially for the critical winter season, have begun to inch upward, the loss of recent business and uncertainty about the future have already taken their toll.
"It has been a very serious situation," said John Bell, the chief executive officer of the Caribbean Hotel Association, whose members account for 110,000 rooms in 35 nations. "If we don't start to see improvements by mid-October, then I'll get pretty scared."
In the Bahamas, where tourism accounts for $1.8 billion, half the nation's income according to government figures, the slowdown is evident in the long lines of idle taxis, near empty casinos and the forlorn faces of the vendors on Bay Street, where thousands of tourists once shopped for everything from diamonds to wooden pipes. Vendors now consider themselves fortunate if they make one or two sales a day.
"The terrorists said they attacked the buildings in the name of oppressed people," said Telator Strachan, the president of the Straw Market Vendors Association, which already had been struggling with its own disaster the week before the attacks when an arsonist destroyed the famous wooden bazaar. "But what they have done is oppress people. They are oppressing us and depressing us."
The government is considering requests from the tourist industry to suspend a 17 percent utilities tax, as well as other measures to allow larger operators to avoid layoffs, which so far have been minimal. 
At Our Lucaya resort on Grand Bahama Island, guests have been consolidated into one of the new resort's three towers, while employees on a reduced workweek take advantage of the lull to paint and clean rooms. One guest, Sean Sullivan, was alone in the workout room as he lifted weights. He said he had no fear of flying, since he was a pilot from Atlanta and knew that airport security was at a record high.
"I feel comfortable," he said. "If I was worried I wouldn't have come. I got the gym all to myself this time. And I got a discount haircut."
In the Dominican Republic, where tourism replaced sugar as the nation's biggest earner in the 1980's, thousands of workers were temporarily furloughed and several hotels in Punta Cana closed down. The smaller operators who have little savings and high debt and expenses were hit the hardest.
"The season was not good before Sept. 11," said Mauricio Bonetti, manager of the Tropic Banana in Las Terenas, who had to lay off 21 of his 27 staff members. "Now it is paralyzed. I have only two rooms occupied out of 27. And I am worried for the high season, which starts in November. Almost all the calls or e-mails I receive are cancellations." 
The smaller islands, like those in the Eastern Caribbean, which may need to rely on outside help from international institutions like the World Bank, are the most vulnerable.
Orsalia Kalantzopoulos, the bank's Caribbean department director, said the bank was already considering emergency steps to spur public works projects. 
"That way they can start with civil works employing people who will be leaving the tourist sector," she said. "The thing you don't want is having people unemployed and out on the streets."
In return, she said, the countries would have to commit themselves to improving airport security to meet United States standards and take steps to reform the banking sector to prevent terrorists from channeling money through ask-no-questions banks.
Most countries stopped all advertising in the United States after the attack. Cut off from a primary source of tourists, they looked for new opportunities, wooing conventions and weekend vacationers from their own countries or refocusing their efforts on drawing tourists from Europe and Canada, where there were few cancellations.
Tourism officials in several islands pumped millions of dollars into new advertising to lure Europeans, who they said would be wary of visiting the Middle East, Turkey or North Africa given the current international tensions. But officials remain cautious. 
"Everything depends on whether people are comfortable getting back on aircraft," said Vernice Walkine, deputy director general of tourism for the Bahamas. "Nobody knows what this war might mean. If there is troop action, there is the potential Europe could shut down, too."
Meanwhile, hotels in the Bahamas have begun to offer discounts, teaming up with American Express for all-inclusive deals that offer savings of more than $500 per person.
Some countries have even begun trying to court American tourists once again, starting with advertisements that express support and solidarity, while trying not to seem opportunistic.
"It is a very difficult decision to make," said Allen Chastanet, Air Jamaica's vice president for marketing and sales. "Some felt we shouldn't have done anything. But the initial message we sent out was not a hard sell; it was a message. 
"At the same time," he added, "President Bush is trying to convince America to get back to some level of normalcy. What the Caribbean has to offer is a remedy for what they've gone through. They need to get away from big crowds and relax a bit."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A lonely beach in the Bahamas. Countries across the Caribbean that depend on tourism, already hurt by the sluggish American economy, have experienced a downturn in tourism since the attacks in the United States. (David Gonzalez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A City Changed Forever? Maybe Not 

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
It has become a widely repeated cliche in New York City in the last few weeks that the future can no longer be predicted because everything has changed. Amid all the losses after last month's terrorist attacks, there is a feeling that the city has lost its compass and its map to the future, too.
 But there is also a deep and substantial body of scholarship about how cities work in times of catastrophe, and how humans make decisions through the tumult of crisis and its aftermath. The inescapable conclusion of that research, the experts say, is that there are patterns to the events that unfold -- a sort of rough guide through the wilderness. 
 Cities, by and large -- with plenty of room for caveats and special circumstances, researchers say -- tend to be stubbornly resilient. The long-term historic momentum of a metropolis, as a collective human creation of ambition and energy, is a force that is far more powerful than the short-term chaos of disaster, however horrific or heartbreaking. 
By that body of evidence, which experts say has largely been validated in disaster-damaged cities as diverse as Miami and Kobe, Japan, there is reason for optimism. 
New York, before the attack, had become a global magnet for immigrants and strivers, and a high-energy playground for millions of tourists who began to arrive as the crime rate fell in the 1990's. Its population, after decades of stagnation or decline, had risen. And it had retained much of its role as a linchpin of global capitalism. Broad social trends like that can stall, researchers say, but hardly ever do they screech to a full stop.
"Disasters don't alter the course of social change," said Kathleen Tierney, a professor of sociology and director of the Disaster Research Center at the University of Delaware. "They may accelerate trends, but you don't see a reversal of what was already happening."
Professor Tierney said that based on the patterns of disasters past, New York -- barring future events that no one can predict -- will probably resume its previous trajectory.
Other experts say that while the optimistic generalizations may yet hold true for New York, the wrinkles and idiosyncrasies of a living city -- and the differences between what happened in Lower Manhattan and the pattern of natural disasters that have mostly been studied -- will also color the city's recovery. 
Most disaster research, for example -- from the Chicago fire of 1871 through the 1964 Alaska earthquake -- has focused on local trends that were heightened, and in many cases accelerated, by disaster. People who might have changed jobs, say, or moved, or bought or sold a business -- but had not done so yet -- are often galvanized, or forced, into action by disasters, researchers say.
After Hurricane Andrew in 1992, for example, an already noticed ethnic trend in southern Florida -- white residents moving out of Miami-Dade County into nearby Broward County, more Hispanic residents and immigrants moving in -- sharply intensified as families lost homes, built homes and made new choices. In Japan, the shipping port at Kobe was losing ground to Asian rivals like Pusan, South Korea, when an earthquake hit in 1995. The trend continued and intensified.
In other cities, like Chicago in 1871 and London in 1666, where vast swaths of urban landscape were destroyed by fire, upward economic momentum was so great that many residents and businesses could not be bothered with the grand redesigning plans that were put forward -- they rebuilt largely as before because commerce could not wait.
New York in 2001 does not exactly fit any of those models, partly because the local and global are so mixed together. Guessing where the economy might go even before the disaster meant taking into account the sales revenues at the corner deli as well as the Shanghai Stock Exchange. And the nature of the damage that occurred -- from a deliberate surprise attack -- has also become part of the equation, embedded into the discussion from Washington to Walla Walla about how the nation should deal with terrorism and the new issues of security. 
That newfound symbolic role could be positive for New York to the degree that rebuilding the city becomes an expression of patriotism or national political policy.
"I think there are some lessons we can learn from other disasters, but it is important to recognize the differences in New York as well," said Stephanie E. Chang, an assistant professor of geography at the University of Washington in Seattle. Professor Chang, who studied Kobe after more than 6,000 people died in its 1995 earthquake, said that in most natural disasters, older, weaker buildings and small businesses are hit hardest, and damage is usually widespread geographically.
The New York experience was completely opposite, she said. Damage was concentrated in a high-rise complex, and the businesses immediately affected were not the poorly capitalized, underinsured mom-and-pop companies that tend to be wiped out by natural catastrophe.
The World Trade Center attack also connects to national and global trends in ways that most natural disasters usually do not.
Travel and tourism around the world have been battered. Patterns and levels of immigration into the United States could be next. Some politicians in Washington, even as they appropriate money to rebuild New York, are talking about restricting the flow of immigrants as part of the nation's antiterrorism strategy. Peter Marcuse, a professor of urban planning at Columbia University, said he believes that a key difference in New York is that rebuilding will not simply be a matter of engineering or design, as is usually the case in disasters. London city planners did not need to think about the possibility of another German blitz in rebuilding the city after World War II, he said. And when earthquake-damaged San Francisco rebuilt after 1989, the likelihood of more earthquakes was certainly there, but the response lay in better understanding of how buildings function, not in contemplating security or how symbols of global power might be seen half a world away in a terrorist training camp.
Other experts say that focusing only on rebuilding misses much of the social picture of where New York was before the attacks, and thus where it might be going. "People equate recovery with physical reconstruction, but there are all these other dimensions that go on," said Professor Tierney. "There also is social recovery to communities and ways of life, and psychological, emotional and spiritual recovery of a sense of place."
Some economists and planners say, for example, that social inequality in the city could be heightened in the trade center aftermath, if many residents with the means and inclination decide to move out of New York. Already, many economists say the effects of a downturn are likely to be felt disproportionately by the city's less affluent residents, many of whom work in service industries like restaurants and hotels that have seen their business sharply decline.
Others say that the symbolic importance that has been attached to New York, through the images of the disaster burned into the consciousness of millions who watched news coverage on television, has created a vast political momentum of its own that will not be stopped.
In the 1970's, when New York teetered on the verge of bankruptcy, the federal government declined to bail out the city and the nation did not seem to care. In an era when the people of Lubbock, Tex., can send a mural of sympathy to Pennsylvania Station, the winds have changed.
"This country has never been in these waters before, so there could be some danger from generalizing," said Dennis S. Mileti, director of the Natural Hazard Center at the University of Colorado at Boulder, which has one of the nation's largest research libraries of disaster research, with more than 27,000 bibliographic entries. "And there will be shifts and changes at the micro level. But if I were a betting man, I'd bet that if you come back in X years, New York will be right back where it would have been if this hadn't happened."

HEADLINE: Crisis Reshapes Mayoral Runoff, But More for Green Than Ferrer 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY

 BODY:
The terrorist attack on the World Trade Center has created sharp stylistic and policy differences between the two Democratic candidates for mayor, with Mark Green seizing on it as the central focus of his campaign, and Fernando Ferrer arguing that it should not overshadow existing problems confronting the city.
 The responses by Mr. Ferrer and Mr. Green expose the divergent views of the crisis by two public officials with very different political and personal backgrounds. Each is trying to measure the impact of the bombing on the city he is seeking to lead, and on his campaign for mayor, in the heat of a tight contest. 
 The divergent reactions are the latest evidence, aides to both men said, that New Yorkers' response to Sept. 11 may vary based on where they live and their economic situation. Both campaigns are regularly polling voters to prepare for the primary runoff on Thursday. 
The central point of contention between Mr. Ferrer and Mr. Green is over where the rebuilding should occur. Mr. Green, the public advocate, who lives in Manhattan, argued that the city should swiftly replace the office space lost in Lower Manhattan. Mr. Ferrer, who has been the Bronx borough president for almost 14 years, said that some of the construction should be spread out across New York, and that the attack was "an opportunity to pursue much-needed redevelopment opportunities" in boroughs that have resented Manhattan's economic dominance.
But the differences go beyond what or where to rebuild. 
Mr. Green raises the terrorist attack at almost every opportunity. He has proposed, in some detail, ways in which New York should direct its rebuilding effort, and how it should guard against future attacks and gird for widespread economic deterioration.
Mr. Green says that some promises he made before Sept. 11, like reducing the size of public school classes, would have to be deferred. He said any hope New York had of increasing spending on, say, housing construction was contingent on re-establishing the financial district as a source of tax revenue.
Mr. Green has used the issue to raise questions about Mr. Ferrer, describing his response as vague and late, and arguing that it showed that he was not prepared to lead New York through difficult times.
"If we have a mayor that doesn't appreciate that a big crisis requires big ideas and a nonpolitical response, the city could be in big trouble," said Mr. Green, adding, "He hasn't shown an appreciation for the magnitude of the problem, and responded more politically than substantively to this crisis."
In his own campaign appearances, Mr. Ferrer also calls the attack the most urgent problem facing the city. And at a debate on Tuesday, he said his promise to raise teacher salaries by 30 percent, in exchange for some productivity gains, may have to be put off.
But Mr. Ferrer, who ran on a promise to be an advocate of New Yorkers who had not prospered under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, argued that the attack should not eclipse the still urgent need to improve schools, health care and the housing stock. "They are the reasons I ran for office in the first place," Mr. Ferrer said in an interview. "It doesn't motivate me to ignore them. Some would say that all that stuff now is unimportant. Well, no."
While his campaign speeches include prominent mention of the attack, they are otherwise mostly indistinguishable from the speeches he made before Sept. 11. 
Mr. Ferrer continues to advocate sweeping governmental programs dealing with housing and health care, even after learning that the next mayor will have to confront a $4 billion budget deficit. After Mr. Green began challenging him for not engaging the issue of the attack, Mr. Ferrer delivered a speech about the attack Tuesday morning in which he proposed creating a blue-ribbon panel after Election Day to advise him on how to respond, and a "New York Rebuilds Corporation" to help oversee reconstruction. 
But that afternoon, he unveiled the surprise endorsement by former Mayor Edward I. Koch, and media coverage of the endorsement, not unexpectedly, eclipsed that of Mr. Ferrer's speech about the attack.
Mr. Ferrer declined to respond to Mr. Green's characterization of his response. "I really do take seriously the pledge we both made primary night not to launch attacks," he said. 
Like many New Yorkers, Mr. Ferrer and Mr. Green may be influenced in their reaction to the attack -- and their assessment of how their supporters might react to it -- by the circumstances of their own lives. 
Mr. Ferrer lives in the Riverdale section of the Bronx; his borough president office is near Yankee Stadium, and he spends much of his time campaigning outside Manhattan. Mr. Green lives on the Upper East Side; his downtown office was closed for a week because of the attack. Mr. Green toured the site within two days after the attack; Mr. Ferrer waited about 10 days.
Aides to Mr. Ferrer said that in seizing on the attack, Mr. Green was, not uncharacteristically, attaching himself to a high-profile issue to draw attention to himself. They noted that Mr. Green had begun attacking Mr. Ferrer when polls showed that Mr. Green was facing a tougher runoff against Mr. Ferrer than he had expected.
"It seems that what Mr. Mark Green is doing is attacking Mr. Ferrer at every opportunity that he has," said Roberto Ramirez, the Bronx Democratic leader.
Mr. Green's advisers argued that Mr. Ferrer, in urging that the redevelopment be scattered in the other boroughs, was playing to resentment of Manhattan and its financial district in other parts of New York. Mr. Ferrer won the first round of the Democratic primary on Sept. 25 with an appeal to "the other New York," a description that he said was based on economic status but that also resonated outside Manhattan.
According to a survey of voters leaving the polls on Sept. 25, Mr. Ferrer won 23 percent of the Manhattan Democratic vote, compared with 45 percent for Mr. Green. But Mr. Ferrer won 64 percent of the Bronx Democratic vote, compared with 19 percent for Mr. Green, and 35 percent of the Democratic vote in Queens and Staten Island combined, compared with 25 percent for Mr. Green. The two men tied in Brooklyn, each getting 35 percent.
That same survey suggested other reasons why Mr. Ferrer is putting less emphasis on rebuilding. Among Democrats who voted for Mr. Green, 7 percent said they considered rebuilding the financial district the most important issue facing the city; just 1 percent of Mr. Ferrer's voters held that view.
And some analysts suggest that voters who were concerned about education and health care before the attack -- and who don't live near Lower Manhattan, work there or know anyone who does -- had not shifted their views to the extent that Mr. Green thinks. 
"Most voters are where they were before," said William Eimicke, a political science professor at Columbia University. "Education is still the biggest issue facing New York."
And the Rev. Al Sharpton, one of Mr. Ferrer's most prominent supporters, said Democrats who had argued that Mr. Ferrer had made a tactical mistake in not adjusting his message after Sept. 11 had been proven wrong by his first-place showing on Sept. 25.
"What all of the pundits are missing here is that turnout wasn't affected and that Freddy's message wasn't affected," he said. "Everyone can give whatever analysis they want: the voting pattern of the 25th was the opposite of Mark's strategy."
Mr. Green's and Mr. Ferrer's different responses have showcased stylistic differences between them. 
Mr. Ferrer has presented himself as a child of the streets of the Bronx, and greeted anything suggesting elitism with an edge of defiance. Mr. Green's campaign manager, Richard Schrader, described Mr. Ferrer's proposal to move some redevelopment away from Wall Street as "kind of a chump populism."
Mr. Green has been aggressive and resourceful in linking the attack to his campaign. He invoked it in a new television advertisement released this weekend -- "Which Democrat has a specific plan to rebuild our economy and increase safety and security?" the announcer asks.
And he has included on his public schedule funerals of firefighters who perished in the collapse. He made conspicuous mention of his sympathy calls during a televised debate on Tuesday night.
"I go to two funerals a day, it seems, and mostly of firefighters, and the police funerals are now just beginning," Mr. Green declared, adding, "I will never forget the 19 families I embraced at Squad 288."
Mr. Ferrer said he, too, had attended many funerals, but had not listed them on his public schedule out of respect for families' privacy. "I don't think it's seemly to keep track of these things," he said. "I'm not toting this stuff up. All I can tell you is, man, I'm going to too many."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE INSURANCE; 
In U.S. Plan, Taxpayers Would Cover Terror Claims

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON with JOSEPH B. TREASTER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 

 BODY:
The Bush administration and Congress are preparing legislation to have taxpayers pay major insurance claims arising out of terrorist attacks.
 The plan would make the insurers the second major industry, after the airlines, to receive emergency government aid after the Sept. 11 attacks on the Pentagon and World Trade Center. 
 Government officials and corporate executives say such a measure, to be announced as early as this week, is essential to avert an economic meltdown at the end of the year, when many insurance contracts covering businesses, office buildings and factories expire. Without such coverage, lenders will not finance real estate purchases, construction or investments by business in plants and equipment. 
Some lawmakers question whether the plan would be an unjustified bailout, and whether the situation is as dire as corporations say. But already, major reinsurers, which protect other insurers against huge risks, have notified their clients and the government that they intend to sharply limit or curtail their coverage for terrorist attacks.
A government program may help limit future rate increases. As the most likely terrorism targets, Washington, New York and other major cities would benefit the most from such a plan. Without it, experts say, businesses are likely to seek safer locations. 
While the airlines' $15 billion aid package helps cover the costs associated with the attacks last month, the proposals for the insurers would cover the unknowable expenses from future terrorism. The government has also agreed to temporarily limit the airline insurers' future losses from terrorism. 
Administration officials and lawmakers, prodded by heavy lobbying from the insurance, real estate, manufacturing and investment industries, say they already agree on the need for quick action. Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the Connecticut Democrat who heads the Senate Banking subcommittee that oversees insurance, said he exchanged drafts of legislation on Friday with senior Treasury Department officials who share his urgency. 
Mr. Dodd said that law enforcement officials' predictions of more attacks made it imperative to act.
"There is a real risk that reinsurance will not be issued, creating broader economic problems," he said. "It's like someone going to get a mortgage on a house, and the bank says, 'Do you have fire insurance?' and you say 'no' and they say 'forget it.' This is not a bailout. It's an economic issue."
Senator Charles A. Schumer, another member of the banking committee, agreed. "There has been a consensus achieved among the White House and everyone here that for an attack of terrorism, the government will have to be the insurer of last resort," Mr. Schumer, a New York Democrat, said. "If there was no insurance, it would really crimp economic activity. "
Insurers generally say they can survive the estimated $40 billion or more in losses from last month's attacks, but cannot bear the full risks of future attacks.
"Everybody is asking for this coverage, but nobody is getting it," said Salvatore Zaffino, chief executive of Guy Carpenter & Company in New York, one of the world's largest reinsurance brokers. "We know of no reinsurer that is offering to provide terrorist coverage." 
Officials say it is impossible to calculate whether the plan will wind up costing taxpayers nothing, like a similar plan in Britain, or hundreds of billions of dollars, which taxpayers paid to cover insured deposits at hundreds of failed savings and loan institutions a decade ago. 
"Nobody knows the upper parameters of the risk," an administration official said last Friday, which is the main reason the reinsurers now refuse to issue such insurance on their own.
Lenders usually require businesses to insure any property they pledge to secure loans. Insurance coverage also supports a $300 billion market for commercial mortgages packaged as securities, the second-largest source of cash for real estate projects after traditional bank loans. 
President Bush has already signed measures providing $20 billion in relief for New York, $15 billion for the airlines and an open-ended fund to compensate victims of the September attacks. 
The insurance measure is expected to move swiftly because virtually nobody has been lobbying against it. But any such measure could encounter resistance from both conservative Republicans who are skeptical of government involvement in the marketplace and liberal Democrats who see it as an unjustified bailout.
Aides to two important lawmakers -- Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democratic chairman of the Commerce Committee, and Representative Michael G. Oxley, Republican chairman of the House Financial Services Committee -- said last week that the lawmakers were urging colleagues to move slowly and assure themselves that a crisis truly existed. 
But industry groups have already lined up powerful support from influential lawmakers. Their high ranking on Congress's agenda was evident last week when they met with House leaders including the Speaker, J. Dennis Hastert, immediately after he conferred with Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, to discuss budget issues. 
Lawmakers and administration officials are working on proposals under which insurers would cover initial terrorism claims, but their losses would be limited. The insurers would finance an industry pool that would then provide terrorism coverage of perhaps $10 billion, with the government paying for any greater losses, industry representatives say.
Last week, officials worked to resolve major issues including how insurance premiums would be set and by whom; whether the coverage would be mandatory; how large a calamity would trigger the use of government money; and whether the program would be permanent.
The most commonly discussed option is one adopted eight years ago by the British government in a similar crisis. But officials are exploring other plans including the creation of a new government-backed enterprise like the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. Another option would be modeled on the 1957 law that limits the liability of utilities for damages resulting from accidents at nuclear reactors. One other possibility, though unlikely, would be a tax break to enable insurers to provide coverage themselves. 
The British program began after Irish Republican Army terrorists attacked the London financial district in the spring of 1992, causing more than $500 million in damage and prompting European reinsurers to announce they would no longer cover terrorism. A feared crisis in the real estate and financial markets was averted by the creation of a company financed by the industry and backed by the government that covers losses from attacks in Wales, Scotland and England (but not Northern Ireland). But claims have never been large enough to require government help.
In the United States, experts say that government protection is now essential. "Who's going to run a business in New York or any other place if they don't think they can get protection?" Jerry Rosenbloom, a professor of insurance at the University of Pennsylvania, said. "I think businesses would try to move out of what they consider to be high-risk areas, and that will weaken the tax bases of a lot of major cities. It would include a loss of jobs right down to people being afraid to go into new businesses."

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Before Donating, Don't Be Afraid to Ask Questions

BYLINE:  By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:
AMERICANS have opened their hearts and their wallets in the weeks after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, eager to help the victims and their families, as well as the thousands of volunteers at the disaster sites. Now specialists in charitable giving are advising people to take a few minutes to learn how to do the most good with their gifts.
 "It is so important to give money away intelligently," said Daniel Borochoff, president of the American Institute of Philanthropy, a consumer watchdog group in Bethesda, Md. "People can exponentially increase the good of their donations." 
 Similarly, the Better Business Bureau advises people to "investigate before you donate." And both groups make it easy to do some basic research -- not only to avoid the scams of which Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani warned within days of the attack in New York, but also to ensure that a charity has a sound record of financial accountability and that the money will be used as intended.
Donations have reached an estimated $675 million since the attacks, and more money is coming in.
Charity professionals say they are pleased with Americans' generous spirit, yet some of them have also expressed concern about the outlook for giving in general late in the year, traditionally a crucial time for charities. Already, several organizations unrelated to the disaster relief efforts have experienced a slowdown in donations, forcing some to scale back programs or postpone fund drives. The Los Angeles Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, for instance, said it planned to close two pet-adoption centers and lay off eight people.
"There may be a 'compassion fatigue,' " said Bennett Weiner, chief operating officer of the BBB Wise Giving Alliance. "Some donors may be drained by this particular event and may not have much left."
Mr. Borochoff said he hoped Americans, who traditionally give 2 percent of income a year to charity, would view the donations related to Sept. 11 as an addition to their normal donations. "We still have homelessness," he said. "We still have people who cannot afford medical care, and these problems will only get worse with the economy turning down."
Ronna D. Brown, president of the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York, agreed. "The entire nonprofit sector needs support," she said, adding, "People's outpouring for Sept. 11 has been wonderful."
Ms. Brown's group, which like other local chapters provides information on many charities, has also posted on its Web site, www.newyork.bbb.org, a table of charities working to help victims of the attacks. The table offers information about each charity, a description of its work, a link to its Web site and to an evaluation by the Better Business Bureau, if one has been made.
The American Institute of Philanthropy lists top-rated charities on its site, www.charitywatch.org/topgrps.html. The group grades charities for financial practices. The charities on the list put at least 75 percent of their budgeted expenses toward the charitable programs while generally spending 25 percent or less on fund-raising. Potential donors can order a copy of the institute's "Charity Rating Guide and Watchdog Report," by sending $3 to the institute, at 4905 Del Ray Avenue, Suite 300W, Bethesda, Md. 20814.
Another site, www.libertyunites.org, has links to charities participating in the disaster relief efforts. And the site of the BBB Wise Giving Alliance, www.give.org, contains a wealth of information, including financial evaluations of hundreds of charities; information may also be requested by PROPERTY AND INVESTMENTS;

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FINANCING; 
G-7 Leaders Pledge To Work In Concert to Thwart Terrorists

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 

 BODY:
The world's leading industrial nations agreed to share intelligence information related to the financing of terrorism and to collectively pressure all other countries to prevent terrorist from using the global banking system, finance ministers announced this evening.
 Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill, who described the agreement as a "huge breakthrough," said members of the Group of 7 have committed themselves to exchange intelligence on money flows and bank accounts related to suspected terrorists immediately after obtaining it. In the past, governments and banks in industrial nations have had widely divergent policies on blocking criminal assets. 
 "For 25 years the U.S. and other countries have been negotiating treaties" to deal with illicit financial flows, Mr. O'Neill said, adding, "Now we have the whole G-7 saying we will do this together-- identify specific individuals and accounts and take action to block them."
Since the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States, Mr. O'Neill has led the American effort to seize the financial assets of people suspected of supporting Osama bin Laden and his Al Qaeda network.
President Bush has said that initial efforts to seize assets of 27 individuals and groups thought to be connected to Al Qaeda have netted $6 million in 50 bank accounts worldwide. But economic ministers are hoping that by tightening laws and recruiting a broader array of nations to cooperate in asset tracking, allies could not only seize more terrorist-related funds, but also make it difficult for people connected with terrorism to use banks for even routine transactions, like wire transfers or credit card use.
Though the G-7 countries pledged to cooperate on seizing terrorist funds before, there were shades of differences in their approaches. A bill that passed the Italian parliament last week would restrict the reach of financial crime investigations by limiting the kinds of information that Italian officials could share with foreign authorities.
Mr. O'Neill said tonight that all G-7 members -- Italy, the United States, Britain, Canada, France, Germany and Japan -- were now of one mind on the subject.
In their joint communique, the ministers vowed to implement two United Nations Security Council resolutions that call for the freezing of suspected terrorist funds.
They also agreed to convene a meeting of the Financial Action Task Force, a multilateral agency that coordinates financial police actions worldwide. The task force would draw up guidelines to help banks identify possible terrorists. The group would also seek to isolate places that facilitate terrorist financing and find ways of stopping them from doing so.
The measures could ease the burden on the United States, which has sought to single-handedly manage a worldwide suppression of the funds in the past two weeks. Mr. O'Neill said the Treasury Department had been corresponding with 107 countries during that time. He said he now expected his Canadian, European and Japanese counterparts to help persuade other nations to join the alliance.
Officials announced no similar concerted action to fight the worldwide economic downturn. Though all major industrial nations are suffering a synchronized slowdown -- the United States and Japan are both likely to undergo recessions this year -- the ministers said individual circumstances varied too widely to prescribe any unified steps to stimulate economic growth.
Still, each nation promised "decisive action" if economic weakness continued.
"We are strongly committed to bringing forward needed measures to increase economic growth and preserve the health of our financial markets," they said in their joint statement.

HEADLINE: Trying to Make Sense of the Senseless 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 One way to respond to the recent terrorist attacks is for the United States to begin another Manhattan Project, with the objective of finding alternative fuels. 
 If American scientists were to develop other ways to fuel our automobiles and heat our homes -- whether hydrogen, solar, electric or fusion -- we would no longer be dependent on foreign sources of energy. 
Our dependence on oil from the Middle East now ties our hands both diplomatically and economically. 
Islamic militants, who assert that the United States exploits the Middle East oil resources, would no longer have another reason to despise the West, our trade deficit would vanish and pollution would decrease. For a few billion invested in the right area, we would all win.

REON E. SWAIM
Belford, N.J., Oct. 3, 2001

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Traci Jones, Ara Lovitt

 BODY:
Traci Leigh Jones and Ara Lovitt are to be married today at the Williamsburg Inn in Williamsburg, Va. Judge J. Michael Luttig of the United States Court of Appeals in Alexandria, Va., will officiate. 
 The couple met at the United States Supreme Court in 1998, when the bride was a law clerk for Justice Sandra Day O'Connor and the bridegroom was a law clerk for Justice Antonin Scalia. 
 The bride, who is 31 and will take her husband's name, is a litigation associate in the New York office of Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue, the Cleveland law firm. She graduated with high honors from the University of Texas at Austin, received a master's degree in economics from the University of Washington at Seattle and a law degree summa cum laude from Duke. 
She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. B. J. Jones of Ocala, Fla. Her father, who is retired, was a superintendent of claims at the Allied Insurance Company in Des Moines. Her mother, Sylvia Jones, also retired, was a claims adjuster in the Des Moines office of the Allstate Insurance Company.
The bridegroom, 29, is an associate working with media and communications clients in the mergers and acquisitions group of Morgan Stanley in New York. He graduated summa cum laude from Dartmouth and received a law degree from Stanford. He is the son of Tara Petrosian Lovitt of Los Angeles and Bert Lovitt of Pacific Palisades, Calif. His mother is a co-owner of Chez Nous, a restaurant in Toluca Lake, Calif. His father is a retired film editor and producer.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Cherry-Picking REIT's in Flux

BYLINE:  By DAN COLARUSSO

 BODY:
ON Sept. 10, a Jersey City office tower being built across the Hudson River from the World Trade Center had lease commitments for roughly one-third of its one million square feet of space. Three weeks later, the building was "close to being full," said Mitchell Hersh, chief executive of the Mack-Cali Realty Corporation, which owns it.
 While the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon have harmed many parts of the economy, real estate investment trusts like Mack-Cali and Vornado Realty Trust, both office building giants, may now have more opportunity. But REIT's focused on hotels, like Host Marriott, are facing new instability. 
 REIT's, which own and operate income-producing real estate and are required to pay most of their earnings to shareholders, have outperformed the overall market for most of the last two years, in part because they have distributed steady dividends.
But because real estate performance typically softens after other sectors in a weak economy, investors have begun to re-evaluate the prospects of REIT's. They are debating whether companies that own large office buildings in metropolitan areas like New York City and Chicago will suffer from corporate flight and steadily declining occupancy rates, and if a paralyzed tourism industry will prevent hotel and resort REIT's from continuing to pay dividends. 
"All we have is uncertainty," said Martin Cohen, the president of Cohen & Steers Capital Management, which specializes in real estate investing. 
The Morgan Stanley REIT Index is up 6 percent this year. As of Thursday, it was down only 2 percent since Sept. 11. But with REIT's yielding 7 percent, investors may be wondering if there is enough income to offset the economic risk now facing all equity investing.
"Right now, I'd rate the sector a 4 or 5 on a scale of 10," said Hamid Moghadam, the chairman of AMB Property, an industrial property REIT. "On the valuation side, if there is a problem with sustainability of dividends, it could have an effect."
Shares of Mack-Cali, one of the largest landlords in New Jersey and the owner of the Jersey City complex, Harborside Financial Center, rallied to a 52-week high of $32 on Sept. 17 because it is expected to reap short-term benefits if financial companies move there from Lower Manhattan. Vornado shares also have rallied, because its New York properties have accommodated businesses moving from the disaster area. 
"Relative to the rest of the country, Manhattan was tight" before the attacks, said Charles Fitzgerald, a portfolio co-manager in the REIT group of J.P. Morgan Fleming Asset Management. "Now, it's much tighter."
Vornado could be coping with a very different set of problems today if it had not ended talks in March with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for a 99-year lease on the World Trade Center. The lease eventually went to another landlord.
Since the attack, five displaced companies have moved into some of the 14.5 million square feet of space that Vornado owns in Manhattan, said Steven Roth, its chairman and chief executive. Before the disaster, the New York real estate market "was O.K.," he said. "Now the displaced tenants have taken up most of the space available. There's no supply now."
BECAUSE New York City landlords and tenants typically sign longer leases than their counterparts elsewhere in the country -- 10 years or more, compared with 5 to 7 years -- many REIT's are insulated from short-term market uncertainties. Mr. Cohen said REIT's like S. L. Green Realty, Vornado and Boston Properties were likely to prosper because of extensive holdings in Manhattan. 
Mr. Hersh of Mack-Cali, however, said many companies were rethinking their real estate strategies. "Do companies want to locate in high-visibility areas? Should its work force be less concentrated?" he asked. "Given the work force availability and the housing availability, I think you'll see companies moving toward suburban markets."
There is little debate about prospects of REIT's concentrated in hotel and resort properties, which accounted for nearly 5 percent of the Morgan Stanley REIT Index at the end of the second quarter. Shares of Host Marriott have fallen 37 percent since Sept. 11 as tourism has dried up. 
After the attacks, FelCor Lodging Trust of Irving, Tex., said it was scrapping its planned merger with the MeriStar Hospitality Corporation of Washington because of "adverse changes in the financial markets." Shares of both companies have fallen substantially.
"Hospitality is not going to be O.K.," Mr. Cohen said, adding that REIT's with the shortest lease commitments should be avoided. That keeps rental properties and hotels out of the mix for him and some other REIT investors. 
Mr. Fitzgerald of J.P. Morgan said he was watching national office space vacancy rates -- which climbed to 10.8 percent in the second quarter from 9.5 percent in the first quarter -- because "occupancy problems can eat into dividends." He said he expected a similar increase in the third quarter. 
For REIT's, the other side of a soft economy is that declining interest rates allow them to borrow at lower rates. Vornado is in an especially good position. "We saw this cycle coming, and intentionally had a lot of floating-rate debt," Mr. Roth said.
Growth in funds from operations at REIT's -- their equivalent of earnings per share -- is expected be 8.5 percent from this year to next, up from 7.5 percent from 2000 to 2001. A slowing economy may cut one or two percentage points off those estimates, Mr. Fitzgerald said. 
Still, combining even reduced growth of 6 percent with the average REIT dividend of 7 percent makes the sector look good in comparison with the overall market, he said. "You're getting a low double-digit return over 12 months," he added.
Last Wednesday, Standard & Poor's said REIT's would be eligible for inclusion in its S.& P. 500, S.& P. MidCap 400 and S.& P. SmallCap 600 indexes.
WALL STREET is somewhat divided about the sector. Two Lehman Brothers analysts, David Harris and David Shulman, took what they called a "more defensive posture" on REIT's, downgrading S. L. Green, AMB Property and Boston Properties but upgrading Mack-Cali.
J.P. Morgan Fleming, which invests in publicly traded REIT's and in private real estate transactions, said it was hopeful but guarded. In a letter to clients last week, J.P. Morgan said "major property sectors, with the exception of hotels, are unlikely to suffer a one-for-one drop with the broader economy" and that "long-term leases will continue to provide an anchor to income streams."
Most REIT investors are similarly wary. "We've battened down the hatches; we have a slightly higher cash level, but we're looking to redeploy it," Mr. Cohen said, pointing to his funds' cash position, now at 7 percent, up from a typical 5 percent. "If we go into a prolonged tailspin. REIT's will probably defend better."
