PERSON: Bill Cella 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
Ready to Ruffle Media Feathers

BYLINE:  By BERNARD STAMLER

 BODY:
BILL CELLA has impressed many advertising colleagues with his self-effacing humor and wit. But they caution not to underestimate Mr. Cella, who just became one of the most powerful buyers of television ad time.
 Mr. Cella, 51, is chief executive of Magna Global, the newly formed media-buying division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, the world's largest collection of advertising agencies. 
 He is a "wonderful person," said Marv Goldsmith, a former boss of Mr. Cella's and now executive vice president of the broadcast group at ABC (which, of course, would benefit from good relations with Mr. Cella).
Keith Turner, a frequent business adversary of Mr. Cella's and the president of sales and marketing at NBC, called him "a talented, bright and extremely funny guy" who does not take himself too seriously.
Mr. Cella does not show obvious signs of strain from his new job, which will test an unproven strategy that uses Interpublic's multibillion-dollar purchasing power from all its clients to buy large blocks of national TV advertising at the lowest rates.
In an interview, Mr. Cella even joked that he got the job only because he and his present boss, John J. Dooner Jr., the chairman of Interpublic, have been friends since Little League.
But there is a tough, serious side to Mr. Cella. He is not afraid to ruffle feathers.
Mr. Cella has taken the job as the advertising world is reeling from the most severe slowdown in a decade -- first from the weakened economy and now also from the uncertainty since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. TV advertising is much more of a buyer's market, which could mean that Mr. Cella is starting his job at a time when his leverage will never be greater.
Interpublic has been an acquisitive giant for some time in advertising, the parent of agencies that include McCann-Erickson and FCB, among many others. The creation of Magna, announced in July, was meant to counter the increased power of the broadcast and cable networks, which have been no strangers themselves to mergers and takeovers in recent years.
The plan, Mr. Cella said, was to "balance the landscape" by consolidating media negotiations for all of Interpublic's agencies.
Taken together, Interpublic's agencies can throw around a lot of financial weight. Last year, they had billings of $40 billion worldwide, $8.6 billion of it spent on United States national TV advertising alone. That is about 25 percent of all national TV ad spending. Mr. Cella said it should be enough to give Magna the ability to "negotiate prices that our clients wouldn't be able to get on their own -- even big clients."
To do that, Magna must avoid conflicts among the many different clients of the Interpublic agencies. Magna is structured so that its negotiators will be informed of the total media needs of Interpublic's agencies, but will not know the specific names of clients for whom they are negotiating. That is the feature that distinguishes Magna from centralized media buyers of other big advertising companies, Mr. Cella said.
For Mr. Cella, the art of negotiating is a basic part of his professional life. He has worked for many years on both sides of the media street.
Mr. Cella, who lives in Manhattan with his wife, Elaine, and 4-year-old daughter, Danielle, began his career in broadcasting, selling radio time at a station in New Rochelle, N.Y., where he grew up. He later went to ABC, starting as an account executive for WXYZ-TV in Detroit. He then moved on to Chicago and later New York, where he rose to vice president for sports sales. In 1994, he left to join McCann-Erickson.
At McCann, Mr. Cella supervised the national broadcast assignment for the Coca-Cola account. He was promoted in 1997, taking on the responsibility for national television media covering all of McCann's clients. Before taking his post at Magna, he was executive vice president and director of broadcast and programming for the North American unit of Universal McCann, which, along with Initiative Media Worldwide is one of Interpublic's two media service agencies. There, he supervised the purchase of about $2 billion in national broadcast time annually.
"Bill is a terrific negotiator," said Mr. Goldsmith of ABC, who was president of sales and marketing for the network when Mr. Cella worked there and who often faced him in media negotiations after he went to the agency side.
"Even sitting on the opposite side of the table, I was still impressed," Mr. Goldsmith said. "He doesn't lose sight of what he is trying to accomplish."
That kind of tenacity will serve Mr. Cella well as he tries to accomplish something that "has never been tried before," in the words of Mr. Goldsmith: treating the purchase of network television time as "a commodity buy."
Will it work? In the aftermath of Sept. 11 and with talk of recession rampant, TV ad sales are weak. And while Mr. Cella can now exert an enormous amount of financial pressure in negotiating, such power may not seem as necessary for media buyers as it did when times were better.
It is also unclear whether Magna's anti-conflict measures will really work. As a result, many people in the industry appear to be taking a wait-and-see attitude about the company. 
Jon Nesvig, president for sales at Fox Broadcasting, is among them. He said he was not sure that Mr. Cella could negotiate prices without giving the seller "a lot of specifics," the kind of specifics Mr. Cella is not supposed to know about when he is buying network time in accordance with the Magna model.
Similarly, Michael J. Russell Jr., an analyst at Morgan Stanley, said he wondered whether there might still be client conflicts despite Mr. Cella's best efforts. And he questioned how Mr. Cella could be effective if the networks started talking privately to some of the bigger advertisers represented by Magna's parent, offering them better deals than Mr. Cella could provide, on condition that they break ranks with him.
For now, Mr. Cella is hiring employees and organizing Magna's move to office space in Midtown Manhattan. The company did "a little live testing" with some cable advertising time purchases over the summer, he said. Although he said he was "very satisfied with the discount levels of the deals we structured," he acknowledged that the big test for Magna would come in the spring, when pilot shows are screened and the first round of significant time-buying occurs. Until then, he said, Magna will "be working on process and procedure -- and we'll be ready."

GRAPHIC: Photo: As chief executive of Magna Global, Bill Cella, 51, will negotiate rates for perhaps 25 percent of national TV advertising in the United States. Magna is a new division of the Interpublic Group. (Carol Halebian for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS for RAINER HERTRICH and PHILIPPE CAMUS; 
Airbus, Unshaken, Is Not Cutting Back

BYLINE:  By RICK GLADSTONE

 BODY:
THE airline industry crisis created by the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 quickly infected the American commercial aerospace industry. A week after the attacks, the Boeing Company said it would lay off up to 15 percent of its work force and trim 2002 production by 20 percent as financially struggling airlines scrapped plans to buy new planes.
 But the news from Airbus Industrie, the European manufacturer that competes with Boeing, was not nearly as bad. Airbus froze its delivery schedule for next year at 330 to 350 planes, announced no layoffs and said it was pressing ahead with its plan to produce a 550-seat superjumbo jet, known as the A380. It also stuck with projections of 15 percent earnings growth for this year. Nonetheless, some of the biggest Airbus customers are in the deepest trouble. 
 Rainer Hertrich and Philippe Camus, the co-chief executives of the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, the parent of Airbus, visited customers and government officials in the United States last week. In an interview last Wednesday, they discussed the airline industry's problems, as well as the military business opportunities that may be created by a United States response to the attacks. 
 RICK GLADSTONE

Q. -- Why does Boeing have to cut back so drastically on commercial airplane production while you do not?

HERTRICH -- We do not need to fire people because we were in the process of ramping up while Boeing was on a much higher level than we were, and therefore, of course, they have to reduce their work force as an adaptation, which was not necessary for Airbus, and this has nothing to do with subsidies or things like that, which was written in some press articles. E.A.D.S. is a listed company; we are as transparent as Boeing. So we feel ourselves quite well positioned in commercial aircraft, knowing that there will be an impact on us, but we are preparing for different scenarios and we believe ourselves excellently positioned to go through this crisis.

Q. -- The United States has rescued the domestic airline industry with emergency loans. Shouldn't we just let the market decide who survives?

CAMUS -- For me there was, and maybe there is still, what we call a systemic risk. A systemic risk was often used in describing the situation for the banks, in case of deep financial crisis. This was the same kind of risk involved, and I feel that the action taken by the U.S. government was really appropriate. Maybe it's not the usual situation, but public money is more involved here than in Europe. I think that was necessary.

HERTRICH -- The impact of the terroristic attacks on the 11th was an attack on the infrastructure, and if the government now would not support overcoming this attack on the infrastructure, we wouldn't have any infrastructure. So I think, following the line of Philippe, that's really government's task -- to safeguard the infrastructure -- but not without putting pressure on the airlines to be sound and to restructure themselves.

Q. -- Why are you sticking with the A380 superjumbo jet in such uncertain times?

CAMUS -- Because, first, it is a long-term program. The commercial life of the A380 will be 25 to 30 years, and we are thinking long term in the airline industry. We do see that after the consequences of the attacks of Sept. 11, which are creating turmoil in the market, passengers will return.
Second, it will be the first aircraft developed since Sept. 11, which means we are able to put on the aircraft all the safety features necessary. They will be, of course, the most elaborate safety features available. The third reason is that it will be the aircraft with the lowest operating cost per seat. And the fourth reason is that we are strongly supported by the airlines, our customers. So we have no reason to stop it, or slow down the program.

Q. -- What are the prospects for trans-Atlantic military cooperation now?

CAMUS -- We've seen that the events of the 11th, even if they are sad circumstances, are creating some opportunities to build. We can provide, together with the American industry, the appropriate capacity to deal with the new fight. Clearly the events of September have triggered a modification, a very deep change, maybe a sea change in the trans-Atlantic alliance. The reaction of the population in Europe can tell you that. I think it's a historical opportunity we should not miss. From an industry point of view, this is what we are favoring, this is what we are trying to implement.

Q. -- Many of your customers are suffering severe financial problems. Will you be more lenient with customers who need more time to pay?

HERTRICH -- Our strong balance sheet definitely will give us the possibility to extend financing where it's needed and where it's appropriate. We are ready to support our customers. It will be a case-by-case decision. I'm expecting there will be additional requests.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE OPPOSITION; 
In New Glare, Questions Dog Afghan Rebels

BYLINE:  By DAVID ROHDE with JOHN F. BURNS

DATELINE: JABUL-SERAJ, Afghanistan, Oct. 6 

 BODY:
Sipping tea in an elegant garden here just 50 miles from Kabul, the foreign minister of the rebel Northern Alliance makes a soothing claim for the future government it hopes to be part of. In it, he said, "the people of Afghanistan will have the right of self-determination."
 But in past years the alliance itself has been accused of shelling civilians, carrying out summary executions, and engaging in opium and weapons trafficking, according to human rights groups. The groups say the alliance has also burned and looted the houses of suspected Taliban sympathizers. 
 The last time the alliance's leaders tried to run Afghanistan, Kabul dissolved into factional civil war. More than 25,000 people died in the fighting, which reduced a third of the city to rubble and carved the country into fiefdoms essentially run by warlords. 
The record raises serious questions for Afghanistan, and for the alliance's backers in Washington, as to how the Northern Alliance might rule. It also suggests that if rebel groups regain power, in the event of American attacks on the Taliban, they may barely be able to work together. 
The last time the allied groups held power, in the early 1990's, the situation became so chaotic that the Taliban found an opening to come to power, promising to restore order to the nation with their strict interpretation of Islam. Now the Taliban are accused of harboring Osama bin Laden.
Adding to the complexity, the Northern Alliance appears to be leaderless at this critical moment. Just two days before the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington, two men believed to have ties to Mr. bin Laden attacked the alliance's charismatic leader, Ahmed Shah Massoud, in a suicide bombing. He died days later, depriving the alliance of a veteran of Afghanistan's long struggle against the Russians and someone whose reputation carried beyond his own faction of mujahedeen, or holy warriors. 
In the weeks since, it is still not clear who is the power broker in the Northern Alliance, though new leaders said that a new generation is emerging.
"So much depended on Ahmad Shah Massoud," one retired Central Intelligence Agency officer said.
"He was far from blameless, but he had an unquestionable commitment to rebuilding Afghanistan," the former officer said. "Al Qaeda, if it was Al Qaeda, knew what they were doing when they killed him before setting off the apocalypse that's going to finish the Taliban." 
The alliance's designated successor is General Muhammad Fahim, who is not the charming character that Mr. Massoud was. The group's titular leader, Burhannudin Rabbani, is seen largely as a figurehead.
In any case the alliance stands to play a powerful role in any future government, a position strengthened by its warming relationship with Washington. Another reason for its influence is sheer power: it can threaten to keep doing what it has been doing for two decades -- using its soldiers, now 15,000, to keep up the fight.
The foreign minister of the rebels, Dr. Abdullah Abdullah, who evidently is determined to cleanse the alliance's image, says that the group has matured greatly over the last five years, and that accusations against it are false or outdated. 
Disputes about the alliance go back almost a decade. In 1992 Mr. Rabbani saw his hour come and go after the mujahedeen triumphantly took Kabul when Soviet forces fled. Mr. Rabbani twice brokered deals that elected him president of Afghanistan. But his period in office split the mujahedeen, and the result was a full-scale civil war.
From 1992 to 1996 fighting raged among the factions, largely divided along political or ethnic lines. The real power behind Mr. Rabbani emerged: Mr. Massoud, the military commander. Both are ethnic Tajiks. 
By 1996, the Taliban, supported by Pakistan, had control of large parts of Afghanistan, forcing Mr. Rabbani and Mr. Massoud to form the Northern Alliance with other factions in the opposition. The alliance consisted of Mr. Massoud's faction, dominated by ethnic Tajiks, and other factions dominated by ethnic Uzbeks, ethnic Hazaras and Shiite Muslims. 
The Taliban are dominated by southern-based ethnic Pashtuns, the country's largest ethnic group. 
The newly allied groups, which had intermittently fought each other over the previous four years, had only one thing in common -- their opposition to the Taliban. Their efforts failed and the Taliban took Kabul and other big cities. 
It was during this period that Mr. Massoud's forces were accused of indiscriminately firing rockets into the capital, killing civilians.
Since then the fractious alliance has suffered military setback after military setback. The Taliban, backed by Pakistani weapons and volunteers, won control of 90 percent of the country.
The death of Mr. Massoud left the alliance at risk. General Fahim and General Abdul Rashid Dostum, two of the current leaders, both have mixed records as men whose loyalties were often in question and who, in General Dostum's case, switched sides at least twice in the early 1990's.
American officials worked closely with the mujahedeen factions now attached to the alliance in the late 1980's and early 1990's. Many of those officials now sigh when asked whether they believe that the fractiousness of those earlier years will be put aside in the quest for a new government.
Aside from the infighting and rights areas, there have also been questions about how the alliance has financed its operations. Alliance officials confirmed this week what has long been known -- that Iran and Russia have supplied it with weapons and financing.
Mr. Massoud was also known to generate funds by selling emeralds mined from the alliance-controlled Panjshir Valley. Alliance officials defend that as legitimate economic activity.
There have also been allegations that the alliance condones opium production and takes a cut of profits to finance operations. Weapons smuggling has also been rumored.
Dr. Abdullah vehemently denied these charges. He said alliance officials had worked to contain opium production by local farmers, who he said profit alone from the trade. 
The most serious allegations of human rights abuses stem from the mid 1990's, when the rule of law was virtually nonexistent in areas under each faction's control, according to rights groups. A report released by Human Rights Watch this spring found that all of the factions "engaged in rape, summary executions, arbitrary arrests, torture and 'disappearances.' "
In the worst single atrocity of the civil war, Uzbek soldiers under alliance command and Hazara civilians executed 3,000 Taliban soldiers in the city of Mazar-i-Sharif in 1997. The soldiers had been captured after an alliance commander reneged on a promise to side with the Taliban.
In 1998, several volleys of rockets believed to be fired by Mr. Massoud's forces landed in a crowded night market in Kabul. At least 76 civilians were killed.
As recently as spring 2000, refugees reported that alliance forces carried out summary executions and burned and looted houses. Ethnic Pashtuns were targeted in the attacks.
In the weeks since Mr. Massoud's assassination, General Fahim has largely kept out of the public eye. In an interview, the 44-year-old general said little and stuck to the alliance's standard line that Pakistan is to blame for all of Afghanistan's problems. The general, Mr. Massoud's longtime top aide, is colorless compared with his predecessor. But other alliance commanders insist his many years at Mr. Massoud's side give him credibility.
Dr. Abdullah speaks energetically of the future, and indeed this week a large contingent of alliance soldiers paraded in brand-new uniforms, said to have come fresh from Iran, along with functioning, if weathered, tanks and equipment. On every tank was a portrait of Mr. Massoud. 
Dr. Abdullah tries to convey the sense that after two decades, Afghanistan's moment has at last arrived. "Now, there is this promise," he said, "there is this hope."

SUBJECT: TALIBAN (91%); WAR & CONFLICT (90%); REBELLIONS & INSURGENCIES (90%); AL-QAEDA (89%); TERRORISM (89%); TERRORIST ORGANIZATIONS (89%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (78%); CIVIL WAR (78%); STATE DEPARTMENTS & FOREIGN SERVICES (78%); MUSLIMS & ISLAM (77%); TERRORIST ATTACKS (76%); BOMBINGS (72%); HUMAN RIGHTS (71%); SUICIDE BOMBINGS (70%); RELIGION (65%); OPIUM (58%); INTELLIGENCE SERVICES (50%) Terms not available from NYTimes. 

PERSON: OSAMA BIN LADEN (89%)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
A Glittering Addition at the Mohegan Sun Casino

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
SOUTHEASTERN CONNECTICUT'S long-suffering economy is experiencing a bracing reversal of fortune generated by three entities: the six-year-old Mohegan Sun Casino in Montville, where the first phase of a $1 billion addition opened last month and where a 1,200-room hotel is to open in the spring; the hugely successful Foxwoods Casino and Resort in Ledyard; and Pfizer Inc.'s 750,000-square-foot global research and development headquarters in New London, which opened in June.
 "We're in an interesting position," said Vivian Stanley, executive director of Connecticut's Mystic & More!, a publicly financed tourism district. "A lot of layoffs are going on elsewhere, but we're in a hiring mode, so we're seeing local people staying instead of moving out, and we're seeing a rise in real estate values." 
 Fueled by a pool of 11,600 Foxwoods employees, 9,000 Mohegan Sun employees and 1,500 people already hired by Pfizer for an eventual work force of 2,000, waterfront homes are being built for executives priced at $750,000 to $1 million, according to area builders. Existing homes that sold for $10,000 in 1990 are on the market for $250,000, said Tony Alves, New London's building inspector. Closer to the gambling sites, casino employees -- many of whom have been renters -- are said to be buying homes at the low end of the market. 
In addition, Greg Young, owner of Prudential Signature Properties in Old Saybrook, said: "We're selling condos to people from New York who want a place to stay when they come to the casinos. They rent them out when they can."
On Sept. 25, Mohegan Sun opened a massive addition to its original 630,000-square-foot complex completed in 1996, bringing the entire installation to a total of 5.5 million square feet, larger than Foxwoods' current 4.7 million square feet. 
The $270 million cost of the original portion pales beside the $986.1 million spent on the addition, plus $30 million that the Mohegans paid to widen Route 2A and create a mile-long Mohegan Sun Boulevard, providing patrons a direct route from Interstate 395 to the 12,500-car free parking garage.
Both Mohegan Sun and Foxwoods are open 24 hours a day, seven days a week, with similar gambling, dining and entertainment options. Because the two tribes have been designated by the federal government as independent Indian nations, they pay no municipal, state or federal taxes on activities that take place on reservation property. Instead, after paying gamblers' winnings, they contribute 25 percent of their monthly revenues from slot machines to Connecticut and give voluntarily to their hometowns as well. Foxwoods' contribution to the state for the year that ended in June was $190.7 million; Mohegan Sun paid $141.7 million.
In April of next year the 1,200-room Mohegan Sun Hotel will open on the tribe's 240-acre tract with rates starting at $175. Foxwoods has 1,416 rooms in three hotels with rates varying from $110 to $475. The Mohegans' hotel will have a 100,000-square-foot convention center, double the space at Foxwoods, with 30 conference and smaller meeting rooms accommodating up to 5,300 people, a 40,000-square-foot divisible ballroom and a business center. At 480 feet it will be the second tallest building in Connecticut, after the 535-foot City Place office building in Hartford. 
The hotel's glittering 34-story glass towers are nearing completion, offering a stunning first glimpse of the casino to approaching visitors. "Rock and crystal forms that are recurring themes in the Mohegan culture," said Lloyd Sigal, project manager for the architects, Kohn Pedersen Fox, "are expressed in the high-tech reflective glass curtain wall of the hotel that angles at the edges and top."
David Rockwell, head of the Rockwell Group, architectural designers for the interiors of the original casino and the addition, said, "The Mohegans really pushed us to dream of an environment that would amaze people." The result is not for admirers of minimalism. Mohegan tribal art and legend have been filtered through the lens of a Las Vegas gambling palace in a wild array of color and materials.
One outstanding feature is an enormous jagged alabaster and onyx construction inside the casino containing an elevated three-level bar, lounge and dance floor, backlit to look like glowing stone. Patrons can look out at the sea of people, slots and gaming tables or up at a planetarium dome suspended 90 feet above the floor, depicting in fiber-optic images the ever-changing night skies. 
"We used more than 30 million glass beads and a lot of crystalline glass throughout the casino to celebrate that aspect of Mohegan culture," Mr. Rockwell said.
The original portion, called Casino of the Earth, hews to the rustic wood, tent canvas, four-seasons coloring and natural design themes of Indian lore. The new section, called Casino of the Sky, contains a similar layout but interpreted in abstract patterns, terrazzo floors with mother-of-pearl inlays, rich multicolored glass domes defining various spaces and contemporary custom carpeting, furniture and lighting. 
Mark Brown, chairman of the Mohegan Tribal Council, which owns and operates the complex, said, "The new addition represents the future of the tribe; the existing casino tells the history of the tribe." 
OTHER features include an 80-foot-high, 120-foot-wide indoor waterfall; a retail corridor of 27 boutiques, including Lux, Bond & Green jewelers, Swarovski crystal, Brookstone, and Godiva Chocolatier; and some 30 dining establishments ranging from the upscale Rain to Michael Jordan's Steak Housea seafood shack, Bubba's BBQ , Ben & Jerry's, and a fast-food court. 
Blackjack, roulette, craps, baccarat, a total of 6,150 slot machines, several kinds of poker and a 3,000-square-foot high-limit lounge are among a couple of dozen ways to gamble. A full-service area for betting on live events taking place elsewhere has 220 self-wagering carrels and 300 television screens for viewing live horse racing at Belmont, Aqueduct and Saratoga as well as greyhound racing and jai alai.
On the roster of entertainers, Tony Bennett is to be featured in the 300-seat cabaret Nov. 9 through 11. In the 10,000-seat arena, which is also a venue for basketball, boxing, other sports and exhibitions, Gloria Estefan and Tim McGraw are to perform on Nov. 9.
Children of patrons have their own entertainment complex called Kids' Quest, for ages 6 weeks through 12 years. A nonviolent video arcade and an activities center cost $6 an hour per child.
Mohegan Sun was developed by Trading Cove Associates, a partnership of Sol Kerzner, chairman of Sun International of South Africa, developer of casinos and resorts worldwide, and Len Wolman, president of the Waterford Hotel Group in Waterford, Conn., builder and manager of 16 hotels in Connecticut and 10 more in nine states from Vermont to Oklahoma. In 1998 Trading Cove relinquished its management contract with the tribal council in return for 5 percent of gross revenues for 15 years beginning last Jan. 1.
"The hotel business in Connecticut," said Simon Flynn, director of the Connecticut Lodging Association, "is off by 30 percent, but southeastern Connecticut is a go-go destination." Studies by Mystic & More! report that hotels in the district have proliferated to 64 today from 22 in 1983.
In addition, a no-frills Microtel Inn, developed by the Konover Hotel Corporation of West Hartford, will open this month at Routes 32 and 2A, with 120 rooms around $100 a night. David Johnson, head of Konover, said, "It is designed to provide accommodation for people who have business or participate in gaming at the casinos."
A Best Western Cristata with 105 rooms ranging from $109 to $200 opened 33 months ago on Route 32. It offers a continental breakfast, indoor pool and round-the-clock limousine service to Mohegan Sun.
In lieu of taxes the casino pays Montville $500,000 a year. "They have been wonderful," the town's mayor, Howard Beetham, said. "They contribute to many nonprofits, and they put up $3 million, or 95 percent of the cost of an area water transmission system. When we were short of money for our youth programs, they sent a check for $2,600, and they bought a new $1,000 oil burner for a woman who lost her husband."
Montville's population of 17,000, which is spread over 45 square miles, formerly depended on two paper mills, two power plants and 700 municipal jobs, according to the mayor. "Now we have more jobs than people to fill them," he said. He estimates that "there are 25 million people within a four-hour radius, and a lot of them who thought about flying vacations will come here instead by car." In the wake of the World Trade Center and Pentagon attacks, business in the casino declined for about a week, but it has since picked up again, Mohegan Sun officials said.
"I grew up here," Mayor Beetham said, "with a Mohegan family living next door to our farm -- side by side for over 80 years. My uncle left some money in trust for their church. He was a farmer -- not rich. He died in 1993. If he were to wake up today, he might ask for a refund."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The 1,200-room Mohegan Sun Hotel towers over the original casino. (George Ruhe for The New York Times) Map of Ledyard, Connecticut

HEADLINE: Wallace In Wonderland 

BYLINE:  By Amy M. Spindler; Amy M. Spindler is the style editor of The New York Times Magazine.

 BODY:
Tom Ford counts Brad and Jennifer as friends, but he can't help making a dry reproach on hearing that Wallace Neff is the subject of this piece. "Friends' is a great television show, so Neff must be a great architect," he drawls. Let's just say Neff never got the kind of press, even when he was remodeling Hollywood's most famous mansion, Pickfair, that he's getting these days. 
 Brad Pitt, a bit of an architectural expert, and Jennifer Aniston, of the aforementioned "Friends," have followed in the footsteps of a few tony couples before them, like Mary Pickford and Douglas Fairbanks, Cary Grant and Barbara Hutton, Charlie Chaplin and Paulette Goddard and John Gilbert and Greta Garbo. The Pitts are shacking up in a house designed by Neff, whose work in the early days of Hollywood earned him the moniker "the architect of California's golden age." 
 When world economic conferences are being disrupted by protests against globalization, Neff is certainly an architect for these times. Richard Neutra, whose style of Modernism has become a brand around the world, was his contemporary and in many ways his bete noire. At the end of his life, Neff succumbed to Modernism over regionalism. In fact, homes like the one he designed for Groucho Marx are great examples of Modernism; Bryan Lourd, one of the partners at the Creative Artists Agency, lives in an astonishing Modernist Neff that was restored, with interior designs by Brad Dunning, who also works with Ford (who owns a Neutra, not a Neff). 
But it was Neff's earliest work that was redolent of California's history: Spanish colonial, mission bungalow, film-studio Mediterranean. And it's his earlier work that is what everyone imagines when they think of Hollywood estates.
"In many ways he could be considered the Stanford White of Beverly Hills, catering to deep-pocketed film stars and executives who could well afford and appreciate his romantic architectural stage sets, in which their well-dressed and well-heeled lives are played out," Dunning says of Neff.
Everyone in Los Angeles who cares about such things (which is to say, everyone) thought Pitt, who had already gone through the prerequisite mission phase with a Craftsman compound in Los Feliz, Calif., was going to go Neutra modern. 
Instead, he and Aniston spent $13.5 million on the Norman-style house that was designed by Neff for Fredric March and Florence Eldridge in 1933. It was March's lead role in "Death Takes a Holiday" that Pitt recreated in "Meet Joe Black." Eldridge was an actress who starred with March and Katharine Hepburn in the 1936 John Ford film "Mary of Scotland."
Madonna almost qualifies as a Neff collector. She and Guy Ritchie recently bought one from Diane Keaton for $6.5 million; the Neff she owned in Los Feliz was sold to Jenna Elfman, of "Dharma & Greg." Rupert Murdoch lives in a croissant-shaped Neff -- once ruled by MCA's founder, Jules Stein -- that takes up half a mountaintop. Star brokers like Barry Sloane, who heads Sotheby's division of historic and architecturally significant properties in Beverly Hills, says clients ask for Neff houses by name.
"Of all the historical revival architects who worked in that medium, he had this wonderful theatrical flair, and that's what people love," Sloane says. "The frivolity, the touches he did. He was a master of scale and proportion. Madonna's old house has two of the most well-proportioned public rooms as I've seen anywhere. If you were made to wait and the pope walked in, you would not be surprised. There's a classical proportion; you could be in Rome. He nailed it. It's a transcendent performance."
Taking a Hollywood tour of Neff homes, as I recently did with Dunning, is the closest thing America has to visiting temples in Greece. When Dunning said at the end of the day that he felt he'd been making a Mount Olympus pilgrimage to the temples of our gods, he wasn't exaggerating.
There are the stone posts -- all that is left of the ranch Neff built for King Vidor, who, in 1929, was one of the first directors to be nominated for an Academy Award. (Vidor's manor, also by Neff, is now owned by the film producer Jon Peters.) There's the sweet house Neff designed for Claudette Colbert, perfectly preserved at 615 Faring Road. Dunning points out the detailing above the door. "Look how overexaggerated the pediment is," he says. "It looks like it's from a Warner Brothers cartoon." He gestures to the turned bricks, which make a jagged ruffle around the house's edges. "He was really so sophisticated." The auto court, another repeated Neff touch, arches to the door. "It's so theatrical to have that," he sighs.
Then there is the gatehouse, and the white post fences, the remains of the entire crest above Angelo Drive that was once the grounds of the estate of Frances Marion and Fred Thomson. Marion, one of the first female screenwriters, had been a journalist and employee of William Randolph Hearst, and won two Oscars, writing screenplays for stars like Pickford and Marion Davies. Her husband was a popular cowboy star of the day.
"You really get a sense of how they lived then, even looking at the ruins," Dunning says, as I stand on the roof of his S.U.V., putting dents in, trying to see over the chain-link construction fence surrounding the grounds.
Later, after pondering the day, Dunning adds: "In almost Olympian imagery, Neff's sites of choice were out-of-reach hilltop retreats where anointed bronzed gods and goddesses of the silver screen ruled by fan decree from these dizzying aeries. The legacy has never waned."
Neff, he continues, deftly worked in "Spanish, Italianate, Normandy and, later in his career, Modern, styles -- as easily as the actors he beroofed changed costumes and period pieces."
In her memoir, "Off With Their Heads! A Serio-Comic Tale of Hollywood," Marion describes what it was like to build a showplace in Hollywood with a master like Neff at your side. "High on hilltops, overlooking the Pacific that is rarely pacific, rose the Temples of Mammon, those houses of bastardized architecture built by the motion picture rich." She goes on to describe the lush lives and extravagant spending of the early 1920's, ending with, "And now I must confess, with embarrassment, that Fred Thomson and I built the largest house on the highest hill in Beverly Hills."
They bought 20 acres for $4,500 an acre (after paying $1,500 an acre for the first four). She wanted a little adobe hut. Thomson wanted stables for his horses. Their original architect recommended Neff, she writes, "whose Spanish houses were attracting a great deal of attention in Pasadena." Neff's resulting plans had a stable, which "rose on paper like the Royal Riding Academy in Madrid," a "men's house" for the farmhands ("When it finally loomed up on the treeless scarred hillside it looked like a Vanderbilt summer place to me") and then a "week later Sherwood Forest began moving up the hill."
After her husband had added a waterfall to the grounds to keep the horses cool, Marion put her foot down: "You can run the stable, but I'm going to have that little adobe farmhouse even if it looks like a wart on top of the hill!" She then reconsidered: "The more I thought about my adobe resembling a wart, the more the idea needled me, like a mosquito in your room at night. So I sent for Mr. Wallace Neff. In a short while our hill resembled a gigantic wedding cake. Pine trees studded every tier, while on top rose a huge house with a drawing room two stories and a half high, rare tapestries on the walls, an Aeolian pipe organ, and windows overlooking five acres of lawn. Beautifully laid out on the terrace were a tiled barbecue, an aviary, and a hundred-foot swimming pool. Fred and his horses and I had gone Hollywood!"
Rudolph Valentino was inspired by their efforts to build his own house, Falcon's Lair, just below them; he thought the Sheik should have horses, and added stables, too.
"On our morning rides, reining in our horses to watch the sun climb over the mountains and send long shafts of light into the misty valley below," Marion recalls, "we saw Rudy as a simple peasant boy who, through a trick of Fate, had become the idol of millions."
As the stars of today, who through a trick of fate have become the idols of millions, buy the Neff houses once lived in by icons whose glamorous lives remain a template, new Hollywood is recapturing a bit of the sheen of Hollywood past. From this historical distance, it may be the sophisticated images of the first movie players that seem more glamorous, but it is probably the innocence of the time that appeals the most. A time when a star like Valentino -- the Sexiest Man Alive of his day -- could ride horses through the Hollywood Hills and dream of breeding them as if on an Italian farm back home. "The colony" then needed sets for the lives of the stars, and Neff provided them. But they also needed a community. Everyone was from somewhere else. Everyone was inventing an exciting future from a dull past. Neff's work said California; it said Hollywood; but it also said home.
As Crosby Doe, the architectual expert at Mossler Deasy & Doe real estate, says of the Pitt purchase: "Even that house is not pretentious. It might be grand, but it's not pretentious. Neff houses have a humanity about them."
Hennessey & Ingalls, based in Santa Monica, has published the two definitive guides to Neff's work, "Wallace Neff: Architect of California's Golden Age" and the paperback "Wallace Neff 1895-1982: The Romance of Regional Architecture." The latter has addresses for his remaining homes, some of which are hard to find as shrubs grow and street names change -- but some of which preen like ingenues wanting so badly to be adored beside the mega-mansions encroaching on the once parklike surroundings. They are like Mary Pickford sharing the Beverly Hills stage with Fatty Arbuckle.
Perhaps the grandness of Neff's buildings, tempered by his Looney Tunes touches, comes from the fact that Neff himself always straddled two worlds. He was from old money -- relative to many of his Hollywood clients, that is. His grandfather was Andrew McNally, who founded the publishing house Rand McNally. Neff toured Europe before ending up as Hollywood's favorite architect; Marion and Thomson's house was his first big Hollywood commission. He included on it two heraldic coats of arms: a roll of film over a horse's head, and a horseshoe for good luck. Clearly, he was having some fun, as were his clients.
William Alexander McClung writes in "Landscapes of Desire: Anglo Mythologies of Los Angeles" that the embrace of such flourishes reflects "the lightening of the high Modernist burden and the lifting of the obligation to disapprove of rich people's tastes in building." He adds, "* but something pertinent to L.A. is at work also: the process by which something threatening to the integrity of the culture has been accepted and revalued as essential to that culture."
That process continues. As the 50's and 60's houses immortalized in Modernist coffee-table books are being fervently embraced, and as the Neutra homes vie for attention with the more typical Neffs, Sloane issues a reminder that not everyone gets the Modernist houses yet, 40 years after they were built.
"They expect them to be empty and in black and white, just like in the 1950's case-study photos they've seen," he says. "If I had glasses to put over people's eyes to make things monochromatic, I'd sell a lot more houses. All these people want to live in a Julius Shulman photograph."
Or in the case of Neff, a silent movie.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT: ESSAY; 
The Bubble's Bill Has Come Due

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM

 BODY:
HOLD tight. Don't panic.
 That has been the advice from the investment world after the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. While this is probably sound counsel for most conservative, long-term investors, it may not be what refugees from the bull market need to hear. 
 Actually, the message to stay the course started in March of last year, when the market topped out and then began its fall. Gone were the pep-rally ads, like the memorable Ameritrade commercials featuring the manic, redheaded office boy Stuart, a champion of day trading, who exhorted his fusty boss: "Let's light this candle." Instead, companies like U.S. Trust and Merrill Lynch offered cuddling reassurance to nervous clients that they could leave their candles in the hands of professionals. 
Now we have the crisis ads. Peter Lynch, a vice chairman at Fidelity Investments and the former manager of its giant Magellan fund, said in a recent newspaper advertisement that he did not know what would happen to the markets in the short term, and never really had. But he had faith in the next 5 and 10 years.
Charles Schwab, the founder of the brokerage firm that bears his name, counseled investors, while they waited on hold during calls to the firm, to "invest for the long term" and to "keep your cool during the rough times."
And according to a message on the Web site of Putnam Investments, "The important thing is to remain calm and not to allow the impact of this near-term occurrence to cloud a long-term perspective."
For most people, this is sound advice. But for some, there is little to be gained by maintaining a strategy that never was. In the flush years of the market, Americans acquired all manner of bad habits. Many had a strategy that amounted to "make a killing."
Now, they are paying the price. Some people plowed all their savings -- through 401(k) accounts, employee savings plans and stock options -- into one stock, that of their company. Then the stock plummeted in value and they were laid off. They were left with no jobs and greatly diminished savings.
Investors also used margin -- borrowed money -- to gamble with more dollars than they actually had, only to be pummeled when the market fell. Some investors would buy only Internet stocks and would never consider a stock like Home Depot, an old-economy company, or even a bond. And average people started acting like hedge fund managers, using strategies like short-selling, futures and options.
"I have a lot of what were instant millionaires who are back to being normal people," said Lewis J. Altfest, a financial planner in Manhattan, referring to some of his newer clients.
Now investors are rediscovering conservative investments like bonds. But if there is a mass movement to bonds, it may not shed any light on whether investors are practicing diversification. Rather, the bird's-eye view suggests that many investors are continuing to run from whatever fell yesterday and to whatever went up yesterday, the opposite of "buy low, sell high."
Figuring the right balance of risk and reward will become even more important. Increasingly, the retirement savings system is moving from one that is overseen by professional investors to one managed by average Americans. 
The State of Florida, for example, will soon offer its employees the closest thing to a 401(k) plan that any state government has come up with, and it could be a prelude to similar plans from other states. And for years, corporations have been trimming traditional pension plans, leaving workers to juggle 401(k) assets. That is not necessarily bad, but it will require people to make complicated choices.
IN short, prudent planning is becoming everybody's business. 
"This is a terrible time to change, but if you've done it all wrong, there's no point in doing it all wrong forever," said John C. Bogle, the founder of the Vanguard Group and creator of the first index mutual fund.
Finding a strategy is not easy. There are financial planners, investing books, magazines, newsletters and software programs that handicap your chances of having enough money to retire when you want. There are rules of thumb, like subtracting your age from 100 and using the answer as the percentage you should invest in stocks. (That would be 70 percent for a 30-year-old, for example.)
No such rules really work, says Roy Diliberto, a Philadelphia financial planner, except for the idea of diversification. Mr. Bogle, 72, says software programs, like those offered by Financial Engines of Palo Alto, Calif., or Morningstar of Chicago, imply that finances can be reduced to an easy science. An investor's best bet, he said, is to use a 50-50 split between stocks and bonds as an axis over a lifetime, and, if they need help, to choose a fee-based financial planner who does not have incentives to sell certain products.
Mr. Bogle invested about 70 percent to 75 percent of his assets in stocks and the remainder in bonds from 1951 through the mid-1990's. Then he had a heart attack and thought it was time to shift into a retirement portfolio, with about 35 percent in stocks and the rest in bonds. For investors ready to dig out of a miscast strategy, he advises starting with half of their invested assets, and moving incrementally.
"I would start today," he said.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
After the Attacks, Which Side Is the Left On?

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL KAZIN; Michael Kazin, who teaches history at Georgetown University, is co-author of "America Divided: The Civil War of the 1960's."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
BEFORE Sept. 11, American progressives had reason to hope they might be emerging from the political wilderness. After years of bitter squabbles over identity politics and the merits of the Clinton administration, the left appeared to have reclaimed its anti-corporate heritage and was growing.
 For the first time since the 1930's, student activists and labor officials championed the same causes. At dozens of colleges, groups sought to curb sweatshop manufacturing in the developing world and to demand a living wage for employees at home. Organizers were predicting 100,000 protesters, including many union members, would be in Washington in late September during the annual meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. 
 Progressives inside and outside the Democratic Party exulted that President Bush's poll ratings were not much higher than the percentage of the vote he had won a year before and that his administration seemed without a purpose beyond cutting taxes. Chances looked good that a liberal coalition could help take back the House of Representatives in 2002 and maybe the White House in 2004.
Those hopes, and the prospect of a unified left, disappeared along with so much else in the wake of the Sept. 11 attack. While labor leaders and liberal lawmakers endorse the administration's anti-terrorist campaign, radical foes of global capital on college campuses and the streets talk of peace and try to grasp why many in the Islamic world seem to hate the United States.
In pleading their case, each segment of the left evokes the metaphors of an earlier war -- using two very different examples. For the embattled new peace movement, the war is Vietnam; for anti-terrorist liberals, it is World War II.
Indeed, the arguments of many peace activists echo those New Leftists made 30 years ago. "The fear and desperation that grows sic from poverty and oppression is crucial to any understanding of violence throughout the world," says a group called the Anti-Capitalist Convergence. Even symbols of the earlier movement are making a comeback -- an ad in The Nation features the peace symbol, now colored red, white and blue. 
Accused of being anti-American, peace demonstrators respond that they are upholding the most humane of secular and spiritual ideals -- protection of the innocent in a world where the gulf between the rich and poor is ever widening. As with Vietnam, radicals accuse American policymakers of caring about acts of mass slaughter only when their own citizens are its victims.
Meanwhile, most liberals and a few chastened radicals view the Sept. 11 attacks through the prism of World War II. For them, Osama bin Laden and the Taliban represent what the author Christopher Hitchens labels, "fascism with an Islamic face." Echoing the words of Mr. Bush, the anti-terrorist left maintains there is a moral imperative to defend a society that remains, whatever its flaws, a pillar of ethnic and religious pluralism and representative democracy. 
Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, entered politics as an opponent of the Vietnam War and the nuclear arms race. But the religious zealots who destroyed the World Trade Center and blasted the Pentagon remind the Jewish liberal of the Nazis; she vows "to stop that from happening again." Labor officials now struggling to help the families of the hundreds of union workers killed on Sept. 11 -- cooks and waiters, janitors and security guards, as well as firemen and police -- are hardly inclined to disagree.
This is no time to talk of peace, such progressives insist, before action is taken to punish those who planned the attacks and prevent them from committing further carnage. Repeating a charge hurled against isolationists 60 years earlier, liberals accuse opponents to their left of being naive about the threat posed to a system in which a culture of opposition can flourish.
This debate within the left also parallels divisions evident in earlier wars. In the 20th century, visionary altruists were both the leaders of America during each major conflict and spearheaded the opposition.
In 1917, President Woodrow Wilson insisted American troops were needed to make the world "safe for democracy," while pacifists and Socialists charged the doughboys were only protecting the profits of munitions makers and British imperialists. In 1940, leftists and isolationists made a similar indictment against Franklin D. Roosevelt when he urged passage of Lend-Lease and the revival of the draft. (It took the attack on Pearl Harbor to squelch or convert his opponents.) In 1965, most progressive Democrats backed Lyndon B. Johnson's decision to defend the "freedom" of South Vietnam, while young radicals argued that the liberal president was using American power to crush a war of independence against foreign rule.
EACH of these ruptures affected the future of American politics in significant ways. The divisions over World War I and Vietnam -- unpopular wars -- helped conservative Republicans dominate Congress and the White House in the 1920's and most of the 1970's and 80's. But most progressives backed World War II as a battle against the enemies of freedom, and their cherished causes of industrial unionism and racial tolerance gained as the fighting raged
Now, though President Bush is a Republican, he is using words saturated with historic left ideals to win the confidence of many Americans. In his address to Congress, the president condemned the Taliban for barring women from school and prohibiting any religious doctrine but their own. He has also condemned acts of prejudice against Arab-Americans and wants to help unemployed workers pay for health insurance. Mr. Bush's oratory of war sounds a good deal like the reformist internationalism that guided the foreign policy of Democratic presidents from Wilson to Bill Clinton.
Anti-terrorist liberals hope the war will be limited and that, as after Pearl Harbor, the communal spirit that has animated New Yorkers and other Americans since Sept. 11 will stir a desire to ease domestic injustices. Antiwar radicals want Americans to put down their flags and address the global ills that the demonstrations in Washington were intended to dramatize.
But activists on both sides fear their chance to build a new left may already have passed.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Trying to Fight Two Wars at Once

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
PRESIDENT BUSH has discovered how hard it is to fight two wars at once.
 Since the attacks he has been trying to steel Americans for a protracted struggle against an elusive foe, warning that "a lengthy campaign, unlike any other we have ever seen" lies ahead. The stock market reeled. 
 Last week, Mr. Bush also stood at Reagan National Airport, a runway's length from the Pentagon, and took on another threat. He said the airport should reopen immediately as a "symbol that America is back in business." The Secret Service, worried about the security risk, cringed. But the stock market surged. 
The administration is battling both global terrorism and economic malaise and is taking some friendly fire. Defeating terrorism requires unprecedented vigilance by airport security and border control agents, passengers on planes and buses, and bank managers who must assume any person could be suspect. Reviving the economy requires more risk-taking by investors, tourists and consumers who believe that the world is small and tomorrow will bring greater prosperity.
America will never be the same. The American way of life will never die. It is tricky to have it both ways.
"When you are telling people that we have a new, unsettled world it makes it that much harder to sustain a sense of well-being," said James R. Schlesinger, the former defense secretary who is now a senior advisor at Lehman Brothers, an investment bank. "The idea of a higher level of tension is not conducive to the sort of consumer confidence we have grown accustomed to."
The insidious challenge of terrorism is that America's leaders have to project caution and optimism. They try to persuade people that the world has changed, requiring heightened levels of security in everything from cyberspace to buses. Yet consumers should also act as if everything is fine -- pile up credit card debt, buy a dream house or take the kids to Disneyland. 
The matter is so touchy because in times of crisis the president and his cabinet have unusual sway over mass psychology, and psychology drives the American economy. Consumer spending and business investment account for the vast majority of economic activity, and they fluctuate depending on how much confidence people have in the future. The United States has had the world's strongest economy, at least in part because it is home to the world's most optimistic people.
Franklin D. Roosevelt appealed to that optimism with his exhortation during the Depression, "the only thing we have to fear is fear itself." So did Ronald Reagan with his "Morning in America" campaign.
Mr. Bush and his team have a tougher task. They cannot blithely claim tomorrow will be a better day when the nation faces the possibility of a cycle of terrorism and retaliation. Complacency could be an enemy in that struggle. Yet the administration is also starting to worry that all its war planning damages consumer confidence, which many economists believe has dropped sharply from already depressed levels.
Not coincidentally, Mr. Bush is now seen more in settings designed to rebuild confidence. His public agenda last week included meetings with Congressional leaders to discuss the budget. He flew to New York to announce his support for a big dose of stimulus spending. He dined out at a steak house in Washington.
But with every word being parsed, he and other top officials have to strike a delicate balance. Attorney General John Ashcroft wanted to pressure Congress to grant him new security powers when he warned that Americans had by no means seen the end of terrorist attacks at home. "There is a very serious threat of additional problems and, frankly, as the United States responds, that threat may escalate," he said.
After gas-mask sales soared and Wall Street traders blamed the comments for Monday's sell-off, administration officials scrambled. Mr. Ashcroft's warning was not based on fresh intelligence, they said. Mr. Ashcroft tried to soothe nerves. "There shouldn't be a cultural paralysis that curtails our activities," he said.
It is too early to assume the economy is paralyzed, of course. The terrorist attacks, themselves, probably did no more damage to overall output than a serious earthquake or hurricane. Reconstruction spending could actually boost the economy in some areas. The Federal Reserve's rapid-fire interest rate cuts should, ultimately, encourage people to borrow money at historically low rates and spend or invest it. Meanwhile, Congress is set to approve tens of billions of dollars in new spending.
BUT if Mr. Bush is right about a long struggle against a resilient enemy, the downturn could persist longer than it otherwise would.
Exuberance fired the 1990's boom, with consumers and businesses spending freely on the promise of ever-greater returns. That bubble was deflating even before the twin towers fell, adding fear to the mix. Economic models suggest low interest rates will eventually stoke consumer and business spending. But models do not measure emotion well, and few economists dare predict when people will stop feeling vulnerable.
Other countries have grappled with terrorism. The Irish Republican Army bombed shopping malls in London. Basque terrorists have tried to destabilize Spain. Suicide attacks are a daily reality in Israel.
But there is a chance that Americans will start acting like the Japanese, whose confidence levels have fallen for a decade. Despite interest rates at zero and a government that has generated gigantic deficits to fuel economic activity, the Japanese lost faith in their economic prospects. Few trust the promises of their leaders to deliver a better future.
The risk is not negligible. The Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, was criticized early on for predicting that stocks would rally (they slumped) and that the economy would avoid recession (most economists agree one is inevitable). No one faults him for sounding optimistic, but there is a fine line between upbeat and glib, and some critics felt he crossed it. Searching for a beacon on stability, Congress invited a former Treasury secretary, Robert E. Rubin, to consult on remedies.
Now, Mr. O'Neill has sought to send a sober message about the interplay between the terrorist threat and the economic slump. He said Americans, like their leaders, will have to be cautious and confident.
"In a society like ours, that's marked by freedom and individual liberty," he said, "we've got to be able to assure people that they're not at huge risk to malevolent, terrible people. Then I would say that our economy is so strong and our potential is so great, that whatever the cost is, we'll suck it up and be able to absorb it."

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL: NOTEBOOK; 
Sprewell Is Repeating His Familiar Lament

BYLINE:  By MIKE WISE

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 6 

 BODY:
Latrell Sprewell is not buying the theory that the Knicks have enough to win the Eastern Conference. His belief has nothing to do with his confidence in his teammates. It is more about their collective size, he said.
 "We are thin up front," Sprewell, a four-time All-Star, said Friday as the Knicks wrapped up their fifth day of training camp here. "So I'm not going to sit up here and say we're a finals team right now. I don't necessarily feel that. I feel we have the potential to probably work towards that. But realistically, probably not. I'm just being straightforward." 
 Sprewell's we're-not-big-enough mantra has been running on for a while, ever since he publicly urged the Knicks to acquire his friend and former teammate Chris Webber, the league's premier power forward. 
But as another season of small ball nears for the Knicks, the lament is starting to fester. "I look at some of the other teams, and on paper they're a lot better than us," he said. "We're going to have to do a lot of work. We can't kid ourselves. I'm not trying to kid myself. We're going to have to work really hard to bring ourselves up to the level of some of these other teams. Some of them are really loaded."
Asked if he felt the need had to be addressed soon, he added: "I would've thought that last year. We've been small for a while now. It's no secret that this team needs size. I said it last year. I'm saying it this year. So I still feel that way until we actually get bigger. 
"We're just going to have to make up for that lack of size with a bunch of hustle, a lot of togetherness and a lot of playing well. If we go out there and don't play well, it's not going to be a pretty sight for us. We're going to have to shoot well and defend well and find a way to rebound well."
For what it is worth, General Manager Scott Layden has for months been scouring the league for a bona fide big man. Before the season begins, the Knicks would like to part with three complementary role players -- as they did to acquire Sprewell in 1999 -- to trade for a quality post player or an elite point guard. But then, so does everybody else.

Jordan vs. Carter
During the 2000 playoffs, Michael Jordan casually said he believed Kobe Bryant was a more complete player than Vince Carter. What seemed like a fair opinion at the time -- Bryant's Lakers were rolling and Carter had had a miserable series against the Knicks -- has ballooned into the absurd.
At his news conference last Monday, Jordan mentioned Bryant and Tracy McGrady as players he is looking forward to challenging in his return. The omission of Carter was brought up by a Toronto reporter, who wondered if Jordan had not issued "a bit of a snub."
"That's you guys," Jordan said. "I'm pretty sure I could have mentioned a lot of names. Everybody thinks I'm trying to omit Vince. I'm not. I didn't mention Iverson, but I don't hear anybody mention anything about Iverson. I think people are just trying to make this little competition between me and Vince." 
Jordan added: "He's a University of North Carolina guy. So am I. I respect him. He's made great strides in improvement and he will continue to improve. But there's no competition in that aspect. And if I forgot to mention him in the press conference, it was just to make it a point that I mentioned the other names. So don't try to make something out of nothing."
There is some history, but it is old and tired. After Jordan's comments in spring 2000, Carter's mother, Michelle, responded that August.
"Michael Jordan is entitled to his opinion just like I am entitled to mine," she said. "Now I have my opinion why Michael Jordan made so public his negative evaluation of Vince's game.
"One day when I meet Michael face to face, believe me, I would like to discuss that with him. If you think Kobe Bryant is a better player, wonderful. There are others who think Vince Carter is a better player. And who is better doesn't really make any difference. Kobe is a fantastic player. Vince is a fantastic player."
At any rate, by the time Jordan faces off against Carter -- the Raptors play the Wizards in a preseason game on Oct. 25 -- the Michael-disrespects-Vince hype will be beyond control.
You wonder if people do not have better things to worry about.

Mason Still Waiting
Day 5, Anthony Mason unemployed. This is not exactly stunning news, either. But when an All-Star forward fresh off a huge season cannot find decent compensation for his talent, it brings up a couple of issues.
Either Mason's stock is terribly low or this luxury-tax matter is really hurting his chances of landing with a team.
Mason's agent, Don Cronson, emphatically said his client would not play for anything less than the midlevel exception in Milwaukee -- roughly $20.8 million over four years.
The Bucks are hedging because they do not want to pay a league-imposed tax for going over the salary cap, which is a bit of a misnomer.
For one, the players this season are kicking back $180 million of their salaries into an escrow fund, to be distributed to all 29 teams. That's about $6.2 million a team. 
Two Eastern Conference executives, on condition of anonymity, said the league was proposing to penalize teams over the luxury tax by refunding only 90 percent of that escrow-fund money this season. Next season, the total would be about 70 percent and the following, 40 percent.
Neither the league nor the union will confirm these figures -- or that it is referred to as the Paul Allen Rule -- but the idea is to strongly encourage owners like Portland's Allen, a billionaire co-founder of Microsoft, not to overspend ridiculously.
Still, if escrow money refunded begins to balance out money lost on luxury tax, how is using an exception such a huge deal? 
"You know what? The N.B.A. is the National Beancounters Association," Cronson said. "Or the National Bottom-Line Association."
Cronson is not the only player agent who wonders aloud why the league refers to its over-the-cap signings as "exceptions," when, in fact, they are counted against the luxury tax.
"What's wrong with the midlevel exception -- any exception for that matter -- without the encumbrance of a luxury tax?" he said. "The exception should be the exception. This would not be a huge number and it would help mostly the older veterans, which is what the collective bargaining agreement was supposed to accomplish."
From Cronson's point of view, Mason, a former Knick, was his client from the beginning, from Springfield Gardens, Queens, to outback leagues in Turkey, Argentina and beyond. Now that Mason is 34, Cronson wants at least one more long-term contract for his friend and client, to reward his perseverance on the court.
Yet what is the great crime in playing one season of pro basketball for $1 million, the veteran exception for which Michael Jordan will play this season?

Abdur-Rahim's Donations
Troubled by the terrorist attacks, Atlanta's All-Star forward Shareef Abdur-Rahim last week told The Atlanta Journal-Constitution that he had persuaded several of his peers to donate several hundred thousand dollars to survivors before the season is over.
With the help of his management team, Abdur-Rahim recruited Stephon Marbury, Gary Payton, Damon Stoudamire, Brian Grant and Alonzo Mourning to support his cause.
Abdur-Rahim and Grant will donate $100 for each rebound this season, Payton, Stoudamire and Marbury $100 for each assist. Mourning will donate $100 for every blocked shot. If they duplicate last season's statistics, the six would pool $336,300 toward relief efforts.
"I'm trying to get some corporations to join us and underwrite our efforts and contribute with us," Abdur-Rahim said. "We would like to make this thing as significant as we can."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE VICE PRESIDENT; 
Out Front or Low Profile, Cheney Keeps Powerful Role

BYLINE:  By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 

 BODY:
Five days after the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington, Vice President Dick Cheney gave a riveting account on television of his role in the first hours of the crisis, including how President Bush followed his advice to order fighter jets to shoot down any rogue airliner that threatened the Capitol or White House. 
 Since then, Mr. Cheney has all but vanished from public view, leaving Mr. Bush and his cabinet secretaries to spell out the administration's goals in the war on terrorism.
 In a rare public appearance on Friday, Mr. Cheney stood dutifully next to Mr. Bush at a Rose Garden ceremony as the president announced the administration's new tax cut proposal. Mr. Cheney looked more rested than Mr. Bush, but he left all the talking to his boss. 
The television appearance the Sunday after the attacks may have left the impression that the vice president was the man in command at the White House, an image he has apparently sought to dispel by keeping a low profile since then. But behind the scenes, Mr. Cheney continues to play a major role as war minister, uber diplomat, political adviser and consigliere to President Bush, lawmakers, military officials and top White House aides say. 
Mr. Cheney was one of the leading administration voices urging Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, who loathes traveling abroad, to visit Saudi Arabia, Uzbekistan, Oman, Turkey and Egypt this week to work out military logistics and meet defense leaders in the region. He telephones Mr. Rumsfeld, his mentor from the Ford administration, two to three times a day. 
Mr. Bush followed Mr. Cheney's recommendation to announce the creation of the Office of Homeland Security in a speech to a joint meeting of Congress on Sept. 20. Mr. Cheney also advised that Tom Ridge, the Republican governor of Pennsylvania and longtime Bush ally, fill the new cabinet-level post as head of the office. 
When a bipartisan deal aimed at avoiding a fight over government spending for 2002 began to unravel on Capitol Hill last week, Mr. Cheney was dispatched to negotiate with House Democrats and quell a revolt among House conservatives, who were angry that the accord increased spending next year by several billion more than Mr. Bush requested. Working the phones and twisting arms, he succeeded. 
"Whenever Cheney's in there, you know they're serious," said David Sirota, a spokesman for Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the ranking Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee and the last holdout on the spending deal. "He's the heavy in the administration." 
It is the multidimensional role that Mr. Bush had in mind for Mr. Cheney, a 60-year-old former secretary of defense, White House chief of staff and House Republican leader, when he picked him as his political partner last year. 
With few political appointees in place in the administration's early days, Mr. Cheney seemed to run the government almost single-handedly. But the vice president's influence appeared to wane over the summer after he underwent his third cardiac procedure since November, and the national energy plan he supervised was criticized for giving short shrift to conservation measures. 
Any doubts about Mr. Cheney's star power ended abruptly after his command performance on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" on Sept. 16. Not only did he relate vivid details of ordering the evacuation of Congressional leaders and cabinet members, but he also delivered a blunt, clinical assessment of the war ahead. 
In fact, some prominent Republicans said, the interview with the program's host, Tim Russert, was just a bit too commanding for senior White House aides like Karl Rove and Karen P. Hughes. In allowing Mr. Cheney to describe his role, the aides walked a fine line between reaffirming the vice president's stature and having him overshadow the president. 
"He went on Russert with the best of intentions -- to be part of an orchestrated campaign to calm the nation's nerves," said an administration adviser who is close to Mr. Cheney. "He succeeded. But he may have rattled the nerves of some of the people right around the president, like Rove and Hughes." 
Mr. Rove and Ms. Hughes have denied being upset or concerned with Mr. Cheney's interview. But Mr. Cheney has not given any interviews since then. 
Mary Matalin, Mr. Cheney's chief political adviser, said the vice president would make some public comments in the coming week. The White House's communications strategy until now has been to put Mr. Bush out front, supported by cabinet members like Secretary of State Colin L. Powell or Attorney General John Ashcroft, she said. 
"He's a 'special use' communicator," Ms. Matalin said. "It would be a waste of resources to have him out there every day." 
All of which befits Mr. Cheney's view of the vice presidency, say friends and associates. 
"Cheney's been extremely careful, because he and Rumsfeld are the inventors of the 'there can only be one president' doctrine," said the administration adviser close to Mr. Cheney. "They insisted to Ford that the word leader is singular and not plural. This reflects Cheney's belief. The vice president is different from a cabinet secretary. As such, he has to play a different kind of role, and there can't be confusion about who the leader is. And there isn't." 
As the loyal and trusted adviser, Mr. Cheney has never been far from Mr. Bush's beck and call since Sept. 11. His only significant trip was last weekend, when he and his wife, Lynne, slipped away to Wyoming for a reunion of old friends. 
Otherwise, it is a job that begins at 8 a.m. in the Oval Office, where Mr. Cheney sits down for coffee with the president and his national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, and, increasingly, the director of central intelligence, George J. Tenet, to review world affairs and the latest intelligence reports on terrorism. 
Since the attacks, Mr. Bush has convened his National Security Council at about 10 a.m. in the White House situation room every weekday, with Mr. Cheney seated just to his right. Those who attend say Mr. Cheney saves his most candid advice for Mr. Bush alone, making it difficult to pin down Mr. Cheney's precise thinking. The two men have continued their weekly private lunch during the crisis. 
Ms. Matalin said that the punishing schedule had not affected Mr. Cheney's health, and that doctors assigned to him around the clock monitor him closely. He exercises several times a week on a treadmill.
As the military preparations fall into place for a strike against targets in Afghanistan, Mr. Cheney has reached out to other members of a national security team that presided over the 1991 Persian Gulf war under Mr. Bush's father, President George Bush. The vice president talks almost daily with Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz, his top foreign policy adviser when he was defense secretary, and occasionally with Mr. Powell, a former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. 
Ten days ago, Mr. Cheney, a former member of the House Intelligence Committee, spent three hours at C.I.A. headquarters receiving classified briefings on counterterrorism and other subjects. 
"He fuses all the major elements together," said one top Pentagon official. "He knows how the press plays. He knows Capitol Hill like the back of his hand. And he has all that experience from the gulf war." 
Mr. Cheney has emphasized to Mr. Bush the importance of building coalitions, and since the attacks has met with the foreign ministers of Italy and China, as well as the emir of Qatar, Sheik Hamad Bin Khalifa Thani and President Eduard A. Shevardnadze of Georgia. 
"He's reinforcing the president's instincts to reach out," said Brent Scowcroft, national security adviser to Mr. Bush's father. 
On Capitol Hill, Mr. Cheney has been a prime, if low-key, force behind the administration's proposals on counterterrorism, economic stimulus and aviation safety. 
Last Tuesday, Mr. Cheney met privately with Speaker J. Dennis Hastert and half a dozen other House Republican leaders to review domestic policy and the campaign against terrorism. 
But it was his appearance at the Senate Democrats' weekly lunch that caused an even bigger stir. Democrats who before the attacks had griped about Mr. Cheney's partisanship, gave him a standing ovation, to which Mr. Cheney responded deadpan, "I wish I was treated this well by some of the Republican caucuses I've been to."
