HEADLINE: Some See Giuliani as Right for an Emergency, but Wrong for Rebuilding 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has long been admired for his crime-fighting skills at a time when the city seemed ungovernable, and more recently for his dynamic leadership in the wake of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.
 But now, looking to the future, a number of urban planners and real estate executives say that Mr. Giuliani -- like Winston Churchill at the end of World War II -- is not the man to lead the city's rebuilding effort as the head of an expected city-state commission on reconstruction. 
 The mayor has been brilliant and resolute in leading the city through the recent crisis, they say, but he did not bring his laserlike focus to economic development during his two terms in office. And they wish he had been faster in moving from dealing with the emergency to developing a broad-based strategy for reconstructing Lower Manhattan. 
"In 1945, British voters said, 'Winnie, we love you; thanks for winning the war, but now we need someone else to secure the peace,' " said Robert D. Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association, a group that deals with development issues. "Rudy, who never had a commitment to big transportation or development projects in the city, has been our Winston Churchill. He goes into history as the mayor who brought us through this tragic period. But as with Churchill, people are ready for someone else to rebuild the city."
Deputy Mayor Robert Harding dismissed the criticisms, saying the administration had used targeted tax breaks to encourage investment and presided over record job growth. "For the first time in memory, the city has outpaced the nation in job growth for the past two years," Mr. Harding said. "That's not to diminish the fact that crime reduction was an economic catalyst."
Mr. Yaro's comments were echoed by several developers and executives in the real estate industry, which has contributed generously to Mr. Giuliani's campaigns and provided considerable political support.
Often Republican but fundamentally pragmatic, many developers and brokers decided as an industry to raise $250,000 for each of the four major Democratic mayoral candidates before last month's primary. Now that the Democratic field has narrowed, many real estate executives say they will support Mark Green because they object to the oft-stated suggestion by his opponent, Fernando Ferrer, that the city should encourage decentralization of the financial industry to places other than Lower Manhattan. 
While not discounting Mr. Giuliani's successes in fighting crime, many said they have been frustrated by his seeming lack of interest in a coherent, thoughtful economic development policy. But few are willing to speak for attribution about the future because, they said, the mayor is a lame duck with a sharp bite.
Even one of Manhattan's more prolific developers, who favored extending Mr. Giuliani's term for the sake of continuity, said the mayor would be the wrong person to head the rebuilding effort. "He's not really the right guy," the developer said. "He's great for crime and safety."
The city has acted quickly to resolve some emergency problems. Bruce Warwick, president of Columbus Center LLC, the developer building the AOL Time Warner project at Columbus Circle, credited the Giuliani administration with moving swiftly last week to identify a site for a temporary concrete plant on the waterfront near West 57th Street after traffic tie-ups prevented hundreds of concrete trucks from reaching Manhattan construction sites. "I have found that this administration really wants to be helpful when there are problems," Mr. Warwick said.
At the mayor's morning staff meetings, Mr. Giuliani moves quickly around the room quizzing each of his commissioners on the status of the cleanup downtown, the reopening of streets and the distribution of death certificates. But, said one participant, there is little or no discussion about a strategy for retaining corporations displaced by the attack or about economic development plans.
The president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, Michael Carey, said the city was working with displaced companies, trying to come up with an incentive package as well as plans for rebuilding the neighborhood. "We understand the urgency," Mr. Carey said. "We are talking to the state and federal government, trying to come up with something that makes the most sense. Hopefully, in the not-too-distant future we'll come up with an across-the-board program."
Real estate brokers and business executives acknowledged that the immediate tasks are daunting and time-consuming, so it may be hard for the administration to quickly develop an incentive plan to keep companies in New York City, especially when it is unclear how much federal aid there will be and how it can be used. But they said they wished that Mr. Giuliani or his deputy mayors would make reassuring telephone calls to chief executives at companies like American Express and Morgan Stanley, which is looking for up to 500,000 square feet of office space in New Jersey. Morgan Stanley is also negotiating to sell its 38-story tower nearing completion at Seventh Avenue and 50th Street to Lehman Brothers for $700 million, according to a real estate broker who was briefed on the talks.
Hugh O'Neil, an economic development consultant and a former executive with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said the Giuliani administration has not "in any active sense" ever focused on economic development. The mayor supported the resurgence of Times Square in recent years, Mr. O'Neil said, but that was a state project that dated to 1982. A buoyant economy fueled job growth and residential construction, which the mayor encouraged, but few initiatives consumed Mr. Giuliani's attention.
Fred Siegel, a history professor at Cooper Union who regards Mr. Giuliani as one of the city's great mayors, conceded that economic development "was not his strong point," though Mr. Siegel said the administration was able to steer technology firms to Brooklyn and Queens, at least before the industry collapsed.
"There was a tendency to focus a lot of energy on issues and projects that are not central to the future needs of the economy, like baseball stadiums and the cross-harbor rail tunnel," Mr. O'Neil said. "The mayor deserves credit for creating an environment that helped make the expansion of the last six or seven years possible. But as that winds down, there's a need for a vision of where the city's economy might be headed and how we can build on its strengths to capture the next round of growth."
In 1994, when Mr. Giuliani entered office, the crime rate, while starting to fall, was still high enough to scare tourists and business executives. He focused on regaining control of the streets, reducing crime and solving quality-of-life issues. Although police tactics sometimes alienated residents of black and Hispanic neighborhoods, his strategy ultimately helped encourage investment in New York and the tourism boom.
But, urban planners and developers said, Mr. Giuliani often delegated economic development issues to his deputies, who had little power. And the mayor was at odds with Gov. George E. Pataki on virtually every economic development issue in the city, an impasse that delayed or killed projects like the expansion of the convention center, the Second Avenue subway, the redevelopment of Times Square and Columbus Circle and the Queens West project.
They said that the mayor was also slow to react in 1998 when big companies began moving some operations to New Jersey because of Manhattan's shortage of office space. Last summer, the administration and the City Council put into place a package of tax breaks designed to encourage companies to move to Downtown Brooklyn and Long Island City, rather than New Jersey.
"They passed a program after the recession set in and 10 million square feet of office space had migrated to Jersey City," said one developer with close ties to the administration. "After a decade of prosperity we should have more to show for it than a 7,000-seat stadium in Coney Island."
That is why many developers say that while they maintain ties to the administration, which controls discretionary permits and tax incentives, they also want to see someone else in charge of a plan for future economic development.
"The mayor's style is command and control," said Elliott D. Sclar, director of the urban planning program at Columbia University. "He handles emergencies brilliantly. But the mayor we need is someone who can do things collaboratively, not just in the city but in the region. The financial services industry has been oozing out of Manhattan for years. The real challenge is going to be to redefine Lower Manhattan as the center of a regional financial services industry."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED; 
Diversity, and Complexity, Of the Muslim World

 BODY:
 From its origin in what is now Saudi Arabia, Islam has spread throughout the world, and is now as ethnically diverse as it is geographically broad. Many governments are faced with increasingly radical, and violent, Islamic elements. Here is a broad look at the geography of the Muslim world and its often charged internal politics.

HEADLINE: AN OVERVIEW: OCT. 6, 2001; 
Warnings to the Taliban, Diplomatic Difficulties and Israeli Concerns

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN

 BODY:
"Time is running out," President Bush warned the Taliban government in Afghanistan, and as if to underline those words, the military action that is coming took more defined shape.

THE DEPLOYMENT -- American forces continued to mobilize in and around Central Asia, with troops moving into Uzbekistan, on Afghanistan's northern border. Other forces advanced by air and sea.
 But even though the United States wants and needs partners in its campaign against Osama bin Laden and the Taliban, it became increasingly clear that it is also prepared to strike against terrorists and their patrons largely on its own. An emerging reality is that Washington may have little alternative. 

THE DIPLOMACY -- Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld returned home after visiting five friendly nations in the region without any getting any assurances -- in public, at least -- that the American military will be able to launch strikes into Afghanistan from their territory.

On the contrary. Countries like Uzbekistan and Saudi Arabia signaled that their airfields would be available to support American operations but not to serve as bases for the warplanes that will actually fly into Afghanistan. In Uzbekistan, for example, airfields may be used for search-and-rescue operations or to bring in supplies for American forces.
 Is that level of support satisfactory to the Bush administration? Apparently yes, if only because this may be as good as it gets, given the political constraints that each of those countries feels. But administration officials sounded confident that they had gotten enough of what is needed, for what will probably be a long and unpredictable war against Mr. bin Laden's Al Qaeda terrorist network and his Taliban patrons.
 Besides, some officials said, there could be a certain advantage to Washington's status as something of a lone wolf in this campaign. Maintaining coalitions is not easy, as was shown by the 1999 war in Kosovo and by the war in the Persian Gulf a decade ago. As one senior administration official put it, "The fewer people you have to rely on, the fewer permissions you have to get."

THE ALLIANCE -- Still, in this operation, the Americans are forced to build alliances with tricky components. One complication is the need to get help from Arab states while nursing Washington's relations with Israel.
 On that front, strains continued after a series of unpleasant exchanges over open Bush administration support for a Palestinian state. Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel warned Mr. Bush that he risked appeasing the Arabs the way European nations appeased Hitler in the 1930's, a comparison dismissed by the White House as unacceptable.
 By the weekend, the Israelis sought to calm the situation, with Foreign Minister Shimon Peres calling the harsh words "an exception to the rule" of a strong American-Israeli relationship. But that did not end obvious differences between the two countries on how the anti-terrorism coalition should go about its business.

THE INTELLIGENCE -- It certainly will not be business as usual, said George J. Tenet, the American director of central intelligence. He was not referring to Middle East politics, though. Rather, Mr. Tenet said that in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the C.I.A. and other intelligence agencies had to end their squabbling and turf wars. There was not nearly enough coordination and sharing of information, the director said.
 "If there is some bureaucratic hurdle, leap it," he said in a memo dated Sept. 16. Its title made his main point succinctly: "We're at War."

THE ECONOMY -- Also looking for fundamental change was the American insurance industry, which followed the lead of the airlines in seeking emergency government aid. The administration and Congress are working on legislation to have taxpayers pay major insurance claims that result from terrorist attacks. Without such help, corporate executives caution, many companies will find themselves in serious trouble, though some skeptical lawmakers are asking if the requested aid amounts to an unjustified bailout. CLYDE HABERMAN

HEADLINE: New Economy; 
Despite its epochal name, the clicks-and-mortar age may be quietly assimilated.

BYLINE:  By Steve Lohr 

 BODY:
REMEMBER the new economy? What does it mean -- if anything -- anymore?
 The catchy term, in its headiest formulation, was a symbolic shorthand for the power of technology to transform the economy, investment strategy, business thinking, even modern culture. Advances in computing and the rollout of the Internet, according to the new economy theory, would change just about everything, and very quickly. 
 After the collapse of the dot-com bubble, a steady retreat in technology stocks this year and an old-fashioned recession surely under way, the new economy theory requires some revision, to put it kindly. 
Its biggest problem came first -- the word new. Almost nothing about the rise of the Internet in the 1990's was really new. 
Yes, new technologies fuel economic growth and productivity. And that has been the story since the dawn of the industrial age. In the 13 centuries until 1800, economic historians estimate, real output per person in Western Europe grew at an annual rate of two-tenths of a percent or less. Since then, the real output per head in the industrialized nations has grown an average of 1.6 percent a year, thanks to the relentless march of innovation.
Impressive as the wonders of the Internet may be, historians point out that all of the technological advances of the post-World War II era probably cannot match the burst of invention that came from the 1850's to 1903: the Bessemer steel-making process, the telegraph, the light bulb, the phonograph, the telephone, the radio, the automobile, rapid transit (subways and elevated trains), the diesel engine, mechanical refrigeration and the airplane.
Frequently, the new technologies of the past touched off relatively brief periods of business euphoria, disenchantment and consolidation, typically lasting 5 to 10 years. It was part of the investment cycle evident in the creation of the railroad, electric power and automobile industries, among others. From 1900 to 1925, there were more than 3,000 automobile start-ups in America turning out cars of every imaginable design. Some had six wheels, others had shiplike tillers for steering.
"You can take the Internet bubble and just drop it into the same mold," observed Thomas Eisenmann, an assistant professor at the Harvard Business School.
Internet technology, to be sure, is not historically or economically unique. Still, it is significant. The Internet, put simply, is a low-cost communications technology. That alone is a big deal, helping reduce the cost of transactions, price discovery and information retrieval in the economy. In addition, the Internet is a communications network with some distinctive features. 
The Internet and the Web together are a medium made of software, which is to say programmable. That makes the Internet a far more flexible medium than other communications technologies like the telephone. So Web pages, for example, can substitute for paper forms, mail and facsimiles -- automating company purchase orders to suppliers and other kinds of so-called back-office transactions.
Such unglamorous dealings in the engine rooms of corporate America represent a big part of the modern economy. For years, companies have been trying to automate these transactions, with systems like electronic data interchange, or E.D.I. The drawback to E.D.I., though, is that it typically requires expensive software and private network connections. The public Internet offers a far less costly alternative, opening the door to efficiency gains for small companies as well as large corporations. 
That kind of economically significant assimilation of Internet technology has begun, but experts believe its impact will continue to spread the next decade or more. An 18-month study, led by the Brookings Institution, concluded in September that the likely impact of Internet technology will be to add one-quarter to one-half percentage point annually to the productivity growth of the United States economy the next five years.
"Economically, the Internet is just like electricity," said Robert E. Litan, director of economic studies at Brookings. "First, it's new and exciting. Then it steadily transforms your economy. And decades later nobody would think to call it the electricity economy. It's just there."
The fractional improvements to productivity add up. Over a decade, the one-quarter to one-half percent a year becomes additional economic growth of 2.5 percent to 5 percent. On a per capita basis, Mr. Litan noted, that works out to about $1,250 to $2,500 of added wealth. "That's as big as any tax cut we'll ever see," he said.
None of that, Mr. Litan added, depends on the fate of the remaining Internet companies. "All the dot-coms could disappear," he said, "and it wouldn't make any difference."
Dan Bricklin is a veteran of an earlier version of the new economy, when the personal computer industry began to take off. In 1979, Mr. Bricklin, then a student at the Harvard Business School, helped the personal computer business catch fire when he and Bob Frankston created VisiCalc, an electronic spreadsheet -- the first "killer app," or killer application, for the fledgling personal computer industry. 
Today, Mr. Bricklin is founder and chief technology officer of Trellix, which makes Web site technology for small businesses. It should be, he believes, a solid, steadily growing market as smaller companies increasingly adopt Internet technology.
Yet, Mr. Bricklin said, what fueled much of the dot-com boom and the frantic investment by large companies, worried that they would soon be "Amazoned," was an intellectual lapse. "The mistake was the impulse to grossly over-generalize, to think that everything was going to go online and that all companies would use the Internet the same way, the way Amazon did," he said.
The trouble with the new economy theory, it seems, is that it was simple-minded. Some see a reactionary simple-mindedness today.
"When the dot-com bubble burst, the pendulum swung and probably too far," observed Garth Saloner, an economist and professor at Stanford's business school. "Even the image of a burst bubble is a misnomer. It suggests that all that's left is suds on the floor. And that's not true."
"The Internet is an important technology, but technological change takes time to work through the economy and society," Mr. Saloner added. "It's not a deep insight, but a lot of people lost sight of that simple fact for a long time."
So the new economy was not so new after all. But the technology still matters -- as it always has.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Owner of Railroad Tracks To Reorganize in Britain
In an attempt to save Britain's railway system from collapse, Railtrack, the company that owns the tracks, will undergo an emergency restructuring that stops short of reverting to government control, a British court ruled.
 Under what is the American equivalent of bankruptcy protection, Railtrack will reorganize into a new private company. It will cease having public stockholders and will be required to reinvest all proceeds into the business to help maintain the system. Page C6. 

Intel to Unveil Chip Breakthrough
Intel plans to announce today that its researchers have come up with a novel method for housing microprocessors that it hopes will speed development of high-performance microchips with more than a billion transistors. The company says such chips could be available in five or six years. C5.

Comics Debate Portrayal of Attacks
Like others in the entertainment industry, comic book writers and artists, and their publishers, are debating how to portray the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, but there is little agreement about future, commercial steps. DC Comics has indefinitely postponed publication of one violent comic and rewritten forthcoming stories to eliminate references to terrorism. On the other hand, Marvel Comics has decided to confront the attacks head on in Amazing Spider-Man No. 36, to be published by the beginning of November. C9.

Biotechnology Start-Ups Struggle
The $25 billion biotechnology sector is riding a wave of innovation focused mainly on health products, traditionally one of the economy's most recession-resistant sectors. But smaller biotechnology start-ups are struggling right now, judging from the fervent pitches that scores of them presented to venture capitalists at a meeting last week. Market Place. C10.

The New Meaning of New Economy
The catchy term "new economy" was a symbolic shorthand for the power of technology to transform the economy, investment strategy, business thinking, even modern culture. But after the collapse of the dot-com bubble and an old-fashioned recession surely under way, the new economy theory requires some revision, to put it kindly. New Economy. C3.

More Web Spending, With a Focus
Going into September, senior managers were already less than enthusiastic about big corporate Internet initiatives. Now, they are even more fixated on prompt payoffs from any investments and seem poised to spend more on a handful of areas -- including Internet security, technology recovery systems and telecommuting gear -- and that should mean more business for companies with those specialties. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C6.

Ads Adopt a Patriotic Flavor
A month after the terrorist attacks on the United States, Madison Avenue is wrapping itself in red, white and blue in an outpouring of patriotism not seen in mainstream advertising since World War II. Already, though, there are complaints about the inappropriateness of using profound symbols for commercial purposes from critics who are concerned that the trend is more jingoistic than patriotic and more exploitive than altruistic. C10.

The Silicon Alley Reporter Closes
The Silicon Alley Reporter, known for its boosterism of New York's new media entrepreneurs, has published its last issue. C9.

Quicker Patents to Fight Terrorism
Under a Patent and Trademark Office provision, inventors seeking patents for devices, methods or technologies aimed at counterterrorism can petition to jump to the front of the line. Sabra Chartrand: Patents. C4.

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
Financing has dried upfor biotechnology start-ups with big dreams for fighting disease.

BYLINE:  By Barnaby J. Feder 

 BODY:
THE $25 billion biotechnology sector is riding a wave of innovation focused primarily on health products, traditionally one of the most recession-resistant sectors of the economy.
 But smaller biotechnology start-ups are struggling right now, judging from the fervent pitches that scores of them presented to venture capitalists last week at a two-day meeting in Washington, held by the Biotechnology Industry Organization and the Tech Council of Maryland. 
 The start-ups were the segment of the industry hit hardest when biotechnology's financial pulse slowed along with the rest of the economy this year and then skipped a beat or two after Sept. 11. There is no appetite for new stock offerings, and the limited crowd of biotechnology venture capitalists, who invested a total of $2.78 billion last year, gave three of every four dollars to the more mature start-ups with products nearer to market, according to a report released last week by the accounting firm of Ernst & Young. 
Entrepreneurs and bankers at the conference said that valuations for the newest companies, which peaked last year, had dropped as much as 50 percent before last month's terrorist attacks. Companies that failed to raise enough money the past two years to get them through the next two are finding that some venture capitalists are reducing the amounts they are willing to invest. Others are demanding a larger share of the company, higher priority in future payouts or other favorable terms. A few are both offering less, but demanding more.
"From talking to investors, I figure our valuation has dropped by about a third since Sept. 11," said Daniel H. Fylstra, president of Sierra Sciences, a two-year-old company based in Reno, Nev., that aims to alter the chemistry that causes cells to age and die. Mr. Fylstra was looking for $5 million to support continuing research at Sierra, which does not expect to have F.D.A.-approved products or a public stock offering before 2004.
Right now, investor skittishness has much more to do with concerns about how quickly they will be paid back and the difficulty of singling out potential winners than doubts about the long-range potential of the biotechnology industry.
The bulk of today's biotechnology sales come from just 120 products that have been approved by the Food and Drug Administration. But the pipeline has been swelling rapidly. Nearly 300 more new drugs are in Phase 3 clinical trials, the last stage of testing before companies can seek approval from the F.D.A. to go to market. As many as 60 could reach the market in the near future, according to R. Nelson Campbell, an investment banker specializing in biotechnology for Friedman, Billings, Ramsey & Company in Arlington, Va. "The industry could double in the next two years," he said.
And after that? Well, no one with small dreams was invited to the Washington conference. 
Those who attended arrived flushed with the possibilities of such breakthroughs as the preliminary mapping last year of the human genome, which for the first time offered researchers a peek at the entire chemical code that goes into creating a human being. They came armed with rapidly expanding data on the nature of the bacteria, viruses and other antagonists that make people sick; novel theories on how to fight the ways human bodies wear out with age; and innovative tools for research, diagnosis and drug development.
It was a meeting for executives and scientists not yet far enough into their work to have serious doubts about whether their visions will pan out. In 10-minute presentation after 10-minute presentation, they pleaded with the fund managers and bankers to give them enough money to make their dreams reality, or at least to sustain them for another year of development work.
The goals are compelling. AngioGenex, based in New York, hopes to figure out how to shut down the "inhibition of differentiation," or I.D., gene, which scientists at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Research Center identified in 1999 as the generator of a protein essential to the growth of tumors. FASgen, based in Baltimore, aims to control cellular production of a chemical involved in converting carbohydrates to fat in all living things. Drugs to attack obesity and tuberculosis are FASgen's first two targets.
RHeoGene, based in Charlottesville, Va., is trying to make the genetic equivalent of a dimmer switch. By carefully raising and lowering the amount of a protein a gene is producing, RHeoGene could initially help researchers figure out the functions of the more than 500,000 proteins the body produces, and, eventually, how to more finely tune the performance of drugs. 
And numerous companies pitched concepts aimed at improving products already in the market, like Juvenir Biosciences, a Johnson & Johnson spinoff based in Skillman, N.J. Juvenir is developing a compound it says will fight acne better than Accutane, the current leader in that $600 million market, without Accutane's potential for causing birth defects when used by pregnant women.
"The better, faster, cheaper crowd is proliferating," said Bryan Roberts, a general partner specializing in health care at Venrock Associates, a venture capital firm in New York.
As investors like Mr. Roberts are well aware, even products much farther along in their development than any featured last week in Washington can falter before reaching the market. A string of such late-stage disappointments dealt the biotechnology sector a crushing blow in the mid-1990's -- a period of crashing stock prices and fleeing venture capitalists that industry insiders now refer to as "the biotech winter."
But the new Ernst & Young report shows how far the industry has come since then. In 1995, there were 10 biotechnology companies with a market capitalization over $1 billion. By the middle of this year, there were 63. Perhaps more importantly, after raising more than $33 billion in public and private offerings last year and another $5.7 billion in the first six months of this year, 54 percent of the companies Ernst & Young surveyed had enough money to last them three years or more, up from 35 percent just two years ago.
"Balance sheets have never been stronger," said Rene Salas, a biotechnology specialist in Ernst & Young's Washington office.
With many bigger biotechnology companies on firmer footing, some financially pressed start-ups now have the option of forming alliances within their industry as an alternative to winning support from investors or from the traditional drug companies, known in the industry as Big Pharma.
"There were more deals between biotech companies to form alliances than between biotech and Big Pharma starting in 1999," said Linda F. Powers, managing partner of the Toucan Capital Corporation, a Bethesda, Md., investment fund. Last year, she added, biotechnology firms supplanted traditional drug makers as the most likely acquirers of smaller biotechnology companies.
Still, there are not enough potential alliance partners or acquirers to go around for entrepreneurs like those in Washington, which leaves those venture capitalists willing to place long-range bets in a strong bargaining position for now.
"You almost expect them to rip off their suits and show you T-shirts saying 'Osama made me do it' when you look at some of the term sheets," said one chief executive, after discretely checking to see who was within earshot.

HEADLINE: What Now for Wireless? Facing Harsh Realities; 
An Industry Adopts a New Pragmatism

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
In Manhattan last June, Discover magazine convened a panel of technology experts from companies that included I.B.M., Walt Disney and Nokia to hold forth on the future of wireless technology. 
 Among the blue-sky predictions were cellphones that would let prospective home buyers find a house's price simply by pointing the device at the building. Another brainstorm involved a wireless toaster that would burn an image of the day's weather forecast right onto a piece of bread. 
 These days, such a giddy gathering is hard to imagine. Last month's terrorist attacks and the mounting evidence of a recession have had a sobering effect on many businesses. The wireless communications industry, in particular, has been forced to curb its futurism. 
Instead of house-hunting gimmicks, executives in the wireless industry are now talking about more mundane services like simple text messaging. Rather than weather reports on toast, wireless officials are concentrating on making their networks robust enough to handle more callers in peak periods. 
Much of the new pragmatism comes from wireless technology's prominent role on Sept. 11, when people spoke to one another or sent short e-mail messages by cellphone or pager. The utility of wireless communications was made even more dramatically clear by victims who called their families from hijacked airplanes and from inside the burning World Trade Center towers.
But some of the wireless industry's shortcomings were also highlighted.
So far, for example, few wireless subscribers even know they have text-messaging, let alone how to use it. And in many cases, so many people tried simultaneously to make cellphone calls that no one could get through. 
"I plead guilty to being one of the spokespersons for the fanciful things wireless technology promised," said Dennis Roberson, chief technology officer of Motorola. "The events of Sept. 11 convinced me of the overwhelming importance of communications on a basic level."
The new pragmatism is most apparent among industry executives and analysts. But venture capitalists, formerly willing to finance even fanciful projects, are taking note. Earlier this year, for example, ComVentures, an investment firm in Palo Alto, Calif., decided to avoid financing start-ups that focus on unproven wireless services.
Instead, ComVentures is backing companies that are seeking to improve existing wireless technology. One of its main investments is in Littlefeet, a San Diego company whose products are designed to extend the reach and improve the sound quality of cellular systems.
"Voice is and will continue to be the killer application of the wireless industry," said Michael Rolnick, general partner of ComVentures. "We're realizing that the national networks don't provide national coverage, leaving a lot of rural areas and small cities off the grid. There's a lot that needs to be done to improve what's out there."
One example of carriers' eagerness to build on what already works was a $100 million joint venture announced last Friday by Sprint PCS and the Virgin Group of Britain. Virgin will use its brand name to sell wireless service in the United States operating on Sprint's network. Virgin will be providing services like entertainment-related text messages, but the emphasis of the venture is on basic voice service.
From the industry's standpoint, a major obstacle to improving wireless services is a shortage of available radio spectrum -- the airwaves that carry the calls and messages. 
"The congestion on Sept. 11 showed how every wireless carrier could have used twice the spectrum they had in lower Manhattan after the attacks," said Ivan Seidenberg, chief executive of Verizon Communications, the parent of Verizon Wireless.
Currently, though, Verizon and many other wireless companies are in a spectrum standoff with the federal government. Last January, the Federal Communications Commission made additional airwave capacity available by auctioning spectrum licenses belonging to the bankrupt NextWave Telecom. But after the industry bid a total of $16 billion for airwaves covered by NextWave's licenses, a federal appeals court ruled that the F.C.C. had no right to seize the licenses. 
A settlement is expected soon, but even the NextWave spectrum would not meet the industry's future needs. Most of the additional airwaves that carriers covet are either in the hands of the military or being held as extra television channels by broadcasters, which can be expected to make wireless carriers pay dearly to use them. 
The capacity constraints pose a problem for cellular companies because the industry has had trouble attracting new subscribers to the wireless world. Unlike Japan and some European countries, in which more than 60 percent of the population uses cellphones, the 109.5 million cellular subscribers in the United States represent only about 39 percent of the population. And while the rate of new sign-ups picked up early this year, lately the rocky economy has discouraged many potential customers, despite reports of a flurry of cellphone buying in the week after Sept. 11.
If the carriers are hoping that consumers' new interest in emergency communications will stimulate demand, the industry is falling short in at least one regard, according to the F.C.C. 
For years, the agency has been pushing for Enhanced 911, or E-911, service as a way to improve the precision of locating people who make emergency calls from cellphones. Current technology enables emergency officials to determine the location of a wireless caller to within approximately 500 feet. With its E-911 initiative, the F.C.C. wants to improve the accuracy to about 150 feet for at least two-thirds of calls and 450 feet for 95 percent of calls.
Under the original timetable, carriers were supposed to have plans in place this month gradually to phase in E-911 the next few years. But many carriers say the more precise systems are too expensive and the F.C.C.'s timetable is unrealistic. 
Last Friday, the F.C.C. said only four carriers, Verizon Wireless, Sprint PCS, Nextel Communications and VoiceStream Communications, had met its preliminary requirements for phasing in E-911 services. The F.C.C. put two other large carriers, Cingular Wireless and AT&T Wireless, under review for disciplinary action for failing to meet the guidelines.
It was not so long ago that industry entrepreneurs were promoting wireless location capabilities as a marvelous marketing tool -- a way for retailers to pinpoint the location of mobile customers, messaging them with special offers on, say, lattes when they strolled by a Starbucks.
Even before Sept. 11, economic concerns were forcing industry executives to think more practically. They were all too aware of the financial woes of large wireless carriers in Europe, which had gone deeply in debt by agreeing last year to spend a combined $150 billion on licenses to provide so-called third-generation, or 3G, services. (The first generation was the original analog-transmission networks of the 1980's and early 90's. The second generation refers to current digital wireless networks.)
Third-generation networks, their supporters say, will usher in high-speed, Internet-inspired services on mobile phones. With 3G services, for example, users could swap digital photographs or download movie trailers on cellphones -- assuming someone would want to do that. Just as important, from a capacity standpoint, 3G networks are supposed to use spectrum more efficiently and increase the speeds with which people can transmit basic data on wireless devices.
But in light of the hammering the global telecommunications industry has taken the last year, the European wireless companies have been trying to find ways to free themselves from some of the license obligations. 
Wireless carriers in the United States were spared some of the Europeans' pain because network ambitions and construction have tended to trail those in Europe. 
Even where American carriers have cautiously proceeded with plans to offer more advanced wireless services, the projects are rather modest. In July, for example, AT&T Wireless, became the nation's first company to offer 2.5G services -- so called because they are a half-step toward true 3G. But so far, it has offered the service only to business customers in Seattle, and the company has declined to say how many have actually signed up. 
In Seattle, AT&T Wireless charges a minimum of $50 a month for 400 voice minutes and one megabyte of data. One megabyte may sound like a lot, but in practice it is a pittance. Without exceeding the one-megabyte allotment, a user of a wireless device could do little more than book some airline reservations, check stock prices or read a few short news articles.
Some customers use the service as a kind of wireless modem, linking their cellphones with a cable to a laptop computer. That provides access to the more sophisticated services that full-blown fast Internet access can provide. But it can also become expensive when incremental data charges are taken into account. 
In Tokyo last week, NTT DoCoMo rolled out what it called the world's first true 3G wireless network. But even in Japan, where wireless phones are much more popular than in the United States, consumers seem to be approaching the pricey service with caution.
Closer to home, the wireless companies' new sobriety is manifesting itself in many ways. Consider the example of Nortel Networks, the big Canadian maker of equipment for wireless networks. 
Before Sept. 11, Nortel, promoting the wireless Internet's potential, was running a TV commercial in the United States, in which an executive delivered a speech dictated to him from an assistant over a video connection on a hand-held computer. (No such technology is commercially available.)
After the terrorist attacks, Nortel dropped the commercial. The company has donated the rest of it TV ad budget for the year, worth about $3.5 million, to the Red Cross.

HEADLINE: Madison Avenue Rides Wave of PatrioticFervor 

BYLINE:  By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
A month after the terrorist attacks on the United States, Madison Avenue is wrapping itself in red, white and blue in an outpouring of patriotism not seen in mainstream advertising since World War II.
 Already, though, there are complaints about the inappropriateness of using profound symbols for commercial purposes from critics who are concerned that the trend is more jingoistic than patriotic and more exploitive than altruistic. 
 The flood of patriotic imagery ranges from American flags and tricolored bunting to fireworks and renderings of the Statue of Liberty and Uncle Sam with their sleeves rolled up, ready to fight. The phrase "United we stand" is being seen almost as often as "Clearance sale," and "God bless America" is being heard almost as often as "And now, a word from our sponsor." 
The terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and Pentagon stimulated a revival of patriotic fervor among consumers that was echoed within hours by marketers, advertising agencies and media companies. Flags were unfurled in television commercials and print ads as well as on Web site banners, signs and billboards. Broadcast and cable networks like NBC and MTV began draping their logos and studio windows in stars and stripes as publications from Parade to Premiere added flags to their covers.
The patriotic pitches are coming from companies large (Anheuser-Busch, General Motors, Kmart), small (Manhattan Mini Storage, National Wholesale Liquidators, Top Tomato and Key Food supermarkets) and in-between (Kenneth Cole, Florsheim, Lands' End). Some are not companies at all but organizations and associations like Major League Baseball and Cotton Inc.
One critic, Allen Adamson, managing director for the New York office of Landor Associates, a company that specializes in advising marketers on corporate identity strategies, said, "If this was never part of your message to begin with, now is not the time to latch on."
He added, "In the very short term it is effective, but if everyone is using it, you're not different. You can blend in with a sea of sameness." Landor is part of the Young & Rubicam division of the WPP Group. 
"Optimism for the country is more appropriate than ever, but companies that arbitrarily wrap themselves in the flag run the risk of having it backfire," said Donny Deutsch, chief executive at the Deutsch agency in New York, which works for advertisers like Tommy Hilfiger, Mitsubishi and Snapple.
"If you glom onto patriotism to pull you through, consumers will see through that," he added. "Patriotic bravado 'brought to you by Joe's Leather Outlet' is not going to work." Deutsch is in the Partnership unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.
"Patriotic appeals are potentially offensive because they can look like overt nationalism," said Simon Williams, chief executive at the Sterling Group, a brand consulting company in New York.
"It's important to keep the nation together," he added, "but 'in-your-face' Americanism is not what we're looking for."
Those presenting patriotic ads acknowledge the criticism and say they are striving to be sensitive.
"It's a very hard line to walk," said Rick Boyko, chief creative officer for the North American operations of the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide agency in New York. "Nobody knows if you do it right or not."
The goal, he added, is to "get a message out, a sign of solidarity, and not sell."
Ogilvy has already produced patriotic ads for clients like AT&T Wireless; American Express; Cotton Inc., the association of American cotton growers; and the Miller Brewing division of the Philip Morris Companies. But rather than capitalizing on the nation's new-found patriotism, Mr. Boyko said, "We're holding up a mirror to what we are seeing."
"We were stuck in Las Vegas on Sept. 11," Mr. Boyko said, referring to a group of Ogilvy and Miller executives, "and as we drove across country in two and a half days, we started to see this spontaneous outpouring of signs, held up by people, hanging from roofs, posted in windows." That inspired the agency to create a commercial for Miller with myriad signs expressing sentiments like "America the Beautiful," "Go U.S.A." and "We Are All New Yorkers." Ogilvy is owned by WPP.
The nation's No. 1 auto maker, General Motors, is running a campaign infused with patriotic elements to promote a zero percent financing program. A TV commercial began with an announcer reciting: "The American dream. We refuse to let anyone take it away." A print ad ended with these words: "This may very well be the most serious crisis our nation has ever faced. In this time of terrible adversity, let's stand together. And keep America rolling." Indeed, "Keep America rolling" is the theme of the campaign.
"It's a fine line between calling the program what it is and going too far," said C. J. Fraleigh, executive director for advertising and corporate marketing at General Motors in Detroit. "I think we struck the right balance."
"The auto industry is a major component of the U.S. economy and we're the largest company in the industry," he added. "The size and history of G.M. gives us a legitimate license to talk about our role in the economy. It is appropriate, again, if you don't cross the line."
Mr. Adamson of Landor agreed that the patriotic appeals may work best when, he said, "it is relevant to the core brand idea."
"Major League Baseball has done a terrific job of wrapping itself in the flag," he added, referring to television commercials, "and it works, because baseball's core is American."
Even so, "over a period of time, its relevance diminishes," Mr. Adamson said, "as consumers begin to ask what does it have to do with the brand.
"And that could do damage," he added.
Mr. Boyko at Ogilvy said he did not dispute that "the shelf life for this type of message will probably be short.
"The public wants to get back to normal, but everybody's still looking for answers," he added. "We're in the process of determining what to do in Month 2, 3, 4."

Companies say they have tried to be tasteful in tapping heady emotions and are merely reflecting the nation's current mood. (Photographs by G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: E-Commerce Report; 
Corporations seem poised to spend more in a handful of areas but have also become fixated on prompt payoffs.

BYLINE:  By Bob Tedeschi 

 BODY:
GOING into September, senior managers were already less than enthusiastic about big corporate Internet initiatives. Given the tightening economy and the slowness with which many business-to-business e-commerce projects pay for themselves, such efforts were quickly losing ground on corporations' priority lists. 
 Now, in the wake of Sept. 11, senior managers are even more fixated on prompt payoffs from any investments they make. Corporate managers seem poised to spend more on a small handful of areas -- including Internet security, technology recovery systems and telecommuting gear -- and that should mean more business for companies with those specialties. Companies that focus on more basic products -- like e-commerce software -- could face much more difficult times in the coming months, though. 
 "Over all, the pie of B-to-B transactions will shrink, because the attacks have really pushed us over the edge into a recession, which will cause a global recession," said Lauren Shu, a research director with GartnerG2, the business strategy division of the Gartner consulting and research firm. As a result, she said, her firm will probably reduce its 2002 estimates for global e-commerce spending among corporations. (The current estimate is $1.93 trillion.) 
In the short term, Ms. Shu said, companies in the industries most directly affected by the terrorist attacks will scale back their e-commerce spending. "We'll see a trickle-down effect from tourism and financial services," she said, adding that industries like oil, gas, industrial equipment, and textiles will also be affected. 
In addition, she said, if consumer spending decreases in areas like furniture, cars and other big-ticket items, those industries will also have less cash to spend on ambitious e-commerce projects. 
Indeed, the economic repercussions of the attacks continued to spread last week. as companies that supply the beleaguered airline industry began discussing cuts of their own. General Electric Aircraft Engines, for one, announced plans to lay off 4,000 of its 30,000 workers. Rick Kennedy, a spokesman for GE Aircraft Engines, said he did yet not know whether employees devoted to the company's growing e-commerce effort would be included in the layoffs. "But we expect everybody's going to be hit by this," he said. And Russ Mayer, vice president for e-business at GE Aircraft Engines, said spending on new e-commerce projects would be cut by 25 to 30 percent.
Dan Ackman, vice president for e-business at the National Association of Manufacturers, said members of his organization would curtail their e-commerce spending. "My gut is that one-third of the companies will stay with their plans, a third will spend less, and a third will take a wait-and-see approach," Mr. Ackman said 
"That last group will lean toward staying the course," he added. "But one thing that will not change is that C.E.O.'s will continue to only do stuff with high priority." 
That means requiring fast payoffs, said Marc Andreessen, the chairman of Loudcloud, which helps run the Internet operations for companies like Nike and Ford Motor. 
Mr. Andreessen, a co-founder of Netscape who is generally credited with inventing the first Internet browser, sees a new pragmatism among corporate technology customers. "The way to sell a year and a half ago was to talk about getting a return on your investment after 12 months or 18 months," he said. "Nowadays, the arguments have to do with cost reduction in the first month." 
As for Loudcloud's business, Mr. Andreessen said he had not seen any evidence of executives balking since Sept. 11. "But that's probably because we usually get called in to reduce the cost of existing projects, not to start a new project," he said. "A lot of companies have killed their plans for new projects."
In addition to hurting established companies, the post-September economic uncertainty will almost certainly crush the hopes of many newly formed business-to-business Internet companies, Mr. Andreessen added. "Sept. 11 drives an exclamation point over the fact that it's brutally difficult for start-ups to raise funding," he said. 
"For the venture capital community, it's a more intense version of what was happening in the six months prior," he added. "In theory, they have a lot of cash, but in practice, they're still losing their shirts over the investments they'd made." 
Ms. Shu, of Gartner, said perceptions about weak Internet security could, in the short term, lead more companies to use networks that connect businesses over dedicated phone lines, instead of the Internet.
But others anticipate a different outcome, pointing to some of the few areas where they see signs of sustained, or increased, corporate e-commerce spending. Steven D. Berkley, who manages the fixed income index group for Lehman Brothers, is expecting to rely increasingly on encrypted Internet communications, given how critical they were in helping his business rebound in the days after the attacks. 
Mr. Berkley's group was located near the World Trade Center, in offices that remained inaccessible last week. Because the usual dedicated networks could not be re-established immediately after the attacks, his group reached clients via Atabok, a service that sends digitally encrypted files over the Internet. Mr. Berkley said the company's employees also used the Atabok service from their homes, when they telecommuted during the week of Sept. 11. 
Given Lehman's reliance on networking services after the attack, Mr. Berkley said he would push the company to create backup sites with more servers, the computers that form the core of any Internet operation. 
Businesses that market secure Internet communications and those that provide help recovering disabled technology systems have experienced a surge in demand in the last four weeks. Jeff Wyne, vice president for marketing at Atabok, said the company had seen a spike in the number of government agencies that have made inquiries -- even if he is at a loss to explain the sudden government interest. 
"But, in general, it's been a little easier for us to get in the door" of prospective clients, Mr. Wyne said. 
Likewise, Damian Walch, senior vice president for professional services for Comdisco, a disaster recovery company, said that since the attacks, businesses had been interested in devising backup systems to keep their e-commerce operations up and running in the event of a disaster. 
This is actually an ideal time to invest in other e-commerce systems, beyond those for security, analysts and executives said. Vendors of products like e-commerce software had seen demand slow even before last month's events, and companies interested in expanding their e-commerce capabilities are in a good bargaining position -- if, of course, senior managers can stomach the financial risk of engaging in a long-term project.
"It's definitely a buyer's market right now," said Mr. Ackman at the National Association of Manufacturers. "The companies that push ahead have a real opportunity."

HEADLINE: Global Markets Still Look To New York For Leadership 

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON and SUZANNE KAPNER 

 BODY:
The sun rises in the east and sets in the west. New days dawn in Tokyo 14 hours before they reach New York. It is the natural order.
 Not necessarily in the financial markets, though. By the time the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq begin trading each day, the stock markets in Frankfurt and London have been open for hours and those in Tokyo, Sydney and Hong Kong are long closed. 
 When United States investors wake up this morning, they will be able to gauge the reaction of foreign markets to the military strikes on Afghanistan. But in practice, American markets are likely to set their own course, analysts say, and foreign markets can be expected to follow on Tuesday. 
For all practical purposes, the clocks of the world's markets -- with the exception in some ways of those in Japan -- are set to 9:30 a.m. on Wall Street, when the day's trading begins on the New York Stock Exchange. 
"When it comes to the global stock markets, the No. 1 question that people start off with is the U.S. outlook," said Subodh Kumar, chief investment strategist in Toronto with CIBC World Markets. Mr. Kumar said that on a 10-day trip to Europe and the Middle East he made in late September, he found that his clients, even those who invested mostly in local stocks, were mainly interested in talking about the outlook for the United States economy and the American markets.
"It's quite amazing," he said. "Even if people have a domestic portfolio, the extent to which they talk about U.S. statistics, U.S. consumer confidence, etc."
The global investment clock's calibration to American time may have been most evident when the United States stock markets stopped running for four trading days after the attacks on Sept. 11. Despite an initial burst of trading activity in Europe that Tuesday afternoon and in Asia on Wednesday morning, as market participants reacted to the news, volume was not particularly heavy thereafter and through the end of the week.
But the next week, after the opening bell rang again at the New York Stock Exchange on Monday, Sept. 17, trading volume soared in Europe and Asia. Stock exchanges in London, Frankfurt and Hong Kong recorded some of their busiest days ever, paralleling the activity in New York. And as stock prices plummeted in the United States, shares in the overseas markets followed.
There are both financial and economic reasons that American stock markets dominate the attention of traders everywhere, analysts say. To begin with, the United States is the world's largest economy, accounting for almost 30 percent of gross global output.
What is more, for the last decade the United States has grown faster than Japan or Europe. Stock investors obviously prefer expanding companies and growing economies, so the United States markets are disproportionately large, even considering the size of the economy. The New York Stock Exchange is the largest share market in the world, and the Nasdaq is second.
Together, they had a market value of almost $13 trillion as of Sept. 1, accounting for about half the total value of stocks worldwide, according to most recently compiled data from the Big Board. A single company, General Electric, with a market value then of $375 billion, represented more than 1 percent of the world's market capitalization.
The influence of the United States markets is magnified by the American influence on global economic growth over the last decade. In 2000, for example, the United States imported $280 billion in goods from East Asia, excluding Japan, accounting for 11 percent of the region's economic output, said Andy Xie, chief economist at Morgan Stanley in Hong Kong.
"The region has been called a leveraged play on U.S. growth," Mr. Xie said. East Asia, in other words, swings up and down with the United States economy, except that Asia's swings are generally wider. Semiconductor makers like Samsung Electronics in South Korea and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, he said, "are bellwether stocks here and trade against U.S. comparables such as Intel."
And even foreign companies that do business mainly in their home markets, like banks, are considered vulnerable to an American economic slowdown, because slower growth in the United States can provoke a slowdown worldwide. "Export drives domestic demand in most cases," Mr. Xie said.
In addition to the influence of the American economy, there is another, more direct connection between United States stock markets and the action elsewhere. Shares of many of the most important companies in other countries are traded on the New York Stock Exchange in addition to their home markets. On an average day, for instance, more shares of Nortel Networks, a Canadian company that makes communications equipment, trade in New York than in Toronto.
Companies choose to list on the Big Board for both practical and symbolic reasons. Gaining a listing in New York provides access to the deepest pool of investment capital in the world. And being allowed to list in the United States shows that a foreign company has met American standards for financial disclosure, usually considered the toughest public accountability standards in the world.
The cross-listings have the effect of binding foreign markets even more closely to their United States counterparts. The Sao Paulo Stock Exchange in Brazil opens half an hour before the New York Stock Exchange, but little trading occurs until the Big Board's opening bell, said Aloisio Villeth Lemos of Lopes Filho & Associados, a investment consulting firm in Rio de Janeiro. Some stocks, like Petrobras, the Brazilian oil company, trade almost exclusively on the Big Board.
The situation has similar aspects in Europe. "The relationship between the United States and Europe is the relationship between a mother and a child," said Michael Hartnett, director of European equity strategy for Merrill Lynch in London.
Mr. Hartnett said the relationship between European and American markets grew stronger in recent years, as mutual fund managers invested money by industry rather than by region. The leading companies in a certain industry will determine how the industry performs relative to the rest of the market, and those leaders are often American companies, Mr. Hartnett said.
"The performance of United States technology companies affects European technology companies," he said. "It doesn't really work vice versa."
Other nations' stock markets have a more limited impact, traders and hedge fund managers said. In financial crises, the importance of Japan increases because it is a large exporter of capital. The big semiconductor equipment manufacturers of South Korea and Taiwan can provide clues to the health of the global economy.
But economic and corporate data from the United States have a much bigger effect, they said.
Typically, three-quarters of the daily volume on the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index, the benchmark for the London Stock Exchange, is traded in the afternoon in London, after the Nasdaq and New York Stock Exchange have opened.
The lack of a single big stock market that spans European borders compounds Europe's competitive disadvantage, making it harder for companies to raise capital and expand their shareholder base across the Continent.
"It's an embarrassment that European fund managers can't seem to find a direction to the market without looking to the United States," said Leonard Geiger, who trades European stocks in London for U.S. Trust. "But the U.S. exerts so much power; to ignore it is like swimming upstream."
Japan does provide a limited exception to the rule of American dominance, said Robert Alan Feldman, chief economist at Morgan Stanley in Tokyo. "There are times when the U.S. is very important, times when it's not," he said. 
For much of the last decade, Japan's economy has stagnated even as the United States' has grown, so Japanese investors are more focused on domestic problems than on the international outlook. In addition, the Tokyo stock market, with a value equivalent to $2.6 trillion as of Sept. 1, was about as big as the Nasdaq. Tokyo's size has given it more power to move independently of American markets.
Still, the United States and Japan are closely tied economically, and traders in Tokyo often look to the previous day's action in New York for direction, Mr. Feldman said.
To that extent, the sun never sets on Wall Street.

And when something goes wrong in one market, it often sends waves around the world, swamping each market as it opens. HEADLINE: Small Loans Help Millions of World's Poorest, Coalition Says 

BYLINE:  By GINGER THOMPSON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 7 

 BODY:
An inter national coalition of microlending agencies devoted to financing homespun businesses from the inner city of Chicago to mountain villages in Chiapas -- plans to announce on Monday that it has made significant strides toward its goals of helping the world's poorest families.
 The group, the Microcredit Summit Campaign, has brought together about 600 experts in microcredit campaigns from throughout Latin America for a meeting in Puebla, beginning on Monday. 
 It will report that since it began an effort in 1997 to reach 100 million of the world's poorest families by 2005, it has reached about 19.3 million families. Meeting organizers, who also have pledged to help empower women, said loans to the world's poorest people were increasing by 37 percent a year. 
Microcredit programs make loans for as little as $40 to help poor people with no credit history start businesses. The programs are aimed mostly at lifting up impoverished areas of the third world. A total of 13.8 million people have been granted loans in Africa, Asia, Eastern Europe and Latin America. But microloans are also made available in urban areas of the United States.
President Vicente Fox of Mexico, who is scheduled to speak at the meeting, had promised to make microfinancing a pillar of his government's antipoverty strategy. But in the 10 months since Mr. Fox took office, his programs have become mired in bureaucratic missteps and stalled by an economic recession.
Queen Sophia of Spain and Muhammad Yunus, the Bangladeshi president of Grameen Bank, who gave out the first microloans in the mid-1970's, are also scheduled to be at the meeting. Grameen, known as the poor man's bank, helps coordinate microcredit investments for individual and institutional investors.
The World Bank has estimated that 1.2 million people around the world live on less than $1 a day, 75 percent of them women.
For years, microlending agencies have been criticized for overlooking the world's poorest people in favor of clients who have at least some business experience and basic financial background. Other microlenders have worried that the poorest people exclude themselves because they believe they are unqualified.
"Too often, the standard in the field is to give loans to people who already have businesses," said Sam Daley-Harris, the director of the Microcredit Summit. "Well, those are not the poorest people."
He added: "Many programs in the world are good at reaching people who already show some financial performance. But they are not strong at reaching further down."
Mr. Daley-Harris said there was little more than anecdotal evidence to indicate the effect microloans had had at lifting people out of poverty. But two recent studies showed that microcredit clients in Mali and Honduras were more likely than nonclients to have larger businesses; to see an increase in personal income and food consumption; to have personal savings; and to feel a greater sense of self-esteem.

HEADLINE: Near His Kibbutz, an Israeli Stops a Bomber and Is Killed 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: KIBBUTZ SHLUCHOT, Israel, Oct. 7 

 BODY:
Shortly after 8 o'clock this morning, the first suicide bomber to strike in Israel during the current cease-fire turned down a narrow lane that leads to this kibbutz, and, passing rows of date palms at his left, began walking toward the entrance.
 The gate was open, as it always is in daylight hours, and no guard stood beside it. Inside, parents were dropping off their children at the day care center and other kibbutzniks were sitting down to their communal breakfast. 
 Driving back from work to join his family for breakfast, Yair Mordechai stopped his white Mazda and climbed out to talk to the stranger. That was when the young man blew himself to pieces, killing Mr. Mordechai, crushing his car and shattering the windows of a silver Toyota that had just passed the two men. 
No one can know for sure why Mr. Mordechai, the 44-year-old father of five, got out of his car, but his fellow kibbutzniks, who considered him family and mourned him bitterly today, said they knew the reason. "It makes sense that he saw something suspicious and he stopped someone," said Devora Liss, who went to high school in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, with Mr. Mordechai's wife, Iria. "He wouldn't think of himself."
She said she thought "he saved the kibbutz from something even worse." From now on, residents said, the kibbutz gate would be closed at all times.
The attacks on the United States on Sept. 11 created an opening for peace here. Under pressure from the United States, Israelis and the Palestinians arrived at a cease-fire a week later, and the militant groups Hamas and Islamic Jihad indicated that they would halt suicide attacks against civilians within Israel. But they imposed a condition: the attacks would resume if the Israelis started making incursions into Palestinian territory. 
Despite the cease-fire, the violence barely paused. The Palestinians accused the Israelis of not withdrawing their troops and tanks from Palestinian-controlled territory, and the Israelis accused the Palestinians of not providing the security that would make such withdrawals possible. In reprisal for past attacks and to prevent future ones, the Israelis resumed attacking some Palestinian-controlled areas in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
Today, a Palestinian was shot dead and three were injured in the West Bank city of Hebron, where Israeli troops attacked two neighborhoods on Friday in hopes of stopping sniper attacks. Palestinians blamed Israeli troops for today's shooting, while Israel said it was part of an internal Palestinian dispute, The Associated Press reported. Israeli troops continued to hold their positions today in areas of Hebron that by previous agreement are Palestinian-controlled.
Palestinian security forces insisted that they were complying with the terms of the truce by arresting some Palestinian militants sought by Israel. But one high-ranking Israeli official said today that too many dangerous militants remained at large.
The Islamic Jihad claimed responsibility for the attack here, in a statement faxed to the Agence France-Presse in Beirut. The group identified the bomber as an 18-year-old Palestinian, Ahmad Abdel Muneim Draghma.
Kibbutz Shluchot, in the arid Beit Shean valley of northern Israel, is a collection of pale yellow homes covered by red tile roofs and linked by asphalt walking paths. It was the first kibbutz established after Israel's founding, in 1948, and is now home to about 120 families of Orthodox Jews.
Until recently, this was considered a safe area. Indeed, two years ago, the Israeli security forces took back guns that had been issued to the kibbutz. "They said we were going to have peace, a new peace here," said Chaim Pearlstein, 50, who considered Mr. Mordechai his best friend and identified his body today. "A new Middle East." 
But lately this area has grown dangerous. Late this summer, a teenage Israeli girl was shot and killed in the Gilboa Mountains, which loom over this kibbutz. In recent weeks, three people were killed in two drive-by shootings in this area.
Mr. Pearlstein said he suspected that new Israeli security measures west of here, on the far side of Palestinian-controlled territory, were having the unintended effect of routing violence in this direction.
His neighbors said that Mr. Mordechai was recently made a captain in the reserves and that he worked as a manager in a nearby date-packaging plant. Residents of the kibbutz contribute their income to the collective and receive an annual salary that increases with every child they have. Housing and bills like electricity and water are paid for communally.
"It's all family," said Niki Weiss, 48. Mrs. Weiss was trying to get the guest quarters ready for Mr. Mordechai's family, and she was calling on her neighbors. "I made three phone calls, and I had 10 or 15 people here," she said.
The kibbutzniks eat breakfast and lunch together, but the families dine on their own. But Mr. Mordechai was constantly inviting others into his home. "He just said to me the other day, 'People don't invite each other over enough here,' " Mrs. Liss said.
Many kibbutzes are now struggling to survive economically and to retain their original ethic of shared sacrifice. This one, like others, has taken to using some outside workers -- Israeli Arabs -- to tend its fields. Kibbutz Shluchot has turkey sheds, a dairy farm, carrot fields and date groves, but it has recently diversified, setting up a factory to make computerized signs and other high-tech equipment.
This afternoon, as the sun dipped toward the mountains, hundreds gathered under the date palms outside the kibbutz synagogue for a service for Mr. Mordechai. The Orthodox do not usually bury their dead in coffins, but because of the destruction caused by the bomb, the mourners today gathered around a plain pine box.

(Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times); An Israeli official collected evidence yesterday around the site where a Palestinian suicide bomber blew himself up, killing an Israeli man who stopped to talk to him near the entrance to Kibbutz Shluchot, in northern Israel. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Mexican Labor Protest Gets Results 

BYLINE:  By GINGER THOMPSON 

DATELINE: ATLIXCO, Mexico, Oct. 3 

 BODY:
At the time, it seemed an insignificant act of disobedience. About 900 workers at Mexmode, which produces sweatshirts for colleges in the United States, boycotted the company cafeteria because they were fed up with finding worms in their salads.
 But their defiance set off a combustible chain of protests that led to negotiations from the wealthiest corners of the first world to the most impoverished depths of the third. 
 Marcela Munoz, 23, a seamstress turned labor leader, still seems amazed by all the attention. "Eyes around the world have been focused on us," she said. 
Mexmode -- an assembly factory, or maquiladora -- is a principal supplier of college sweatshirts to Nike and Reebok. Hearing that Mexmode workers were fired for their cafeteria boycott, leaders of an activist coalition supported by students and administrators from about 85 American colleges and universities rushed here to investigate.
The group, the Workers Rights Consortium, heard complaints about low wages, verbal abuse and corruption among union officials, then began a high-profile campaign that threatened the image of the Nike swoosh.
Nike, the world's largest athletic shoe and clothing manufacturer, had already come under fire for similar conditions at Asian plants. Nike officials pressed Mexmode managers to abide by corporate codes of conduct that guarantee fair conditions for workers.
As a result, workers at Mexmode, most of them single mothers in their 20's with elementary school educations and no prior work experience, have received two raises this year. The cafeteria food now seems safe for human consumption. Some employees even say it tastes good.
Child laborers have been removed from production lines. The 450 seamstresses and machine operators at Mexmode recently won the right to kick out corrupt labor leaders and form their own union.
The actions at Mexmode invigorated the American anti-sweatshop movement. Labor experts argue that the changes here prove that corporate codes of conduct can reach across borders to protect workers' rights in regions of the world where labor laws are weak or poorly enforced.
"This fight showed that globalization has another face," said Huberto Juarez Nunez, a labor expert at the Autonomous University of Puebla. "Companies are going to be required to do more than abide by weak regional laws. Their codes of conduct must set global standards that treat workers as world citizens and guarantee them certain levels of dignity and respect."
The changes won in this scenic city filled with colonial churches some 70 miles southeast of Mexico City, a center of the textile industry since the 1930's, have also provided help for Mexico's fledgling independent labor movement.
With an explosion in the number of foreign-owned assembly plants since the North American Free Trade Agreement went into effect seven years ago, labor organizers hope the movement at Mexmode will inspire workers in 3,400 foreign-owned assembly plants across the country to fight against poverty wages and unsafe workplaces.
The fight will be a tough one. In recent months, in a tough economy, open acts of intimidation by government-controlled unions have shut down campaigns by independent unions and raised concerns about President Vicente Fox's commitment to labor reforms.
As the first opposition politician to win the presidency in more than seven decades, Mr. Fox promised to promote workers' rights and to dismantle labor organizations that had operated hand in glove with the former governing party, the Institutional Revolutionary Party. 
Critics charge that Mr. Fox has so far forged alliances with traditional union leaders and turned a blind eye to their corruption.
Under the former governing party, unions operated as pillars of the political machine, looking out for the interests of the employers. Workers were forced to belong, were rarely included in negotiations with management and never received a clear accounting of how their dues were spent.
Talking over plates of enchiladas and lemonade, Mexmode workers, who still earn $4.50 to $5 a day, said that conditions had improved but that they did not make enough money to support their children, and so they were forced to rely on their parents. Most of their men, they said, migrate to the United States.
"How can a man support his family on $5 a day?" asked Josefina Hernandez Ponce.
During a tour of the $25 million factory, which can produce 500,000 sweatshirts a month, Hoon Park, the general manager, pointed out that workers got free breakfast and lunch, birthday cake and performance awards.
Ms. Munoz was one of the workers fired after the cafeteria boycott. When workers turned to their former union leaders for help, Ms. Munoz said, they were ignored.
Officials of that union, the Revolutionary Confederation of Workers and Peasants, did not respond to several telephone requests for interviews.
In early January, Mexmode workers walked off their jobs and staged a sit-in. Police officers forcibly removed workers from the plant, and managers refused to let protest leaders return to work.
In response, leaders of the United Students Against Sweatshops staged their own protests outside Nike stores and offices across the United States. Officials from the Workers Rights Consortium and from Nike conducted separate investigations of conditions at Mexmode.
"The burning question on U.S. campuses has been whether colleges and universities can really make a difference in the conditions in overseas factories," said Scott Nova, the executive director of the Washington-based consortium. "Now we know the answer is yes."
Sportswear companies including Nike and Reebok have come under fire from the anti-sweatshop movement for conditions in the factories across Asia as well. And mirroring the workers' triumph here in Mexico, a new semi-independent trade union in a tennis shoe factory in China has won new rights for its workers.
The cross-border campaign prompted Nike to press managers at Mexmode to reinstate the ousted workers, to create a formal grievance process, to address complaints of harassment by its managers and to improve cafeteria conditions.
A Nike spokesman, Vada Manager, said the company takes seriously its power to make sure that its suppliers adhere to fair labor practices. He said some 50 employees at Nike were assigned to monitor compliance with the corporate codes of conduct.
"We remain vigilant about these issues," Mr. Manager said. "We have learned a lot" at Mexmode, he added, "that will allow us to apply new monitoring rules at other factories."
Two weeks ago, after Mexmode managers revoked the former union's collective bargaining agreement, workers were granted the right to form an independent union. Membership is voluntary. Yet leaders of the new union said they have already signed up 80 percent of the plant's workers.
