HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: STOCK MARKETS; 
Investors Expected to Take Raids in Stride

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON with MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Investors will enter unfamiliar territory as stock markets in the United States and around the world open this morning for trading.
 Asian stocks markets fell Monday morning, after the attack in Afghanistan. In Hong Kong, stocks were trading down 2.6 percent, and in South Korea a principal stock index fell 2.3 percent. 
 In the short term, a violent market reaction to yesterday's strike against Afghanistan is unlikely. The military action by the United States and Britain was widely anticipated, so analysts do not expect investors to panic today. But a major rally, like the one that followed the beginning of American bombing in the Persian Gulf war a decade ago, also appears to be a long shot. 
After falling sharply when trading resumed the week after the attacks of Sept. 11, stocks in the United States have gained back most of their losses, with most foreign markets also rebounding. A further rally would put markets higher than they were before Sept. 11, which analysts and investors consider unlikely given the uncertainty and disruption that the terrorist attacks generated.
"The markets have priced in and do expect a U.S. response," said David G. Dietze, president of Point View Financial Services, a money management firm, adding, "The markets have been looking very favorably on the way the U.S. has been building a strong, broad-based coalition."
Stock markets in the United States are open today, but bond markets are closed for Columbus Day. The Japanese stock market is also closed for a holiday. In early trading, most Australian and South Korean markets were slightly lower. 
The longer-term outlook may be less rosy. The history of the 20th century shows that the impact of military action on the markets and the economy depends on how well the United States fares in battle. And this conflict, which has already taken the lives of thousands of American civilians, is unlike any other the United States has waged.
If the United States and its allies can quickly oust the Taliban, capture Osama bin Laden, and uproot his terrorist network, the odds of a deep recession will drop significantly. A victory will help consumer and business confidence, making companies more willing to invest and consumers more ready to spend. The travel industry, hard-hit, might see the greatest gains. "A lot depends on the result of the attack," said Jack Shaughnessy, chief investment officer for Advest. 
If the United States overcomes the Taliban, stocks may rally strongly, especially because the policy makers are all taking action to aid the economy, he said. The Fed has cut interest rates nine times this year, with more cuts likely, while lawmakers and the president are working on tax cuts and new spending.
But if the terrorists mount more attacks against the United States, the economy and investor confidence could be dealt a heavy blow. A videotaped statement by Mr. Bin Laden released yesterday raised fears of more attacks. 
During the 20th century, stock markets had widely varying responses to war. In 1914, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 9.7 percent in the two days after World War I began on July 28, and the New York Stock Exchange was then closed for more than four months. But the early stages of the war proved to be a boon for American business, and the Dow rose 81.5 percent in 1915.
When Hitler invaded Poland on Sept. 1, 1939, prompting Britain and France to declare war, investors hoped that American businesses would again benefit from conflict in Europe, and United States stock markets rose strongly. Within a week, the Dow was up 11.6 percent.
But as Hitler's armies rampaged through Europe in 1940 and 1941, investors grew increasingly worried that the United States would be drawn into the conflict. By the end of November 1941, the Dow had fallen 25 percent from its high of 1939.
Stocks fell further after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941. But as war's tide turned, investors grew bullish. Over the next three years, the Dow nearly doubled.
The Persian Gulf war, which ended in a military victory for the United States and its allies, also helped stock markets. Markets rallied in January 1991, when the United States and its allies began bombing Iraq, and continued their gains throughout the year. The Dow ended 1991 with a gain of 20.3 percent, and the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 26.3 percent.
But the Vietnam War had a far different impact on stock markets and the economy. Heavy government spending on the military fueled inflation in the late 1960's, and as the war dragged on and domestic dissent worsened, markets stagnated. The decade ending Dec. 31, 1974, was one of the worst 10-year stretches for stocks since the Depression, with the Dow falling 36.4 percent and the S.& P. down 19.1 percent.

HEADLINE: Bloomberg Plows Ahead in Changed Political Landscape 

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

 BODY:
Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican businessman running for mayor, has been caught in the long shadow of the Democratic runoff between Mark Green and Fernando Ferrer ever since the primary two weeks ago.
 But Mr. Bloomberg has been putting his time outside the spotlight to strategic use. He has been methodically creating an image as an alternative to the Democrats. 
 As Mr. Green and Mr. Ferrer poke and nitpick each other, Mr. Bloomberg has been laying the cornerstones for his campaign against the eventual nominee. Though public opinion polls suggest he would lose to either of the Democrats in November, Mr. Bloomberg seems unworried by the odds with a month still to go and encouraged by the changed political landscape since the attack on the World Trade Center. 
After taking his advertisements off the air for two weeks because of the events of Sept. 11, Mr. Bloomberg has resumed his buying spree, spending about $1 million a week on new television spots that have been produced and written with the terrorism and its aftermath in mind.
"In a challenging news environment like New York is now, Bloomberg can't afford to let all of the attention go to the other two candidates," said Ken Goldstein, director of the Wisconsin Advertising Project at the University of Wisconsin in Madison, which analyzes political advertising. "The Democrats have a contested election in a week, and Bloomberg is still spending more than they are."
In both the advertisements and campaign appearances, Mr. Bloomberg has sought to position himself as a nonpolitician who, by inference, is immune to the internecine rivalries on display in the Democratic contest, and who is most likely to do what is right for the city. 
Mr. Bloomberg's aides suggest that each new barb exchanged between Mr. Green and Mr. Ferrer can only enhance Mr. Bloomberg's stature. The Democrats dismiss the idea, saying all will be forgotten after the runoff. In keeping with the theme of being above it all, Mr. Bloomberg rarely answers questions about his rivals and steadfastly refuses to criticize them.
"I am not a person to point out differences," he said last week. "I try in my personal life and with my company, and will do it as mayor, to point out similarities rather than differences. I think it is unhelpful in relationships to focus on the negatives."
In tandem, Mr. Bloomberg has moved to highlight his record as a successful and well-connected businessman.
Even more so than before the Republican primary, he has portrayed himself as someone in the know, who is accustomed to being at the helm of a big ship in both calm and troubled waters. He has even taken to dropping hints during news conferences that he has a list of heavy-hitting business leaders ready to step into top government posts in a Bloomberg administration.
As a result, Mr. Bloomberg's big media company, Bloomberg L.P., has assumed a more obvious presence in the campaign. Just a few weeks ago, when he was being criticized for a booklet of off-color jokes given to him by some employees at the company, Mr. Bloomberg told reporters that he no longer runs the company and that he rarely even visits its headquarters.
Now, a new advertisement shows him hard at work at his desk and it speaks almost exclusively about his business accomplishments. His daily schedule sometimes includes company-related events and his campaign aides keep a tally of the company's good deeds in the wake of the World Trade Center destruction (among them, providing 150,000 free meals for volunteers and others working at the site).
From a meeting with President Bush last week to an appearance before the Breast Cancer Research Foundation with its founder Evelyn H. Lauder, Mr. Bloomberg has played the part of chief executive officer as much as aspiring mayor. Mr. Bloomberg said that his candidacy came up only in passing during his 10 minutes with Mr. Bush.
"We talked about the needs of New York City and how I thought the federal government could help," said Mr. Bloomberg, who is the majority owner of Bloomberg L.P. but has handed off the day-to-day job of operating the company to run mayor. "I thanked him for the help to date, as a private citizen."
Just as Mr. Bush ran a campaign against the political establishment in Washington, Mr. Bloomberg appears to have pinned his mayoral hopes on a strategy that places a premium on his status as a political outsider. Though the underpinnings of the strategy are not new, Mr. Bloomberg is counting on the central theme finding new resonance with an electorate less tolerant of politics-as-usual and deeply worried about the city's economic future. 
"In these tough times, New York City needs a leader, not a politician," the announcer concludes in one of three new advertisements broadcast since Sept. 26 by Mr. Bloomberg.
Mr. Bloomberg says in another of them, "The bottom line: not just talk and promises, but results."
All of the advertisements focus extensively on the aftermath of the terrorist attacks and feature Mr. Bloomberg as calm, composed and even-handed in addressing the problems of running the city.
"The next mayor must lift our spirits, focus on rebuilding our city, every borough, all New Yorkers," Mr. Bloomberg says in one of them.
In his first week back on television, beginning Sept. 26 and ending Oct. 3, Mr. Bloomberg spent an estimated $1.2 million for 338 advertisements on the major broadcast channels, according to the Wisconsin Advertising Project. Over the same period, Mr. Green and Mr. Ferrer together spent an estimated $800,000 for 282 spots, the project said.
Mr. Bloomberg's advertisements were everywhere. His spots ran during "Frasier," "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire" and "Family Law." They also ran on "Monday Night Football," "Wheel of Fortune" and "Dateline NBC." And two of the new advertisements were 60 seconds instead of the usual 30 seconds, allowing them to "get out of the political box" and seem less like standard campaign pitches, according to Mr. Goldstein, who is a professor of political science. 
"The only example of a candidate who used lots of 60-second spots was George Bush in 2000," Mr. Goldstein said.
State Senator Guy J. Velella, the Bronx Republican leader who endorsed Mr. Bloomberg on Saturday, said Mr. Bloomberg was "holding his own" during the Democratic runoff on the strength of his television ads. He predicted the quality and scope of his advertising in the next month would determine Mr. Bloomberg's political fortunes on Nov. 6.
"I think TV is the key to the whole race," Mr. Velella said. "I have been in politics for 30 years, and I can tell you that in big offices like mayor, it is more and more media focused and less and less a grassroots operation."
Mr. Bloomberg's most recent advertisement seems to support the contention that his television campaign has a life of its own. The new advertisement promotes Mr. Bloomberg's economic development plan, including rebuilding Lower Manhattan.
"I have a five-borough plan to take on the crisis and begin the hard work of getting things done," Mr. Bloomberg says into the camera.
But asked about the plan during a visit to the Malcolm Shabazz Mosque in Harlem on Friday, Mr. Bloomberg acknowledged that it was still in the works. He said he would release it after the Democratic runoff on Thursday, when he expects the news media will show more interest.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL; 
Bonds and Henderson Combine to Make 2001 a Very Bad Year for the Babe

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Major League Baseball battered Babe Ruth this season. Not that the Babe should take it personally; it's just that he held so many records, he lost a bunch of them in these offensively inflationary times.
 Barry Bonds eclipsed yet another of the Babe's marks yesterday, finishing the season with an .863 slugging percentage after slugging his 73rd home run, further dwarfing Ruth's once-legendary total of 60. Ruth had held the highest slugging percentage, .847, since 1920. 
 Last week Bonds broke Ruth's season record for walks (he finished with 177), just as Rickey Henderson surpassed Ruth's career record for walks earlier in the season.
Henderson, who last week broke Ty Cobb's record for career runs, reached another milestone yesterday, his first-inning double for San Diego making him the 25th player in history to have 3,000 hits.
Lest Ruth fans become too disconsolate over his record-book erosion, he did hold onto one hitting distinction, albeit barely. In 1920 Ruth had a combined slugging percentage and on-base percentage of 1.379. Bonds, with a .515 on-base percentage, finished with a combined 1.378, showing what a remarkable performance he had. One more hit, even one more walk, would have sent Bonds past Ruth.
The only players who took a bigger beating than the Babe this year was the Texas Rangers' pitching staff. What does that have to do with anything?
Well, in a season loaded with developments mind-boggling and bizarre, the Rangers owner saved the most ludicrous development for last. He fired his general manager, whose payroll he hamstrung by overpaying by at least $100 million to sign Alex Rodriguez. Tom Hicks yesterday acknowledged Doug Melvin's contribution to the Rangers' three division championships in a four-year span, but he said, "The last two years have produced very disappointing results."
The last-place finishes that understandably disappointed Hicks were fueled by pitching. Last year the Rangers had a major league-worst 5.52 earned run average, but Hicks fell in love with Rodriguez and agreed to a contract number that only Rodriguez's agent could love -- $252 million.
Though he supported the signing, Melvin was clearly uncomfortable with it and embarrassed in the face of criticism from fellow general managers. Instead of focusing on the pitching improvements the team needed, the Rangers added another bat that they did not need. 
Rodriguez performed brilliantly, gaining career highs in home runs with 52 and runs batted in with 135. But the pitching staff was even worse than last year, finishing with a 5.73 E.R.A. So Melvin joins Johnny Oates, who resigned as manager a month into the season, as the two primary victims of the Rodriguez signing. The Rangers join Canada's two teams, Toronto and Montreal, as teams seeking new general managers. More are most likely to follow.
Melvin becomes an instant favorite to get the Blue Jays' job because he is a native of Chatham, Ontario, but he will also most likely be considered for other openings that could develop. The Yankees, for example. 
Brian Cashman, having already served a life sentence in his four-year term under George Steinbrenner, may decide to walk away and take a general managing job elsewhere. Melvin would be a natural replacement because he pitched in the Yankees' minor league system and began his front-office career with the Yankees.
Besides being saddled with a dreadful pitching staff, the Rangers had the misfortune of playing in the same division with the Seattle Mariners. Four American League teams finished with lower won-lost percentages than the Rangers, but no one finished as far back as the Rangers' 43-game deficit.
If baseball people were stunned that Bonds should break Mark McGwire's home run record only three years after he broke Roger Maris's record, here come the Mariners only three years after the Yankees set an A.L. record with 114 victories to win 116.
The only team that previously won 116 games was the 1906 Chicago Cubs, and the Mariners had a chance to break that record, too. But they lost the final game of the regular season yesterday to the Rangers, 4-3, on a ninth-inning run.
It remains to be seen if any team should come along in the next few years and eclipse the Mariners' record, just as it will be interesting to watch home run developments. After hitting No. 73 yesterday, Bonds initially said, "I think anybody can do it" when he was asked if he thought someone could eclipse his total. But in the next breath he said, "Break 73? I don't think anybody's going to do that."
Two very old records once again withstood challenges. Ichiro Suzuki of Seattle finished with 242 hits, short of George Sisler's 1920 record of 257, and Ruth's 1921 record of 457 total bases remains in the books. Luis Gonzalez of Arizona was threatening it earlier in the season but finished with 419, second to Sammy Sosa's 425.
Sosa finished with 64 home runs and 160 runs batted in, the third most R.B.I. ever produced by a National League hitter.
Bonds, Sosa, Gonzalez and Rodriguez were the members of the 50-homer club.
Jose Hernandez did not break the strikeout record. He finished with 185, four short of the record Bobby Bonds, Barry's father, set in 1970. But Hernandez lost a chance for the record because Davey Lopes, the Milwaukee manager, opted not to play him in the final two games.
The Brewers, however, became the first team in major league history to have more strikeouts (1,399) than hits (1,378).

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: FRONT-LINE ALLY; 
Pakistan's Leader Takes Steps to Solidify Control Ahead of U.S. Air Raids

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: QUETTA, Pakistan, Oct. 7 

 BODY:
Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, moved swiftly today to tighten his grip on the country's military by promoting two generals and restricting political opposition by placing a militant cleric under house arrest.
 The actions, coming hours before the air campaign began on Afghanistan, indicated that General Musharraf knew the timing of the American-British strikes, and wanted to ensure as much control as possible over the potentially volatile reaction within Pakistan. 
 In Islamabad, the capital, the ambassador of Afghanistan's Taliban rulers denounced the strikes as a terrorist act and said Afghans would be united in their resistance. 
"Afghanistan will rise against the new colonialists," said Ambassador Abdul Salam Zaeef. "We tried hard to find a solution to the problem, but America chose the path of power and arrogance. We cannot hand over Osama to America."
Pakistan, the only nation that still recognizes the Taliban government, was unsuccessful in efforts to broker a deal for the Afghan rulers to turn over Osama bin Laden, as the United States had demanded.
"We regret that diplomatic efforts to convince the Taliban leadership to respond to the international demands did not succeed and now military action has started against the Taliban regime," a Pakistan Foreign Ministry spokesman said. 
Muslim leaders across Pakistan swiftly denounced the attacks, calling them brutal and unwarranted. But there were few demonstrations and no reports of violence following the strikes, which occurred at about 9:30 p.m. local time. 
Here in Quetta, there were reports that refugees fleeing from Afghanistan included senior Taliban officials.
According to the Pakistan correspondent for the Far Eastern Economic Review, a publication based in Hong Kong, the mayor of the Afghan city of Kandahar, the spiritual center of the Taliban, as well as Islamic judges and members of the religious police, were among the defectors mixing with ordinary refugees.
Pakistani police said they were braced for anti-American protests on Monday, possibly starting after morning prayers in the country's mosques.
The government tried to reduce the chances of widespread unrest by placing Mullah Fazlur Rehman, the leader of the hard-line Jamiat Ulema-i-Islam political party, under house arrest. 
An advocate of a Taliban-style Islamic state in Pakistan, he was accused of taking someone carrying a rifle to an anti-American demonstration on Friday. But Pakistani officials said the government's chief concern was that Mullah Rehman was trying to incite mutiny in the armed forces.
General Musharraf's effort to strengthen his control over the military began on Saturday, when he extended his own three-year tenure as chief of the army staff, a position he had been required by law to relinquish earlier this month.
The next step came today with the promotion of two of his allies to top positions. Lt. Gen. Muhammad Aziz Khan, who played the crucial role in the 1999 military coup that brought General Musharraf to power, was made a full general and chairman of the joint chiefs of staff.
General Khan is regarded in some circles as an Islamist, and his promotion was seen as a way of both satisfying Islamic elements within the military and removing someone with Islamic leanings from direct control of troops.
Lt. Gen. Muhammad Yousuf, a longtime ally of General Musharraf and a pro-Western voice in the military, was also promoted to full general and made deputy chief of the army staff.
The promotions open the way for a broader reshuffle in Pakistan's powerful military. Analysts said that General Musharraf is building a more American-oriented senior staff in order to shore up support for the alliance with the United States against Afghanistan.
General Musharraf's early decision to back the American effort against the Taliban and Mr. bin Laden, whom the movement has sheltered for years, threatened to divide the nation.
In the first days after the decision, thousands of protesters took to the streets across the country, though the demonstrations have been smaller in recent days.
In the eastern Pakistan city of Lahore, a group of Muslim clerics met in special session to discuss the Afghanistan crisis after they learned of the attack. They condemned the strikes and said Americans now faced a "highly critical situation" in the Muslim world.
About 150 people gathered spontaneously in the Aabpara marketplace in Islamabad and chanted slogans in praise of Mr. bin Laden, but they dispersed after the police arrived in the area.
Reaction was mostly muted anger here in Quetta, a Taliban stronghold about 60 miles from the Afghan border and home to the families of several Taliban leaders.
Earlier in the day, Pakistani authorities began clearing the way for the American warplanes. The Civil Aviation Authority closed the airspace along a corridor into Afghanistan from the Arabian Sea and restricted any civilian aircraft to an altitude below 22,000 feet in the hopes of avoiding encounters with military planes.
Joint military-civilian airports in the southern cities of Pasni, Jiwani and Turbat were closed and civilian flights were restricted elsewhere in the country, Pakistan authorities said.

HEADLINE: Democrats' Clashes Grow Sharper in Final 2 Primary Debates 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
In back-to-back caustic and testy debates, Fernando Ferrer and Mark Green challenged each other's credibility yesterday, as Mr. Green said Mr. Ferrer had flip-flopped on abortion and the death penalty, and Mr. Ferrer disparaged Mr. Green for aligning himself with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's attempt to extend his term.
 With four days left before the Democratic mayoral primary runoff on Thursday, and polls showing those two Democrats in a dead heat, Mr. Green and Mr. Ferrer clashed with an intensity that had not before been seen in this campaign for mayor. 
 Mr. Green said Mr. Ferrer had failed to offer a plan on how he would lead New York City in recovering from the attack on the World Trade Center. He said one of the few rebuilding proposals Mr. Ferrer had made -- to disperse some of the office space that had been in Lower Manhattan to the other boroughs -- was "wrong and naive." 
"That's an ill-conceived suggestion," Mr. Green said. "They attacked there. That's where we have to rebuild -- not because of downtown Manhattan but to help and rescue the whole city."
Mr. Ferrer attacked Mr. Green for having agreed to Mr. Giuliani's attempt to extend his term up to three months, as a way of easing the transition at City Hall. "You have to do a gut check here, and that's what it was for me," he said.
And he dismissed Mr. Green's criticism about his response to the World Trade Center as a political attack by a candidate who, Mr. Ferrer asserted, saw his support slipping "and poll numbers dropping."
"To compare our ideas is fine," Mr. Ferrer said. "To denigrate ideas and say, 'Mine's a big idea and yours is a little idea,' is not only beside the point, it's frankly apart from what there should be in this debate, Mark." 
At that, Mr. Green turned to face Mr. Ferrer, seated in a chair next to him at WNBC-TV studio at Rockefeller Center 
"It's not beside the point -- it IS the point," Mr. Green said. "The greatest municipal crisis that we or any city has faced should test who responded well and who didn't." He added that "to say right away that, 'Gee, I was the borough president in the Bronx when there was rubble there,' " showed a "lack of appreciation of the magnitude of the economic impact, the safety impact and the federal impact."
One hour after the two men shook hands at the conclusion of their debate on WABC-TV, President Bush announced the launching of air attacks by the United States and Britain. Mr. Ferrer suspended the rest of his campaign events, as aides to both Democrats contemplated another week in this long campaign in which anything they did or said would be dwarfed by global events.
In tone and substance, the two debates -- a punchy and fast-flowing 30-minute appearance moderated by Gabe Pressman on WNBC, followed by a 60-minute session on WABC -- were the latest evidence of how quickly and dramatically the tenor of the contest had changed. The two men interrupted each other, glowered at each other and mocked each other with sharply sarcastic asides. At times, their encounters sounded more like a debate to be high school class president than to be the next mayor of New York.
"If you can't take the heat, you shouldn't be in the debate," Mr. Green snapped. 
Mr. Ferrer retorted: "Well Mark, I can certainly take the heat, but I'm not going to allow you to stand there and distort." And at another point, Mr. Ferrer was talking about rebuilding New York, and, speaking slowly, observed: "You know, we live in the 21st century, the communications age."
"That's true," Mr. Green said sarcastically.
Mr. Ferrer frowned. "Forgive me: I'd like to finish, Mark," he said.
After the candidates' first debate on Tuesday, some of Mr. Green's supporters expressed concern that Mr. Green, the public advocate, had shied away from engaging Mr. Ferrer, and they urged him to be more aggressive in drawing contrasts with his opponent. And that he did, repeatedly criticizing Mr. Ferrer, who responded by, in effect, attacking Mr. Green for attacking him.
"That's the the fifth attack that Mark is -- and I'm keeping score here -- from a fellow who promised primary night that he would not make negative attacks," Mr. Ferrer said wearily. Mr. Green had just asserted that Mr. Ferrer had switched his position so that he now said he opposed restrictions on late-term abortion and supported a moratorium on the death penalty.
Mr. Green insisted that he was not attacking Mr. Ferrer, but emphasizing differences between the two, which he asserted was a traditional form of political campaigning.
At both the NBC and ABC debates, Mr. Ferrer was asked about his apparent shift in position on the death penalty and on abortion restrictions between 1997, when he was running to win the Democratic nomination to challenge Mr. Giuliani, and presented himself as a moderate, and this year, when he has been running on the left.
Early in 1997, Mr. Ferrer switched his position from opposing the death penalty to supporting it. At the start of this campaign, Mr. Ferrer announced that he now supported a moratorium on executions, citing recent evidence that innocent people were being put to death.
At the WABC debate, he told a questioner that voters should not be confused. "I am a supporter of capital punishment," he said. "I also support the moratorium." 
On abortion, in his last campaign, he described late-term abortions as "barbaric," and added: "Every time a mother hiccups, that's no reason to abort a child." Mr. Ferrer said yesterday that notwithstanding those comments, he had always supported abortion rights.
"I haven't changed my position on it," he said, adding: "I am 100 percent pro-choice, have been my whole public life."
Mr. Green did not accept that assertion. "You're allowed to change your mind," he said. "But you've got to be honest with people when you do it. To say you didn't change your mind raises questions about your veracity on this issue."
He added: "You flip-flopped on choice and death and you should admit it." 
Mr. Ferrer shot back: "That's ridiculous."
The Bronx borough president then switched the subject to Mr. Green's support of Mr. Giuliani, asserting that Mr. Green had called him up soon after the mayor proposed extending his term. Mr. Ferrer said Mr. Green proposed that the two men stand together and oppose Mr. Giuliani. He suggested that Mr. Green then double-crossed him by backing Mr. Giuliani's position. Mr. Green denied that.
While Mr. Ferrer continued to insist that extending the mayor's term might still be considered when the Legislature meets later this month, Mr. Green declared that Albany had rejected the idea and that the issue was moot. Late yesterday, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, who has said many Assembly Democrats opposed the extension but that it could be considered after the runoff, said the proposal was now dead.
Mr. Ferrer and Mr. Green also tussled over the influence of the Rev. Al Sharpton, who has endorsed Mr. Ferrer. Mr. Ferrer expressed incredulity at Mr. Green's assertion that he had not sought Mr. Sharpton's support, leading to this exchange.
Mr. Ferrer: "Who are you trying to kid, Mark? I mean ----"
Mr. Green: "Stop acting, Freddy. I didn't ask for his support."
Mr. Ferrer: "Who are you trying to kid? You took them out to the theater, you had them over at your apartment for breakfast ----"
Mr. Green: "Did I ask him for his support?"
Mr. Ferrer: "You courted his support."
Mr. Green: "Freddy, you're not telling the truth."
Finally, Mr. Green said that he "didn't seek it the way you did," leading to another explosion between the two men. "Now you're trying to use it against me in the most cynical and divisive way," Mr. Ferrer said.
"Hold it: I didn't raise Sharpton: You did," Mr. Green said, adding: "You said I sought it. It's untrue. I'm going to call you on it."
By this point, Mr. Pressman, looking a bit like an exasperated viewer at a tennis match, urged his guests to move on to another topic.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: TONY BLAIR; 
In His Own Words

 BODY:
 Following are excerpts from a speech yesterday by Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain about his country's role in the attacks on Afghanistan, as recorded by The New York Times:

"The military action we are taking will be targeted against places we know to be involved in the Al Qaeda network of terror or against the military apparatus of the Taliban. This military plan has been put together mindful of our determination to do all we humanly can to avoid civilian casualties. I cannot disclose, obviously, how long this action will last, but we will act with reason and resolve. We have set the objectives to eradicate Osama bin Laden's network of terror and to take action against the Taliban regime that is sponsoring him.
 As to the precise British involvement, I can confirm that last Wednesday the United States government made a specific request that a number of U.K. military assets be used in the operation which has now begun, and I gave authority for these assets to be deployed. 
They include the base at Diego Garcia, reconnaissance and other aircraft, and missile-firing submarines. The missile-firing submarines are in use tonight; the air assets will be available for use in the coming days.
The United States are obviously providing the bulk of the force required in leading this operation, but this is an international effort. As well as the U.K., France, Germany, Australia and Canada have also committed themselves to take part in it. 
On the diplomatic and political front, in the time I've been prime minister, I cannot recall a situation that has commanded so quickly such a powerful coalition of support, and not just from those countries involved in military action, but from many others in all parts of the world. That coalition has, I believe, strengthened, not weakened, in the 26 days since the atrocity occurred. And this is in no small measure due to the statesmanship of President Bush, to whom I pay tribute tonight. The world understands that whilst, of course, there are dangers in action, the dangers of inaction are far, far greater: the threat of further such outrages, the threat to our economies, the threat to the stability of the world. On the humanitarian front, we are assembling a coalition of support for refugees in and outside Afghanistan, which is as vital as the military coalition. Even before Sept. 11, four million Afghans were on the move. There are two million refugees in Pakistan and one and a half million in Iran."

A full transcript of Tony Blair's remarks is available from The New York Times on the Web:
www.nytimes.com/2001/10/07/international/ 07BLAIR-TEXT.html

In a speech to the nation, Mr. Blair said American officials had requested British support in the attack. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: ARTS IN AMERICA; 
Guggenheims Offer Novelty In Las Vegas

BYLINE:  By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Oct. 5 

 BODY:
This city already has an Eiffel Tower, an Empire State Building and even an indoor version of the Grand Canal of Venice. So why not its own Guggenheim Museum? After all, New York, Venice and Bilbao each have one, as does Berlin, in a way.
 When it first arose about a year ago, the idea of a Guggenheim in Las Vegas -- a city known more for its kitsch than its art -- set off a round of clucking about the future of museums in America, about the blurring of lines between commerce and art, between culture and entertainment. If a major New York cultural institution opens in Las Vegas, charging tourists and gamblers $15 admission, would Disneyland be the next stop? 
 The debate ended with the opening of not one but two museums at the gargantuan 3,036-room Venetian Resort-Hotel-Casino. First there is a soaring 63,700-square-foot exhibition hall -- known as the Guggenheim Las Vegas -- designed by the Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas and inaugurated with the Guggenheim's signature "Art of the Motorcycle" exhibition. It was installed here by Frank Gehry, a favorite architect of the museum, with shiny swirls of stainless steel and sheets of chain-link curtains. 
And then in the lobby of the Venetian, just off the grand entranceway with its faux Tiepolo ceilings, is the smaller Hermitage Guggenheim Museum, a novel joint venture with the illustrious State Hermitage Museum of St. Petersburg, Russia. There, in a 7,600-square-foot space also designed by Mr. Koolhaas, with walls of reddish-brown Cor-Ten steel, hang (by way of powerful magnets) 45 paintings by Matisse, Picasso, Gauguin, Cezanne and other Impressionist and early Modern artists, drawn from the collections of the two museums.
Both museums are open from 9 a.m. to 11 p.m., and the Hermitage Guggenheim offers discounts to the young, charging $11 for students and $7 for those 6 to 12. Children under 6 are free.
Thomas Krens, director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and champion of its global ambitions, arrived in town Thursday on his own motorcycle. He said Mr. Koolhaas was chosen in part because his stern, rational aesthetic is the antithesis of Las Vegas's native flamboyance.
"In Bilbao we built an exuberant building in an industrial environment," Mr. Krens said of the acclaimed Guggenheim branch designed by Mr. Gehry. "This is an exuberant landscape, so we were looking for a more industrial building."
In six months the exhibition at the Guggenheim Hermitage will be replaced with other works from one or both of the two museums or perhaps from some other museum altogether. The concept here is novel and elastic, and for that reason a fitting response to the chameleonlike Las Vegas landscape.
David Hickey, an art critic and professor at the University of Nevada, called the Guggenheim's appearance here a logical next step for a museum after its extravaganza exhibition last spring of clothes by the Italian designer Giorgio Armani. That show was criticized for its commercial overtones.
"This just theatricalizes what was already going on at cultural institutions in New York," Mr. Hickey said. "I have no problem with any of it. But it's nothing that anybody here thought up."
The best news for Las Vegas, Mr. Hickey said, will be the impact of good art in an environment that does not really know what that is. "In general I believe that the good drives out the bad," he said. "You put a Jackson Pollock in your office, and you have to redecorate your office."
There have been other attempts to bring high culture to this city, and some at times have been successful. The gallery at the Bellagio Hotel begun by Steve Wynn, the casino magnate, was later filled by paintings from the Phillips Collection in Washington and most recently by the entertainer Steve Martin's collection. But it has been closed indefinitely, in part because of the economic blow felt here after the Sept. 11 attacks. In the first two weeks after the terrorism, the number of visitors to Las Vegas fell off substantially, resulting in layoffs that have already exceeded 10,000.
In the week after the attack there was some doubt about whether the Guggenheim Hermitage Museum could open as planned. In St. Petersburg and Moscow top officials weighed the risks and difficulties of transporting national treasures across the United States at a time of crisis against the value of forging ahead with a new relationship.
"It was a big decision," Culture Minister Mikhail Shvydkoi said. "But we understood we had to do it. At times like these, military cooperation is not enough. Now more than ever Russia must show that she is part of the civilization that is under attack by the terrorists."
The last of the Russian shipments -- deliberately distributed among five planes for security reasons -- arrived only on Tuesday night, just in time for a Friday opening. In the meantime ceremonies were toned down as the Russian contingent brought along ballet dancers and choral singers but left behind dance troupes of Cossacks and Gypsies whose boisterousness suddenly seemed inappropriate.
Both Mr. Shvydkoi and Dr. Mikhail B. Piotrovsky, director of the State Hermitage Museum, said they were somewhat puzzled by the criticism both here and at home that a Las Vegas location was somehow beneath the dignity of a museum started by Catherine the Great.
"We keep hearing a lot of criticism that this is somehow too commercial," Mr. Shvydkoi said. "But I think that shows a lack of understanding. What is the difference between an exhibit of paintings at Gorky Park, or Park of Culture, as it is called, and an exhibit in Las Vegas, which is a bit like America's own Park of Culture?"
"A Picasso doesn't become any worse for being in Las Vegas," he said. "And maybe the people who see it will become better."
For his part Dr. Piotrovsky said he found himself defending Las Vegas to his American friends. "This is America, while New York is really more a European city" he said, "Las Vegas is a big new thing that was invented here. It is a postmodernist city, if you define postmodernism as a fake that understands that it is fake."
Dr. Piotrovsky noted that revenue from the Las Vegas exhibition would go toward the Hermitage's ambitious $150 million expansion plan and not toward its modest but strained $14 million operating budget.
Dr. Piotrovsky cited initiatives taken at the Hermitage, including an expanding list of traveling exhibitions, permanent collections at Somerset House in London and one planned later for Amsterdam as well as a host of ventures in cyberspace.
But he said the Hermitage had proved resistant to the traditional moneymaking notions, or as he put it, "Shops, shops, cafes and more shops: our building just rejects them."
"Everybody says Tom Krens is too commercial," he said. "But all museums are commercial. This is just a more modern way to get money, and we definitely need money."
The financial arrangement for their joint museum is relatively simple. The Venetian has invested $25 million to $30 million to build the two museums and to install the motorcycle show. The Guggenheim will rent the larger hall, and both museums will rent the smaller lobby space and split other costs and profits.
There is no knowing how well they will do in a city that is so dedicated to popular culture. But the experience of the Bellagio gallery, where the Phillips Collection netted $1 million with a six-month exhibition, and other indicators suggest that they could draw thousands of visitors a day.
Most local experts predict that this venture will endure. "They are in it for the long haul," said Jerry A. Schefcik, director of the Donna Beam Fine Art Gallery at the University of Nevada. "I often used to wonder what it would take to bring a cultural institution like this to town, and I understood that there would have to be a casino involved because ultimately, we are a one-horse town."
Robert G. Goldstein, president of the Venetian, said: "My belief is that it will succeed. Any product attracts the audience it deserves. This will attract a mass audience, it's that good."

HEADLINE: Stocks Drop In Europe But Recover 

BYLINE:  BySUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 8 

 BODY:
European stocks recovered from early declines today, after investors were heartened by a steadier opening on Wall Street.
 Trading was calm across the Continent after the onset of American and British strikes against Afghanistan. "The Bush administration has done a good job of telling people that this will not be a weekend war," said G. Scott Clemons, who manages some $750 million in European equities for Brown Brothers Harriman in New York. The American-led bombing campaign "was so well telegraphed, it's not surprising to see the market hold its own." 
 The Dow Jones Stoxx Index of shares of 50 European companies recovered from a drop of 116.81 points, to close down just 0.86 of a point to 3,384.19. Markets in Frankfurt, Paris, Milan, Madrid, Amsterdam and Stockholm closed higher after initial declines. In London, the benchmark Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 shares recovered from a low of 4,900.7, to close down 0.06 percent to 5,032.7.
But the relative strength of Europe's leading exchanges masked a jitteriness among investors, who feared a retaliation.
"There is some nervousness, but we have spent the past four weeks getting used to the idea of some action," said Clive Beagles, who helps trade some $20 billion in equities for Newton Investment Management in London. "Most people are surprised it has taken this long."
Britons working in the City, London's financial district, have had the last quarter-century to get used to the idea that they could become targets of I.R.A. terror campaigns. But for Americans, even those living abroad, the notion that their safety is not assured takes some acclimation. Now many investment bankers and traders are shrinking from the spotlight even more than usual.
"I would have never thought twice about being quoted in a newspaper," said one American equity trader, who works for a large investment bank in London. "But now I don't want to draw attention to myself."
Stocks of insurance companies, airlines and financial institutions were again among some of the biggest losers today, as investors continued to worry that a prolonged conflict would further derail the global economy.
The airline industry suffered a further blow today, after a Scandinavian Airlines Systems commercial jetliner carrying 104 passengers and 6 crew members collided with a small plane and crashed into a hangar at Linate airport in Milan.
And shares of HSBC, Royal Bank of Scotland Group and Abbey National fell, as concerns mounted that a slowing economy might increase the rate of bankruptcies and loan defaults for their clients.
Drug makers and utilities were among some of the gainers, as investors search out what they hope will prove safe havens in a time of crisis. GlaxoSmithKline rose 0.6 percent, while AstraZeneca gained 0.5 percent.
Shares of technology and telecommunications stocks have also outperformed the broader market since the Sept. 11 attacks, mainly because they had taken such a hammering in prior months, traders said.
Also acting as a cushion for European exchanges today was the fact that many had been trading at three-year lows even before the Sept. 11 attacks. "There is decent value in European markets," Mr. Clemons, of Brown Brothers, said. "But that doesn't mean they can't go lower."

HEADLINE: Homegrown Guards 

BYLINE:  By HENRI E. CAUVIN 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 8 

 BODY:
The world's biggest security companies could be forced out of the lucrative South African market under legislation that would ban foreign ownership of such businesses.
 While the proposed law has been in the planning for months, the terrorist attacks on the United States have brought increased public attention on security here and given the matter added urgency. 
 The proposal, part of a bill scheduled for a vote this month, has outraged industry leaders and alarmed some investment experts, who say South Africa cannot afford to send such a signal to the world.
But important lawmakers from the governing African National Congress say that having multinationals in control of crucial companies in the industry is a threat to the national security of South Africa. 
Several foreign companies, including Securicor of Britain and the ADT unit of Tyco International of Exeter, N.H., have acquired subsidiaries in South Africa, where poor police service and one of the world's highest crime rates have made private security a booming business.
"This is a very sensitive industry," said Mluleki George, chairman of Parliament's committee on safety and security and principal sponsor of the proposal.
He said that many members of the police and military under apartheid had ended up in the security industry and that it would be much more difficult to monitor the personnel of companies that were in foreign hands. Critics say such fears are unfounded.
The bill, a sweeping effort to update oversight of the fast-growing industry, would require that registered security guards, their supervisors and security companies' corporate directors all be citizens or permanent residents of South Africa.
By saying at this time that the law would apply even to shareholders -- an interpretation that arose in recent weeks, during formal debate on the measure -- the legislature has aroused suspicion that it is making a backdoor move to open the industry to black entrepreneurs. None of the country's biggest security concerns have any significant black ownership, a problem the industry acknowledges and that experts say must be addressed.
But a spokesman for the Security Employers Alliance, an umbrella organization of trade groups here, says that if greater diversity is the goal, "there are other ways to bring that about."
Indeed, some say that the international interest has encouraged consolidation, which in turn could actually help diversify the business, with its handful of giants and thousands of bit players.
"The more dominated a sector is by a few companies, the easier it is to push through black empowerment," said Reg Rumney, a director at Business Map, an investment consulting firm in Johannesburg. "You can exert leverage on bigger companies. They are clear targets. How do you say to a guarding company that has three people that 25 percent need to be black?"
Mr. George said that the industry did need to diversify but denied that this motivated the proposal.
The impact could be significant, and not only in the security industry. Britain, where Securicor is based, is one of South Africa's biggest investors and an important trading partner.
Nick Sheppard, the spokesman for the British High Commission in South Africa, said the proposed law could violate a 1998 trade agreement between the countries.
"We are concerned," he said, "and we are talking to the companies about what action we should take." 
Alec Erwin, South Africa's trade minister, thinks that there are other ways to meet national security concerns, a spokesman said, and he will take up the matter this week with the minister of safety and security, who backs the foreign-ownership ban.
Representatives of ADT and Securicor did not return calls seeking comment.
South Africa's private security business is one of the few bright lights in an economy that, while it is stable, has yet to produce the amount of growth the country needs to deal with huge and deeply entrenched income inequality -- a legacy of apartheid.
With violent crime increasingly spreading to affluent white neighborhoods, demand for armed patrols has surged. The thick walls and high gates that ring many houses in Johannesburg are almost invariably emblazoned with the signs of private-security companies.
This year, Credit Suisse First Boston estimated the size of the country's security industry at $1.2 billion at current exchange rates and found that spending on security, as a percentage of gross domestic product, was 1.25 percent, the highest in the world.
While demand is projected to slow somewhat, the introduction of new technologies, in particular the integration of fire and medical protection into the packages of security services, has been seen as a key to sustaining growth. 
And experts say it is foreign concerns like ADT, a pioneer in alarm systems, that will drive the new push into security technology -- if they are not forced out.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE PORT; 
Ripples From New York Start to Subside at Baltimore Waterfront

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, Oct. 4 

 BODY:
First came the unexpected shipment of a couple of hundred Jaguars, originally destined for New York. Soon cruise ships whose Hudson River dock was serving as a morgue began to arrive. And just the other day, the sailing of the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy from Newport News, Va., delayed for four hours a container ship headed here, raising the cost of unloading.
 But the commercial ripples at the port here from last month's terrorist attacks have now largely subsided, and the movement of goods is little changed from the preattack pace, according to the United States Customs Service, port officials, freight forwarders and others in the shipping business. 
 "For a period of three or four days, we handled some additional New York cargo," said David M. Thomas, general manager of operations at the 570-acre Dundalk Marine Terminal, the biggest for general cargo here, in the harbor where Francis Scott Key wrote "The Star-Spangled Banner" in 1814.
"After that," he added as he watched longshoremen simultaneously load and unload the Atlantic Concert, a container ship more than 1,000 feet long with its loading ramp down, "It's been business as usual."
To be sure, security at this port -- the nation's ninth biggest by dollar volume -- has been stepped up, some costly overtime work is still required, customers are extra vigilant about the timeliness of shipments, and the strain of more than three weeks of 12- and 13-hour shifts for customs workers still lingers.
"We pretty much doubled everybody's workload to keep the traffic moving," said Charles Bartoldus, director of the Customs Service for the port as well as for Baltimore-Washington International Airport. As a result, he said, "there was no disruption or backup in traffic flow," at least no delays or disruptions in traffic flows big or persistent enough to prompt complaints.
Robert Gould, a spokesman for the CSX Corporation, which has major railroad operations here, said, "We haven't seen any impact on our operations."
According to Mr. Thomas, whose employer is the Maryland Port Administration, trucks have spent an average of 28 minutes picking up or discharging goods and 50 minutes when doing both, unchanged from before the terrorist attacks.
The number of containers lifted on and off ships, 36 per stevedore gang an hour, is also unchanged, he said. The figures are for the port's container-only Seagirt Marine Terminal adjacent to Dundalk.
Richard Higgins, marketing director for John S. Connor Inc., one of the area's biggest freight forwarders, also found little fault with port operations in recent weeks. "We saw a little bit of a delay right after the incident," he said, but "the cargo was being handled and released by customs" with near-usual dispatch.
He said Connor's customers, including one who had two containers "bumped" when a vessel sailed without them, had asked to be informed promptly of any chance their merchandise might not be transported as scheduled. "There's a lot of just-in-time concerns," said Mr. Higgins, referring to the practice of many cost-conscious manufacturers of taking delivery of materials only a short time before they are needed.
He added that new details had been required in the documentation of shipments and that there was also "some anxiety among the employees" about coming to work. Connor, along with the Maryland Port Administration, is housed in the heart of downtown in Baltimore's World Trade Center, which has been subjected to multiple evacuations and has more than once put in place extremely tight security measures.
 On Oct. 5, the Coast Guard began requiring 96 hours' notice of ship arrivals instead of 24 hours, giving various agencies more time to plan clearances. 
The slowdown in the economy this year has no doubt helped the port cope with increased post-attack security efforts, including putting goods under scrutiny that is said to be improved, but is not necessarily broader or more intense. Another factor was generally ample capacity here, the port having lost some traffic to competitors. Contracts with longshoremen here, for one thing, has long barred work in even the lightest rain.
Port and industry people credit the Customs Service with efficient redeployment of personnel in the attacks' aftermath, shifting many inspectors to the airport in support of federal marshals and replacing them with specialists who check cargo declarations and another group that classifies and values goods.
"We did better, more refined targeting" of goods selected for physical inspection, Mr. Bartoldus said, and his people paid less immediate attention to the clerical work, "which we can do after the fact."
"We kept all business cargo flowing in the port of Baltimore without disruption," Mr. Bartoldus declared. "If there is unhappiness out there, I haven't heard of it." 

CORRECTION-DATE: October 10, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the diversion of shipping from New York to Baltimore referred incorrectly to a longshoremen's work rule. Although contracts once barred them from working in the rain, they now handle cargo in all weather.

HEADLINE: Review/Fashion; 
Taking a Back Seat To Unfolding Events

BYLINE:  By GINIA BELLAFANTE 

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 8 

 BODY:
Seven months ago the last time the affluent society's tastemakers convened here to think about clothes -- the Champagne that had fueled fashion's party for so long was already showing signs of running low. It was in mid-March, at the showing of the fall 2001 collections, that stock prices fell drastically enough to bring an end to the bull market and the euphoric new-economy spending that attended it. If French fashion seemed of questionable significance before that moment, it became even less justifiable as skirts resembling swatches of AstroTurf appeared on the runway while financial advisers on CNN were warning investors to put their money in recession-proof companies like those that make toothpaste. The mood was shifting, and presumably fashion would be shifting right along with it.
 No one, of course, could have anticipated then just how dramatically at variance with fashion's giddy nature the mood would turn out to be. The spring 2002 collections now under way in Paris were dreamed up long before the attacks of Sept. 11. But already they are providing a hint of just how ill-equipped fashion may be to deal with the reality of upheaval. 
 Unbeknown to anyone present at the time, the Comme des Garcons show early Sunday evening began at almost the moment the United States initiated its assault on Afghanistan. More than any other designer, Rei Kawakubo, that label's creative engine, is considered someone who thinks. Indifferent to trend, she has always seemed connected to ideas beyond the half dozen or so that keep recirculating within the insular universe of fashion. So it was disheartening to learn that what appeared to be a gesture of social engagement derived merely from the kind of whim that moves so many of fashion's lesser minds.
The models in Ms. Kawakubo's show wore their hair matted down and tucked under skintight caps that looked like early-aviation-era helmets and were made from newspaper, Le Monde's headlines in full view. The decision to style the models in this manner was reached the day before the show, suggesting that Ms. Kawakubo intended to make a statement about the extent to which the privileged classes are now inhibited by political forces beyond their control.
But after the show, Adrian Joffe, who is both the managing director of Comme des Garcons and the reticent Ms. Kawakubo's husband, stressed that there was no such idea at play. "No, no, Rei doesn't usually have a political message," Mr. Joffe explained. "She wanted to feature a small head, like a bird." Newspapers were used, he said, because the collection was a homage to white, and they are "gray and graphic and looked good with the clothes." 
As happened in a number of collections in recent days, Ms. Kawakubo's show contained feats of sculptural prowess: a dress of tiered eyelet, others that revealed an exquisite manipulation of accordion pleats. But now, more than ever, the notion of the fashion object as museum piece seems little more than a flexing of narcissistic muscle.
The collection that the Dutch team of Viktor & Rolf showed on Saturday evening featured jackets made entirely of stiff bows the size of Cornish hens. They also showed stiff collars rising up to consume heads and trousers that tiered out from midtorso to reveal three separate waistbands. All the clothes were cut in communion-dress white, which seemed merely a response to the team's all-black collection of last season. It's true that each piece in the show amounted to a magnificent display of craftsmanship, but given the new mood, how will that matter two minutes after the last model has walked down the runway? 
Unwearable runway fashion, by turns loopy or ingenious, has traditionally been justified as the means by which designers build their identities, identities they trade on to sell the shoes, cocktail dresses and doctor bags that offer their distinct but tempered fantasies of womanhood. But how many different fantasies will there be room for when actual women mostly just want to feel safe?
There was a time when the pose of sexual aggressiveness so unequivocally endorsed by Alexander McQueen's show on Saturday would have had less trouble attracting followers. Mr. McQueen drew from the realm of the bullfighting ring, stabbing his deconstructed gowns with picadors' lances from which the trains of the gowns were hung. He tore up men's suit jackets so that sleeves were sprouting from hips, and performed mind-boggling dissections of corsets, which left them worthy of inclusion in a Gray's Anatomy of Fashion, if such a compendium existed. Mr. McQueen has excelled so stupendously at the science of his work that he is uninterested in using it to make his audience feel anything.
What ultimately seemed to be motivating Mr. McQueen, now backed by Gucci, was a desire to show up the conglomerate's other young star, Nicolas Ghesquiere, who last season demonstrated little restraint in displaying his technical sophistication, using the corset as his medium.
Perhaps the problem with Parisian fashion is that it is plagued with too many designers who feel as if their gift for incision exonerates them from having to wrestle with ideas. It is hard to fathom the kind of self-imposed isolation that would lead a designer to stage an entire show to demonstrate just how many different, unpredictable ways he can cut a piece of denim. Junya Watanabe turned out one bias-cut, couture-draped, cummerbund-appended distressed denim gown after another, all to the music of Chicago and to what larger artistic or commercial purpose one will never know. 
Nor was it easy to understand why Yohji Yamamoto's show took longer to sit through than some works of Noh theater. Mr. Yamamoto invoked kimono prints to make athletic pants. He played with satin bombers, making them look like so many variations of a Members Only jacket. There is always a place for Mr. Yamamoto's quiet poetry, but sometimes you can't help feeling that life is too short.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: ASIA; 
StocksFall, With Notable Losses in Some Muslim Lands

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Oct. 8 

 BODY:
Financial markets across Asia shivered today after American and British military strikes against Afghanistan. But the greatest tremors were felt in parts of Southeast Asia, where investors fled from countries with large, potentially restive Muslim populations.
 Indonesia's currency and stock market tumbled amid fears that the military action would provoke a backlash from Islamic militants. Authorities in the capital, Jakarta, deployed 3,500 police officers to keep order after a few radical Muslim groups threatened reprisals against United States citizens and companies. 
 Shares fell 3.8 percent, and Indonesia's currency, the rupiah, dropped as much as 6.4 percent.
Two other Asian countries with significant Muslim populations, the Philippines and Malaysia, also suffered market declines, though not as sharp as in Indonesia, the world's most populous Islamic nation.
"A lot of traders took the attitude 'sell everything Muslim, including Singapore,' " said William H. Overholt, chief Asian strategist at Nomura International. "The markets are overreacting to things they don't understand."
Mr. Overholt noted that Malaysia was politically stable, and that Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad had moved to mollify his country's Muslim majority by denouncing the military strikes today.
The Philippines is fighting a Muslim insurgency, Mr. Overholt noted, with the rebels based on the southern island of Mindanao. The nation's president, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, has backed the American-led coalition against terrorism, even offering combat troops.
Shares in the Philippines slid 3.65 percent today, closing at their lowest level since 1991. Jitters in Manila were magnified by the bombing of two hotels in Mindanao by the Abu Sayyaf group, a radical Islamic movement.
The benchmark stock index in Hong Kong lost 2.76 percent today, while Taiwan's market fell 1.82 percent and South Korea's declined 1.15 percent. (Tokyo markets were closed for a holiday, Sports Health Day.) Analysts said that the declines were predictable and that trading was orderly.
"There was no panic," said Henry Lee, managing director of Hendale Asset Management in Hong Kong. "But the markets are looking at this differently than the gulf war because of the potential for a counterstrike."
Despite the losses in Hong Kong, analysts said that it, and other markets like South Korea, were likely to draw capital away from some in Southeast Asia because of concerns about political instability. That could widen a gap between north and south Asia that has existed since the financial crisis of 1997-98.
Hong Kong, in particular, may be seen as something of a safe haven because of its links to China, analysts said. Although China has its own problems with a restless Muslim population in the far western province of Xinjiang, it has been largely insulated from the worldwide war on terrorism.
"You're going to get a new iron curtain between countries the U.S. trusts and countries the U.S. doesn't trust," said Simon L. Ogus, chief executive of DSG Asia, an economic research firm here. "Trade and capital flows will be diverted through favored partners."
Such a distinction could badly hurt Indonesia, where anti-American sentiment has been simmering. Bands of Muslim extremists swept through hotels in the central Java city of Solo in recent weeks, looking for American visitors. Others have threatened the United States ambassador, Robert S. Gelbard.
About 200 people protested today in front of the American embassy, which was closed and guarded by 300 police officers and tanks. The embassy warned United States citizens to stay home and exercise "maximum caution."
The political tension there is coming at a particularly inopportune time. Indonesia's president, Megawati Sukarnoputri, has won respect for her economic policies, and despite a general economic slowdown, the rupiah had been strengthening. Mrs. Megawati was the first leader of a Muslim country to meet President Bush after last month's attacks, offering measured support for his campaign against terrorism.
Experts note that Islamic extremists are a tiny minority in a country of more than 200 million. But if they carry out their threats, it would persuade American companies that Indonesia is no longer a safe place and presumably choke off much of the foreign investment that is trickling into the country.
"If terrorists are seen to be operating in Indonesia, the ability of foreign capital to go there will be much reduced," said Eugene K. Galbraith, an Indonesia expert and the founder of Asiawise.com, an Internet news service. "How could foreign companies put people or operations there?"
"These events could really relegate Indonesia to permanent second-class status in the world financial community," Mr. Galbraith added.

HEADLINE: PARIS DIARY; 
Refugees at the Ritz

BYLINE:  By Guy Trebay 

 BODY:
A quiet panic seems to hang in the air at the spring 2002 ready-to-wear collections in Paris, affecting even the most heedless observers of fashion's ongoing parade. It is not that the city itself has reacted with conspicuous alarm to the terrorist attacks in the United States and the allied bombing of Afghanistan. As beautiful as ever under chalky autumn skies, the city is steadfast in conforming to its pictorial cliches, and its residents to their temperamental ones. The overarching anxiety takes a subtler form.
 Despite a shaky economy, luxury suppliers remain busy. Stores as diverse as Colette, the laboriously hip "concept" boutique; Annick Goutal, the high-end French perfumer; and Hermes, supplier of status purses and power ties, have been thronged in recent days. Despite discovery of a terrorist plan to bomb the American Embassy, signs of heightened security are not overwhelming. 
 It is true that parking is sporadically suspended on the Rue du Faubourg St.-Honore, where both the embassy and the flagships for many high-end retailers are located. A fortified security force of 5,000 has been deployed to airports and national borders. Public trash cans have been sealed, metal detectors installed and bag checks made common. But these efforts can seem less prophylactic than symbolic. Tickets to fashion shows are still being bootlegged. Fanatics, of the fashion sort, are still sneaking into shows. In certain cases, stealth has been anything but necessary; on Saturday, a number of fans headed for the concert of the rhythm-and-blues singer R. Kelly accidentally wandered into Yohji Yamamoto's show, which was held in another part of the sports arena the two events shared.
Inside the catwalk shows, one finds a group of people whom recent events have marooned from significance. More than ever the fashion flock has come to resemble a small but decorative 18th-century court whose purpose in the larger scheme is far from secure. Wandering from New York to Milan and Paris like glamorous vagrants, they continue to follow the familiar circuit from five-star hotel (the Ritz, the Crillon and the Meurice) to celebrity dinner hangout (Stresa and Voltaire), although now they bypass the shoemaker Rodolphe Menudier's fabulously costly shop near the Place Vendome and seek out pharmacies that carry Cipro, the antibiotic used in the treatment of anthrax. 
"It's been like that since Milan," Sally Singer, the features editor at Vogue, said. "It's the one thing everyone's buying. You hear about a driver who knows a friend who knows a pharmacist who still has some in stock." 
The current climate has abruptly changed the fashion script, slightly souring the comic operetta atmosphere that is so much, and often so charmingly, a part of fashion's public identity. Those few retailers who made the trip to Europe now seem to view their participation mainly as a diplomatic act. Everyone knows that, even before Sept. 11, the apparel business in the United States was in trouble. "I've never seen changes as rapid and as deep and large," said Todd Slater, a retail analyst at Lazard Freres in New York, referring to second-quarter data compiled by his firm showing a decline in women's wear sales of 16 percent and in men's wear of 14 percent.
"I've been instructed not to talk about business," Kal Ruttenstein, Bloomingdale's longtime fashion director, remarked, before the start of Alexander McQueen's presentation in Paris. Still, "it's going to get worse before it gets better," Mr. Ruttenstein said. 
Collections of clothes conceived of well before Sept. 11 are suddenly subject to intensified readings. Critics ask what was meant by Mr. McQueen's theatrical, and distinctly insensitive, use of a stage set covered in smoke that billowed in ways that inevitably evoked the World Trade Center collapse? They demand to know the significance of many thoughtful designers, among them Hussein Chalayan and Junya Watanabe, choosing to present unraveled, half-torn garments that used deconstruction as their principal metaphors. 
"Tailoring didn't seem appropriate," Mr. Chalayan told Suzy Menkes, the fashion critic for the International Herald Tribune, after his showing, as if that were any kind of explanation.
But after all, fashion designers are not fortune tellers (or civics majors, for that matter). One can read meaning into the clothes without forgetting that there are times when fashion does not mean all that much. Earlier this season, just before the show cycle began in a New York that does not exist anymore, one fashion editor remarked on the enduring fascination with military camouflage cloth, a once ubiquitous fabric that, at least in the Paris of this moment, is nowhere to be found. "We live in an environment that is very safe somehow, and we are attracted by themes of military adventure because we live in anti-heroic times," Stefano Tonchi, the fashion creative director of Esquire, said only a month ago. 
He was referring, among other things, to a terrorist-inflected collection by the Belgian designer Raf Simons that took inspiration from what French Vogue, which features Mr. Simons's clothes in its October issue, called the right thing to wear on clandestine missions or in contaminated hot zones. Presumably, this was ironically intended. But that was then.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Lebenthal to Be Sold To MONY for $25 Million
Lebenthal & Company, a New York institution made famous by its ads extolling the virtues of tax-free municipal bonds, plans to be acquired by the MONY Group for about $25 million.
 Lebenthal will operate as a subsidiary with MONY's Advest Group, a Hartford-based brokerage firm that MONY acquired in August 2000. Alexandra Lebenthal will stay on as president and chief executive of the Lebenthal division. Shares of the MONY Group fell 78 cents, to $32.20. Page C4. 

U.S. Consumers Remain Undeterred
The bombing in Afghanistan and the threats of retaliation do not appear to have deterred Americans from continuing to return to their malls and movie complexes. B12.

The military action in Afghanistan did not touch off a drastic new plunge in air travel, airlines and travel agents said. B12.

Ads Are Shifted Again for News
For the second time in less than a month, the major television networks scrambled their advertising schedules -- moving, postponing and canceling commercials -- to cover breaking news. The maneuvering included lengthening programs, shifting a show from one network to another and calling marketer and agency executives at home to buy commercial time on short notice. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C13.

Economics of Fighting Terrorism
Given the nature of the conflict with terrorism, the economy is not likely to be revived by the developments that fueled previous wartime booms, like surging orders for tanks and airplanes or demand for workers to replace those who go off to fight. This time, the course of the economy will be determined in large part by the relative power of two opposing forces: the uncertainty that has gripped businesses, consumers and investors and government economic policy. News Analysis. B12.

Images of War Are Scarce for TV
For the second consecutive day, frustrated television executives groped unsuccessfully for images of war in Afghanistan and said the United States attack was shaping up as the least accessible in television history. B12.

A Shareholder Fight at Metromedia
The investment of John Kluge, the 87-year-old media entrepreneur, in Metromedia International Group has fallen from just less than $100 million to just less than $21 million. Some investors suspect that Mr. Kluge plans to buy out the outside shareholders while the stock is depressed and then sell the company's assets at a markup. One dissident shareholder has called for an increase in the number of outside directors to prevent Mr. Kluge from taking the company private. Market Place. C8.

A.M.D. to Introduce Latest Chip
Advanced Micro Devices will introduce today its newest microprocessor for desktop microprocessors in an effort to regain both lost ground on its rival, Intel, and momentum in a troubled chip industry. C2.

Limbaugh Says He Is Almost Deaf
Rush Limbaugh, the country's most popular talk radio host, announced to his listeners that he has suffered severe hearing loss over the last four months and is almost deaf. A14.

South Africa May Ban Some Guards
The world's biggest security companies could be forced out of the lucrative South African market under legislation that would ban foreign ownership of such businesses. The attacks on the United States have given the matter added urgency. World Business, Section W.

Swissair Resumes Half Its Flights
Swissair was operating only half its flight schedule and said it would cut 9,000 jobs as banks, creditors and shareholders wrangled over who was at fault for last week's grounding of the airline. World Business, Section W.

Glaxo Allows Generic AIDS Drugs
GlaxoSmithKline has handed over rights to its market-leading AIDS medicines in South Africa to a local generic drug company. C4.
