HEADLINE: Lebenthal to Be Acquired by the MONY Group 

BYLINE:  By ANN WOZENCRAFT and JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
Lebenthal & Company, a New York institution made famous by its quirky ads extolling the virtues of tax-free municipal bonds, will announce today that it is being acquired by the MONY Group. 
 The boards of both companies have approved the deal, which is estimated to be worth around $25 million. 
 Lebenthal, founded in 1925, will operate as a subsidiary with MONY's Advest Group, a Hartford-based brokerage firm that MONY acquired in August 2000. The acquisition is being made using 50 percent cash and 50 percent MONY Group stock. 
Alexandra Lebenthal will stay on as president and chief executive of the Lebenthal division. She will also take on a senior management role at Advest. Her father and Lebenthal chairman, James Lebenthal, will become chairman emeritus and serve as a consultant. 
Ms. Lebenthal said that merging with Advest would allow the company to grow significantly by tapping into MONY's resources. "It's extremely difficult to run a profitable small firm in today's world with the overhead that we have and our technology needs," she said. "I think we've done a great job diversifying the business, but we're limited as a smaller player.'
Lebenthal, a municipal bond retailer, was started by Louis and Sayra Lebenthal as an odd-lot bond clearinghouse that made municipal bonds available to individual investors. Before then, municipal bonds were primarily owned by wealthy investors and institutions. 
After a stint as an entertainment reporter and television producer, James Lebenthal returned to the family business in 1967. Over the years, he made hundreds of whimsical ads, with catchy phrases like "Bonds are my babies" and "Built by Bonds," making Lebenthal a household name in New York. Typically, he introduced himself as Jim Lebenthal.
In 1995, he turned over the daily running of the firm to his daughter, Alexandra. Under her direction, the firm has expanded from its traditional base of municipal bonds to include stocks, mutual funds and portfolio management. 
While the company is small by Wall Street standards, with only 100 employees, MONY is hoping that the Lebenthal brand name will lure investors. "Lebenthal is very well respected and we want to take advantage of that brand name," said Michael I. Roth, MONY's chairman and chief executive since 1993.
Since becoming a public company in 1998, MONY has been trying to increase its size and broaden its array of products and services. Lebenthal will be its fifth acquisition. In February 2001, MONY purchased Matrix, a small mergers-and-acquisitions specialist based in Richmond, Va., that works with deals valued from $25 million to $200 million. 
For most of its 158-year history, MONY has concentrated on life insurance. But now 60 percent of its operating income is from commissions and fees on mutual funds, securities transactions, investment banking and annuities, which are similar to mutual funds but include an insurance feature.
"We were interested in growing our retail bond business," said Grant W. Kurtz, the chief executive of MONY's Advest unit. 
Mr. Kurtz said Advest planned to move its municipal bond operation into Lebenthal's offices. He said none of Lebenthal's 100 employees would lose their jobs immediately, but that eventually less than 10 jobs would be eliminated. Advest announced in June that it was cutting 150 of its 1,800 positions.
Ms. Lebenthal has been outspoken about the lack of progress women have made on Wall Street. During her tenure, Lebenthal has made a concerted effort to reach out to women and younger investors. In her new role at Advest, Ms. Lebenthal said she planned to continue her focus on women investors by starting a Women's Initiative that will focus on investors of all income groups.
"We need women in all income brackets to feel that their money is important and that it's the same color as men's," she said.
Analysts reacted to the deal skeptically. MONY, a relatively small insurer with assets of about $25 billion, has been struggling to compete with the giants. "MONY doesn't have nearly the scale required to compete these days," said Colin Devine, an insurance analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. 
Mr. Devine said Lebenthal would mesh well with MONY's Advest unit. But he said the parent company's biggest problem is that its return on equity has been running around 6 percent, compared with more than 15 percent for the industry leaders.
"This acquisition fails to address the fundamental problems facing MONY," he said, "which are lack of earnings growth, inadequate return on capital and uncertain strategic outlook in an industry that is consolidating, and increasingly gaining economies of scale. Their competition is not insurance companies their own size or even other insurance companies. It's really the Merrill Lynches, the American Expresses and the other really big guys."
Vanessa Wilson, a life insurance analyst at Deutsche Bank Securities, said: "The Lebenthal name certainly provides a lot of cachet, but it's only a small step. This acquisition gives MONY access to more high-net-worth individuals without a big capital investment."

HEADLINE: One Part Columbus Day, and One Part 4th of July 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
Under seas of American and Italian flags, thousands of marchers surged up a sun drenched, crowd-lined Fifth Avenue yesterday in a decidedly untraditional Columbus Day Parade that combined the patriotic themes of a nation newly at war with the tensions of a city under the threat of terrorism.
 There were traditional displays of Italian-American pride and subdued cameos by mayoral candidates. But the usual ethnic braggadocio and the talk about who discovered the New World were set aside as bands, floats and uniformed marchers turned the 57th annual parade into a Norman Rockwell poster for America and a remembrance of heroes and the missing and dead at the World Trade Center. 
 On a day that seemed more like an old-fashioned Fourth of July, bands played "God Bless America" and "The Star-Spangled Banner," military personnel and vehicles joined a three-hour line of march, and crowds that parade organizers called the largest in memory waved flags and spoke of a need to conquer fears and support the city and the nation in a time of crisis. 
"I think it's important that we aren't afraid," said Tim Amuchastegui, 50, a contractor from Klamath Falls, Ore. "Osama bin Laden has done what he's done and he may do more. We came all the way across the country to show support for New York."
Nearby, Mike Falcone, 70, who attended with 12 members of his Staten Island Bocce Club, said, "It gets you out of your funk to come out on a beautiful day like this, and there was no way I was missing this parade out of all the ones I've been to. It feels more patriotic this year. I like it that way."
It was a blustery autumn afternoon, with cornflower blue skies, green leaves fluttering out of Central Park, and splashes of dazzling color: bright green and gold uniforms, jugglers in white, celebrities in shiny red cars, and flags everywhere -- waved by spectators and marchers, on T-shirts and hats, draped from buildings and light poles, and on every float, with one exception.
The Arab-American Parade Committee float sported a score of flags of various Arab nations, but not the Stars and Stripes. Unlike the other floats, too, it was unoccupied. As it passed 49th Street, spectators reacted coolly. Some applauded, others watched in silence.
City police officers and firefighters were represented by vehicles rather than marching contingents, whose participation was deemed inappropriate given the heavy losses of life -- 343 firefighters and 23 police officers -- at the trade center.
Security was typical for a parade. There were uniformed police officers on every corner, and barricades along the curbs kept the crowds on the sidewalks. A man who ducked under a barricade was tackled by officers as he tried to cross the line of march near 49th Street, but the police said there were no arrests.
An unmarked black van and a detail of police bodyguards hovered about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani as he strode up the avenue with Gov. George E. Pataki and Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican candidate for mayor. The Democrats, Mark Green and Fernando Ferrer, who face each other in a runoff on Thursday, marched as well, as did Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.
But it was Mr. Giuliani who drew the attention, as crowds yelled, "Rudy! Rudy!" and shouted praise for his handling of the crisis over the last month. Some even tried to hug and kiss him. The mayor, pausing for interviews, said public officials and parade organizers had debated whether to hold the celebration this year in view of the attacks.
The mayor and Charles A. Gargano, the state's commissioner of economic development and president of the Columbus Citizens Foundation, which sponsors the parade, said a decision to go ahead had been made to help the city get back to normal, and to honor those lost in the trade center and the thousands of firefighters and other emergency workers who have searched the rubble for them.
"This demonstrates that we're going ahead with our lives," the mayor said, his chin tucked up like a marine at boot camp. "We're not going to let terrorism hinder us."
Even so, a day after retaliatory strikes in Afghanistan and vows by Osama bin Laden to destroy America, there was concern that the crowd might be small. In recent years, the parade had dwindled.
But the crowds were dense and enthusiastic along much of the 35-block line of march, though they were thinner near the end. The police gave no estimate, but one organizer said that more than 300,000 people had lined the way, far more than in recent years.
The parade was as much tribute as celebration, and the mood of the day was an unusual blend of solemnity and exuberance.
The crowd grew silent as the Guardia di Finanza marching band stood at attention and played "The Star-Spangled Banner," and again when a woman stood alone atop the Medaglio d'Oro coffee float and sang "God Bless America."
Later, chants of "U.S.A.! U.S.A.!" met troops of the 777th Regional Support Command marching by in battle fatigues, calling cadence.
"Stand tall, boys!" a man shouted.
And another doffed his stars-and-stripes baseball cap and hollered, "Thank you!"
Rifle-spinning displays and the fresh faces of young cadets from the New York Military Academy, marching in dress grays, were grim reminders of the thousands in United States military services posted halfway around the world to fight terrorists and the government that harbors them in Afghanistan.
Peter Engel, 32, of Ossining, a former marine who served in the Persian Gulf war, lofted a sign proclaiming "Death to the Taliban," and said that he and his friends had attended the parade to show support for the city and America. "We made it a point to come today to show that we weren't afraid to come to New York, especially for a big public event."
Ron Horan, 43, of Atlantic Highlands, N.J., said the parade for him was a kind of ratification of certain ideals. "It reaffirms our faith in America," he said. "Look at all the flags here. It's absolutely wonderful. I think it's the best thing we could do."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: WORLD MARKETS; 
Trade, Already Off, Faces New Hurdle

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Trade, which contributed so powerfully to the world's growth for much of the 1990's, had been falling everywhere even before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, pulling national economies down with it. Now, with the prospect of further economic fallout from the war against terrorism, the damage is expected to increase, sidelining global trade as a force for economic recovery.
 The numbers are particularly startling for the United States. Exports of goods and services reached a high last year of 11.4 percent of the value of the country's total economic activity, and then dropped by nearly a percentage point -- equivalent to almost $100 billion in annual exports -- in just nine months. That was enough to help push a weakening economy into a slump. 
 The same pattern was evident worldwide, despite the considerable progress in recent years in pulling down trade barriers. 
The Bush administration, trying to reverse the trend, sees the terrorist attacks as an opportunity to push harder than ever for a new round of negotiations that would knock down more trade barriers. Administration officials argue that by lowering tariffs and other obstacles once again, they can to some extent counter the new costs of moving merchandise across borders that have arisen since Sept. 11, in effect offsetting new frictions by removing old ones.
"I do not see any reason why Sept. 11, if we follow the right policies, should have any negative impact on the ability of people to exchange goods and services around the world," said John B. Taylor, the Treasury Department's under secretary for international affairs. More globalization and fewer tariffs, he added, "will emphasize that trade is a good source of economic growth."
Jeffrey Schott, a trade expert at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, agreed. "Not going forward with these initiatives," he said, "increases the risk that a country will revert to protectionist measures in response to recession and unemployment."
Lower tariffs would help companies like Lands' End, the catalog retailer, which imports 70 percent of its merchandise, mostly apparel. Immediately after the attacks, shipments arrived a day late because of the extra security procedures, said Charlotte LaComb, manager of investor relations, "and then the customs brokers and freight forwarders, the people who handle our shipments, instituted a small surcharge."
This terrorist "tax" is still too slight to prompt Lands' End to purchase less from abroad, Ms. LaComb said. But it raises new concerns for thousands of companies engaged in cross-border transactions.
That is one reason the administration offers as justification for pushing so hard on the international trade front. It finally forged a compromise with moderate Democrats last week in hopes of achieving quick passage of a bill that would grant the president the right to negotiate trade agreements without being second-guessed by Congress. Under the bill, lawmakers could only approve or reject trade deals but could not amend or rewrite them -- a concession that Congress has denied to the White House for nearly a decade.
The administration also stepped up the pressure to start a new round of tariff-lowering negotiations under the umbrella of the World Trade Organization at a scheduled meeting in Qatar in November, and new agreements in the Western Hemisphere that would in effect extend the North American Free Trade Agreement, known as Nafta, to nearly every nation.
"This administration will fight for open markets and free trade," Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, declared in an outspoken speech right after the attacks. "The global trading system," he added, "has demonstrated -- from Seoul to Santiago -- that it is a pathway out of poverty and despair."
Not everybody agrees with that claim. The economic theory that underlies Mr. Zoellick's argument sometimes fails to work as advertised, or works better for some countries than others, some economists argue. The anti-globalization demonstrators who first appeared in strength at a World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle two years ago embrace this view.
"The important thing to remember is that none of these trade agreements are about free trade," said Thea Lee, an international economist at the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "They are about trade with rules, managed trade, and then the question is: Managed in whose interest?"
Nafta, she argues, was more in the interest of American companies than Mexican enterprises. "Mexico, for example, was required to prolong patent protection on drugs to match patent protection in the United States," she said. "That helped American pharmaceutical companies export brand-name drugs, but Mexicans must now wait longer to purchase less-expensive generic drugs." 
Most economists, however, argue that freer trade makes it easier for nearly all countries to increase production, profits and income when the rising output of goods and services can be sold freely abroad as well as at home. Nafta "enormously expanded Mexico's access to the United States market," said Barry Eichengreen, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley.
But this year a worldwide slowdown radiating from the United States has reduced exports across the globe, to 16.3 percent of the total value of economic activity among all nations from 17.3 percent last year, according to the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis.
Now the terrorist attacks, and the fear of more, are adding a new burden on global trade. "For all the talk about globalization, we are recognizing suddenly that there are national borders," said Joseph Stiglitz, a Columbia University economist, who added that this comes "after trying to pretend in the 1990's that there were none. There could not be two countries with more mutual trust than the United States and Canada, and yet we are being much more thorough in checking goods crossing the border from Canada. An important cost is being added, in Canada and elsewhere, to world trade."
The "tax" on trade from the fear of terrorism is showing up in bits and pieces all over the world. American Eagle Outfitters, for example, a popular clothing retailer among teenagers, has closed an operation in Pakistan and shifted its production to Jordan, to avoid the interruption in shipments that might come from American military action in neighboring Afghanistan.
And in Atlanta, Dan DiMaggio, chief executive of the Logistics Group of United Parcel Service, finds himself contending constantly with new obstacles to the smooth flow of commerce. His division helps companies ship products from overseas cities that are not sufficiently served by U.P.S. cargo jets.
That is especially the case in Asia, where Mr. DiMaggio's staff arranges for passenger jets to carry computer parts, cellphones, semiconductors and the like in their cargo compartments, usually to the United States. In response to the terrorist attacks, the Federal Aviation Administration banned cargo from passenger flights. It has since eased that rule, but cutbacks in trans-Pacific flights have left Mr. DiMaggio scrambling for alternatives, many of them slower and more expensive.
"It is hard to assess whether we are witnessing a permanent change in the supply network or a temporary one," Mr. DiMaggio said. "Right now, logistics people are dealing with the problem on a short-term basis. If we see the changes developing on a more permanent basis, then we will adjust." 
Mr. Eichengreen still believes that world trade will flourish in the long run. Manufacturers in particular, he says, have become very dependent on a global supply chain in assembling products from parts that arrive from many countries. Outsourcing internationally has become too entrenched to go backward now, Mr. Eichengreen says.
But Dani Rodrik, an international economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, says there will be substantial changes ahead anyway.
"In the 1990's, with the cold war over, the No. 1 issue on the world agenda was to push for global trade and free capital flows," he said. "Now the push for globalization is being overshadowed by military issues. That means the economic dimension will increasingly be viewed as an instrument" of military priorities and foreign policy.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FLEET; 
A Wary Warship Launches New Salvos

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: ABOARD THE U.S.S. ENTERPRISE, in the Arabian Sea, Oct. 8 

 BODY:
As warplanes from this ship joined in a second round of strikes in Afghanistan, commanders here said tonight that their greatest worry was the potential for retaliatory action.
 The commanders, who under military rules speak only on condition that their names not be published, said fighter pilots from the Enterprise had encountered some antiaircraft artillery on their initial strikes in Afghanistan, but had seen only a few surface-to-air missiles, all unguided and some shoulder-fired, and that none had posed a threat. 
 They said that a concern about possible retaliation began with that first round of allied attacks on Sunday. It prompted senior officers to monitor civilian air traffic even more intensively. 
"We didn't anticipate any traditional adversary to come back at us after we sent lead across the beach," said the Navy admiral who is the senior officer aboard this ship. "We knew that we weren't going to see masses of enemy planes head into the skies. But we didn't know what terrorist attacks might occur." 
More than anything else, said the admiral, who commands the Enterprise battle group of about a dozen vessels, the concern about the nature of possible retaliation reflected a sense that the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States had changed the rules of war, particularly in what he called an asymmetrical conflict. Even an aircraft carrier, he suggested, could no longer assume that a civilian airliner was benign.
Still, he quoted from Edmund Burke to illustrate what he called the determination of those aboard the ship to do their part in trying to strike a blow against terrorism: "All it takes for evil to triumph is for good men to do nothing," he said.
Within hours of the first strikes, the commanders invited reporters to watch some of the infrared video images recorded by the F-14 and F-18 warplanes on their overnight missions. The images showed their precision-guided munitions homing in on their targets, including what was evidently a deep penetration bomb that struck what the officers said had been an underground cave or bunker.
"The pilot told me that after the hit, the whole hillside around the target came alight with small-arms fire," the ship's commander said, suggesting that the target might have been significant. 
The video images showed a strike on what commanders said had been a storage site for antiaircraft missiles, with an initial explosion from the bomb followed seconds later by a large secondary explosion and then the sight of at least one missile zooming erratically into the sky. 
The video was shown by the commander, a Navy captain, who had snatched just two hours of sleep during the flight operations that continued through Sunday night and well into this morning. The images were displayed in the admiral's comfortable wardroom, on a giant screen even as warplanes on the noisy, busy flight deck several decks above continued to roar into the sky.
The commander said he wanted to underscore what he said had been extraordinary efforts to use the precision munitions to minimize the danger of other damage. 
"Our initial assessment is that we had a very high success rate in hitting our targets," he said. "It's very important that we keep the moral high ground by showing that we are not going after civilian targets." Still, the commander said he wanted to wait until he had access to satellite images before making a more definitive judgment.
After the last of the carrier aircraft returned to the flight deck early this afternoon, crew members worked quickly to replenish the planes with rack after rack of munitions. 
In a military tradition, sailors had inscribed some of the bombs with messages for the presumed targets, including some sober messages recalling the deaths of so many Americans on Sept. 11. One spelled out the initials of the Fire Department of New York; another read simply, "For Doug Cherry, Jr., 9/11/01."
Beginning about 10:30 p.m., the fighter planes and support aircraft, many of them refueling craft, began to roar again, ending a nine-hour lull and signaling the onset of another wave of strikes that was expected to last well into Tuesday morning.
The last planes that participated in the combat operations did not return to this carrier until early this afternoon. Along with striking at the targets in Afghanistan, their missions had included serving as escorts for other aircraft, commanders said, including the C-17's used to drop food near the Afghan border.
Another vessel in the battle group, the Philippine Sea, was among the ships and submarines that fired Tomahawk missiles into Afghanistan in the very first wave of the attacks on Sunday. "It's not over," the executive officer of the ship said. "Yesterday was merely one more step of many steps along a long, long road."
The ship's chaplain, a Southern Baptist from Annapolis, Md., said he was "hoping God would be with the people" on the other end of the missile attacks. "We see a lot of fishermen out there and I was wondering what would be going through the minds as they see something go past them."
The commanders said most of the early strikes staged from aboard this carrier had been aimed at air defense targets but would not say what would be the targets of tonight's attacks. "We've proved in past campaigns that your efforts in the early hours in taking down the air defenses will make your mission later on a little easier," the ship's captain said.
About 70 separate sorties flew from the Enterprise in the first round of combat on Sunday and today, with about a dozen F-14's and F-18's actually taking part in the strikes on targets in Afghanistan, commanders said.
In Washington, Pentagon officials said the aircraft in the first wave of attacks included about 25 from aircraft carriers, with others coming from the Carl Vinson, stationed with its own battle group in the Arabian Sea.
Some of the precision-guided bombs dropped by strike aircraft aboard the carrier would have been directed by lasers aimed by the pilots themselves. But others, particularly those carried by the F-18's, were more sophisticated munitions that are guided remotely, via satellite.
"It's like sending an e-mail," the ship's commander said. "You give it an address, and off it goes."
"Our objective is to terrorize the terrorists," the admiral said. But he added later in a long conversation over dinner with a small group of reporters, "The principle we adopted last night was economy of force."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: SECURITY MEASURES; 
Americans Feel Jittery, And Proceed With Caution

BYLINE:  By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK with ROBERT PEAR 

 BODY:
Last weekend, visitors to the Liberty Bell in Philadelphia could walk straight through its pavilion to the enduring national symbol. Yesterday, they had to pass through metal detectors. 
 Across a jittery nation, state and local officials, fearing retaliation for American air strikes in Afghanistan, continued putting in place new security measures. 
 In some cases, the security measures extended to events months into the future. In Denver, city officials said yesterday that a New Year's Eve celebration had been cancelled because there were not enough "police resources" available to ensure a safe event. 
In state after state, officials announced steps that would have been unthinkable a month ago. At this week's Mississippi State Fair, visitors are to receive copies of a "terrorism awareness" pamphlet, with information on chemical and biological warfare. 
The Massachusetts Emergency Management Agency, saying it was acting in response to worried calls, has issued a list of suggestions for dealing with a chemical attack. The document advised people to buy extra food, water and pet supplies and to become familiar with evacuation routes. It also suggested they conduct "shelter in place" drills -- shutting doors and windows and sealing off sources of outside air. 
Peter Judge, a spokesman for the agency, said that the guidelines had been issued to media outlets and to the local emergency management directors across the state. 
"We're making every effort to get it out there and let people kind of get their arm around this a little bit," he said. "If they feel they have a little bit more control over their lives, this will help." 
Attorney General John Ashcroft said yesterday that law enforcement agencies, public utilities, airlines, railroads and other businesses should maintain the highest possible degree of vigilance.
He added that Americans should not be paralyzed with fear or "intimidated away from liberty." But he added, "Every American should be vigilant, and we're counting on each American to help us defend our nation in this war."
Most government offices were closed yesterday for Columbus Day, but new safety precautions were evident.
On Capitol Hill, police stepped up security around Congress, with extra officers patrolling the grounds. Several lawmakers of Congress said they had been advised not to wear the lapel pins that identify them as members of Congress when they leave the Capitol grounds.
At noon, the United States Park Police arrested nine people singing antiwar songs on the sidewalk in front of the White House. The protesters carried a sign that said, "Stop Bombing." 
Lt. G. William Davis, a spokesman for the police, said the demonstrators -- one man and eight women -- had violated a federal regulation requiring demonstrators to keep moving along the sidewalk. They offered no resistance when they were arrested. Violations are punishable by $50 fines.
A few national parks have closed temporarily, and some have imposed new restrictions -- for example, limiting access to bridges and lakes near dams and reservoirs. 
Peggy Wilhide, a spokeswoman for the Association of American Railroads, which represents freight railroads, said they had been operating on "a red alert status" since Sunday, when President Bush announced the air strikes in Afghanistan.
Railroads have increased patrols and security at rail yards, bridges, tunnels and other key sites, Ms. Wilhide said. Rail carriers have also removed some data from their Web sites and have severely limited access to information on the shipment of chemicals, munitions and other materials that could be used in acts of terrorism.
The general fear of reprisal led to many other unusual security measures and advisories yesterday, including these:
*The Georgia Emergency Management Agency advised visitors to government buildings, including post offices, to allow at least an extra 15 minutes for possible security checks. 
*At Sky Harbor Airport in Phoenix, passengers were asked to remove their shoes before passing through security checkpoints. An airport spokeswoman said the request shortened the time people waited in line because metal plates in shoes could set off the detectors.
*At the Silverdome in Pontiac, Mich., where 80,000 fans were scheduled last night to see a football game between the Detroit Lions and the St. Louis Rams, the Federal Aviation Administration said it would restrict all air traffic within four miles of the indoor stadium. 
Some people said they were taking at least small daily measures to ward off the chance of attack. 
"I'm sure it's going to happen, it's just a matter of where," said Roy Green, a retired grocery clerk who was on the Third Street Pier in Santa Monica, Calif., yesterday. 
"But I think there's a certain advantage to being outdoors," he added. "You've got visibility. I don't like to be confined in big places anyway." He said he was trying to "steer clear" of all large indoor gatherings. 
In addition to concerns about terrorism, many people said they were worried about economic problems. 
At a Starbucks cafe in suburban Chicago, amid the scent of fresh-ground coffee and the sounds of jazz piped over the speakers, Brenda Klinger, a clerk, worried that she might not be working there much longer. "It's a chain reaction," she said. "If more corporate executives lose their jobs, they won't be able to afford a five-dollar cup of coffee. That entails losing my job." 
Still, fears of terrorism did not keep a boisterous crowd from attending the Taste of Boston, an outdoor culinary event on Boston's City Hall Plaza yesterday. "I've got to live," explained Pat Grant, a real-estate broker from Chelmsford, Mass. "What the terrorists want you to do is stay home. They talk about a lot of people not breathing easily, and that's their goal. But you just can't worry about it."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FINANCIAL RISKS; 
A Different Kind of Wartime Economy

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 

 BODY:
Given the nature of this new conflict with terrorism, the economy is not likely to be revived by the developments that fueled previous wartime booms, like surging orders for tanks and airplanes or demand for workers to replace those who go off to fight.
 This time, the course of the economy will be determined in large part by the relative power of two broader but opposing forces. 
 On the negative side is the uncertainty, and in some cases fear, that has gripped businesses, consumers and investors since Sept. 11, further weakening an economy that had been teetering on the brink of recession, if not already in one.
On the other side of the equation is government economic policy, which had been performing mild CPR on the decade-long business expansion through much of the year. But now fiscal and monetary stimulus are being engaged full force in an effort to make sure that the downturn after the terrorist attacks is as short and shallow as possible. 
"The question is whether this situation will push us into recession or pull us out of it," said Martin N. Baily, who was chairman of the White House's Council of Economic Advisers under President Bill Clinton.
"The part pushing us into recession is that everyone is more concerned about risk," he said. "The part pulling us out is increasing government spending, cutting taxes, being less concerned about the budget deficit and having the Fed move more aggressively to stimulate the economy than it probably would have without this attack."
The Federal Reserve has lately been pulling out all the stops to cut interest rates. Congress and the Bush administration have already approved substantial increases in government spending and seem headed toward approval of a second round of tax cuts and additional stimulus measures this year.
By comparison with past efforts, however, the one-two punch of monetary and fiscal policy falls short of the equivalent of the war mobilization of the World War II era, and may not even pump up the economy in the way the Vietnam War did in the 1960's. 
"My guess is that this is not going to be all that similar to previous wartime economies," said N. Gregory Mankiw, an economics professor at Harvard University. "Unless the fiscal stimulus ends up being a lot bigger than I expect, the differences will be greater than the similarities to the past."
Instead, the effectiveness of lower interest rates, higher government spending and tax cuts in turning the economy around will depend to some extent on how the battle against terrorism goes, and on whether the United States and its allies suffer retaliatory attacks.
Given that the modern-day economy of the United States is far more substantial than in the past, the combination should pack enough of a wallop, economists say, to keep the fallout from the terrorist attacks and the military response from overwhelming the nation's economic strengths. Moreover, once the worst of the war is over, it should set the stage for a healthy recovery, probably sometime next year.
In the past, wars have had varying effects on the economy.
On Dec. 7, 1941, the United States was still struggling to emerge from the Depression. The war effort finished the job, creating what amounted to a full-employment economy.
On Aug. 7, 1964, when Congress passed the Gulf of Tonkin resolution, giving its backing to increased American involvement in Vietnam, the economy was already recovered from a 10-month recession that ended in early 1961. Military spending helped keep the expansion going until 1969, even fueling inflation by over-stimulating growth. 
On Aug. 2, 1990, when Iraq invaded Kuwait, the economy fell into what proved to be an eight-month recession. A spike in oil prices hurt the economy, and the modest and temporary increase in military spending was not enough to give the economy much of a lift.
On Sept. 11, it was already clear that the United States was enduring a sharp slowdown and that the expansion -- the longest on record -- might already have come to an end. 
Despite a series of interest rate decreases by the Fed and a tax cut signed into law by President Bush, unemployment was creeping up, business investment in new factories and equipment had stalled, and consumers were growing increasingly jittery.
If the economy was not in recession before the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, it almost certainly went into one afterward. Big companies have announced about 200,000 layoffs and have put expansion plans on hold. 
The economy's strength in recent years has derived in part from a sense of excitement about the availability of jobs and the opportunities generated by technological advances, coupled with a drive by companies to drive down costs. 
Both those factors are now at risk of being overwhelmed by fallout from the campaign against terror.
Companies in many industries now face the prospect of having to invest heavily in increased security, costs that do nothing for their bottom lines. Mr. Baily said El Al, the Israeli airline, spent about 4 percent of its own revenue on security, plus an amount equal to about 3 percent of its revenue from the Israeli government. 
Airlines based in the United States, by contrast, have typically spent only about 2 percent of their revenues on security.
It is harder to put any figures on the potential for a loss of enthusiasm among investors, businesses and consumers.
"We simply do not know how the military action will play out, or what response there might be from the terrorists," said Ian Shepherdson, an economist at High Frequency Economics, a consulting firm. "Even if the U.S. and other governments manage to foil attempted attacks, we do not know how American consumers will respond to what might amount to a state of perpetual national insecurity."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE SUPPLIERS; 
Agents of Recovery Under Stress

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
Xerox was lucky. It had enough parts to keep going, even when the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks caused a three-day hiatus on shipments. Still, Xerox factories that had previously stocked a day's supply of semiconductor chips -- items readily available from Japan -- will now hold four days' worth.
 "We can't risk running out of commodity items if they are essential to making our products," said Ursula Burns, president of Xerox Worldwide Business Services. 
 Makers of the radioactive drugs used in cancer treatments and diagnostic tests were not so lucky. The shelf life of their finished product is measured in days, or even hours. When all airplanes were grounded for a few days after the attack, manufacturers scrambled to move products by truck, but some shipments decayed nonetheless. 
Now, in the event that another terrorist attack threatens disruption, the industry is seeking regulatory preapproval to make sure its products will continue to move by air. "Things are back to normal," said Roy W. Brown, chairman of the industry's trade group, "but our products are too important to chance a break in supply."
In a superficial sense, the complex American supply chain is almost back to normal. Airplanes are flying, trains are rolling, ships are docking -- and delays at various choke points have been sharply reduced. Indeed, by Sept. 14, United Parcel Service was again offering next-day delivery guarantees. The outbreak of retaliatory strikes in Afghanistan has done little to alter that.
But it is by no means business as usual for American manufacturers. Increasingly, companies are being forced to add the unthinkable to their what-if situations: what if some other event again impedes the easy flow of goods they had come to take for granted? 
"The American production system," warned Donald B. Rosenfield, senior lecturer at the Sloan School of Management at M.I.T., "has moved so far toward lean manufacturing that simple disruptions in supply can cause problems."
Indeed, he remembered seeing an auto plant shut down half a day last winter merely because icy roads delayed parts shipments.
Now, in response to the terrorist attacks, many companies are rethinking just-in-time delivery systems that were predicated on parts and materials' coming into plants as they were needed.
"Businesspeople are starting to talk about keeping more robust inventories to guard against future disruptions," said Tom Duesterberg, president of the Manufacturers Alliance, a Washington research group.
For example, Ford Motor, said Della DePietro, a spokeswoman for the company, is "putting a little more float into our system," by increasing the inventory for selected parts in selected plants.
Still, few companies seem to be in a crisis. For one thing, there have been few repercussions about missed deliveries, probably because so many customers were in the same plight. The American subsidiary of Ricoh of Japan normally ships replacement parts by air, and many of its customers had to cope with unusable printers and copiers for a while in September. 
"Normally dealers and customers would complain about the slightest shipment delay, but this time we didn't receive one call," said Jim Ivy, the American unit's president.
Most manufacturing experts say that, by now, global buying practices and just-in-time production systems are so entrenched -- and have yielded such benefits -- that few companies plan to backtrack very far.
"None of our members are building warehouses to cope with the aftermath of Sept. 11," said Frank Vargo, the vice president for international economic affairs at the National Association of Manufacturers.
Nor are many companies seeking made-in-the-U.S.A. labels. "The United States plants that might have once stepped into the breach have long since closed," said J. Michael Schaefer, a supply chain consultant at Electronic Data Systems. 
Myriad superficially unrelated reasons kept the damage from freight delays to a minimum and have kept American companies from panicking.
To begin with, the country was already in an economic slowdown at the time of the attacks, and excess inventory was more of a problem than shortages.
"We're facing such sluggish demand that it really didn't matter if product got stuck in the pipeline for a few days," one steel company executive said.
James L. Welch, president of Yellow Freight Systems, the big trucking concern, said that shipments started dropping off as far back as July 2000.
U.P.S., which estimates that the attacks cost it about $130 million in added costs and lost revenue, also had already had a decline in business before that date.
Many companies have dusted off the contingency plans they had set up in case computer problems associated with the Year 2000 transition destroyed crucial data and brought air traffic to a halt. And most companies that rely on parts made in low-wage but politically volatile countries have longstanding plans to cope with catastrophic events like hurricanes, wars and political unrest.
"Smart companies have long built the chance of floods and tornados into their plans," said Ananth Raman, a logistics specialist at the Harvard Business School.
Similarly, most transportation companies, fearful of robberies and hijackings, long ago installed random checks of packages, driver identifications and other hefty security measures.
"Railroads have had a fairly state-of-the-art security system in place since the days of Jesse James," said Patrick Hiatte, a spokesman for the Burlington Northern and Santa Fe Railway in Fort Worth.
Technology has helped, in that software that is routinely used to track shipments also lets companies do triage on those shipments.
For example, many ships carrying goods destined for Home Depot stores are still facing unloading delays at ports. But so far, no Home Depot outlet has been out of stock on those items. The retailer, based in Atlanta, has electronic records showing what was in what cartons and where those cartons were on the ship.
"We prioritized our hottest merchandise," said Joseph McClelland, a Home Depot vice president. Seasonal items like gifts are unloaded first, while ceiling fans, not a high priority now that summer is over, are being left for last. 
No one is suggesting that there will not be freight delays for some time. Economically beleaguered airlines were canceling some flights before Sept. 11.
American Airlines' latest round of cancellations has reduced its capacity to carry freight nearly 19 percent. And, new Federal Aviation Administration regulations severely restrict the types of mail and packages airlines can now carry, and the types of new customers they can serve. 
"Most of our longstanding customers are getting their shipments out on time, but new businesses will find it hard to work with commercial airlines for some time," said Richard L. Denhart, a spokesman for American Airlines Cargo. 
Border bottlenecks remain a problem. Mr. Duesterberg of the Manufacturers Alliance noted that even before Sept. 11 the cost of paperwork and customs delays at borders ran to 5 percent to 13 percent of the cost of goods moving -- a pretty hefty number considering that last year the United States did $653 billion in trade with Mexico and Canada.
Mr. Duesterberg says that without streamlined procedures tighter security measures could add as much as another 3 percent, or about $17 billion, to the costs of delays. 
On Sept. 24 the National Association of Manufacturers and its Canadian counterpart, the Canadian Manufacturers and Exporters, said they would form a task force to discuss ways to ease delays at the five main border crossings.
Among the measures on the table are electronic processing of customs reports, bar codes on trucks and ways to preapprove shipments from companies that are certified as having adequate security when they load up. 
But Mr. Vargo of the American association says that the two trade groups began hammering out their plans in August. "Even if Sept. 11 hadn't happened," he said, "we would have been running out of capacity at the border crossings."

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Mayor Embraces New Airport Plan 

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8 

 BODY:
Mayor James K. Hahn today formally abandoned a highly divisive plan for expanding Los Angeles International Airport, proposing a more modest strategy that emphasizes security over increased capacity.
 Mr. Hahn's predecessor, Richard J. Riordan, had spent years battling to expand the capacity of the airport to about 89 million passengers a year. (Last year it handled 67 million.) But the cities surrounding the airport fought the plan bitterly, fearing added noise and traffic. 
 Mr. Hahn, who took office in July, announced his support today for a new master plan under which capacity would grow to 78 million, but with most improvements involving security. For instance, parking garages next to the terminals would be removed, and a new terminal just for checking baggage would be built a short shuttle ride away from the existing terminals. The plan envisions a new system of rail lines for ferrying passengers to the airport from downtown Los Angeles and other areas.
Opponents of the old plan said they were generally pleased, in part because the new one would not increase the number of gates or build a big new road around the airport.
"Today is officially the end of the old master plan, and we're very pleased with that," said Mayor Mike Gordon of El Segundo, a town justsouth of the airport, who vigorously opposed the old approach.
"The devil is always in the details," Mr. Gordon added, "so we reserve our full judgment until we see those. But this mirrors many of our own proposals."
Mark Pisano, executive director of the Southern California Association of Governments, a regional planning body, also expressed approval, saying the new approach was compatible with a regional model, developed over the last eight years, that anticipates big increases in population and air traffic. The regional plan would accommodate those increases by expanding several other airports.
Still, adoption of the new plan for Los Angeles International is far from assured. A more detailed proposal must be worked out and then approved by local and federal agencies.
Mr. Hahn said in a statement today that the emphasis on security was partly a response to the prospect of terrorist attacks. The airport was the target of a foiled plot in 1999, an effort linked to agents of Osama bin Laden, and there has been great concern here about a second attempt.
Mr. Hahn leads a new task force appointed by the United States Conference of Mayors to coordinate efforts across the country to overhaul security at airports with minimal disruptions. "LAX," he said today, "can be both safe, consumer- and community-friendly, and a key component of our regional economy."

HEADLINE: Green Broadcasts Runoff Campaign's First Negative Ad 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER and RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

 BODY:
The campaign of the Democratic mayoral candidate Mark Green unleashed the first negative ad of the runoff election last night, labeling his opponent, Fernando Ferrer, "borderline irresponsible" and a proponent of "higher taxes" and a "divided city."
 The commercial uses a split screen, with a picture of Mr. Ferrer on the left and a series of newspaper clippings on the right, including an editorial from The New York Times that said Mr. Ferrer's call to increase financing for parks, even after the World Trade Center attack, was "borderline irresponsible." A narrator reads excerpts from the clippings. 
 The ad then labels Mr. Ferrer himself "borderline irresponsible."
"Can we afford to take a chance?" the narrator asks.
John Del Cecato, a spokesman for Mr. Ferrer, said last night: "Every time there's a test of character in this campaign, Mark Green fails. Now, faced with plummeting polls, he launches an ugly, misleading attack ad with a coded message. After promising not to make negative attacks, it's clear he's intent on dividing the city."
Mr. Green's spokesman, Joseph DePlasco, said last night: "This is not a negative ad. Fernando Ferrer and his surrogates and supporters have hurled a series of personal assaults against Mark. Rather than engaging in personal attacks, we are focusing on issues. New Yorkers have a right to know what Fernando Ferrer has said. He's called for tax increases and his own supporters have said he's running a divisive campaign."
Mr. Ferrer has advocated raising some taxes, especially to pay for after-school programs. The same editorial that criticized Mr. Ferrer criticized Mr. Green for agreeing with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposal to extend his term for three months. 
Some people, including Peter F. Vallone and former Mayor Edward I. Koch, both of whom later endorsed Mr. Ferrer, accused him of running a divisive campaign for talking about his plans to help those in the "other New York." But Mr. Ferrer has denied that the theme is divisive; he says he wants to help those left behind by the recent economic boom.
The ad's release came on the day that former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo endorsed Mr. Green and implied that Mr. Ferrer had misconstrued his famous keynote address to the 1984 Democratic National Convention when he cited it to bolster his theme of the "other New York."
Mr. Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, invoked Mr. Cuomo's speech during a debate on Sunday. Mr. Ferrer asked Mr. Green whether he had attacked Governor Cuomo for being divisive when he "gave his very stirring speech about the shining city on the hill and the other city."
Mr. Ferrer's question prompted Mr. Cuomo to go out of his way to "make clear what my message in that speech was" yesterday afternoon as he endorsed Mr. Green, the public advocate. "My speech was all about the politics of inclusion, as opposed to the politics of division," Mr. Cuomo said.
When Mr. Ferrer was told that Mr. Cuomo had suggested he misread the speech, he shrugged it off. "O.K., I guess the whole world did, too," he said.
In fact, the speech, which Mr. Cuomo said was intended as a rebuttal to President Ronald Reagan's description of America as "a shining city on a hill," did mention two cities. "Mr. President, you ought to know that this nation is more a 'Tale of Two Cities' than it is just a 'Shining City on a Hill,' " Mr. Cuomo told the delegates.
Yesterday's endorsement was a nimble performance by an old political pro. He poked fun at his reputation for being overly deliberative and bantered easily with reporters. And he managed to be sharply critical of Mr. Ferrer without saying anything overtly negative.
Mr. Cuomo never said outright that Mr. Ferrer had misunderstood his speech. He simply spent a large part of his remarks clarifying its meaning. Nor did he say that he thought Mr. Ferrer's campaign was divisive, as Mr. Green has charged. But he pointed out that his own speech "argued for inclusiveness instead of divisiveness."
Perhaps Mr. Cuomo's sharpest dig came when he was asked about Mr. Ferrer's changes of position on the death penalty. (Mr. Ferrer went from opposing it, to supporting it, to supporting a moratorium on it.) 
"If you change your mind about the death penalty, then maybe you'll change your mind about taxes, and this and that and that," Mr. Cuomo said. 
Mr. Ferrer shrugged off the Cuomo endorsement of Mr. Green. "Mario Cuomo is entitled to his opinion," he said early in the day. Later, when asked again about Mr. Cuomo, he implied that he was ahead of Mr. Green in voters' minds and therefore should not respond. "As Mario Cuomo himself said in 1982, 'You never shoot anybody in back of you,' " he said.

PERSON: George P. Brockway 

HEADLINE: George P. Brockway, 85, Publishing House President 

BYLINE:  By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
George P. Brockway, former president and chairman of the publishing house W. W. Norton & Company, died on Friday at his home in Chappaqua, N.Y. He was 85.
 He had a long illness, the company said in announcing his death. 
 After doing much editing at Norton, which is based in Manhattan, Mr. Brockway was its president from 1958 to 1976 and chairman from 1976 to 1984, when he retired. He joined the company in 1942, beginning as a copy editor and salesman. 
In 1973, when independent book-publishing houses were considered fair game for takeovers, he vowed that Norton had "never been for sale and is not likely to be."
Norton's current president and chairman, W. Drake McFeely, said, "He invented Norton's independence and ownership structure that allowed W. W. Norton & Company to remain independent 78 years after its founding and long after all the other famous book-publishing houses established in the 1920's have been merged into larger corporate entities." All Norton's stock is now owned by people who currently work at Norton.
In the 1950's Mr. Brockway also created the Norton Anthologies, a still continuing series of collections of writings, including "The Norton Anthology of World Masterpieces," "The Norton Anthology of English Literature" and "The Norton Anthology of American Literature." A total of more than 20 million copies of the books in the series have been sold.
Mr. Brockway also published such bestsellers as Betty Friedan's "Feminine Mystique," Fawn Brodie's "Thomas Jefferson: An Intimate History," Judge John Sirica's "To Set the Record Straight," about the Watergate case, and Norman Cousins's "Anatomy of an Illness."
He also published many books by the psychiatrist-author Erik H. Erikson.
In addition, Mr. Brockway and a colleague, Evan W. Thomas 2nd, bought the book rights to Robert F. Kennedy's 25,000-word account of the Cuban missile crisis, "Thirteen Days," for more than $250,000, which was a bestseller.
George Pond Brockway was born in Portland, Me., grew up there and received a bachelor's degree in 1936 from Williams College, where he was the editor of Sketch, the college literary monthly, and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa.
He was with the McGraw-Hill Book Company from 1937 to 1942 and served in the Army from 1944 to 1946. He was an artillery officer in France and Germany. He went on to be a vice president at Norton and a member of its board of directors.
He was also a director of the Yale University Press, wrote books and articles on economics and was a columnist for New Leader magazine and a founder of the journal Post-Keynesian Economics.
His wife, Lucile Hunt Brockway, died in 1988. His wife, Elizabeth Love Brockway, died in 1999.
He is survived by four daughters, Susan Brockway Aradeon of Lagos, Nigeria; Nancy Brockway of Concord, N.H.; Sally Brockway Borger of Ridegefield, Conn.; and Laura Brockway of Atlanta; three sons, David, of Washington; Douglas, of Acton, Mass.; and Andrew, of Maynard, Mass.; and nine grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: George P. Brockway, in 1976. (Joan Bingham)

HEADLINE: Morgan Stanley Selling Nearly Completed Office Tower to Lehman for $700 Million 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Morgan Stanley, the giant financial company, is selling its 33-story tower nearing completion on Seventh Avenue in Midtown to a rival, Lehman Brothers, for about $700 million and moving several thousand employees outside New York City.
 In the topsy turvy world that has become New York real estate since the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, the announcement yesterday by Morgan Stanley and Lehman Brothers was both good news and bad news for New York. 
 City officials were relieved that Lehman Brothers had finally found a home in Manhattan four weeks after it was displaced from its headquarters near the World Trade Center. Many had feared that Lehman Brothers would move more of its operations to New Jersey. But it was something of a blow to downtown landlords and others who worry that the attack will prompt companies to leave Lower Manhattan for good and lead to a dissolution of the financial district. 
"I'm very disappointed that they're leaving downtown," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the Alliance for Downtown New York. "But at least they're staying in the city."
Lehman, which has leased the Sheraton Manhattan Hotel in Midtown as a temporary work site for its traders and bankers and has an office building in Jersey City, put it another way.
"This agreement reaffirms our commitment to New York and is a win-win solution to a difficult office space problem facing both of our firms and the city," said Richard S. Fuld, chairman of Lehman Brothers, which expects to move into the tower early next year.
Lehman is uncertain what it will do with the space it owns at 3 World Financial Center, a tower that was damaged in the attack, or when that space can be occupied. The other tenant, American Express, has rented space in New Jersey and Connecticut.
There was also some bad news in Morgan Stanley's decision not to occupy its million-square foot tower on Seventh Avenue, between 49th and 50th Streets, only two blocks from its headquarters at 1585 Broadway. The financial services company had planned to move its 3,700 employees at the trade center to the new building. 
Morgan Stanley, which has about 10,000 employees in New York City, had announced construction of the skyscraper with a great deal of fanfare in 1998, during the boom on Wall Street. But with the downturn in the economy, it laid off 1,500 employees worldwide in April. Another 150 bankers in New York are reportedly going to be cut from its investment banking operation.
Now, according to real estate executives, it is selling the tower to Lehman Brothers for about $700 million, or about what it cost to build.(The project was co-developed by the Rockefeller Group, whose stake in the deal remains unchanged.)
Morgan Stanley is not about to move its headquarters. But instead of filling out its corporate campus at the north end of Times Square, where it has space in four towers, Morgan Stanley appears to be dispersing some of its employees.
The financial services company will be subleasing the building at 825 Third Avenue, at 50th Street, where it would house about 500 employees. It is also hunting for 500,000 square feet of office space in New Jersey, Westchester and Connecticut, according to a Morgan Stanley executive and to real estate brokers on both sides of the Hudson River. 
Philip J. Purcell, chairman of Morgan Stanley, described the bright side of the announcement. "Morgan Stanley will continue to have a major presence in New York City and will be better positioned from a business continuity standpoint," he said in a statement issued by the company.
But ever since the attack, there has been debate in corporate circles about whether a company should continue to concentrate employees in one location, either a single building or in a group of buildings, as Goldman Sachs, J.P. Morgan Chase and Morgan Stanley have done in the past.
Although financial services companies have been moving some of their operations to New Jersey for a decade, city officials, urban planners and New York real estate executives are now worried that that trend will accelerate.
Mitchell E. Hersh, chief executive of the Mack Cali Realty Corporation, acknowledged yesterday that Morgan Stanley has talked to him about taking additional space at his company's Harborside office complex in Jersey City. Morgan Stanley already leases about 200,000 square feet of space there.
"I believe that Lower Manhattan will remain the capital of the financial world," Mr. Hersh said. "But I do hear more discussion about dispersion by corporate decision makers. Jersey City is easy to get to, it's on a different power grid and it's easy to attract a work force."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE VIDEOTAPE; 
Bin Laden Images Mesmerize Muslims

BYLINE:  By SUSAN SACHS 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Oct. 8 

 BODY:
Osama bin Laden's internationally televised speech on Sunday mesmerized many Muslims with its religious and historical imagery, a powerful combination that only magnified his standing with people who wanted to see him as a heroic spokesman for the weak against the strong. 
 Framed in the camera's eye by barren rock and a solitary rifle, Mr. bin Laden summoned up Islam's desert roots. He spoke of swords and horses and the camp of the infidel enemy. His language recalled the contained fury of passages in the Koran where God promises Muslims that they will triumph over nonbelievers and hypocrites who only pretend to accept Islam. 
"The way he talks, his tone and his quiet voice, his vocabulary and his logic -- it's all so charismatic," said Doaa Mostafa, a student of Arabic literature at Ain Shams University in Cairo. "He is so convincing. This was the first time I've seen him on TV and I felt sure he is not a terrorist. I felt his aim is to protect Islam, nothing more."
But while Mr. bin Laden impressed many Muslim listeners with his simple phrases, his championing of the Palestinians and his flowery contempt for the United States, he also frightened others with his vision of an apocalyptic war between Muslims and non-Muslims. 
"He made me feel he is defending the Arabs' rights, since all Arab leaders are silent," said Mohammed Ahmed, another Ain Shams University student. "But I would prefer that he stop using violence and negotiate instead of kill. We agree with him on his point of view, but we do not agree with his methods."
In his speech, the Saudi exile condemned the Muslim leaders who have sympathized with Americans over the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. He called them hypocrites, a word with particular resonance for Muslims because it is used throughout the Koran to describe people who falsely claim to be Muslim. 
According to Islam, which considers the Koran the word of God, hypocrites are doomed to a hell worse than the one that awaits nonbelievers. "The hypocrites," the Koran states in one of many such passages, "will be in the lowest depths of the fire." 
"This is language that can really reach the people, especially in the gulf where the tension is very high," said Fahmi Howeidi, an influential writer on Islamic politics for Al Ahram newspaper in Cairo. 
Similarly, the historical episodes Mr. bin Laden chose to invoke revealed much about his view of the conflicts that continue to simmer in the Arab world, placing them among Islam's greatest defeats. His reference to 80 years of "humiliation and disgrace" was apparently a timeline that began with the end of the Ottoman empire and the beginning of British colonization of the Middle East after World War I. 
In the same broadcast, Ayman al-Zawahiri, Mr. bin Laden's deputy and the leader of the Islamic Jihad group, vowed that "the tragedy of al Andalus" would not be repeated. He was referring to the period widely considered the Islamic golden age in Andalusia, in Spain, that ended in the ignominy of Muslims being driven out of Europe by Christian armies in the 15th century.
Such historical allusions may well tap into the widespread sense of siege among many Muslims who see themselves threatened by a modern world dominated by the United States and Western secularism. 
But Mr. bin Laden was not the first would-be savior of the Muslim world to use the language of religion as part of his appeal. Most recently, the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, whose political roots are in secular Arab nationalism, tried to portray himself as a champion of Islam to garner support. 
But Mr. bin Laden has the unique advantage of having been born into one of the richest families in Saudi Arabia, while now living the austere life of mountain warrior. 
"Here you have a simple man who presents himself as someone who left behind millions of dollars to defend Muslim dignity," Mr. Howeidi said. "He has become the symbol now of challenge to the West."
Still, there was little evidence, so far, that anyone in Egypt was ready to answer Mr. bin Laden's call for battle against the nonbelievers and Americans.
About 30 students, all members of a group devoted to the Arab nationalism of the late Gamal Abdel Nasser, held a brief protest rally at Ain Shams. A young woman climbed the iron fence to the university grounds and shouted out anti-American slogans, while police armed with bamboo sticks surrounded the protesters. Small demonstrations also erupted at a few other universities.
"We all feel sympathy and admiration for bin Laden," said Mostafa Rushdi Ali, a business administration student at Helwan University in Cairo. "But Egypt must remain neutral because if we interfere this will worsen our economy."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE PALESTINIANS; 
Arafat Decides to Take A Gamble on the West

BYLINE:  By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Oct. 8 

 BODY:
Today, Yasir Arafat took a gamble, confronting a radical Palestinian crowd in a bid to shore up his own position and assert his international credibility as the possible leader of a Palestinian state. 
 For the first time in years, Mr. Arafat's security forces used deadly force against Palestinians to suppress a demonstration in support of Osama bin Laden. In a cloud of tear gas and a hail of bullets, two Palestinians -- one of them only 13 -- were slain. Another was close to death. 
 It was the most dramatic evidence to date that the terrorist attacks on the United States have dented the entrenched thinking of the enemies in the conflict here and created a new chance for peace at the same time as causing a spike in violence.
Many Palestinians sympathize with Mr. bin Laden regardless of whether they supported the attacks on the United States. They say he is a fellow Muslim, accused on trumped-up evidence out of a secret desire by the United States to assault Afghanistan. They say Americans react only to their own suffering and economic interests, and will make no effort -- much less war -- to provide other peoples with enduring freedom.
Yasir Arafat knows this bitterness better than anyone. For years, he has deftly capitalized on it. And today he took brutal measures against the people of the West Bank and Gaza Strip to stop them from expressing it.
In the Persian Gulf war, Mr. Arafat backed Saddam Hussein and saw his international support vanish. On Sept. 11, some Palestinians were filmed celebrating the attacks and Mr. Arafat was once again given a glimpse of the abyss, of life as an international pariah.
Turning his back on this possibility, Mr. Arafat opted to preserve his links with Western governments, while at the same time to send a clear message to radical Palestinian factions, some of whom threaten his authority that the time has come to rein in their agitation, at least for now.
The message he wanted to send out was the one that the Bush administration wanted to hear. As Mr. Arafat himself stayed silent, his spokesman delivered it in response to Mr. bin Laden's televised attempt Sunday to rally support by invoking the Palestinian cause. His spokesman, Yasser Abed Rabbo, said that what he called crimes against Palestinians could not justify killing civilians in New York. There was wriggle room left even in that statement: Mr. Abed Rabbo did not say that Mr. bin Laden was behind the attacks. Regarding the airstrikes in Afghanistan, Mr. Abed Rabbo said that Mr. Arafat was waiting to develop a joint statement with other Arab and Muslim foreign ministers. But a few hours later, Mr. Arafat's guns, turned on supporters of Mr. bin Laden, were more explicit.
Mr. Arafat's calculation appears to be that most Palestinians, even if they sympathize with Mr. bin Laden, will accept today's police action as necessary.
"There is a Palestinian political state of maturation," said Dr. Ziad Abu Amir, a political scientist who is the head of political committee of the Palestinian Legislative Council. Dr. Abu Amir noted that Mr. Arafat, Mr. bin Laden and President Bush had one thing in common: all have expressed sympathy for the Palestinian plight -- some far more recently than others -- in hopes of generating Arab support. 
But Palestinians are jaded when it comes to low-cost compassion. "Over one year of intifada and Palestinian resistance, people saw a level of Arab or Islamic intervention or support that was below expectations," Dr. Abu Amir said. This fact inevitably makes Mr. bin Laden's appeal to the masses more attractive. The Israelis have been pushing Mr. Arafat to arrest militant Palestinian leaders to demonstrate a commitment to the peace process. For the most part, he has resisted. But now it seems his hand may be forced.
Hamas, the radical Islamic movement with broad backing in Gaza and the West Bank, today expressed strong support for Mr. bin Laden. The violence in Gaza began when the police tried to stop demonstrators from Islamic University, a Hamas stronghold.
Late tonight, Palestinians wre still battling against Palestinian police forces in Gaza.
In 1996, at another critical juncture in the peace negotiations, Mr. Arafat arrested some leaders of Hamas, dramatically reducing violence against Israelis. It is that experience that Israeli officials keep citing as they press Mr. Arafat for action now. Mr. Arafat later released those leaders, and they are now more popular, and their followers better armed, than they were in 1996.
Mr. Arafat, a senior Israeli intelligence official said, has not yet "had his Altalena." That was a reference to a fateful decision taken a month after Israel's founding by David Ben-Gurion, then the new nation's prime minister. Rather than permit a ship called the Altalena to bring in guns for a right-wing Israeli movement, he ordered it shelled. It sank off Tel Aviv.
If Mr. Arafat does crack down on militants -- to protect himself, to promote peace, or both -- then it is Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel who will be put to the test. The world may learn if has been seeking to provoke civil war among the Palestinians, as some Palestinians believe, or whether he wants a secure peace, as he says.
The Bush administration's new commitment to a Middle East peace effort will also be tested. Colin Powell, the secretary of state, has also been urging Mr. Arafat to make arrests.
