HEADLINE: Fiscal Disaster the City Can't Face Alone 

BYLINE:  By Felix Rohatyn; Felix G. Rohatyn, ambassador to France from 1997 to 2000, was chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation from 1975 to 1993.

 BODY:
"Anything it takes to help New York." That sentiment from George W. Bush, expressed on Sept. 13, is in obvious contrast to the feelings of an otherwise not-so-different president, Gerald Ford, as summarized in the famous 1975 Daily News headline: "Ford to City: Drop Dead." President Ford eventually did come to understand that the country couldn't afford to let its largest city, then in fiscal crisis, go bankrupt. Now, in a disaster for the city economy that has very different causes, President Bush's continuing support will be crucial. New York does not have the resources to recover on its own.
 The city is in greater economic jeopardy today than it was in the fiscal crisis of 1975, and Gov. George Pataki, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and our Congressional delegation should propose a long-term federal program of assistance. New York has the country's sympathy and admiration: under the leadership of Mayor Giuliani and with the strong support of Governor Pataki, the city and its citizens have conducted themselves heroically after a murderous assault. President Bush immediately offered $20 billion in federal assistance, and for the moment, Congress appears to be supportive. But the long-term prospects are daunting. 
 Before Sept. 11 the city was already feeling the bite of a significant national downturn. This came on top of the stock market collapse of Internet and telecommunications companies, serious downward pressures on the financial services sector, and the increasing impact of these declines on city revenues. The additional emotional and economic shocks of Sept. 11 are only beginning to be perceived. They are already quite serious; their ultimate impact is impossible to predict.
The city has had 20 consecutive balanced budgets, in good times and in bad. The fiscal structure and controls created in 1975 -- the Municipal Assistance Corporation and the Financial Control Board -- helped achieve this good record. But estimates of the city deficit in the next fiscal year are now put at $4 billion and are likely to rise to at least $6 billion. Estimates of the state's revenue losses in the same period are $2 billion to $6 billion.
For the last year or so, the weakness of our economy has been understated by economists looking for rosy scenarios and by securities salesmen on television trying to prop up the stock market. But to a very weak economy we have now added the shock to public confidence created by the terrorist attacks, as well as a huge national loss of jobs -- the airline industry alone expects to eliminate 100,000. The result is bound to be negative for the city and the state. Alan Hevesi, the city comptroller, has estimated the total economic loss to the city as a result of the attack on Manhattan at more than $100 billion, a truly staggering figure.
In this context the city and the state have to be treated as a single unit. Few remember today that in the winter and spring of 1976, the State of New York was shut out of the public markets and was unable to sell its bonds because of the fiscal weakness of the city.
It took five years, from 1975 to 1980, with enormous sacrifices on the part of all New Yorkers, with the strong support of the city's labor unions and the banks, to close a gap of about $1.5 billion on a city budget of $15 billion. And this took place in a relatively benign economic environment, at a time when New Yorkers, by and large, were confident that we would prevail. Now we are facing a potential deficit of $4 billion to $6 billion on a $39 billion budget. Is it reasonable, under existing circumstances, to believe that the city and the state can close budget gaps of possibly $6 billion each in one fiscal year and maintain the city as a viable economic and social entity?
It would be impossible to do so as a practical matter, but it would also run counter to President Bush's stimulus program. New York will not be the only city with a large budget deficit next year, though it will have the biggest one, some of it due directly to the attacks on Sept. 11. Nor will ours be the only state in trouble. Layoffs throughout the declining economy, both reducing revenues and increasing costs for state and local governments, will undo many of the positive effects of any federal stimulus program proposed by President Bush.
It is urgent that our governor and mayor, with their counterparts in other parts of the country, develop with the Bush administration a plan of short-term assistance to states and cities, one that would prevent what is likely to be a hard national recession from turning into a real depression. Such a plan could include a temporary assumption by the federal government of certain state and local costs, coupled with incentives for local tax reductions, federal guarantees to pension funds for the financing of infrastructure projects, and private-public partnerships for functions like school construction.
In 1975, after years of overspending and excessive borrowing camouflaged by accounting fictions, New York was widely viewed as the main culprit in its problems, deserving of a bankruptcy. Federal help in the form of loans and loan guarantees came only after President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of Germany warned Mr. Ford that a New York bankruptcy would set off a crisis for the dollar and impair America's credit. Now New York has a good fiscal record as well as the nation's sympathy, and its importance to the national economy is well recognized.
As long as the international situation remains as cloudy as it is now, as long as Americans have to respond to calls on the one hand to live a normal life and on the other to be ready for more terrorist attacks, it is unrealistic to expect a strong economic recovery. We should be realistic about what this implies. We were able to deal with the last fiscal crisis mostly with our own resources. This is no longer possible for us or for many other cities and states. Until the national economy recovers and national confidence is restored, we cannot do this alone.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Anxious Days in Pakistan 

 BODY:
Though Afghanistan has become the first battleground in America's war against terrorism, Pakistan could well be the political epicenter of this unfolding conflict. The United States can win the military confrontation in Afghanistan but lose the war if Pakistan, with its 142 million people and nuclear weapons, falls under the control of Islamic fundamentalists. That is why the latest actions of Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, require the closest attention of the Bush administration, which is dispatching Secretary of State Colin Powell to Islamabad later this week. 
 By arresting a leading dissident and replacing his top military and intelligence commanders in recent days, General Musharraf has bought short-term support for his decision to cooperate with the United States. With his permission, American and British bombers and cruise missiles have flown through Pakistan's airspace in the last two days on their way to targets in Afghanistan. 
 But in dismissing powerful aides who helped bring him to power two years ago and managed Pakistan's close ties to the Taliban, he has added kindling to a highly combustible political climate. As President Bush prosecutes his campaign against terrorism and Osama bin Laden, he must be mindful of General Musharraf's fragile position.
For most of its troubled history since independence and partition from India in 1947, Pakistan has been plagued by coups, insurgencies and sometimes repressive military rule. The sensitivity of the Pakistanis to perceived assaults on Islam combined with anti-American fervor in 1979 when a mob torched the United States Embassy in Islamabad because of rumors of American involvement in crushing a rebel takeover of the Great Mosque in Mecca. The problem is compounded by the decision years ago by Pakistani military and intelligence services to forge a close relationship with the Taliban. The move was in part an effort to make sure that Afghanistan would not foment violence among the restive Pashtun population among the villages and refugee camps on Pakistan's northwest frontier.
Until now, General Musharraf has generally exercised restraint toward those in his country who do not support the new alliance with the United States. Demonstrations, in turn, have been noisy but restrained. But the general needs to remember the dangers of cracking down on dissent, which can easily provoke more turmoil, particularly among the well-financed religious parties. 
The United States can help the general by showing the public that supporting the destruction of terrorism under Mr. bin Laden will bring its rewards in the form of American economic and perhaps military aid to Pakistan. General Powell will undoubtedly discuss such possibilities during his visit to Islamabad. He also plans a stop in India.
There are some things that the United States must not do, such as encouraging Pakistan to support the Muslim rebellion in the Indian state of Kashmir or to expand its nuclear weapons program. Washington must still strive for a peaceful resolution of nuclear tensions in the subcontinent, including treaties and agreements to control testing and production of nuclear materials. There must also be a peaceful settlement of Pakistan's dispute with India over the future of Kashmir.
One measure of General Musharraf's obvious anxiety over his new close alliance with the United States came yesterday with his call for limiting the air war in Afghanistan and for the installation of a new government in Kabul that would be friendly to Pakistan. In response, the United States must be sensitive to the Pakistani leader's concerns but not let him dictate the conduct of the war against terrorism.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: GERMANY; 
Berlin's Support of the U.S. Puts Greens in Uneasy Spot

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Oct. 8 

 BODY:
The Greens, junior partners in Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's coalition, neatly caught their own predicament in a statement today that on one hand supported the American fight against terrorists but on the other stressed that "the use of the military is never a solution to problems."
 Mr. Schroder, eager to underline Germany's relevance and seriousness as a trans-Atlantic partner, has sought to make a meaningful military contribution to the attacks on the ruling Taliban in Afghanistan. 
 In this, Mr. Schroder has the full support of his foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, the senior member in the government of the normally pacifist Greens. 
On Saturday, Mr. Fischer, much to his relief, won support from a special congress of Greens' state leaders.
But the longer this war goes on, the harder it will be to maintain the coalition's solidarity and support for Washington, key politicians here say. With federal elections a year away, the Greens face an existential dilemma, with their participation in a government engaged in a war a sign of political maturity to some, but to others, possibly a death knell for the party itself.
Today's statement tacitly acknowledged the fix. American actions to fight terrorists, "whom the Taliban regime has continued to harbor and support even after the criminal attacks on the United States, are justified," it said, especially since the American actions "are not aimed at Afghan cities or the Afghan civilian population."
And yet, it stressed, "it remains necessary that these military actions stay part and parcel of a comprehensive political plan."
The uncertainty surrounding the Greens has fed much speculation here that Mr. Schroder and his Social Democrats will turn eventually to the liberal Free Democrats as a coalition partner.
"In some ways, the Greens are not seen as a party that is needed anymore by a new generation," said Angelika Koster-Lossack, a Green legislator, expert on South Asia and party spokeswoman for economic cooperation and development.
"The challenges of this new world are tremendous, and we never assumed it would be like this," Ms. Koster-Lossack said. "After the breakdown of the cold war and the confrontation of the two empires, we should have expected many more smaller conflicts. But we tried to believe in the best."
The Greens were born in the 1968 student rebellions against imperialism, capitalism and the Vietnam War, and much of the left that grew up at the time is fundamentally skeptical of the United States.
In 1997, a year before he became foreign minister, Mr. Fischer told his party that he did not expect that "an expression of commitment" to NATO would be necessary, even in government.
But the attacks on America, by Islamic militants supported by a country that has been relentlessly reported to mistreat women, children and minorities, have pushed the Greens toward the Americans.
Mr. Schroder's Social Democrats are also having some problems with this war. His conversion to strong support for the United States is a sincere but relatively recent phenomenon. Aides say he sees this latest challenge as an important moment for his party and his generation, with Germany's interests lying clearly with Washington.
Both he and Mr. Fischer have done well, said Friedbert Pfluger, a Christian Democratic member of Parliament and an expert in security and alliance issues. "Schroder understood that you have to be either on the side of the United States or not, but his leeway to demonstrate that support is limited," he said, explaining that it is constrained by the Greens and narrower than that enjoyed by Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain or President Jacques Chirac of France. 
Mr. Pfluger, a member of the opposition, said it was important for Germany and NATO to contribute to this fight against terrorism. "But are we politically and militarily good enough to really contribute, over the long haul? And if not, are we relevant enough for the future?"
Robert von Rimscha, the expert on Parliament for the newspaper Der Tagesspiegel, said the threat to Mr. Schroder and the coalition was that prolonged military action might see the Greens eventually paralyzed by their divisions.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: MOSCOW; 
Tying Russia to West, Putin Unveils Strategy, But Risks a Backlash

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 8 

 BODY:
Until this month, critics here dismissed President Vladimir V. Putin's foreign policy as little more than tactics -- a trip to Cuba to appease nationalists, one to Germany to mollify liberals -- trying to placate everyone, but offering no strategy for Russia's future.
 Now Mr. Putin has been forced into offering an almost breathtaking vision of the country's future. And suddenly, the question is whether he has the tactical skills to achieve it. 
 There is broad agreement that last month's terror attacks on New York and Washington effectively pushed Mr. Putin into choosing between a Russia allied with no one, and a Russia bound to the West -- and that he chose the latter.
His statement today at a government meeting here could have been lifted intact from recent speeches by British Prime Minister Tony Blair: a ringing condemnation of terrorist strikes "monstrous in their brutality," aimed at sapping civilized people's will to resist.
"But humankind has matured after the horrible tragedy on Sept. 11," he said. "I think their arrogance and self-confidence has been the terrorists' undoing. They did not expect the international community to show such cohesion in the face of a common threat."
Mr. Putin's own challenge is to create cohesion in his own country. Anecdotal evidence and public opinion surveys suggest that his internationalist stance is, for once, far ahead of not just the average Russian, but of the military and political elites on whom his power partly rests.
In a poll conducted from Sept. 21 to 24 by Russia's National Center for Public Opinion and Research, 48 percent of respondents expressed sympathy for the plight of the United States after the attacks.
But 50 percent said that "it served the Americans right," and 54 percent called for Russia to remain neutral in the conflict. Russian Communists, who still command the votes of a quarter of the electorate, are calling the crisis an excuse for the United States to seize control of Central Asia. Many in the military echo that.
"If you listen to the elite types, many of them, he's fighting the pack," said Dmitri Trenin, an expert on Russian geopolitics at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace Moscow Center. "Many would still say he's selling Russia for a song; that he's giving and giving and giving and not receiving anything in return.
"As someone put it," Mr. Trenin said, "the Yeltsin-Gorbachev syndrome of unilateral concessions may now be prolonged into the Putin presidency."
For all their popularity in the West, Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin are almost universally seen here as the agents of the demise of Soviet greatness. Tarring Mr. Putin with the same brush could be politically fatal for him.
So far, he has tugged Russia into the alliance against terrorism on the strength of his own immense popularity. More than 7 in 10 Russians consistently approve of Mr. Putin's performance in most polls.
But many experts believe that that rests in part on Russia's surprising economic rebound in the last year. That could be strangled by any crisis that causes a steep recession.
In a speech in the United States last week, President Bush's national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, praised Mr. Putin for engineering a historic turn in East-West relations. But to sustain any turn to the West, many analysts say, Mr. Putin needs not praise, but a response.
The United States and Germany have tacitly agreed to take a second look at the role of terrorists in the conflict in Chechnya, the breakaway region in Russia's south. And last week, the American trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, spoke in Moscow of accelerating Russia's entry into the World Trade Organization.
Apart from that, Mr. Trenin and other Russia experts say Mr. Putin has little to show for his efforts so far. But the dance between Russia and the West is still in its early stages.
Robert Legvold, a Columbia University historian with ties to American government specialists on Russia, suggested in a recent interview that Mr. Putin also may be seeking relatively narrow forms of assistance from the West, like intelligence on Central Asian hot spots. 
Mr. Putin already is pressing for greater economic integration not only into the world trade structure, but the European Union. And he has called publicly for speedy consideration of Russia's entry into NATO -- a practical impossibility, but something which might be symbolically achieved through a mutual security pact between the Western military alliance and Moscow.
Such an agreement would resolve a host of Russian questions about its own exposure in the developing war against terrorism. Russians frequently complain that they have been asked to contribute to that struggle with none of the security guarantees offered to European and North American nations fighting the same battle.
"People in the West don't realize that now that he's made a strategic move -- not just in foreign policy, but in many ways the boldest move he's ever made as president of Russia -- the domestic constituency that supports him is rather weak," Michael McFaul, a Russia scholar at Stanford University's Hoover Institution, said in an interview.
Mr. McFaul offered his own list of slights: Russia still labors to win most-favored-nation trading status under the Jackson-Vanik amendments, which were intended to punish Soviet restrictions on Jewish emigration. NATO nations remain barred from buying Russian weapons, although a Russian threat to NATO is vanishingly small.
"The military doesn't support him. The military-industrial complex doesn't. Even the liberals are divided. And even societal attitudes, they're rather split," Mr. McFaul said. 
"So that leaves him exposed," he continued. "If he doesn't show that Russians get something out of this new full-fledged reorientation toward the West, he could easily back away toward what he did before -- back toward the tactician, finding the medium on every issue."
One longtime Russian student of East-West relations, Georgi Arbatov of the government's United States-Canada Institute of Studies, believes that unlikely.
"Before, he was a very modest man in intelligence and couldn't think about such global matters. Now, and I think it is encouraging, he changes himself.
"He becomes a real statesman," Mr. Arbatov said. "And of course, we don't know how far he will go. But there is hope."

HEADLINE: Schumer Role Transformed by Alliance With Bush 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 

 BODY:
Senator Charles E. Schumer traveled across his home state today, from Buffalo to Rochester to Syracuse, announcing the resumption of some commercial flights upstate but also taking time to try to reassure New Yorkers of their safety.
 It was, in a way, a typical day for Mr. Schumer. As the state's senior senator, he has switched from cheerleader to counselor to lawmaker, sometimes alternating among all three roles in the same day in the weeks since the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. Mr. Schumer has also seen his responsibilities transformed and broadened, becoming an unlikely ally, at least temporarily, of the Bush White House. 
 For example, the administration recently turned to him in its effort to win approval of an antiterrorist measure that raised some privacy concerns.
Only a few months ago, an alliance between Mr. Bush and Mr. Schumer would have been highly unlikely, if not unthinkable. But the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington have created a strong bipartisan mood here in the Capitol, at least on some issues. 
The measure advocated by the White House would allow the government, among other things, to get its hands on the financial records of people suspected of terrorist activities more quickly, a move that raises privacy concerns. But having a Democrat like Mr. Schumer on board potentially gives the measure bipartisan appeal -- and might minimize criticism from the left.
Mr. Schumer's support was noteworthy enough that Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, recently phoned a reporter to discuss how helpful the senator had been on this and other matters. "If Senator Schumer's bipartisanship is contagious," Mr. Fleischer added, "all the better."
People close to Mr. Schumer and Mr. Bush say that the two men have developed a cordial relationship in the attack's aftermath, directing their staffs to work together to size up the damage to New York and determine what Washington can do to help.
Mr. Schumer said that his opinion of the president changed just hours after the attack when he walked into the White House, along with other members of New York's Congressional delegation, and asked for $20 billion in disaster relief aid for New York. "He really showed his mettle to me," Mr. Schumer recalled of the president and his commitment to persuading Republicans to go along with the initial aid request.
There have been some openly warm exchanges between the two men, such as when the president greeted Mr. Schumer with a pat on the cheek on the night Mr. Bush told Congress that the nation would go to war over the terrorist attacks.
And Mr. Schumer chuckled over the fact that he, too, like many in the Bush cabinet and on Capitol Hill, had finally been given a nickname by the president. It is Ellis, Mr. Schumer's middle name. "We're not bosom buddies," Mr. Schumer added. "Don't get me wrong."
Whether Mr. Schumer will be able to parlay this arrangement into anything more is an open and critically important question. New York political leaders are hammering out a proposal seeking billions in federal funds to help New York's economy recover from the attacks. But already, Republicans on the Hill are voicing skepticism about whether Washington can fully meet New York's plea for help beyond the $20 billion already set aside for disaster relief for the city and state. 
Mr. Schumer's aides say he is counting on the president to help overcome any resistance from Congressional Republicans.
Even if the two sides were not actually cooperating on some policy matters as they clearly are, they are talking about each other in ways that would not have seemed possible a few months ago.
"Chuck is a nice man," one White House aide said in explaining the sudden change.
"He is a friendly guy," Mr. Schumer said of the president. "He has a way of putting you at ease."
Both sides know that the lines will divide again and that Mr. Schumer will have sharp differences with the White House on certain issues.
But at the same time, both sides clearly want to use the good will to advantage. Mr. Fleischer recently recalled, for example, that the president had an economic stimulus plan that required Congressional approval. Some Democrats are balking, but Mr. Fleischer playfully suggested that the White House was counting on its new friend. "Now let's hope he votes for the president's stimulus plan," he said of Mr. Schumer.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: POLITICAL MEMO; 
On Home Front, Bush Seeks to Avoid His Father's Fate

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 

 BODY:
One of President Bush's most vital assets as he leads the military operation in Afghanistan is that Americans, overwhelmingly, have rallied behind him. His advisers say that if he is to succeed in getting his way on both the military and domestic fronts, he must maintain that steadfast public support for as long as he can.
 But there is a downside to Mr. Bush's impressive popularity ratings: No one believes they will last. 
 "When you're sitting on 90 percent," said Senator Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, "there's only one way to go -- and that's down."
A danger for Mr. Bush is that he has to wrestle with an array of unfolding developments that could imperil his public support. Many pollsters agree that people are so enraged by the attacks that they are willing to tolerate American military casualties in combatting terrorism.
That raises the question: What constitutes combatting terrorism? These pollsters say that Americans expect Mr. Bush to have a clearly defined and achievable objective.
Then there are the wild cards: what happens if there is another attack or if American casualties are higher than seemed necessary?
Further complicating the issue of public support is that many pollsters argue that Mr. Bush's biggest vulnerability is not in the military campaign but the economy.
If the country's economic woes worsen, they say, the public will be touched more by that than any perceived terrorist threat. Some public opinion experts also say that people might feel more comfortable defecting from the president on the economy, since it seems to be more in his direct control than battling terrorists on foreign soil.
William McInturff, a respected Republican pollster, concluded in a recent nationwide survey that "there is dramatic new evidence of increasing concern about the issue of the economy and jobs." 
In addition, he said that if there were no other attacks in this country or major change in the efforts to fight terrorism, Mr. Bush's "job approval rating could drift back down to the mid-50's by roughly June of 2002."
The three presidents who enjoyed the most enduring surges in public opinion -- roughly 30 weeks apiece -- were Franklin D. Roosevelt after the bombing of Pearl Harbor, John F. Kennedy after the Cuban missile crisis, and Jimmy Carter after the hostages were seized in Iran.
Yet all the historical evidence does not necessarily serve as a guide, because this country has never in modern times been so threatened on its own turf. Despite predictions that the economy could trump worries about the war in commanding public attention, it could be that Americans are so unnerved about their own safety that they will continue to offer the president unyielding support.
John Mueller, a political scientist at Ohio State University who has written extensively about war and public opinion, said people might not give Mr. Bush credit for winning a war against terrorism because the goals, inevitably, are amorphous.
"The thing about wars is they end," he said. "But now we're having victory in this war defined as a situation in which Americans feel free to live their lives. It's not like, even, getting the hostages back from Iran because then there was a goal, you did it and it was over."
Mr. Bush's aides say they realize that they have only so much time to capitalize on his public support. They note that while the public's attention could wane, the terrorists' does not. And if the support slips, it would be more difficult for Mr. Bush to maintain bipartisanship in Congress and to maintain discipline within a multilateral coalition.
As one senior administration official put it, "The clock is not on our side."
Mr. Bush's advisers said that Mr. Bush believes that his father, the former president, squandered his political capital during the Persian Gulf War by focusing almost exclusively on the military operation and not on the declining economy.
They said Mr. Bush was determined not to repeat that mistake of his father, whose high approval ratings evaporated when the war ended.
So Mr. Bush has put a premium on a two-track public opinion strategy: Rallying the country to war and explaining the goals at every turn, while taking visible steps like proposing a stimulus package to jolt the economy.
"All the historical research shows that if you have a military conflict and the economy is in trouble, the political impact of the economy on voting and approval ratings is much greater than the military conflict," said Robert J. Blendon, an expert on public opinion at Harvard.
"My belief is that Bush has got six months or a year of public support unless there's some disaster," he added. "If you start combining casualties and the message at home is that the goals are not resolvable, then you'll start seeing support going down."
Senator Sam Brownback, a Kansas Republican, agreed that maintaining "90 percent favorability is a tall order."
"The economy is likely to get in much more difficult shape before it gets better," he said, "and it's likely that we're going to see retribution from the terrorists as we get at them. It may get more people questioning the administration: 'Was that the right action to take?' "
Ed Gillespie, a Republican strategist who worked for Mr. Bush in the 2000 campaign, said, "It's going to be a constant challenge" for the president to convince the public that he is supervising the military effort while not neglecting the economy.
"Some of these roles he has to play can be competing," he said. "As you prepare the country mentally for a war that could take over a year, if not years, that can have a dampening effect on the economy."
Mr. Bush's aides have long insisted that they are not driven by polling -- and have resisted comparisons to former President Bill Clinton, who could recite survey statistics off the top of his head. Still, Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, said Mr. Bush "appreciates the support he receives from the public." He added: "In a democracy, public support is always important."
Senator McConnell asserted that the president should move even more aggressively on economic and other domestic matters to capitalize on the support while it is there.
"I do think the administration needs to walk and chew gum at the same time," Mr. McConnell said. "They need to conduct a war effort and also know there are other needs to be addressed."
Some Republican strategists suggested that people might forgive Mr. Bush for a deteriorating economy, saying they might blame the terrorists. "Will people say a bad economy is a function of external threats?" Mr. McInturff asked. "It's a debate we're having inside our firm between different partners."
One who knows about ratings firsthand is former President Gerald R. Ford. Asked how long Mr. Bush -- or any president -- could maintain high support, Mr. Ford laughed and said, "It's pretty flexible. You have to be realistic about it. It can dive as much as it can rise."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 10, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption yesterday with an article about President Bush's popularity ratings since Sept. 11 referred incorrectly to crises that faced Presidents Franklin D. Roosevelt, John F. Kennedy and Jimmy Carter. They were not entirely free of threats to the American mainland. Roosevelt faced some during World War II, notably Japanese bombing runs over Oregon, which set off forest fires, and balloons with incendiary bombs launched by the Japanese against the West Coast.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
WENDY'S TO MISS FORECAST FOR 3RD QUARTER AND YEAR

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 Wendy's International, the hamburger chain, said yesterday that it expected third-quarter and full-year earnings to fall short of Wall Street forecasts because of slower sales after the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States. The company said it expected third-quarter earnings of $52 million, or 44 cents a share, up from 41 cents a year earlier. 
For the full year, it predicted earnings of $1.64 to $1.67 a share, compared with $1.44 a year earlier. Analysts expected Wendy's to earn 46 cents a share in the third quarter, and $1.69 a share for the full year, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. Wendy's said the slowing economy, the strength of the United States dollar against the Canadian dollar and higher beef costs also hurt results.

HEADLINE: IN THE SHOWROOM; 
New Cars, New World, New Doubts, New Deals

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS 

DATELINE: CHERRY HILL, N.J. 

 BODY:
FOR car dealers and buyers, early fall is usually a bustling time, a period when the new year's models are about to be shown and the deals on the previous year's overstock make a shopper's blood run faster. 
 This year, it need hardly be said, is different. Car sellers, like all retailers, have been hit with a couple of blows. The first, the sagging economy, was already a problem when the second -- last month's terrorist attacks -- struck, sending flagging consumer spending spiraling even more downward. Big-ticket items like autos were especially hard-hit. 
 The outlook in the near term has been anything but cheerful. Americans, however, tend to be resilient, usually eager to get on with things. And they're not particularly good at resisting that new-car urge once it takes hold. So on a Friday several weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks, a reporter visited a number of car showrooms here and in the neighboring towns of Marlton and Mount Laurel, N.J., just southeast of Philadelphia, to see if there were some buyers and to assess their mood. 
The first person encountered was not a customer but Edward Albertus, the general manager of Mercedes-Benz of Cherry Hill, who shrugged at the suggestion that the attacks had slowed the pace of buyers coming into his dealership. 
"All right," he said, "for a few days it was not so good, but the next Saturday we sold eight cars. (In an average week, he said, his dealership sells about 30 cars.) "Other places, maybe they are down," Mr. Albertus said, "but our customers seem to still want to buy." 
Though random and informal, the interviews bore out Mr. Albertus's assertion. Customers were not out in significant numbers, but they seemed determined to buy.
The reasons behind their determination were the extremely attractive loan rates -- as low as zero interest for 36 months to qualified buyers -- and the discounted price tags on many 2001 models.
If an added incentive was needed, it came in the form of a patriotic call to duty. Red, white and blue was the predominant motif at most dealerships. The doors at Winner Ford were plastered with posters saying "Give It Your Best" under an American flag. Even the Mitsubishi and Honda dealerships were festooned with balloons and large American flags.
"If you are ready to buy," said Thomas Flynn, the sales manager at Winner Ford, "this is a great time to get a lot of attention." 
Veronica Williams was ready to buy -- although not a Ford. She and her husband, Robert, came to Cherry Hill Dodge from Camden to shop for a replacement car for her 1993 Intrepid, which no longer has a working transmission.
"I've never really bought a new car, always used," Mrs. Williams said. "We're leaning toward used, but I'd like something new." She gazed longingly at a black 2002 Intrepid ES, with a moonroof, air-conditioning, CD player and other extras, for $26,820.
Mr. Williams said he was not particularly worried about the economy, but added, "Something could always happen that would affect my thinking." But Mrs. Williams, who is a sales representative , said she could not be without a car for long. "I'm not that worried about the economy," she said. "In fact, I don't even want to be away from work to buy a car. If there is one thing going for us, it is that there may be deals because people are worried that the economy isn't that good." 
Lily Wu said she was not in a rush to buy a car, but she knew she wanted a Mercedes-Benz. She has owned them before and liked them. "And I have found a good service team here, so that encourages me, too," she said of the Cherry Hill dealership.
"I am looking for a used car, something two or three years old," she said. She had already seen a dozen cars, her favorite being a 1999 E300 Turbo with extras like a six-CD changer, a sunroof and an eight-speaker sound system, with a sticker price of $39,900.
Ms. Wu said that while she had not been overly concerned about the economy, the terrorist attacks had given her pause. "But my friends said, 'Spend some money, it's patriotic,' " she said with a slightly uncomfortable laugh. "So that is what I am going to do." 
Dennis Duffy, who lives in Philadelphia and works in a school for the disabled in Haddonfield, N.J., was spending his lunch hour car shopping. He said he had not been to a car dealership since the 1980's, but his Ford Ranger pickup truck is now 14 years old, with "about a billion miles on it," he said. 
THE week before he had seen ads offering zero percent interest over 36 months at Ford dealerships. He called himself a Ford man, so that was enough for him. "I told my wife I was going in, and she said, reluctantly, 'O.K.,' " he said. "There isn't going to be a better time to buy. I hate to take advantage of the potential war and all, but the financing deal is just too good." 
Mr. Duffy was looking long and hard at a 2001 XL Ranger Supercab with a five-speed automatic transmission and air-conditioning. The sticker price was $18,260, which did not seem to faze him.
"I'm not going to pinch pennies if that is what I find I want," he said. "This deal won't get any better." 
Gary Heck, who was helping his mother, Helen Kaminski, shop for a car, said they had planned to visit several dealers, including foreign car showrooms, but a traffic jam caused them to go by Saturn of Mount Laurel, where they liked what they saw.
"Mom, I like the room for you here and I can sit comfortably in the back seat," said Mr. Heck, who lives in Voorhees, N.J.. He was at the dealership, sitting in a new Saturn L200, listed for $19,375 with air-conditioning, a CD player and other small extras.
Ms. Kaminski, who walked quickly with the help of a cane, lives in Allentown, Pa., about 70 miles away. Like Mrs. Williams, she was looking for a car to replace one that had recently died.
"I want something reliable and moderately priced for her," said Mr. Heck, who said he was less concerned about the economy and prospects of war than about his mother. "A new car is what she needs," he said, "so we'll be buying, one way or another." 
Mel Gerstein, a salesman who lives in Marlton, said that he was concerned about the economy, "but my car is coming off warranty on Dec. 1, and I'm pretty sure I'm going to replace it by then."
Mr. Gerstein said that at first he thought he would replace his go-to-work car, an Oldsmobile Bravada sport utility vehicle, with something foreign, and had looked at Lexus, BMW, Mercedes-Benz and even Jaguar dealerships. But that was before Sept. 11.
"Absolutely, I want to buy American now," said Mr. Gerstein, who was reading the catalog at DeSimone Cadillac in Mount Laurel.
"I'm lucky," he added. "I've owned Cadillacs before, and I like this dealership." 
On this particular day he was looking at a 2001 DeVille with leather seats, a 4.6-liter V-8 engine, daytime running lights and an Onstar communications system. He decided, however, that he would wait for a 2002 model.
"I may be wary of the economy, but I still want something as new as possible," he said.

HEADLINE: When More Options Are Standard, the Choices Boil Down 

BYLINE:  By JIM McCRAW 

 BODY:
THERE was a time, when the moving assembly line was young, that all cars were built pretty much the same way and all the customer could choose was the body style and the number of doors. Almost every item of optional equipment, from radios and heaters to rear-view mirrors and spare-tire covers, was arranged for and installed by the selling dealer.
 In today's market, with as many as 17 million new cars and trucks sold each year, even small, inexpensive cars come with power steering, power brakes with anti-lock systems, power windows, power mirrors, power locks, automatic transmission and AM/FM/CD sound systems. The reason is simple: economies of scale mean it's easier and cheaper for factories in the United States, Japan, Korea and Europe to build them that way. And customer expectations of what is standard have risen to this level. 
 A number of carmakers, among them Ford and DaimlerChrysler, are devising ways to refine the option selections even further.
Ford recently announced changes in the way many of its 2002 models would be built and sold, with most car lines having more models, all built the same way, but with fewer options at generally lower prices.
"The objective is to minimize the number of orderable combinations, and get the right ones to the dealers and customers," said John Jelinek, a Ford marketing spokesman. For instance, he said, "On the Ford Focus, we went from over 9,000 orderable combinations last year to 152 for 2002."
Mr. Jelinek said that last year about 40 percent of Ford's customers reported they were unable to find the car they wanted in dealer stocks or were forced to buy a car with items they didn't want to get the items they did want. The new system was offered on certain models last year, with positive consumer response. Now it will be expanded to the Taurus, Excursion, Escape, Crown Victoria, Thunderbird and Windstar, among others, making it easier to comparison shop on the Internet, Mr. Jelinek said.
The Chrysler Group has shocked the industry by lowering prices on most of its 2002 models while generally keeping its standard equipment lists intact. Price reductions vary from $450 on a Dodge Neon (now $12,204) to $1,200 on a Chrysler 300M (now $28,340) to $2,000 on a Jeep Grand Cherokee (now $25,425), averaging $200 across the board. 
Chrysler also had Internet shoppers in mind. "We took a holistic look at all our vehicles in an attempt to get to 'right' pricing, to get less dependence on incentives and to help the more than 60 percent of all automotive consumers who do research on the Internet before they buy," said Thomas R. Marinelli, an executive of Chrysler and Jeep Division Global Brand Center.
"We're trying to make it as easy as possible," he continued. "On the new Jeep Liberty, there are only two models, the Limited and the Sport, with four option packages on each model." The Liberty option list offers a convenience group (things like power windows, mirrors and door locks), an off-road group, a power convenience group and a security group on either model, in addition to 28 individual options, from a bigger engine to bigger tires, anti-lock brakes, air-conditioning, a six-CD changer and a sunroof. 
THE company also looked at what should be standard and what should be optional on each of its car and truck lines, to simplify the offerings and price classes, Mr. Marinelli said. He added that in 2000, the company created a Dodge Grand Caravan minivan and a Chrysler Town and Country minivan, called the EX, a well-equipped minivan priced for Internet shoppers at $26,500, with no incentives. This year, there will be an EC version for $16,995, and an EL long-wheelbase minivan for $24,300, both aimed at Internet shoppers, neither one eligible for incentives.
A notable exception to the trend toward simplicity in options is Toyota, which offers a large number of free-standing options in its various models. The popular Camry for 2002 offers anti-lock brakes, keyless entry, a six-CD changer, a navigation system, moonroof (also called a sunroof), aluminum wheels and heated seats as individual options, but Camry also offers nine different packages of options on the Camry alone.

HEADLINE: Old-Fashioned, High-Powered or Just Max Deluxe 

BYLINE:  By DAVID J. WALLACE 

 BODY:
IN every generation, a few adventurers feel the need to put their name on hood ornaments by reinventing the sports car, reviving a classic marque or building the ultimate car in luxury or speed. The members of this small group are not building automobiles but "motor cars," as they call them, striving to give each one a unique look.
 Some of these carmakers are more like cosmetic surgeons than automakers or mechanics. Zimmer Motor Car Company, for example, gussies up Ford and Lincoln cars, leaving Detroit's factory warranty in effect. Other companies modify the engines, chassis or body designs of large manufacturers. 
 Using parts from Detroit or Stuttgart can help these independent carmakers succeed, even in an uncertain economy. They do not need huge plants to produce the cars, a capital cost that helped sink John DeLorean, who designed and manufactured a gull-wing sports car in the 1980's.
These carmakers have other advantages. Seeking exclusivity over broad appeal, they may sell only dozens of cars a year. Such low output allows them to build custom cars. Profit can be a secondary consideration, and some businesses act as tax shelters. Others hope that their innovations can be spun off profitably in the racecar industry or the mass market. 

Revivals
AVANTI(www.theavanti.com) Reincarnated more often than Shirley MacLaine, the Avanti, a flat-nosed sports car with porthole headlights, has a new life after a decade in dormancy.
Designed by Raymond Loewy for Studebaker, the car was an overnight success when it was rolled out in the early 1960's. In 1963, however, Studebaker stopped production in the United States. Since then, half a dozen owners have tried to revive the brand. John Seaton, the current chief executive of Avanti, worked for several of these owners from 1968 to 1983. In 1999, he bought a stake in the company himself.
Today's Avanti resembles the original, but its fiberglass body is stitched to a General Motors chassis, and it has a modified 330-horsepower Corvette engine. A T-top coupe is $79,000 and a convertible is $83,000.
ZIMMER (www.zimmermotorcars.com) Arthur Zimmer was driving a Chrysler minivan in 1995 when he encountered a gleaming roadster, which coincidentally bore his family's name. At his wife's urging, he bought a 1987 Zimmer Golden Spirit for the novelty. "A car was just basic transportation to get from point A to point B," Mr. Zimmer said, "until I saw this gorgeous car with my name on it."
Mr. Zimmer, an entrepreneur in Syracuse, had already ventured successfully into the restaurant, hotel and publishing businesses, so he decided to revive the carmaker as Zimmer Motor Car Company in 1997, because the original company had gone bankrupt. 
"I figured I knew nothing about manufacturing cars, so I'd be a natural," he said. "I've never even changed my own oil."
Although he calls himself semiretired, he has several businesses, and said that he expects steady growth for Zimmer, which is currently breaking even. Starting with a Ford Mustang or a Lincoln Town Car, Zimmer creates his roadsters by extending hoods and adding chrome sidepipes. The cars retain their Ford warranty because the engine is untouched, he said.
A two-door coupe starts at $89,900 and goes up to $135,900 for the four-door sedan.

High Performance
MOSLER (www.moslerauto.com) Warren Mosler, an economist, found his calling as a racecar builder. Since the mid-1980's, the company's Consulier, Intruder and Raptor cars have attracted the attention of racecar enthusiasts, thanks to innovations like V-shaped windshields, which reduce wind resistance.
Mr. Mosler's new racecar, the MT900, was designed by computer and is very light. The MT900 is expected to be certified for consumers with crash-testing and emissions-testing, Mr. Mosler said, by the end of this year. A racecar version is $119,000; the street version will cost $159,000, according to the company.
PANOZ (www.panozauto.com) Panoz Auto Company retired its AIV roadster last year and introduced the Esperante sports coupe, a more traditional-looking convertible. 
The first Esperante was sold last year, said Jack Bair, the marketing director. The company plans to turn out about 100 cars each year, said Mr. Bair, who compares the performance of the $79,950 Esperante with the Porsche 996 and the Jaguar XJ-8. The Esperante uses the Ford SVT engine and an aluminum chassis and body with a warranty from Panoz, though Ford-trained mechanics can work on the car, Mr. Bair said.
SALEEN (www.saleen.com) The S7, which looks as aggressive as a tiger shark complete with gills, is the latest product of Saleen, which until now has concentrated on selling modified vehicles, primarily Ford Mustangs. The founder, Steve Saleen, chose Brembo brakes from Italy and Connolly leather from England for his low, wide, long and light 550-horsepower car. At $375,000, the S7 is said to have a 0-to-60 mile-an- hour time of four seconds and a top speed above 200 m.p.h.
"We've sold 41 of them," said Jack Gerken, a spokesman. "We plan about 100 a year for four years."
Mr. Gerken said the company offered its own warranty because it had to obtain its own certification for emissions and crash-testing. This is the case for all companies that build new cars, even if they are substantially modifying other vehicles.
SHELBY (www.shelbyamerican.com) Carroll Shelby is well known for his Cobra racecars and for vehicles that he created for Ford and Chrysler in the 1970's and 80's. The Series 1 convertible, his latest model, introduced last year, was built with a modified Oldsmobile Aurora V-8 engine. Prices start at $142,000 and, depending on options and upgrades, can rise to $219,000 for a 370-horsepower version, according to Gary Patterson, who coordinates online ordering.

Luxe
CUNNINGHAM Ford is not the only auto company with a family legacy. In 1952, Briggs Cunningham II built the C4R, considered by many in the industry to be the first modern racecar. His son, Briggs Cunningham III, plans to build a grand-touring car, dubbed the C7, modeled after the classic Stutz or Duesenberg. 
Expected to come out by late 2004, the C7 will have an aluminum V-12 engine and room for four adults, said Larry Black, a principal in Cunningham Motor Car Company. The C7 will cost about $250,000, said Mr. Black.
PACKARD (www.packardmotorcar.com) The Packard Motor Car Company, only six years old and based in Phoenix, has been testing two touring cars with a custom-built aluminum engine and all-wheel drive system, said Roy Gullickson, the company's president.
These Packards have been completely redesigned, though they have nostalgic touches, like the original script logo and imposing grilles, which harken back to the elegant 12-cylinder cars last produced in 1958.
"We first showed the car at Packard clubs three years ago," Mr. Gullickson said. "Since then, we've been continuing with engineering and development."
The company has no production schedule and is still seeking financing, Mr. Gullickson said. But he estimates the cars will cost about $155,000 for a sedan and $175,000 for a coupe or a convertible, which, he pointed out, is less than a Rolls-Royce or Bentley.

HEADLINE: HOW WE DRIVE; 
The Fine Art of Shifting Slips Into a Lower Gear

BYLINE:  By LESLEY HAZLETON 

 BODY:
IN the world of car guys, not all of whom happen to be male, it's an axiom that if you want to drive (really drive, that is, not merely commute or cruise), you'll choose a stick shift. 
 Car magazines use a special language for stick shifts. They write of going "snik-snak" through the gears, while if I heard sniks or snaks from my transmission, I'd drive straight to the repair shop. 
 They love "short-throw" shifts, where you only have to move the stick a couple of inches into gear, though devotees of old pickup trucks and Citroen 2CV's, like myself, still hanker for the long throw. And they rave about buttery smooth gear changes -- a description that really isn't apt, because the real feeling of a good manual transmission is soft and pliable, with an edge, like suede. 
But the sign of a true car guy is the way he or she handles the stick shift before even starting the car, getting the feel of it in the palm of the hand. 
Of course, not all stick shifts are alike. The golf ball on top of the aluminum stick of the new Beetle doesn't have quite the heft of the luxurious leather one in the Honda S2000 roadster. But even a golf ball is better than what you get on an automatic transmission, which is basically a prosaic handle. More like the grip on a shovel, in fact. And there's nothing very appealing about shifting with a shovel.
How you use that gear knob is a kind of driver's Rorschach test. Some tend to grab the knob as though they are wrestling, and move their whole arm to push the stick into gear. Those who strive to be masters of finesse use a magician's legerdemain, a lightness of hand: a forward flip of the palm or the fingers for first, third or fifth gear, and a backward flip for second, fourth and, if you're lucky, sixth. 
Sadly, this sort of dexterity is rapidly becoming an anachronism, at least in the United States. Car-guy axioms notwithstanding, it looks as though the stick shift is nearing extinction.
For decades, the number of automatic transmissions sold has been steadily declining about a percentage point a year. The latest National Automobile Dealers Association figures show that manuals were only 8.9 percent of all cars sold in the United States last year, down from 9.8 percent in 1999 and 10.6 percent in 1998. Almost a quarter of all Porsches sold in the States are automatics, and even Ferrari -- yes, Ferrari, the ne plus ultra of the car-guy pantheon -- went automatic in l995 on its four-seater 456 MGTA. 
At this rate, it looks like the stick shift will go the way of the carburetor within the next decade. But while fuel injection is a boon to all but shade-tree mechanics, the automatic transmission is not quite as clear a gain. True, it makes driving much easier, but it also makes it less interesting. You lose the poetry inherent in auto-motion.
What happens to the dramatic gesture if you can no longer spin the wheels, pop the clutch and roar off leaving a faithless lover to eat your dust? What happens to the exhilarating effect on your internal organs as you're flattened against the seat in a high-speed takeoff? What happens to the sheer fun of being able to turn the cheapest econobox into a mini-Ferrari by working it up through the gears with a firm foot on the gas pedal?
Equally important -- O.K., far more important -- what happens to your control? 
Stick-shift aficionados swear they have greater control over their cars. Terry Earwood, the chief instructor for the Skip Barber Racing School, readily backs them up. 
"With a stick, you're more involved with the car, so you're paying more attention to driving," Mr. Earwood said. "And the car is more responsive. The liquid coupling in an automatic transmission means there's some time loss between the gear shift and the transmission of power to the wheels. With the mechanical coupling of a manual transmission, you don't get that lag; a stick driver is more in control."
GREATER control certainly means greater safety. Well, almost certainly, because there's no way to tell for sure. Crash and moving-violation statistics do not track types of transmission. And while some safety experts are at least willing to speculate that drivers of standard shift cars are less likely to use a hand-held cellphone until they come to a stop, here again, there are no statistics to prove it.
In the end, though, the choice between manual or automatic transmission is not really about safety, or control, or drama or even sexiness. No, it's far more mundane. A single Sunday evening on the Long Island Expressway inching along with a manual transmission, shifting gears dozens of times a mile, is enough to convince most stick-shift drivers that the time has come to give in and go automatic. Even the most suedelike shift begins to feel like congealed grease. Legs and hips ache. The commonplace nuisance of a traffic jam becomes a form of torture. 
If you happen to live in a city of hills, as I do in Seattle, the toll on body and mind is compounded. Never mind that I love cornering hard by shifting down and powering through the turn. And don't let's talk about that surge of engine power vibrating through the gear knob into the palm of my hand. 
I confess: I'm only human, I drive an automatic.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 15, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in the special Cars section on Wednesday about gear shifting misstated the type of transmission that is becoming less common. Automobiles with manual transmissions, not automatic, have been declining in the United States at the approximate rate of 1 percent a year.

HEADLINE: LIFE'S WORK; 
Restaurants Grieve, Family Style

BYLINE:  By LISA BELKIN; This column about the intersection of jobs and personal lives appears every other week. E-mail: Belkin@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
TO an outsider it looked like a reunion, which, in a way, it was. Friends greeted friends with hugs and with tears. "I've missed you so much," someone said. "It feels like years since I've seen you." Someone else walked over to the front plate-glass window and smoothed the edges of the American flag where the tape had sagged. Then the group filed into the empty party room to hear what their boss had to say.
 Tony May's business card says he is the owner of three restaurants, but the card is a month out of date. Mr. May owns but one restaurant now: San Domenico on Central Park South, where he has gathered his workers for this dinnertime meeting. 
 The dozens of men and women crammed into the party room are refugees from Gemelli's and Pasta Break, two restaurants that disappeared with the World Trade Center. Waiters and busboys, chefs and bartenders, they are part of a separate layer of loss. Yes, they are alive, but the support beams of their lives are broken. They worry about paying the rent, about filling the hours of the day, about the panic that invades their dreams.
"I had a job that I liked, a boss that I liked, but now it's gone," said Idi Diawara, who used to be the manager of Pasta Break.
He was at work at the Trade Center early that last morning, opening the restaurant for the breakfast rush, when there was a noise "like when you put the A.C. on," and then the lights flickered. He left the building to investigate, saw the flames where the first plane had hit, then returned to clear out the other employees and lock the door.
When the second plane hit he began to run and did not stop moving until he reached his apartment in the Bronx.
Mr. May as well does not want to stop moving, because then he would have to confront all that he has lost. Instead, he keeps himself busy worrying about workers like Mr. Diawara. Several days after his restaurants were obliterated, he called the staffs together and promised to pay their health insurance for six months and to keep them on at half salary until his reserves ran out. At that first meeting he taught them how to apply for unemployment, and also brought in a psychiatrist, Dr. Alan Manevitz, to listen if they wanted to talk.
For hours, they spilled their stories -- of watching bodies fall, of being chased by clouds of debris. Dr. Manevitz was particularly concerned about one worker who sobbed through the entire session. He asked her to telephone for a private appointment, but she never called. So Mr. May brought the doctor back again, for this second meeting in his burnished wood party room.
Sitting at the front of the group, the doctor looked even more drained than the workers. Already on this day, he had been to talk to a group of bereaved firefighters and a group of widows from Cantor Fitzgerald. "Is anybody having trouble sleeping?" he asked. A few hands are raised. "Are you more irritable with your family?" More hands. "Nightmares? Trouble eating?" Nearly everyone nodded. 
"I don't even want to leave my house," said the woman who sobbed through the last meeting. 
"You were supposed to call me," the doctor said, gently, and she started to weep again.
"I have a job for you," Mr. May blurted out. He planned to send out fliers to rustle up more business for his one remaining restaurant, and he offered to hire the woman to stuff those fliers into envelopes. 
Mr. May started to spin out other ideas to keep the woman from crying: vocational courses ("If it is not an exorbitant amount of money, we might even be able to help pay for it"), travel ("Many of you have family outside the U.S., this might not be a bad time to go and visit them"), volunteering ("Sometimes you can help yourself by getting out and doing things for other people"). They nodded at his suggestions, but everyone in the room knew the truth. As hard as he tried, he could not give them the one thing they all needed.
"It's not going to be easy for you to find new jobs," he said finally, "because the entire restaurant industry is behind 30 to 40 percent. We are trying to find some locations where maybe we would reopen the restaurant. But it will be a number of months before we can put you all back to work."
When the talking was through, dinner was served -- a family-style meal like the ones they used to share before each restaurant shift. The pasta and chicken were devoured in near silence, as Mr. May walked among the group. He patted a shoulder here, shook a hand there. Once or twice he reached into his pocket and fished around for a copy of his outdated business card.

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section F; Column 1; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1955 words

HEADLINE: Beyond Quiet Dining Rooms, A Quiet Crisis in the Kitchen 

BYLINE:  By AMANDA HESSER 

 BODY:
AT Town, one of the year's most successful new restaurants, Geoffrey Zakarian is no longer flying in fresh turbot from France, because the restaurant can no longer afford it. He's using local fish instead.
 Rather than foie gras, Christina Kelly at Avenue is serving duck liver mousse. The price: $6 versus $15. 
 At Abajour, where the prix fixe menu has been dropped to $19.95 from $25, gulf shrimp have been replaced with less expensive popcorn shrimp. Halibut has been swapped for catfish. 
At Union Pacific, a menu called "market treats," which featured exotic sushi from Japan, top-quality caviar and esoteric herbs, has been dropped. Instead, Rocco Di Spirito said, "We're running a menu that's slightly smaller but that has friendlier choices." Like steak and mushroom soup.
While small neighborhood restaurants have been thriving since the terrorist attacks, high-end restaurants all over the city have watched their businesses fall by as much as 50 percent. For many, that has meant layoffs, lower prices and promotions that they would have never imagined during the economic boom of recent years.
But deeper changes have taken hold, too: chefs are tiptoeing instead of swaggering, pulling back from experimental dishes and innovative menus, and not always reaching for the best ingredients. It may be a temporary reaction to quiet dining rooms, or a change for the long term -- for now, nobody can say what the effect will be on New York's remarkable growth as a restaurant city. In recent years, the city was considered to have overtaken Paris as the culinary star of the world. Now, it looks like a town of timid and frightened cooks.
There is reason for restaurateurs to worry.
Last week, Peacock Alley in the Waldorf-Astoria closed for good. So did Virot, a promising new restaurant run by an acolyte of Jean-Georges Vongerichten. Daniel, perhaps New York's most revered restaurant, stopped serving lunch for lack of business. Charlie Palmer cut prices 10 to 15 percent at Alva, his casual restaurant in the Flatiron district. Abajour, an Upper East Side bistro, sent out 30,000 cards offering free dessert.
"There's no question that things weren't great before the disaster," said Mr. Di Spirito, the chef at Union Pacific. "The disaster just sort of sealed the deal."
Since Sept. 11, tourism in New York City has fallen drastically, deeply affecting destination restaurants like Tavern on the Green, Picholine and Aureole. Trendy restaurants like Peasant and Mercer Kitchen downtown have also suffered, while business-lunch traffic in Midtown has slowed to a crawl.
"I used to go out to lunch three, four times a week," said John Kim, a banker at J. P. Morgan in Midtown. "Now, I just want to order in a sandwich. Everyone in my office is doing the same thing. No one wants to go out."
To reverse this trend, some restaurants have resorted to behavior usually associated with theme restaurants. Shelly's New York, Redeye Grill and Trattoria Dell'Arte began Red, White and Blue Wednesdays, when they are filled with red, white and blue balloons, all containing prize tickets. Diners may win a bottle of wine, a dessert or a T-shirt. Abajour began Monday Menu Roulette, placing a menu without prices into the stack and giving the diner who receives it a free dinner.
D'Artagnan has a waiter dressed as a musketeer handing out leaflets on the street. Restaurant Associates, which owns 10 restaurants, including the Sea Grill, Tropica and Brasserie 8 1/2, promised to send $50 gift certificates to the first 25,000 people to respond to an Internet offer. A week was allowed for responses, but within 48 hours, the limit was reached. "They were coming in about two per second," said John Harding, the director of marketing. "It was like watching an electricity meter running."
For diners, the impact of such changes is far-ranging. Deeper price reductions may make some restaurants newly affordable. You may get into Balthazar, and they may actually be nice to you.
But in many cases, you will also have a different kind of dining experience. Lower prices may mean dining on more modest kinds of food, and a more modest style of cuisine. "We've analyzed our menus," said Mr. Zakarian, the chef at Town. "And we've definitely determined that we're going to be less celebratory than before. We'll be using truffles and foie gras, but not nearly as much." Instead, customers will see more refined takes on homey dishes like navarin, stews and soups.
At Avenue, one of the small bistros that have prospered during recent weeks, Ms. Kelly said, "I've been very conservative, trying to be more clever about the way we do things."
"I just don't use anything baby anymore," she said. "Truffles are going to be another issue. I think a lot of people are going to start turning to truffle butter."
Rather than lobster, she will serve crab. Rather than Chilean sea bass, she will cook local fish like fluke and skate.
In some cases, like foie gras, which had become cliched, this all may be for the better. "It's so played out," Ms. Kelly said. "It's so rich. I think people have gotten away from that."
While many menus are shrinking, it's hard to predict what will happen next. Each restaurant is conducting its own experiment, hoping the results will allow it to stay in business, from reducing prices to responding to the mood of people's appetites.
"I notice people are drinking like crazy," said Mr. Zakarian at Town, "and gorging on fatty foods. I know, myself. I've been eating hamburgers like crazy."
At Metrazur, the bar business has grown so much that the management has changed the lounge menu and begun offering reduced-price supersize martinis and other drinks at happy hour.
"They're not so interested in sitting down to a dinner," Charlie Palmer, an owner, said. "They want to eat burgers and pizza." So he expanded the menu and cut the prices of pizza by a few dollars.
It's a big adjustment, after a boom that threw up unprecedented obstacles to diners, from stratospheric prices and condescending attitudes to reservation books filled months in advance. While it would be nice to rid the restaurant scene of such annoyances, it is important to note that during the boom, New York dining experienced a surge of creativity and progress not seen since the days of Le Pavillon.
The Harrison, a restaurant that is to open in TriBeCa this fall, has scaled back plans for its wine list. Originally, the list was to have included 500 wines, at $18 to $500. Now, there will be 220, at $18 to $250.
"There aren't a lot of luxury wines going out the door," said Mr. DiSpirito at Union Pacific, which had planned to buy $100,000 worth of wine this fall. "Obviously, we're not doing that now."
Restaurant Associates is also draining its current supplies and starting a wine program that will offer high-quality wines at lower prices. De Loach's Russian River Valley Chardonnay and its single-vineyard cabernet sauvignon will be selling for $20. "Basically, we're just cutting back our margins," Mr. Harding said.
D'Artagnan is offering the same kind of deals on its food. Takeout sandwiches, which used to cost $7.75 to $9, have all been reduced to $6. And P.B.J.'s they are not. For $6 you will get saucisson with truffle butter and smoked duck breast with red wine jelly. The $36 early-bird dinner is now $29, including three courses that could easily have cost twice that two months ago.
Such measures are not an overreaction. The first week following the terrorist attacks, Union Pacific's business was off 80 percent. Since then, it has crept back, but is still down 30 percent from this time last year. Check averages at Aureole are down 25 percent. In addition, the number of diners has been 30 percent lower than normal.
Mr. Palmer has reduced menu prices at Alva 15 to 20 percent. There, too, wines by the glass, which used to be $8 to $14, are now all $8. Some staff members have been laid off, others moved around. "Now at Aureole, Gerry Hayden, my head chef, is down to one sous-chef," Mr. Palmer explained. "And so now I fill in in spots when it's needed."
It is an almost unfathomable reversal, considering the fact that last year, restaurants around the country were so desperate for cooks, waiters and sommeliers that they were poaching them from each other. Now, even top chefs are having trouble finding work.
"It's Darwinism," said Alfred Ehrlich, the owner of Kitchen Maestro, a headhunter for chefs. "The strong will survive and get stronger. And we'll learn from what happened, just like in 1987, when the market crashed and the gulf war."
For those involved, it hasn't seemed so clear and simple.
"The last recession, you had a gradual drop in business," Mr. Palmer said. "When this thing happened, the business just dropped off so dramatically, so quickly. It's just hard to react to anything like that." All of his managers have taken pay cuts; Mr. Palmer has not had a paycheck for more than a month. "It's not my choice," he said. "There's just no money to take."
With fewer diners, each customer might receive more attention than before. But the reduction in servers may also mean poorer service. Rather than four people swarming around your table, there may be just two. Rather than a trained, high-salaried sommelier fetching your wine, it may be an inexperienced minimum-wage busboy who does not drink wine.
It is difficult to gauge what will happen in the coming months. "I'm worried about all of the cutbacks that are coming," said Steve Hanson, the owner of several restaurants in Manhattan, including Ruby Foo's and Ocean Grill. "I think we'll stay about where we are until the end of the year, but I'm deathly afraid of the first quarter of '02."
As Mr. Zakarian put it, "It's like a tsunami hitting after the earthquake."
Restaurants preparing to open have regrouped, bracing themselves for whatever may unfold. Suba, which is to open on the Lower East Side later this year, has already decided to cut the prices of its entrees to $20, from $22 to $25.
Meanwhile, restaurants like Brunelli, on the Upper East Side, which have neither the buffer of name recognition nor generous investors, are struggling to keep their doors open. After the attacks, 40 percent of Brunelli's clientele -- those from outside Manhattan -- stopped coming, and tables of six and eight dwindled to twos and threes. The restaurant has stopped serving lunch and removed expensive items like steak from its menu.
"I have about a month here," Russ Brunelli, the owner, said. "Then we have to reassess and re-evaluate. Do you go to a bank and take out a loan? What happens if things don't come back?"
If the experiences of purveyors are any indication, things don't look good. "The wholesale took a huge hit in receivables," said Ariane Daguin, the owner of D'Artagnan, a large supplier of specialty meats. "To this day, we don't know if we will be paid by the restaurants that are being closed every day.
"My sales in Florida are terrible. In Atlanta, it's really stagnant. My sales in Long Island are terrible. San Francisco, Las Vegas. Las Vegas is . . . bff!"
Christopher Pappas, the president of Dairyland, which supplies specialty foods to more than 3,000 restaurants in the New York area, said its sales were also down drastically. In SoHo and Midtown, they are off 50 to 75 percent.
Others remain steeled with optimism. "You know," Mr. Ehrlich said, "restaurants provide so many more outlets for people, not just nutrition. Being able to communicate with others, to distract us from the stresses in the world."
Restaurateurs, for perhaps the first time in years, though, are not so sure of their invincibility.
"We're doing O.K.," said Donny Evans, an owner of Marika on the Upper West Side. "If you say you're doing O.K., that's good at this point."
