HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
In a muted environment, agencies try new approaches to drum up domestic tourism.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
WITH a fervor perhaps not evidenced since Dinah Shore last belted out "See the U.S.A. in your Chevrolet," the organizations that help market American tourist destinations are working determinedly to deliver pitches meant to resonate with consumers now leery of traveling.
 The drastic decline in trips after Sept. 11 has spurred organizations and associations to introduce ads tailored to the tempered climate as well as revise campaigns that had appeared before the terrorist attacks. At stake are, well, their stakes of the estimated $500 billion spent every year for travel and tourism. 
 "It's taken on a new urgency," said Nat Gutwirth, creative director at the Weightman Group in Philadelphia, which introduced yesterday a campaign for the Center City District, an organization that promotes downtown Philadelphia. The theme is: "There's a time and place for everything. Make it Center City." 
"The ultimate purpose is to make people more comfortable using the resources of the city, primarily shopping, dining and cultural," he added, particularly when "there has been an increase in people feeling less secure about coming into cities." The campaign, with a budget of $150,000, is to run through the fall.
When one client, the Empire State Development Corporation, asked about the feasibility of quickly producing an appropriate campaign, "at first, I was numbed by the questions," said Mike Rogers, president and executive creative director at the New York office of the Wolf Group. " 'What are we going to do?' 'Where do we go from here?' "
"But the answer is simple, obvious," he added. "You go on."
So the agency is creating a $40 million campaign, to be sponsored by the development agency and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, that carries the familiar "I Love New York" theme but presents an entirely new message "to show that New York is going on," Mr. Rogers said, "refracting back that unquenchable spirit." A television commercial is to start running today.
"We wanted to recognize the current sensitivity in the marketplace and develop a program that we think is right for the time," said William Talbert, president and chief executive at the Greater Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau, "but also has legs and can go on." The bureau's agency, Turkel Schwartz & Partners in Coconut Grove, Fla., accelerated work on a campaign so it could begin appearing last weekend.
During a meeting of the bureau's marketing committee, said Bruce Turkel, executive creative director at Turkel Schwartz, one member, Jessica Goldman, vice president of Goldman Properties, which owns hotels and restaurants, described how at Yom Kippur services "the rabbi was talking about what you really need to do now is stop and think about what makes you happy."
"We said, 'Whoa, back up,' and seized on that," Mr. Turkel said, using it as the centerpiece of the campaign, which asserts that "now is the time to connect with the things that matter, with the people important to you, and why not in a place that's warm and welcoming."
So the campaign, with a budget of $2.2 million, carries the theme "What makes you happy?" The television, radio, print and interactive ads offer answers that range from spending more time with your children ("When was the last time you giggled?") to slowing down ("When was the last time you danced till dawn with your spouse?").
Another organization racing to introduce a campaign that would appeal to travelers after Sept. 11 was the Washington, D.C., Convention and Tourism Corporation, which had been involved in a review for its advertising account when the World Trade Center and Pentagon were attacked. The account was awarded on Friday to Eisner Communications in Baltimore and Washington, which accelerated the planned introduction of ads so they could start this week.
"We were involved in an effort to help characterize what sets Washington apart from other great cities," said Steve Eisner, president and chief executive at Eisner, "and what we learned in talking to 1,500 travelers and travel planners was that Washington is clearly a city of inspiration, from its architecture to its museums to its political power to its important moments in time."
"That was the track we were on, but in light of what happened, we had to see whether it would hold up," he added. "In polling the week after, we learned that among the same 1,500 people there was more of a desire to touch D.C., an interest in making a literal connection. We discovered the city was again representing a real sense of inspiration for the rest of the country."
So the print ads coming out carry the theme "Come. Be inspired," and feature patriotic images. For instance, one ad shows a man waving an American flag under the words "There's only one way to get back in touch with what's really important. Come home." Another ad depicts the Capitol and the text reads: "People everywhere are looking for inspiration. Here's one place you're sure to find it."
One change in the bureau's plans, Mr. Eisner said, was a refocusing of the media schedule for the $2 million campaign to "more deeply reach the neighboring states" rather than potential visitors farther away.
That is a shift being made by many other tourism organizations like the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Bureau, which doubled to $13 million the budget for a campaign introduced last week by R&R Partners in Las Vegas, which carries the theme "It's time for you," but deferred spending in Eastern markets to concentrate on closer cities like Chicago, Houston and Los Angeles.
By comparison, Mr. Turkel said, the Greater Miami bureau is continuing to spend nationally because "for Miami and Dade County, 96 or 97 percent of traffic is by air."
"Let's say we triple the 'drive market,' " he added, referring to visitors who travel by car. "Oooh, that's still only 12 percent" of total traffic.

HEADLINE: For Mark Green in the Runoff 

 BODY:
New York City's voters have a right to feel they've fallen into a political whirlpool. A terrorist attack halted the mayoral primary. The runoff will be held tomorrow, in the middle of an international crisis. A race that was declared boring only a month ago now has so much on the line that people seem almost unable to comprehend its full import.
 Neither Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, nor Mark Green, the city's public advocate, is an ideal mayoral candidate. But the differences between the two men, which were noticeable before, have stretched to formidable over the last few weeks. Mr. Ferrer is the product of the Bronx Democratic machine and his career has hewed closely to the party organization's political rulebook. Mr. Green has always been a political outsider who had to fight for what he wanted, an idea man who specialized in problem-solving. In a time of quiet prosperity, perhaps either man could have handled the job. But now the city needs Mr. Green, who knows how to operate in uncharted waters. 
 Mr. Ferrer began the campaign as the candidate who promised to bring the city's economic boom to the "other New York" that had not yet benefited from good times. He came in first in the primary, and has since collected the endorsements of the city's most influential labor unions, along with their formidable get-out-the-vote machinery.
Now the good times have vanished. Experts are beginning to predict that the loss of tax revenue from the terrorist attack will be so tremendous that the city will be incapable of balancing its budget, forcing control of municipal finances into the hands of the state. But Mr. Ferrer has not really adapted his sales pitch to the new realities. His ads still promise expanded services, and he still vows to improve things for the "other New York." The only difference is that Mr. Ferrer, in need of a broader base, has now decided that the other New York includes everybody in the city.
No one who understands the way elections are run would expect either candidate in an extremely close runoff to produce an instant list of city services he planned to reduce. But Mr. Green has been franker than Mr. Ferrer in warning that his administration would be much different from what he, and the city, imagined during the summer. Unlike Mr. Ferrer, Mr. Green has also been very clear, since shortly after the attack, about what he would do to rebuild Lower Manhattan. 
Mr. Green, who ran a smooth and successful campaign until Sept. 11, has been off his game for most of the last month. Some of his comments, particularly when he theorized that he would have handled the terrorist attack as well as or better than Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, reminded people that he can be irritatingly self-absorbed. Much of the campaign focus in recent weeks has been on personality, and it is absolutely true that Mr. Ferrer has a softer demeanor than Mr. Green's. But the city's most successful recent mayors, Edward Koch and Mr. Giuliani, are both difficult personalities. With the city in such a perilous condition, we cannot afford to judge mayoral candidates on the basis of who would be a better seatmate on a long train trip.
The bottom line is this: Right now the city needs strong leadership, innovative thinking and a mayor who comes into office owing as little as possible to the many unions and political interests that naturally expect to be rewarded for services rendered. On all those points, Mr. Green is the better choice. He made a tactical error when he agreed to Mayor Giuliani's idea for an extended term, but his entire career has demonstrated that he is not afraid to take risks or say no to powerful interests. Mr. Ferrer does not have Mr. Green's gravitas, his interest in policy, his ability to bulldoze forward toward a goal no matter the obstacles. Perhaps most critical of all, Mr. Green is likely to pick deputies and commissioners for their ability to solve problems. Mr. Ferrer's history suggests he will reward political service.
More than a month ago, this page endorsed Mr. Green in the Democratic primary. The very long road we have traveled since then has only reinforced that choice.

HEADLINE: Review/Fashion; 
Small Escapes, With Flounces and Twirls

BYLINE:  By GINIA BELLAFANTE 

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 9 

 BODY:
In some sense, Fashion Week here is set up like the perfectly planned fifth-grade school day. Upon arrival, editors engage in the exercise of show and tell. What gets shown is usually something that was purchased the previous week in Milan from Prada or Gucci; what is broadcast is how little that something cost taking into account the strong dollar, the VAT and the 30 percent discounts offered to certain members of the fashion press.
 This episode is followed by an exam period, or at least what constitutes as much in fashion -- the showing of difficult work by conceptual designers whose garments have been deconstructed and reconstructed so baroquely they make you wonder if they aren't also capable of morphing into Cuisinarts. Happily, by Day 4 or so comes the equivalent of recess -- the point at which most of the designers feel that advanced engineering is best left to the fine people at M.I.T. 
 If fashion shows have any compelling purpose in a week of cruise missile strikes, globally scattered bomb threats and fear of anthrax, perhaps it is to keep those whose livelihoods depend on looking at clothes contentedly distracted for the occasional 21 minutes.
Whether an audience member turns to the person on the right or left at the spring 2002 shows, the same conversation always ensues. It always begins with the words, "When do you get to go home?"
Welcome are the collections that manage to take you someplace else, a point which hasn't bypassed John Galliano, who at his show for Christian Dior today wittily took his audience everywhere else. A mix master of the supreme order, Mr. Galliano, in 57 looks, managed sabbaticals to Avenue D and Fourth Street; Sedona, Ariz.; Graceland and greater Memphis; Reno and Las Vegas; Oaxaca, Mexico; and possibly, as one python blazer suggested, some imagined nation state that merged a Dean Martin Palm Springs with a modern-day Baku.
Typically, the references were piled on top of one another in way that made each model look like a furiously packed piece of carry-on luggage -- the shirtdress that screamed Mexican table linens with the striped cotton pants that said Rikers Island, topped off by a hat that suggested Jackson Hole and traditional Navajo costume.
It was Mr. Galliano's conspiratorial humor that made the whole enterprise succeed, sending up as he did the kind of designer who ventures away from the fashion capitals, earnestly attempting to absorb the larger world, and returns ready to commodify the experience with a product that says, "Look, I went to Tunis and made this turquoise djellaba."
Meaningful, too, was Mr. Galliano's engagement with the notion of globalism, which is so easily lost at a moment when even the world's least exotic corners seem out of reach. It presented a counterpoint to the poignancy in hearing Thomas Maier, the creative director of Bottega Veneta and the designer of his own rarefied knitwear line, promote his collection as "really comfortable for being on planes."
There would be little overlap in a Venn diagram linking Mr. Galliano with Valentino, but today both designers left you nostalgic for that time -- let's say late August -- when traveling did not seem to require the stashing away of a supply of Xanax. Valentino paid tribute, as he has for more seasons than there are bottles of Barbaresco in Rome, to the woman of multiple residences.
Today there were beautifully ruffled chiffon palazzo pants for her summer nights in Forte dei Marmi, quiet Shantung peasant skirts for her experiment with late March in Taos, painstakingly beaded chiffon miniskirts for wherever someone she hasn't yet met might ask her to come. So many of the clothes, some embellished with exquisite twiglike corals, made you wish a little for her life, no matter how deflated a version.
Not as meticulously circumscribed is Olivier Theyskens's vision of womanhood. Though his talent for producing high-minded feminine clothes seems to grow each season, Mr. Theyskens distracts in the manner of a Gothic novel. He presents his unrelentingly romantic clothes in big gloomy spaces, lending the dresses and suits the air of the doomed lover whose gifts no one ever manages to clearly see. His black skirt suits unfolded to reveal panels of satin. An otherwise unadventurous tulle dress revealed a bare back etched in a black trapezoid. Like Alexander McQueen a few days earlier, Mr. Theyskens shrank down a man's jacket and incorporated it into an evening dress, for which it served as a strapless top and bodice, the sleeves of the jacket outlining bare arms. His effort was as economically beautiful as Mr. McQueen's was aggressively showy.
Economy of a different sort is the mode at Cacharel, the French house revived by the design team of Suzanne Clements and Inacio Ribeiro as a maker of clothes priced well below those meant to be worn on yachts. The show offered another opportunity to put aside whatever unsettling bit of hard news you had just acquired from MSNBC. The clothes were cheerful in the best sense of the term, mixing well-matched stripes with florals and drawing from the comforting images of domestic life: picnic-tablecloth-check tops, wallpaper-patterned cotton dresses, skirts emblazoned with pet parakeets.
How well-timed the clothes seem at a moment when most people are keeping a hand on their wallets and pointing compasses in the direction of home.

HEADLINE: Craving a Comfort Zone; 
Homespun Activities and Purchases Have New Appeal

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN and JULIAN E. BARNES 

 BODY:
Sewing machines and batik pillows are in. So are Lego construction sets and scrapbooks, along with bowling and brownies.
 While the attention of many economists has focused on what people are avoiding in the aftermath of last month's terrorist attacks and the first waves of retaliatory bombings in Afghanistan -- traveling on airplanes, making luxury purchases, going to expensive restaurants -- executives and store data suggest a pattern of what people are doing instead. Americans are seeking solace, it seems, in mundane and homey activities and purchases. 
 Businesses are understandably loath to talk much about benefiting from a horrible human tragedy, but it is clear that consumers are crowding into stores that promote old-fashioned crafts like quilting and knitting. And whereas retailing as a whole is hurting -- sales for the week ended Saturday, according to the Instinet Research Redbook, were down 1.3 percent from the week last year -- products associated with cocooning, like candles and DVD players, are experiencing a spike in popularity. Meanwhile, fast foods (pass the pizza) and comfort foods (hooray for ice cream) are moving well.
"People want to sew, create and get back to basics," said Judi Appel, who runs a fabric and home decor store in Morro Bay, Calif. Ms. Appel said customers began to stream into her store, the Cotton Ball, within hours of the attacks. They nestled into the plush purple chenille-covered sofas, cradled mugs of coffee and then bought small things like red-white-and-blue fabric for flags and big things like $1,500 sewing machines.
By the end of the day her sales were roughly one-third above a normal day and they have remained as strong in the weeks since. The Cotton Ball is not alone. Arts-and-crafts stores nationwide are reporting lines out the door. Michaels Stores, an arts-and-crafts chain with nearly 700 stores, announced this week that it expected sales to rise 8 to 10 percent this year, compared with prior forecasts of 6 to 8 percent. "We are an industry people go to in times of trouble," said Susan Brandt, director of communications at the Hobby Industry Association. "They take solace in staying busy and doing things with their hands."
Another bit of old-fashioned Americana that appears to be making a comeback is bowling. Robert D. Putnam lamented the dissolution of community in his book "Bowling Alone: The Collapse and Revival of American Community". But in recent weeks many bowling center operators are reporting a resurgence of interest in the sport as families and friends look for bonding activities.
Dick Corley, chief executive of Bowl New England, which operates 13 centers in 7 states, said nonleague play rose two consecutive weekends at the end of September as parents and children jammed his businesses. "After the terrible tragedy in New York people want to be with other people," he said. "The family thing is huge."
Marge Bergeson works two jobs and is usually tired when she ends her shift at the Holiday Bowl in Groton, Conn. But on the last two Tuesdays, she has received a call from her daughter Jennifer, 23, who wanted to organize a family bowling night. Ms. Bergeson complied, suspecting a link to the terror attacks.
"My daughter told me how important her father and I are now," she recalled. "She wants to be around us more."
When parents are not doing activities with their children, they are buying them things to comfort and reassure them. The movie featuring Harry Potter, the bespectacled boy wizard, will have its premiere in November, and retailers were worried earlier this year that merchandise related to the film might not sell. But that has all changed.
"There is a rush to foster play patterns that are safe, and Harry Potter is a known character," said Michael McNally, a spokesman for Lego, which has temporarily sold out of many of its Harry Potter construction kits. "He is the kind of safe role model parents are looking for, and Harry Potter is also an individual kids can relate to." Parents are also buying stuffed Harry Potter dolls and electronic databases of spells, said David Niggli, the chief operating officer of F. A. O. Schwarz, the toy retailer.
Looming economic uncertainty and concerns about overseas fighting have also aroused American's urge to nest. "We had a great weekend after the 11th and had an incredible weekend after that: traffic, sales and transaction size were all up," said Marvin Girouard, chairman and chief executive of Pier 1 Imports, whose 800-plus stores specialize in low-cost items for the home.
He is even optimistic that sales will hold up through the holidays. "People may not buy a new car or new computer, but they will buy ornaments, wreaths and placemats," he said. "And that serves us really well."
Large consumer electronics are ordinarily the first kind of luxury to stop selling in a slowing economy, but NPD, a market research firm, has raised its estimate for sales of DVD players to 13 million from 11.4 million since the attacks.
Dave Powers, a 34-year-old Manhattan resident, spent the first weeks after the attacks seeking the company of friends at New York bars. But last week he was at Circuit City in Union Square looking at DVD players and thinking about buying a wide-screen television and sound system.
"It's partially escapism," he said. "There is not really anything anyone can do now, besides make a donation. Now I feel like I want to pull myself in."
The need to find comfort has, of course, powerfully affected what Americans are eating. Fancy restaurateurs may be dusting empty wine glasses right now, but the makers of the fast and the fattening have been nourishing the nation's neuroses at a swift pace. Sales at quick service restaurants like McDonald's and Taco Bell have been higher during the last three weeks, compared with the period a year earlier, according to NPD. Supermarket scanners also recorded an increase in sales of candy, soup, peanut butter, frozen cakes and ice cream in the first week and a half after the attacks, according to ACNielsen. Sales of frozen cakes were declining in early September, but rose nearly 30 percent in the weeks after the attacks.
Leisy Abreu, a 33-year-old office manager from San Francisco, can relate to all of this. After the terrorist attacks, she abandoned her regular diet-conscious lunch in favor of burritos and brownies. At night, instead of a simple sandwich and a cup of coffee, she began making elaborate pasta dinners with friends. Late at night she has been settling into her living room sofa and eating peanut-butter-and-fudge ice cream right out of a pint container while flipping through the Disney Channel or Nick at Nite.
"I just needed to get into the comfort zone," she said. "It was like I wanted to feel like a kid."

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN; 
Green's Latest Commercial Calls for a Closer Look at Ferrer

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
 Mark Green began broadcasting the first negative television commercial of the Democratic runoff election on Monday night, a 30-second spot called "A Closer Look."

PRODUCER -- Trippi, McMahon & Squier

ON THE SCREEN -- The ad opens with slightly grainy footage of Fernando Ferrer, with the words "Take a closer look at Fernando Ferrer" on the screen. The image dissolves into a split screen, with slow-motion footage of Mr. Ferrer talking on the left-hand side of the screen and text, including quotations pulled from newspapers and actual clippings, against a black background on the right hand side. The ad ends with the same shot it opened with, this time with the words, " Can we afford to take a chance?"

THE SCRIPT -- Take a closer look at Fernando Ferrer. The New York Times calls him "borderline irresponsible" and said his economic recovery plan was "vague and confusing." In the face of a deepening recession, The Times reports Ferrer remains "completely committed" to raising taxes on New Yorkers. And at a time when our city is pulling together, Ferrer has been criticized for running a campaign to divide our city. Fernando Ferrer. Borderline irresponsible. Higher taxes. A divided city. Can we afford to take a chance?

ACCURACY -- An editorial in The New York Times said that it was "borderline irresponsible" for Mr. Ferrer to keep calling for an increased parks budget even after the trade center attack. (The same editorial also criticized Mr. Green for supporting Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's attempt to extend his term.) An earlier Times editorial, which ran before the Sept. 25 primary and before Mr. Ferrer released his recovery plan, called his ideas about Lower Manhattan "vague and confusing." Mr. Ferrer supports raising taxes, saying that it would cost the average family four cents a day to pay for afterschool programs. And he has called for reinstating a commuter tax on people who live outside the city but work in it. And former Mayor Edward I. Koch and Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker, both criticized Mr. Ferrer's campaign theme of the "other New York" as divisive before they turned around and endorsed him.

SCORECARD -- For more than a week now Mr. Green has tried to raise doubts about Mr. Ferrer's ability to help rebuild New York's economy and to keep it safe and secure in the aftermath of the World Trade Center disaster. In condensing his arguments and putting them in a commercial, his campaign hopes that the questions it raises about Mr. Ferrer will outweigh the risk of alienating voters who do not like negative ads. MICHAEL COOPER

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: STREET RAGE; 
Pakistani Police Kill 3 Protesters and a 13-Year-Old

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: QUETTA, Pakistan, Oct. 9 

 BODY:
Three anti-American protesters and a 13-year-old boy were shot dead today by Pakistani police officers as demonstrators tried to storm a police station in Kuchlak, a town near the Afghan border. 
 The deaths came on the second day of violent protests against the American-led airstrikes on Afghanistan. A fifth person was killed in a village farther north along the border, and a man was killed and 26 people were injured in Quetta on Monday. 
 Fearing that unrest might spread to major cities, Pakistan's military government increased security in Karachi, the commercial center in the south, and set up bunkers of sandbags and posted soldiers armed with automatic weapons at key points in Islamabad, the capital. 
The longer the air attacks on Afghanistan continue, the greater the danger that protests could threaten the stability of this volatile nation. A public opinion poll released today said that 62 percent of Pakistanis opposed involvement in the war.
This poll contradicted President Pervez Musharraf, who said on Monday that a vast majority of Pakistanis supported a limited role in assisting the United States and its allies.
So far, the violent protests have been restricted to the fundamentalist region along the country's western border with Afghanistan. The ruling Taliban in Afghanistan have strong support in this region, and sympathies have been fanned into angry flames by a vocal minority of hard-line religious leaders.
The main protests have been orchestrated by the Jamiat Ulema Islam, a militant religious political party whose leaders have been placed under house arrest by the government in an attempt to tamp down the passions of their followers.
Roving bands carrying the party's distinctive black and white banner burned buildings and broke shop windows in Quetta on Monday. Some of the group's leaders responded by calling for peaceful demonstrations.
"We condemn the violence," Mullah Kifayat Ullah, a party official, said today.
The rally this afternoon in Quetta drew about 1,000 people and there were no incidents. But a party-organized demonstration in Kuchlak, 15 miles away, turned ugly as a mix of Afghan refugees and students from the party-run religious school marched through the streets chanting pro-Taliban and anti-American slogans. 
Witnesses said demonstrators broke windows at a bank and ransacked a post office. When the police tried to stop the melee at the post office, witnesses and the police said, a portion of the crowd turned on officers and tried to storm the local police station.
"The people had weapons and they tried to take over the police station," Shoaib Suddel, the top police official in the province, said in an interview. "The police had to take action to defend themselves." 
One of the protesters, Muhammed Aman, told The Associated Press that the demonstration was peaceful and the police gunfire was unprovoked. But witnesses confirmed the police account that protesters fired at the police station and at the nearby post office, which was scarred by bullets. 
"People in the crowd had guns and they used them," said Nazir Khan, a laborer who said he had watched the exchange of gunfire with the police from two blocks away.
Three protesters in their 20's were shot and died at the scene. Doctors at the hospital in Quetta, where two of the bodies were taken, said two of the men were shot in the head. 
Hamid Ullah, 13, was shot in the stomach and died shortly after arriving at the Quetta hospital. The boy's weeping mother carried his body out of the hospital for the trip back to Kuchlak. Family friends said Hamid was an only child who had attended the religious school, or madrassah. They said his mother was barred from attending his funeral because women were not allowed inside the school. 
Two photographers taking pictures as the boy's body was carried toward the madrassah were struck by policemen. The photographers, Vincent Laforet of The New York Times and Patrick Aventurier of the Gamma agency, said they were struck with batons and a rifle butt by police officers who tried to take their cameras. Neither was seriously hurt.
Moinuddin Haider, the interior minister, said a fifth person was killed by the police today when protesters tried to attack a police station in Hangu, a small town in northwestern Pakistan. There also were protests in numerous other cities throughout the country, including a peaceful demonstration by 5,000 people in Karachi.
"After the attacks, people's tempers are high, and basically the religious elements and mostly people from the madrassahs have been demonstrating," Mr. Haider said in an interview with CNN. 
There are concerns in some quarters that prolonged attacks on Afghanistan could lead to wider unrest and deepen divisions in Pakistan. 
"If you want to see the future of Pakistan, it is Afghanistan," Abdul Basit, a law professor and defense attorney in Lahore, said in an interview before a court appearance in Quetta. "This country is ripe. There is an army of unemployed with nowhere to go, and religious rhetoric is very appealing.
"President Musharraf's decision to align the country with the United States in the war against Afghanistan will make heroes of the hard-line clerics," Mr. Basit said, and could tip the balance of public opinion in their favor, increasing the political influence of pro-Taliban clerics. 
But Naseer A. Tareen, a businessman in Quetta, said the protests were unlikely to spread beyond the vocal minority.
"The majority of Pakistanis are so docile that they will never come out in the streets," he said. "Public opinion is being hijacked by a minority who want to take us in a direction that we don't want to go."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE REGION; 
5 Ex-Soviet Asian Republics Are Now Courted by the U.S.

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN KINZER 

 BODY:
The five countries that emerged in Central Asia after the collapse of the Soviet Union a decade ago -- Turkmenistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan -- are unknown to most Americans but are now being urgently courted as the United States seeks to destroy terror bases in nearby Afghanistan.
 Until a month ago, even many officials in Washington tried to avoid dealing with these countries, whose complex challenges range from surging Islamic militancy to lucrative drug trafficking. 
 With the exception of the Pentagon, which early on recognized that the Central Asian states might someday prove a valuable security asset, American and many other diplomats viewed them as dangerous places, and best avoided.
Defense Department officials dispatched senior officers to the Central Asian countries soon after they became independent. The focus on military cooperation rather than promotion of democracy proved a success, with none of the five Central Asian leaders -- almost all of them holdovers from the Soviet era -- displaying much interest in Jeffersonian ideals. 
The region's presidents range from the relatively benign autocrat Askar Akayev in Kyrgyzstan to the dictator Saparmurad A. Niyazov in Turkmenistan, center of one of the world's most bizarre personality cults. Mr. Niyazov views himself as a demigod and has ordered that his image adorn every coin and bank note and that it be displayed in every public place.
These leaders are not new types in Central Asia. For centuries the region was the domain of colorful emirs and khans. Some fostered artists and scientists whose extraordinary achievements during the Middle Ages pushed the Islamic world far beyond then-primitive Europe. Others are remembered for developing excruciating forms of torture.
Central Asia remains rich in cultural heritage and natural resources, including huge reservoirs of oil and gas. But it is also dominated by rulers whose ruthlessness in crushing dissent has, according to some specialists, fed the very extremism they seek to suppress.
"If you're too tough on people, something's going to happen," said an Asian diplomat who spent several years as an ambassador in Uzbekistan, where human rights groups say thousands of Muslims, accused of being Islamic insurgents, have been unjustly arrested, tortured and even killed. 
"The instinct out there is to repress," the diplomat said, "which might have worked when the lid was on tight, as it was during the Soviet period. But now some people who feel victimized by repression are turning to Afghanistan for help."
In the last two years religious radicals, evidently with Afghan support, have mounted armed attacks in Uzbekistan and Kyrgyzstan. They have proclaimed their desire to turn those countries into Islamic states modeled after Afghanistan.
In the bazaars of the Fergana Valley, the teeming heart of Central Asia, vendors sell cassettes of sermons in which radical clerics call the faithful to rebel against their leaders and replace them with others who share the Taliban's ideas.
"There's a real nervousness about the rise of Islamic radicalism," said Martha Brill Olcott, a scholar who has written extensively about the region. "It's not a threat in the short term, but in the long term it is. 
"Leaders there want to reduce or eliminate that threat, and they'd welcome American help in doing that. But they don't want to get involved in the American operation in ways that will destabilize their regimes and their countries."
All of the five Central Asian countries were essentially forced into declaring independence as the Soviet Union collapsed, even though they were spectacularly unprepared for the challenges of nationhood.
During the 1990's, leaders of all five nations played the United States and Russia off each other. Now Washington and Moscow, seemingly united in the anti-Taliban cause, are well positioned to join together in seeking Central Asia's help.
Three of the five Central Asian countries share borders with Afghanistan. United States troops have been sent to Uzbekistan partly because it has the only year-round access to the border over a decent road. 
Turkmenistan is less likely to help, because President Niyazov is deeply wary of foreign influence. The third country bordering Afghanistan is the region's wildest and most lawless, Tajikistan.
The Tajikistan-Afghanistan border is long and porous, but impassable for much of the year. Tajikistan is also deeply unstable, racked by civil war and with a government that controls only part of the country. The rest is run by clans and warlords, some of whom support themselves with a thriving drug and weapons trade.
Central Asian warriors spent much of the 19th century defeating Russian and British invasions. After their lands were forcibly incorporated into the Soviet Union, guerrillas fought the Red Army for years before being crushed. To this day, family and clan weigh stronger in many areas than the nation.
That web of loyalties means that populations do not automatically follow their presidents and may oppose the closer ties to America.
American diplomats have been reluctant to deal with the warlords, especially those whose power rests on controlling lucrative heroin-smuggling routes. But many of them fear that a radical Taliban-style government would destroy their standing. 
Thus they could find common cause in Afghanistan, much of which is also under the sway of hereditary chiefs who instinctively support whichever side seems likely to win the next war.
Like their counterparts in other parts of the world, Central Asian leaders wonder about the staying power of the United States. Many believe that the Americans helped create the current situation by effectively abandoning Afghanistan after Afghan rebels financed by Washington succeeded in chasing Soviet troops out in the late 1980's, and by doing much the same to Pakistan, leaving it awash in weapons and militant Islamic guerrillas.
These leaders fear that Washington will turn its attention elsewhere again after achieving or failing to achieve its first set of goals.

HEADLINE: Gasoline Mileage for New Cars Declines Slightly, E.P.A. Reports 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 

 BODY:
Less than 6 percent of the 2002 model cars and trucks arriving in showrooms get better than 30 miles per gallon, and new cars on average get slightly less gasoline mileage than the 2001 models.
 The popularity of gas-guzzling sport utility vehicles and pickups again held down the overall numbers for the 865 cars, trucks and vans listed in the annual fuel economy statistics released today by the Environmental Protection Agency. 
 Just 48 models, led by two hybrid vehicles powered by gasoline and electricity, get 30 m.p.g. or more in combined city and highway driving. More than a third, 330 models, get less than 20 m.p.g.. The majority, 487 models, get 20 to 30 m.p.g.. 
Over all, new passenger vehicles average 21 m.p.g.. Last year's weighted average, based on sales for all new passenger cars and trucks, was 20.4, a 21-year low.
While promoting the need for fuel-efficient vehicles to decrease American dependence on foreign oil, two top officials of the Bush administration were reluctant today to embrace changing government standards to require that vehicles go farther on a gallon of gas. They said safety must be paramount in any such decision.
Average fuel economy for the 491 cars is 23.9 m.p.g., a slight decrease from 24.2 in 2001. That compares with 17.9 for 374 models or variations of sport utility vehicles, vans and pickup trucks, a modest increase from 17.3 in 2001.
The hybrids, the two-seat Honda Insight coupe and five-seat Toyota Prius sedan, topped the list of fuel misers for the third straight year, at 64 and 48 m.p.g., respectively. They are followed by four Volkswagen diesel cars, the Honda Civic HX and the Toyota Echo, all at 37 m.p.g. or better.
By class, the best achievers are compact cars at 25.8 m.p.g., followed by small station wagons and subcompact cars at almost 25, and midsize station wagons at 23.7. Cargo and passenger vans and standard pickup trucks are the fuel spendthrifts at 16 m.p.g..
Among midsize cars, the Mazda 626 and Honda Accord reported the best combined city-highway mileage of 28 m.p.g.. The worst in that category is the Bentley Arnage, at 13. Most cars in the category are in the low to mid-20's.
Three similar minivans from General Motors -- the Chevrolet Ventura, Oldsmobile Silhouette and Pontiac Montana -- again have the best mileage, 22 m.p.g. combined, in the passenger van category. The Kia Sedona has the worst at 17.
King-size sport utility vehicles like the Cadillac Escalade, Ford Expedition and Lincoln Navigator account for 13 of the 35 vehicles on the list with the worst gas mileage, all 14 m.p.g. or less combined.
The luxury sport import Lamborghini L-147 Murcielago is the biggest guzzler, at 10 m.p.g., followed by the Ferrari 360 Modena/Spider, at 12.
The E.P.A. administrator, Christie Whitman, said more efficient vehicles could save owners more than $1,500 a year. An increase of just three miles per gallon industrywide could cut carbon dioxide emissions by 140 million metric tons, the agency said.
But the agency reported last week that the fuel economy of new passenger vehicles was as poor as it has been in the past 20 years because automakers are trading mileage gains for larger, more powerful vehicles.
In August, the House rejected a proposal to make sport utility vehicles attain the same fleet average of 27.5 m.p.g. that the government requires of automobiles.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE REAL ESTATE; 
Plan for Lower Manhattan May Propose Too Much

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The plan announced by the state and the city yesterday to rebuild the equivalent of 12 Empire State Buildings in Lower Manhattan may have a small crack in the foundation: few experts believe there will be enough companies to move into that much office space anytime soon.
 The danger is that the city could be stuck with a lot of empty office towers, as it was in the late 1980's when the real estate boom gave way to a recession. 
 "I don't think there's a need for a lot of new construction downtown or anywhere else," said Barry Gosin, vice chairman of Newmark & Company, a real estate company.
But proponents, like the Real Estate Board of New York and Carl Weisbrod, president of the Alliance for Downtown New York, say the $20 billion incentive plan is a good first step in rebuilding Lower Manhattan, especially coupled with the proposed transportation improvements and benefits for residential tenants displaced by the attack. 
The $20 billion plan is part of the larger $54 billion blueprint for aid in the wake of the World Trade Center attack, presented yesterday by Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. 
Mr. Weisbrod said that there was a need for prime office space downtown that would be available when companies need to expand or move back to New York.
Peter Muoio, a managing director and real estate analyst at Deutsche Bank, said, "If the New York City economy starts growing again, the issue will be a lack of office space."
Many urban planners and some state officials say transportation improvements are far more important to the future of Lower Manhattan than subsidized office buildings will be, since they would make the area accessible. 
Under the plan, the state would establish a Liberty Zone in Lower Manhattan in which companies displaced by the attack could receive an unspecified subsidy per employee, as well as tax breaks and other incentives to remain or return from Midtown and the suburbs. Developers who build office towers would be eligible for tax-exempt financing that could save them millions of dollars.
Although the real estate industry had wanted the subsidies to be granted to all projects, state officials said in interviews that benefits would be discretionary.
But it remains unclear exactly how much office space is needed, given that the economy has slowed considerably, freeing up space when companies reduced staffs, and that displaced companies like Merrill Lynch were able to move employees into vacant space they controlled in Midtown, Jersey City and elsewhere.
In the days after the trade center attack, executives and real estate brokers said that the city should move immediately to build new skyscrapers downtown, or risk the decline of the financial district and the third largest central business district in the country, after Midtown and Chicago. Developers huddled with Deputy Mayor Robert M. Harding and Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission, offering to erect an office tower on a parking lot or development site under their control if only the city would do away with zoning regulations and public reviews.
But the rush for a building bonanza has given way to a more modest reality: many real estate experts say there is a need to build new office space, but more like 2 million square feet, not the 10 million square feet at 1 and 2 World Trade Center, or the 25 million square feet described in the proposal by Governor Pataki and Mayor Giuliani.
At the end of August, there was nearly 30 million square feet of vacant office space in Manhattan, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the large broker. The economic slowdown had prompted many companies to abandon expansion plans, while many technology companies had closed.
Even after some companies moved to Midtown from downtown, there is almost 23 million square feet of vacant space in Manhattan, according to Cushman & Wakefield.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ISOLATED TOWN; 
Faraway Events Hit Home For Town in Eastern Oregon

BYLINE:  By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: PENDLETON, Ore., Oct. 9 

 BODY:
The little airport at the edge of town now is barricaded by a fortress flank of concrete so jarring that everyone calls it the Ugly Wall, and trembles at its sight. The crop-dusters are flying again, seeding next year's alfalfa, but nobody looks at them in the same way. And the walk-in mental health clinic has never known such a clutter of nerves, nightmares and edgy what-ifs.
 Tucked away in a desert draw beneath the tawny expanse of the Columbia Plateau, Pendleton is as close to nowhere as it is far from somewhere. But the war and its jumble of fears about anthrax, retaliatory acts by terrorists and an ever-widening conflict have come home to this town of 17,000, as they have to nearly every acre of American soil. And beneath the brave front of flags and tight-jawed rituals, people are scared by an enemy they cannot see and a conflict that should seem so far away. 
 "I tell people we are so remote we're not on the map, that nobody would ever want to bomb us," said Mike Thompson, a psychiatric counselor at the mental health clinic here. "But people are not sleeping, they have these big fears, and you can see how this thing has had a real ripple effect all the way down to some isolated little farm."
Mostly, there is a sense that life is suspended, waiting for something to nudge it forward. Jobs have been lost, trips canceled, weddings delayed. 
Things had almost returned to normal, and in the straw-colored light of eastern Oregon people slipped back into the routines of small-town autumn, of shooting birds and debating football facts. Then came the Sunday bombings, and the swagger of this big-belt-buckled town was gone once again, replaced by elliptical statements and questions like one on the sign in front of the Peace Lutheran Church: "If God is for us, who can be against us?" The well-known biblical verse took on new meaning this week.
Over the last month, Pendleton has become both more isolated from the outside world, losing two of its five daily commercial flights to the downturn in air travel. But it is also closer. "We hardly even knew where Afghanistan was," said Pat Kennedy, who manages the convention center. "We sure as hell do now."
Now when the air-raid siren, a cultural artifact from the cold war, gets its regular test, the police chief, Gary Ward, trembles. "What crosses my mind when I hear that is: I wish they wouldn't do that anymore," Mr. Ward said.
"It's just going to scare people."
A further scare lies about 30 miles down the road, where an Army chemical weapons depot holds a lethal stew.
Night duty for Tom Hartzell has gone from being on standby for the Fire Department to security patrol, looking for threats at the edge of town.
Mr. Hartzell is a barrel-chested park employee by day who tries to distract himself by imagining all the ways his beloved Washington State Cougars can keep their unbeaten football season intact. Reality keeps intruding, and it has gotten closer since the bombing campaign began.
"What I realize now for the first time is that we can be big and bad and still be got," said Mr. Hartzell, who was working on a stone memorial to firefighters and police officers from Umatilla County, built around a statue of a sheriff who was killed in a long-ago jail break. "It's kind of obvious, but nobody knows how many days they have left in this world." 
A graduate of Pendleton High School, Mike Selves, a civilian employee in the Pentagon, was killed when Flight 77 rammed into the building. 
Time has hopscotched over Pendleton, once a stopping-off point on the Oregon Trail that celebrates its past with one of the nation's biggest rodeos. It is the kind of town that "if somebody waves to you when you drive by and you don't wave back, they think there's something wrong with you," as Mr. Kennedy said.
The town wears its Western heritage in all manner of civic costumes and displays. But it is the very nature of Western stoicism that frustrates people now.
"Some people feel very isolated here, and that's why they've always learned to take care of problems by themselves," Mr. Thompson said. "Now they feel distraught, frustrated because they can't do anything. They feel helpless."
The biggest event of the year, the Pendleton Round-Up, was just getting under way on the morning of the attacks. It continued throughout the week, despite criticism. In the streets at night, people drank hard, and there were more fistfights and arrests than usual, the police said.
At the airport on that first day, there was a bomb scare. A suitcase, having traveled from London to Portland to Pasco, Wash., to Pendleton, was found unattended, with what the police described as "Arabic writing" on the outside. It turned out to be harmless, belonging to an exchange student headed to the Pendleton airport from Azerbaijan who mistakenly got off his flight in Pasco, ahead of his luggage.
Travel may only become gloomier and stranger in coming months, people fear. "Losing two flights a day like we did, that's a real hit," said Mike Hatt, who stood in front of a faded poster of New York's skyline inside his small travel agency in downtown Pendleton. "It makes it real hard to get anywhere from here. And it's a snowball effect. I may not be able to stay in business."
The ripples continue. The tiny airport has a $28 million-a-year impact on Pendleton. Losing 40 percent of its flights, means 500 fewer passengers, mostly business travelers, a month. If the trend holds, Pendleton would fall below the minimum of 10,000 air passengers a year that it needs to be eligible for federal financing. Without that money, which comes to $1 million a year, people wonder how the airport would survive.
"They crash two planes into two buildings in New York, and our world is turned upside down nearly 3,000 miles away," said Larry Dalrymple, the airport manager.
There are no mosques in town. And when asked if there were any practicing Muslims, many people mentioned a coffee-colored man who runs a motel. That man, Manny Patel, was full of good cheer as he explained that he is Indian-born and that he was raised in Wisconsin.
"I don't have any problem here," Mr. Patel explained, when asked if he felt the stares of Pendleton. "But the reason is because I don't go out much. I don't go into town." He plans to stick it out, running the Econo-Lodge off the exit of Interstate 84. He fears for the future.
"I am afraid what has been started will never end," Mr. Patel said.

HEADLINE: House Panel at Odds Over a Trade Bill 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM and JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 

 BODY:
Disregarding the spirit of wartime bipartisanship, the House Ways and Means Committee approved a bill late tonight that would give the Bush administration enhanced authority to negotiate trade agreements.
 The measure was adopted, 26 to 13, on nearly a straight party-line vote. All Republicans on the panel voted for it, and all but two Democrats -- William J. Jefferson of Louisiana and John Tanner of Tennessee -- voted no. 
 The committee's chairman, Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California, called the legislation bipartisan, noting that it contained language on protecting labor rights and the environment that reflected some Democratic priorities. 
But Democratic support -- which is crucial in the closely divided House -- was thin when compared with previous efforts to approve so-called trade promotion authority. That suggests that the Republican leadership would face a fight if it chooses to put the measure to a vote before the full House soon.
Mr. Thomas said the trade authority was an "urgent priority" for the president and "symbolizes our commitment to American business and American workers" that they can compete on the world economic stage. Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, has called the measure essential because it would help the president build a coalition to fight terrorism.
But the top Democrat on the committee, Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, said none of the senior Democrats on the panel and no one in the House Democratic leadership had been consulted on the drafting of the legislation.
"This has nothing to do with the war on terrorism," Mr. Rangel said, or "with providing short-term economic stimulus to the economy."
The bill would allow the administration to negotiate trade accords that Congress could not amend, but only approve or reject. This used to be called "fast track" authority.
Every president since Gerald R. Ford has had the authority. But President Bill Clinton's expired in 1994, and Congress refused to renew it. Without the powers, trade deals are harder to seal because both sides are wary that Congress will tinker with the details on behalf of powerful constituencies.
J. Dennis Hastert, the House speaker, has given no indication that he intends to bring the bill before the full House for a vote soon.
The last time trade authority was seriously debated in the House was in 1997. Republican leaders withdrew the bill on the day the vote was scheduled because nose counts showed it would have been defeated by 20 votes or more.
Neither side expressed confidence today about where the votes would stand this year if the matter came before the full House. The best guess is that no more than a dozen Democrats in the House would vote for it and perhaps a few more Republicans, mainly those with large labor constituencies, would vote against it. Republicans have a nine-seat majority in the House.
Opponents of the measure, mostly Democrats, say that past trade accords have allowed nations that violate international standards for protecting workers and the environment to sell goods to the United States, causing the loss of American jobs.
Mr. Thomas has included language in his bill that obliges the administration to address labor and environmental concerns in the main text of any new trade accord. But many Democrats, union and environmental groups say that language is far too weak.
Even some business leaders say that President Bush will probably need to push the measure strongly if it is to win broad support.
"If the president wants trade authority to build his coalition against terrorism, he will get it," said Thomas Donohue, president the the United States Chamber of Commerce.
Mr. Donohue said he felt that business groups could endorse stronger provisions to protect labor and the environment to recruit more Democrats. Labor leaders, however, said they had mobilized to defeat the bill.
"The proponents have really gone about this in a way designed to maximize the partisan bickering," said Thea Lee, a senior A.F.L.-C.I.O. official. "We don't see much room for compromise."

HEADLINE: Runoff Campaign Turns Confrontational and Strange as Candidates Trade Charges 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER and RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

 BODY:
The Democratic mayoral runoff election grew nastier yesterday on its next-to-last day, with an exchange of attack ads on the airwaves, sharp words between the candidates and even a circuslike confrontation, complete with an acrobat, between supporters of Fernando Ferrer and Mark Green on a Midtown street.
 It began when supporters of Mr. Ferrer, including former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro and Ruth W. Messinger, the former Manhattan borough president, assembled outside Mr. Green's campaign headquarters on Lexington Avenue near Grand Central Terminal for a news conference to denounce a Green campaign ad that calls Mr. Ferrer "borderline irresponsible" and asks, "Can New York afford to take a chance?" 
 But chaos broke out as the news conference ended when young Green campaign aides poured out of the building with a street-theater counteroffensive. To draw attention to Mr. Ferrer's shifting positions on the death penalty and late-term abortions, Mr. Green's supporters chanted "flip-flop! flip-flop!" and gave out flip-flop sandals picturing Mr. Ferrer along with the words "Death Penalty" and "Choice."
An acrobat, wearing a shirt that said "Death Penalty" on one side and "Choice" on the other, then began performing flips in the air.
It was the most visual manifestation of a campaign that has turned increasingly confrontational and strange in its final days. Mr. Green charged yesterday that Mr. Ferrer's plan to decentralize office space in the wake of the World Trade Center attack was motivated by patronage. Mr. Ferrer complained that Mr. Green's attack commercials were ugly and unfair and said that they should embarrass "his supporters, who purport to be liberal and who purport to be interested in unifying the city."
Last night, Mr. Ferrer's campaign answered the Green campaign's commercial with one of its own -- an ad criticizing Mr. Green for running an ad criticizing Mr. Ferrer.
Mr. Ferrer likened the Green commercial to an attack ad used this year in Los Angeles to help derail the surging candidacy of Antonio Villaraigosa, who sought to become the first Hispanic mayor there in more than a century.
In that race, James K. Hahn, who ultimately won, released a commercial late in the campaign that focused on Mr. Villaraigosa's support for clemency for a convicted drug dealer. It ended with the line: "Los Angeles can't trust Antonio Villaraigosa."
Mr. Ferrer said that Mr. Green "seems to be taking a page out of the playbook" of Mr. Hahn.
"I think you would have to ask Mark what his intent was in raising this ugly campaign, raising the fear factor," said Mr. Ferrer, who would be New York's first Hispanic mayor if elected. "I mean that's ugly. That's divisive and for someone who really does portray himself as a great unifier to do that in this moment in the life of this city is so cynical, so awful, so ugly, so divisive, that it just turns my stomach."
Joseph DePlasco, a spokesman for Mr. Green, said in response: "It's ridiculous for the borough president to compare this ad to a race where one candidate attacked another for helping a drug dealer. There's no similarity. This is about a critical election where New Yorkers should be looking to see how each of the candidates have addressed this crisis."
Mr. Green -- who as public advocate issued a report in 1999 that criticized the Police Department for failing to adequately discipline officers accused of misconduct -- was endorsed yesterday by the police union, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.
He told the union's president, Pat Lynch, that as mayor he would negotiate a fair contract for the police. "You can't put a price on heroism, fixing up police precincts, better training for cops at the beginning of their careers, having a more fair and efficient trial process," Mr. Green said.
For more than a week, Mr. Green has painted Mr. Ferrer's plan to rebuild the city in the wake of the World Trade Center attack as insufficient; yesterday he charged that Mr. Ferrer's plan to decentralize offices in the wake of the attack was motivated by patronage.
In a morning interview on WLIB radio, Mr. Green said that Mr. Ferrer had come up with "a patronage response, rather than an economic response to the attack when he suggested that we redistribute economic development funds and he named different locations, for political appeal, throughout the city."
In response to Mr. Green's attacks on Mr. Ferrer's rebuilding plan, Mr. Ferrer made an evening appearance with Donald Trump, who endorsed him and called his rebuilding plan excellent.
Mr. Trump said that he agreed with the idea of spreading office space to the other boroughs. "What he really is doing is diversifying for a short period of time," Mr. Trump said. "Look, nothing can be built there right now. He wants something built so they don't move to New Jersey, they don't move up to other parts of the world. So, what he's done is very smart, it's a very smart plan. It gets something done immediately and then ultimately they are going to move back to downtown Manhattan, we all hope." 
The Green campaign quickly produced old newspaper articles in which Mr. Ferrer had been critical of Mr. Trump. For example, "When Donald Trump says this is the best site in the world, hold onto your wallet," Mr. Ferrer was quoted as saying in an article in The Daily News in 1998.
Mr. Ferrer's campaign recorded a telephone message by the Rev. Al Sharpton, a key supporter who has become a lightning rod in the campaign, in which he complains that the Green campaign is trying to scare voters away from Mr. Ferrer by invoking his name.
And some of Mr. Ferrer's supporters went even further than he did in suggesting that Mr. Green's ad contained a veiled racial or ethnic appeal. Hazel Dukes, the president of the New York chapter of the N.A.A.C.P., said of the ad, "I woke up this morning and thought I was in Mississippi."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: SECURING THE SKIES; 
Senate Stalls On U.S. Role In Screening At Airports

BYLINE:  By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 

 BODY:
After more than a week of meetings, the Senate remained bogged down over the scope and cost of a bill to federalize the jobs of baggage screeners at major airports.
 The Senate began the day by voting 97 to 0 to proceed with the bipartisan bill, but leaders on both sides retreated behind closed doors to continue negotiating the legislation's most contentious measures. 
 The White House, which wants the federal government to hire, train and supervise baggage screeners, without necessarily creating a new federal work force, met with the bill's Republican sponsors today to ask for more flexibility over federalizing employees, Republican aides said. Administration officials also requested details of how the bill's provisions would be put into effect. 
But the administration has sent Congress mixed signals. Just last week, Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta told House Republican leaders that they might have to accept federalization if they wanted to move the legislation.
The bill was written by Senator Ernest F. Hollings, the chairman of the Commerce Committee, and Senator John McCain, the ranking Republican on the panel.
Most Republicans, wary of a major expansion of the federal work force, oppose making as many as 28,000 baggage screeners federal employees. The opposition is more intense in the House than in the Senate, but House leaders lack the votes to push through their version, which calls only for federal supervision.
Still, the question of federalization is just one conflict weighing down the bill.
Democrats are pushing to attach a measure by Senator Jean Carnahan, Democrat of Missouri, to provide extended unemployment benefits to laid-off airline workers and to help those who cannot afford health insurance. Angry that airlines received a $15 billion bailout while airline workers received nothing, Democrats are demanding action on the measure.
Trying to forge a compromise, Democrats suggested a possible alternative, a scaled-back version of the proposal that would reduce the size of the worker aid package to $1.9 billion from $3.1 billion. But Republicans said they wanted to keep the measure severed from the aviation security bill altogether, preferring a separate vote on the legislation.
The two sides were also at odds over a Democratic measure to steer $3.2 billion to Amtrak for upgrades and security. But one Senate Democratic aide said Democrats would be willing to compromise by possibly accepting $1 billion.
Also at issue was whether the Department of Justice or the Department of Transportation should oversee aviation security, and how much to charge passengers for aviation security, a cost per ticket that could be $2.50 to $3.
"It will only be the responsible approach to pay for this in the long term rather than rely on temporary measures we have now," said Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, a Texas Republican who is a sponsor of the bill.

HEADLINE: Worried Carmakers Appeal to Patriotism and Pocketbooks 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
AS the 2002 model year begins, the timing could hardly be more challenging for automobile manufacturers. Thanks to slow summer sales, an even slower economy and post-Sept. 11 jitters, dealer lots are jammed with last year's cars. While such circumstances usually cry out for aggressive marketing, advertisers are wary of offending the public with pitches that might appear insensitive during a time of mourning and reflection. 
 How does an automaker move cars off the lot in such an atmosphere? For some, the answer is to change nothing and hope for the best. For others, the solution is to mix financial incentives with a healthy dose of patriotism. That is what America's big three carmakers are doing, in addition to continuing all the regular new-model advertising they had planned before Sept. 11. 
 Ford, for example, pulled back its advertising after the terrorist attacks, said Paige Johnson, the company's global marketing communications manager. But after President Bush exhorted Americans to return to "business as usual," Ford and General Motors began special campaigns, offering zero percent financing through the end of this month on many of their 2001 and 2002 vehicles. 
Ford's new ads, called "Ford Drives America," speak euphemistically about "challenging times" and that "we at Ford want to do our part to help move America forward." G.M.'s campaign, "Keep America Rolling," however, explicitly refers to Sept. 11, calling it the day "the world as we knew it came to a halt."
"We think it's important to keep workers working, and for the economy to keep rolling along," the ad says. "In this time of terrible adversity, let's stand together."
"This is what we call a 'call to action' ad," said Margaret G. Holmes, the director of regional marketing and communications for G.M. The company did not stop its advertising after Sept. 11, although few ads, if any, actually ran on television during the days after the terrorist attacks, when most network and many cable outlets stopped running commercials altogether. Instead, Ms. Holmes said, the company moved its retail advertising to newspapers and local television.
The Chrysler Group of DaimlerChrysler, like Ford, suspended ads for a few days. Like Ford and G.M., it is now offering interest-free financing, said James Kenyon, a company spokesman. But its new ads do not specifically mention the terrorist attacks. Chrysler, he said, also made significant changes only in Spanish-language print ads for the new Jeep Liberty, to run in magazines like People en Espanol. These ads featured a backdrop of the New York City skyline that was changed hastily to an image of the Statue of Liberty.
Nissan and BMW also reviewed their ads.
BMW pulled a commercial showing the company's Z3 sports car. The ad, which had been running before Sept. 11, featured "very spirited driving," as well as a number of quick shots of "all the wonderful things you can do in a car," said Jim McDowell, the vice president of marketing at BMW of North America. It ended with the wry tag line "God Bless America," which company officials thought was inappropriate after the attacks. 
BMW also pulled an ad for its 3-Series that featured the statement "life is short," Mr. McDowell said. (Some publishers, however, were unable to pull it, so the ad may still be in some magazines.) Images of the twin towers were also removed from the photo archives that are used for company ads.
Nissan removed a few commercials for Maxima, the company's midsize sedan, said Dierdre Dickerson, a spokeswoman for Nissan North America. The ads did not contain any images of New York or its skyline, but they featured the car traveling at very high speeds. "We believe that people now are hypersensitive to anything that they might think is dangerous," she said.
Otherwise, it is business as usual for Nissan. Now that broadcast and print ad schedules overall are back to normal, Ms. Dickerson said, so is Nissan's ad schedule, without any changes.
That is also the case at Honda. The company has not changed its ads, and was proceeding normally with its promotions, according to Art Garner, a spokesman for American Honda Motor Company. Honda's most important model introduction -- a 2002 version of its CR-V, a small sport utility vehicle -- was always scheduled for mid-November, Mr. Garner said. 
Toyota had already begun the much ballyhooed introduction of its newly redesigned Camry when the terrorists struck. The $160 million campaign is said to be Toyota's biggest effort since the company first started selling cars in the United States more than 40 years ago. And despite Sept. 11, "we haven't changed anything in the campaign for the Camry," said Ming-Jou Chen, a spokeswoman for Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. 
Nor has the advertising changed for Toyota's other products, Ms. Chen added. As of early this month, there were zero percent financing offers for some models, including Corolla, Tundra and 4Runner, but these were not in response to the terrorist attacks, she said.
SO far, it is hard to tell whether the advertising is working. Car sales have rebounded since Sept. 11, but the levels are nowhere near what they were a year ago. The zero percent finance promotions seem to be yielding greater showroom traffic and sales, said Ms. Holmes of G.M., though the uniqueness of current circumstances makes it "hard" to be sure. 
Although more sales may be a good thing, in the short term the financial incentives may not help the industry in the future. The zero percent interest incentives may haunt them, according to Jim Hall, the vice president of AutoPacific, an automotive industry consulting firm in Southfield, Mich., and Tustin, Calif.
"People may begin to expect low-cost financing at all times," Mr. Hall said. "It's like the rebates that started during the 1973-74 fuel crisis that never went away."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Mixed Signals As Motorola's Loss Meets Expectations

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Investors nervously awaiting earnings data reflecting the business impact of the Sept. 11 attacks received mixed signals late yesterday from Motorola, the first large technology company to report earnings for the quarter that ended on Sept. 30.
 Motorola lost $1.4 billion, or 64 cents a share. But after excluding special charges for items like bad debts and previously reported measures to trim costs, the company said the loss was just $144 million, or 7 cents a share. The latter figure matched Wall Street's expectations as tracked by Thomson Financial/First Call. 
 Motorola said that revenue for the quarter was $7.41 billion, about $100 million less than the company had projected just a week before the attacks. Some analysts had expected better while others had feared a steeper drop. The figure reflected a decline of 22 percent from the quarter a year ago, when the company reported net profit of $531 million, or 23 cents a share.
Motorola said that its cellular phone business returned to profitability after two quarters of losses and that orders for its troubled semiconductor unit had exceeded sales for the first time since the third quarter of last year. But the cable modem and broadband equipment operations and network systems had a rougher quarter than some had expected.
"Motorola is an especially challenged company in a challenging environment," said Brian Modoff, an analyst at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown in San Francisco who is expected to be among many seeking clarification of the figures in a Motorola conference call this morning.
Christopher B. Galvin, Motorola's embattled chairman and chief executive, said the Sept. 11 attacks had made forecasting the timing of an economic upturn more difficult. But Mr. Galvin was not ready to abandon Motorola's previous projections that a recovery will begin in the first half of next year. He said in a statement that any negative effect from the unpredictability associated with fighting terrorism might be offset by positive factors like tax relief, interest rate reductions and increased government spending.
Motorola, which is based in Schaumburg, Ill., made its announcement after the close of trading on Wall Street. The company had been the fifth most active Big Board stock and lost 67 cents to close at $16.72. In after hours trading, the stock fell a further 36 cents a share.
Analysts had been split on the importance of Motorola's earnings. Although the company is the first major technology giant to report, it is no longer the industry leader in either cellular communications or semiconductors, its two main businesses.
Jeffrey D. Saut, senior vice president for investment strategy at Raymond James & Associates, a brokerage firm based in St. Petersburg, Fla., said that investors should not read too much into the earnings of any major technology company over the next few weeks. Most technology companies derive a large part of the quarter's business from sales in the last half of September, a period when many businesses slowed to a crawl this year, he said.
But others said that Motorola's report was an especially revealing indicator because on Sept. 6, just five days before the attacks, the company had advised Wall Street to reduce its expectations. As a result, the actual results seemed to provide strong evidence that business did not plunge sharply after the attacks.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Supreme Court Rejects Latest Microsoft Appeal
The Supreme Court rejected a request by Microsoft to consider throwing out the government's antitrust lawsuit because of misconduct by the federal trial judge, Thomas Penfield Jackson.
 The decision clears the way for another judge to consider the most appropriate penalty for Microsoft's antitrust violations. That judge has ordered lawyers from the company, the federal government and the states to engage in settlement talks, but the nearly two weeks of talks have so far been fruitless, several participants said. Shares of Microsoft fell $3.48, to $54.56. Page C2. 

Airlines Demonstrate Lobbying Skill
The speed with which Congress agreed to $15 billion in aid and loan guarantees for the airline industry is not just a testament to the importance of air travel to the nation's economy. It is also an example of the power of the airline lobby, and the skill with which it marshaled its considerable resources. A1.

Shipping Industry Slump Deepens
The container shipping industry is in a deepening slump, a result of the sagging global economy, the Sept. 11 attacks and the war on terrorism. World Business, Section W.

Social Networks Survive Attacks
In the wake of the terrorist attacks, left behind at firms like Cantor Fitzgerald are networks of survivors, loose-knit clans of wives, partners and children woven together by the office friendships of people now dead. D1.

Small Law Practices Hurt the Most
There are 14,000 lawyers in Lower Manhattan, and most have been affected by the World Trade Center's collapse. D1.

Ruling Issued in Credit Card Case
Visa and MasterCard must end their practice of barring member banks from distributing rivals' credit cards, a federal judge ruled in a decision that will most likely benefit American Express and Morgan Stanley. C17.

Judge Decides in Part for El Paso
A federal administrative law judge recommended that the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission throw out a complaint contending that the El Paso Corporation manipulated natural gas prices higher in California. But the judge also said that El Paso skewed the bidding for capacity on its natural gas pipeline to help its subsidiary win the auction. C4.

She Was Shaped by Family Debates
Anne M. Mulcahy, chief executive of Xerox, said she grew up in a home that did not differentiate between being a man or a woman. Each night at dinner, she and her four brothers, mother and father would discuss politics, religion, "anything that was contentious," she said. "I learned that you can disagree, even fight, without confusing theoretical arguments with personal attacks." The Boss. C6.

Digital Music Rights Licensed
The major record companies said that they had licensed digital distribution rights from the nation's songwriters and music publishers in a deal that paves the way for the introduction of new Internet music services. C2.

A.I.G. Chief Sees Rates Leaping
Maurice R. Greenberg, the chief executive of the American International Group, said that prices for some kinds of commercial insurance were doubling, up from expected increases of 20 percent to 60 percent. C4.

Loss at Motorola Meets Forecasts
Motorola, the first large technology company to report earnings for the quarter ended Sept. 30, posted a loss that matched estimates. C3.

F.A.A. Issues Carry-On Guidelines
The Federal Aviation Administration this week issued guidelines on what may be carried on board an airplane. Fliers may now bring on board one carry-on bag and one "personal bag," defined as "a purse, a laptop, a briefcase." Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. C8.
