HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: AN OVERVIEW: OCT. 9, 2001; 
A Riskier Phase, a Widening Focus and Stress and Strain All Around

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
On the third day of American airstrikes against Afghanistan, the Pentagon already had its eye on the next phase of the operation, and it seemed likely to be riskier than anything carried out thus far.
 Indeed, the hazards until now have been minimal for American forces, who were described by officials in Washington as having essentially taken control of the Afghan skies while knocking out some of the larger and more sophisticated training camps of Al Qaeda, Osama bin Laden's terrorist network. One camp near Jalalabad, in eastern Afghanistan, was said by intelligence officials to have been a site for testing chemical and biological weapons. 

THE NEXT STEPS -- The sense from the Pentagon was that United States bombers and fighter planes were running out of significant military targets. If so, that cleared the way for the next stage, which officials said would involve helicopter gunships flying low to find and attack forces allied with Al Qaeda. Those helicopters come equipped with various defensive measures. Inevitably, though, they run a much greater risk of ground fire than the high-altitude bombers have faced.
When would the new phase begin? Officials were not saying. From their remarks, however, it seemed that an invasion by American ground troops was not in the planning, for now anyway.

BEYOND AFGHANISTAN -- It did appear that Washington had more than Afghanistan's Taliban government in its sights. Southeast Asia could be next. Officials said that terrorists with links to Al Qaeda, based in the Philippines, Indonesia and Malaysia, were among the likely targets of future American actions, both overt and covert. On that score, too, no timetable was offered. But the officials repeated that the worldwide campaign against terrorism could go on for years.
Although officials pronounced themselves pleased with the progress of the military campaign, strains in the American-led coalition were evident. Tensions ran especially high in Pakistan, where President Pervez Musharraf tried to keep pro-Taliban protests from spinning out of control. Pakistani policemen killed at least five people, including a 13-year-old boy, during anti-American protests in Kuchlak, a town near the Afghan border. Also, Pakistani troops fought a gun battle with Taliban soldiers who had crossed into Pakistan, apparently to hide from the American bombing. Both episodes underlined the problems facing General Musharraf, who has been an unenthusiastic ally of the United States in the anti-Taliban campaign and who must worry about growing instability in his country of 140 million people.

IN CONGRESS -- Strains were also apparent in Washington, where leading members of Congress from both parties chafed at President Bush's order limiting classified military and intelligence information to eight senior lawmakers. Mr. Bush grew angry after some sensitive material from congressional briefings made their way into news media reports. "When we have troops at risk" that is unacceptable, the president said. Lawmakers did not disagree on the need for everyone to be more careful. But they must have access to restricted information, they insisted, if they are to do their jobs right.

NEW YORK -- One other place with stress was New York City, the chief victim of the Sept. 11 attacks. The city's finances had been hit so hard and so fast that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced a hiring freeze and a cut of $1 billion in planned municipal spending.
Beyond that, Mr. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki asked the federal government for $54 billion in incentives, tax breaks and subsidies to rebuild the battered local economy, redevelop lower Manhattan and help devastated businesses get back on their feet.
It was a highly ambitious proposal, and some officials acknowledged that parts of it amounted to a wish list. New York, they knew, is still not universally loved in Washington. But they argued that the city in effect took the terrorist hit for America, and that reviving the country's financial capital was in everyone's interest.
 CLYDE HABERMAN

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: GLOBAL LINKS; 
OTHER FRONTS SEEN

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 

 BODY:
Terrorists tied to Osama bin Laden's network and based in the Philippines, Indonesia and Malaysia are among the likely targets of future covert and overt American actions, United States officials said today.
 The officials gave no timetable; they said the campaign against the groups linked to Mr. bin Laden and his group, Al Qaeda, is global and may last for years. But they said that the East Asian groups have expanded their operations in recent years, exchanging money, personnel, materiel and experience with the bin Laden organization and its allies, and that they pose a clear and present danger to American institutions overseas. 
 "There has been a concerted effort by bin Laden and his people to expand their activities in East Asia, not only in the Philippines but in Malaysia and Indonesia," a United States official said. "The Philippines have become a major operational hub, and it's a serious concern. People linked to bin Laden are not only in Manila but elsewhere in the Philippines." 
The groups have thrived in the political and economic instability in the Philippines, a predominantly Roman Catholic country, and in Indonesia, which is predominantly Muslim; street protests against the airstrikes on Afghanistan took place today outside the American embassies in both countries. In recent years, the fundamentalist groups have gained adherents in the name of a holy war against American institutions and influence, officials said. 
The United States ambassador to the United Nations, John D. Negroponte, told the Security Council on Monday that the United States, acting in self-defense after the Sept. 11 attacks, may take "further actions with respect to other organizations and other states." 
Mr. Negroponte, an American ambassador to the Philippines in the 1990's, cited no groups or states by name. But administration officials have said repeatedly that Mr. Bin Laden has adherents and allies all over the world, and that the war against them will range far beyond Afghanistan. East Asia, and particularly the Philippines, officials said, is an area where terrorists who have struck the United States before are known to have planned their attacks. 
Militant Islamic groups in East Asia -- chief among them, the Abu Sayyaf group, based in the Philippines -- are high on the list of American counter-terrorism targets to come, officials said today.
Hundreds of Abu Sayyaf fighters are battling the Philippine army on Basilan, an island in the south. The group has taken two American hostages: Martin and Gracia Burnham, missionaries from Wichita, Kan.
The Burnhams were celebrating their 18th wedding anniversary in May, when they and a third American, Guillermo Sobero of Corona, Calif., were kidnapped from a resort on Palawan, a large western island of the Philippine archipelago. Mr. Sobero may be dead, officials said.
The Abu Sayyaf group, which is on the official United States list of terrorist organizations, has obtained millions of dollars in ransom from kidnapping tourists, missionaries and resort workers. Libyan representatives played a role in the release of some hostages for ransom, State Department officials said.
The group has used ransom money to buy weapons and speedboats, to pay recruits and to bribe Philippine soldiers, American officials suspect.
Members of Abu Sayyaf, which says it is fighting for a separate Islamic nation, have links to the bin Laden organization, officials said. 
The leader of the group is known as Abdujarak Abubakar Janjalani. He is a Filipino Muslim who has said he fought alongside the Afghan rebels battling the Soviet invaders of Afghanistan during the 1980's.
Al Qaeda's connections in the Philippines include Islamic schools and charities through which millions of dollars have flowed to support the group and its allies across South and East Asia, officials said. 
They include the International Islamic Relief Organization office and Al Makdum university in Zamboanga, a city on the island of Mindanao, just north of Basilan island. Mr. bin Laden's brother-in-law, Mohammed Jalal Khalifa, was an administrator at both institutions. Neither is operating any longer, and Mr. Khalifa was arrested by the Saudi government after the Sept. 11 attacks.
Also since the attacks, Philippine intelligence officers have arrested two suspected Abu Sayyaf commanders and several men they described as foreigners carrying bombs. Malaysia has charged the son of a leading opposition politician with plotting to overthrow the government. Indonesia has imprisoned two Malaysians in connection with a series of bombings.
In Indonesia, armed Islamic fundamentalist groups have received money, men and arms from the bin Laden group and its allies, officials said. One group, Laskar Jihad, they said, has been reinforced by Taliban guerrillas. Another, the Islamic Defenders Front, is threatening violence against American officials and organizations.
Some members of Al Qaeda have transited through the international airport at Kuala Lumpur in Malaysia, officials said. One of the Sept. 11 hijackers, Khalid Al-Midhar, was videotaped at a terrorist meeting in Kuala Lumpur in January 2000. 
President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo of the Philippines said recently that "traces of relationship" exist between the Abu Sayyaf guerrillas and the Sept. 11 attack plotters. She has offered the United States airspace and the use of two large former United States military installations, the Clark Air Base, and the Subic Bay naval base, for transit and staging operations. 
The offer was secured in a meeting at Subic Bay two weeks ago between Adm. Thomas Fargo, commander of the Pacific Fleet, and Rolio Golez, the Philippine national security adviser, both 1970 graduates of the United States Naval Academy.
President Bush is scheduled to discuss the counter-terrorism campaign with the presidents of the Philippines and Indonesia and the prime minister of Malaysia in Shanghai on Oct. 19 at the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting.
Terrorists aiming to attack the United States have been based in the Philippines for years. 
Ramzi Yousef, a convicted ringleader in the 1993 World Trade Center bombing, plotted in Manila to blow up 11 jumbo jets headed for the United States. He was arrested in Pakistan at a rooming house financed by Mr. bin Laden. His roommate in Manila, Abdul Hakim Murad, had a commercial pilot license and plotted to crash a jet into the Central Intelligence Agency headquarters in Virginia. 
And Mohammed Saddiq Odeh, convicted in the 1998 bombing of the United States Embassy in Nairobi, was a student in the Philippines when he first came to the bin Laden organization.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 12, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Wednesday about the possibility of action by the United States against terrorist groups in the Philippines and Indonesia misidentified the leader of Abu Sayyaf, an organization tied to Osama bin Laden that operates from the Philippines. The leader was believed to be Khaddafi Janjalani. (Abdujarak Abubakar Janjalani was his brother, who founded and headed the group but was reportedly killed in a firefight in the Philippines in 1998.)

HEADLINE: Bird's-Eye Views, Made to Order 

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
AMONG the indelible images from the terrorist attacks last month were commercial satellite photographs showing smoke and dust of volcanic proportions stretching for miles from the ruins of the World Trade Center. 
 But satellites were capable of taking far more detailed photographs, with features as small as a burning vehicle or a pile of rubble that might keep rescue crews from passing. No wonder phone calls from disaster-recovery teams and emergency services started pouring into Space Imaging, the owner of the Ikonos satellite, which provides the sharpest available images. 
 By the next morning, when Ikonos was in position to take new pictures of the trade center and the Pentagon from 400 miles above, Space Imaging had taken the unusual step of making images of the disaster sites available free on its Web site, and some competitors had done likewise. "We had so many emergency groups calling that we decided to just put it out there so they could use it as quickly as possible," said John Copple, chief executive at Space Imaging, based in the Denver suburb of Thornton, Colo. 
As it turned out, officials planning the logistics of the disaster response were just a sliver of the audience. By the end of the week, more than 70,000 visits a day were being logged at Space Imaging's Web site (www.spaceimaging.com), according to Jupiter Media Metrix, which tracks the popularity of Internet sites. 
For many of the visitors, it was probably the first glimpse of the abilities of a fledgling industry with diverse clients and missions. Now that the focus has shifted to the fighting and the flight of refugees in Afghanistan, the satellites' view of the combat zone is in demand from both military clients and news organizations. 
Commercial satellite photography began gaining momentum in 1994, when the federal government started allowing companies to make and sell images precise enough to show features just a few feet in diameter on the ground. People in the industry say that its worldwide revenues range from a few hundred million dollars to as much as $2 billion -- depending partly on how much consulting, data analysis and other related work is included in the estimate -- but that none of the satellite owners are profitable yet. Nearly all the work is done by small, privately held companies that do not report revenue. 
With such photography now used to help fishing fleets find tuna, power companies plan the routes of gas lines, mining companies search for minerals and farmers manage crops, the benefits of the change in federal policy seem obvious in retrospect. But it came only after a long and contentious debate in Washington in which the Defense Department and many in Congress were leery of making such detailed images easily available to potential enemies. 
Those in favor of commercialization argued that foreign companies would be offering such products whether American companies were allowed to compete or not. They contended that opening up the commercial photography sector would help preserve production and engineering expertise when military spending was declining. 
Finally, in a point still debated, proponents argued that commercial photography would contribute to world peace by making everything from natural disasters to the effects of local wars visible to all.
The industry's biggest customer is the United States government, which uses the commercial companies' services for activities like map-making, monitoring beach erosion or air pollution and reporting on crops. The biggest government demand comes from the military and intelligence agencies, which rely heavily on the industry to supplement data from satellites owned by the United States and other governments. 
The commercial satellites cannot gather data as precise as what the newest government satellites glean about the dimensions, position and physical nature of objects in a photograph. The government does not provide details about its satellites' abilities, but military officials offered this comparison: while commercial satellites can distinguish between different crops planted in adjacent fields, the latest military satellites can recognize different varieties of the same crop. 
Under ideal conditions, government satellites can even identify objects as small as four or five inches in diameter. That compares with the sharpest Ikonos images, provided to customers at a resolution of one meter (39 inches) -- meaning an object one meter square can be made out. But even though the capacities of government satellites are greater, they are spread thin. 
The Pentagon's frequent use of commercial satellites arises from both economy and efficiency. Extraordinary resolution is not always needed, and "it costs much less to process the commercial images," said William E. Burrows, author of the new book "By Any Means Necessary: America's Secret Air War in the Cold War" (Farrar Straus & Giroux). 
Moreover, commercial satellites are often in orbits that make them the quickest source for an important image. "Defense satellites are optimized for coverage of high-risk areas, but they don't always cover every region where problems come up," said Gilbert D. Rye, president and chief executive of the Orbital Imaging Corporation, another satellite photography company. 
Commercial companies sometimes pick up what they call "pretty picture" orders, like a photo of a client's ranch or last year's graduation ceremony at the United States Air Force Academy, where cadets arranged themselves to spell AFA 2000 as Ikonos passed overhead. But with a minimum charge for new orders running close to $1,800 a photo, with a 60-day wait, no one is basing a business on such demand. 
The bulk of the business requires careful melding of the photographic image with other data, starting with the satellite's exact location at the instant a picture is taken. In addition to images showing where masses of phytoplankton can be found, for example, Orbital Imaging sells a software package that allows clients to calculate the plankton's movements based on weather and ocean conditions. Tuna fishermen know that fish are likely to be near the plankton, and getting to the fish faster can add as much as $1 million a year to a boat's revenue. 
Many companies offer not just visible-light photographs but also images relying on radar or parts of the electromagnetic spectrum invisible to the human eye, like infrared light. Radar can pass through foliage and clouds and be used for tasks like measuring the thickness of ice or the height of waves. Infrared images are ideal for spotting deposits of copper or iron and monitoring air pollution. 
Mr. Copple, chief executive of Space Imaging, said that its focus was increasingly on selling an analysis based on the images. "We might sell a report based on comparing two images rather than the images themselves in some cases," he said. 
Analysts say the industry might best be viewed as a specialized segment of aerial photography, pioneered by balloonists in the 19th century. Such photography took a leap forward when the invention of airplanes gave practitioners more control of their working conditions. It took the arrival of the space age, though, to open the door to images covering continental swaths of territory or areas where governments were likely to shoot down any foreign aircraft.
Photography taken from aircraft is still more precise than anything offered by the satellite companies. But the airplane-based services lack the global reach of the satellite operators, who can photograph almost any location on the globe every day and pass almost directly over most sites every third or fourth day. In addition, commercial satellite photography is digital, which allows for rapid delivery of the results and relatively easy integration with many other data sources. Most aircraft still rely on film. 
Until the 1980's, space was almost entirely off limits to commercial enterprises outside the telecommunications industry. That grip began to loosen in 1982, when a European consortium led by France's national space agency created Spot Image to sell photos for commercial use that were detailed enough to show objects as small as 36 feet in diameter. Russia, Israel, India and Canada have since entered the market. 
The domestic commercial companies operate under a number of security restrictions. Like any other business, they are forbidden from dealing with customers in countries like North Korea and Cuba. Wholesale customers, the kind that want to buy what John Pike, director of Global Security.org, a research group based in Alexandria, Va., called a "militarily significant" number of images over time, require a separate license. 
And the companies' operating licenses allow the government to put any area off limits in the interests of national security. That policy has not been invoked, Mr. Pike said, because no new customers could obtain images from the companies quickly enough to compromise the military operations in Central Asia.
"If you ordered an image of Afghanistan from Space Imaging today, it would cost a minimum of $6,000 and you couldn't get it before Thanksgiving," because the government and other customers would have priority, Mr. Pike said. "It would take 10 days just to get an archival image."
For all the industry's rapid development, though, it is not an easy business. Satellites from several companies have been destroyed in launching attempts over the last two years or failed once they were in orbit. In addition, the satellites that are in orbit are not generating the anticipated profits. The government's Landsat satellites, whose images are sold at the cost of production, grab a lot of the business in markets like vegetation analysis where many customers are content with less precise but more economical data. Similarly, many users of map data are content to work with old paper maps rather than pay for satellite images. 
"The sensitivity to price has surprised the companies," said Christopher Roberts, chief executive of PixSell, a consulting company that specializes in analyzing satellite and aerial images. "The industry is desperately searching for a killer application."
The industry's visibility in the last month, however, may help stimulate business as potential customers realize what the satellites can do. "Sept. 11 may speed up the demand for mapping," Mr. Copple said. "Mapping underlies everything."

G7) Chart: "Covering the Earth"For satellite imaging companies, quality and flexibility are vital in serving clients with varied needs. With its Ikonos satellite, Space Imaging can produce images of any area of the Earth every three days at top-grade resolution, and daily at lower resolutions. IMAGING AREAThe satellite can rotate up to 51 degrees to direct its camera at a target. It can make its highest-resolution photos -- showing details one meter square -- of any location in a 435-mile-wide swath below it. Images with a resolution of one and a half meters can be made of sites in an area 900 miles across, and with two-meter resolution at greater distances. On an orbit taking it over central Washington and Oregon, the satellite could produce top-quality photos of any place from Portland to Boise. COMING INTO RANGEAs the Earth rotates beneath the Ikonos satellite's north-south orbit, every point on the planet eventually comes into view. The orbit is at a slight angle to the Equator so that Ikonos consistently appears over a point on the daylight side around 10:30 a.m., when skies are most likely to be clear and shadows minimal. The Ikonos satellite, launched two years ago, makes 14 orbits a day and is expected to have a life span of five to seven years. SECTION: Section G; Column 1; Circuits; Pg. 3

HEADLINE: ONLINE DIARY 

BYLINE:  By Pamela LiCalzi O'Connell; E-mail: online@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Ooh, Circa '94
 Are America Online's promotional CD-ROM's -- those shrink-wrapped discs that regularly appear in your mailbox -- junk mail or pop-culture artifacts? 
 To John Lieberman and Jim McKenna, technology professionals from San Francisco, those seemingly ubiquitous CD's, which cannot be used for any other computer-related purpose, are "needless pollution." Through their Web site, at www
.nomoreaolcds.com, the two have embarked on an online mission to amass one million of the discs and deliver them to AOL's headquarters in Dulles, Va.
Since August, Mr. McKenna said, he has received more than 2,600 discs as a result of his effort. An affiliate site is gathering discs in Britain, and other sites are being readied in Australia, France and Germany. 
A spokesman for AOL, Nicholas Graham, emphasized that the company has an internal recycling policy, adding, "We think the number of people who are pleased to get the discs far outweighs those who are not pleased." 
In fact, there is a growing segment of the population that can't wait for the next AOL CD to pour out of cereal boxes: collectors. AOL has distributed more than 1,000 versions of the discs, and there are people who want to collect all of the many permutations. Some versions with distinctive artwork have sold on eBay for more than $100 each.
Lydia Cline, an architect in Overland Park, Kan., has collected more than 500 AOL CD versions. Far from detritus, AOL's discs "are destined to be among the antiques of the digital age," she said. "Ten years from now everyone who has tossed them out might wish they had saved a few." 
Mr. McKenna found that some people could not resist turning their discs into art objects. "Many people are submitting CD's with statements or poems on them," he said. "A good number of them are not fit to print. My favorite haiku read: 'Mailbox is full of surprises, Square round thing arrived, Yet another 1,000 free hours.' "

Dark Prophecies
At the Foresight Exchange
(ideosphere.com), a virtual stock market where you can bet with play money on events from the political to the trivial, the odds have shifted in a sobering direction since last month's terrorist attacks. For example, one of the most active issues in the week after the attacks was the betting on whether a nuclear weapon will be used somewhere in the world by 2010. The chances, according to the site's 4,000 players, are better than 50 percent.
The site, which is not for profit, began seven years ago on the basis of an idea floated by Robin Hanson (hanson.gmu.edu
/ideafutures.html), now an assistant professor of economics at George Mason University. He argued that citizens should have the opportunity to bet in policy markets in such a way that their views would help shape the priorities of politicians and researchers.
Players at the Foresight Exchange test their prognostication abilities by making "claims" about future events. Shares in those claims are then bought and sold, driving their value -- the probability that they will occur, according to market consensus -- higher or lower. While not all predictions involve earth-shattering concerns (Will the Clinton marriage last through 2003? More than 80 percent say yes), most deal with serious topics. 
A claim by one player, Randall Burns, that a major act of war or terrorism would occur on American soil by 2010 was recently judged to have come true, and trading was halted. Ken Kittlitz, who manages the site, said that claim had typically traded above 50 percent, its perceived probability, before Sept. 11. 
Recently there has been active trading in Mr. Burns's next prediction, that another terrorist attack in the United States will claim more than 200 lives before 2010. That claim is trading at more than 70 percent.

Binding Memories
While mainstream publishers prepare quick books on the events of Sept. 11, the online world is busy cataloging its own reaction, some of which has already made it into printed form. 
Blue Ear (blueear.com), one of the more literate discussion forums on the Web, has produced a work with help from New York University's journalism department titled "09/11 8:48 AM: Documenting America's Greatest Tragedy." It is a form of oral history consisting mostly of accounts posted online by survivors, witnesses and what Blue Ear's editor in chief, Ethan Casey, called "helpless onlookers." 
The book is available as an e-book for $6 and as a print-on-demand paperback for $14.99 from Booksurge.com. Profits are being donated to Red Cross relief efforts related to the attacks.
On the graphic arts front, more than 200 artists worldwide are contributing online works to Project091101.com, created in reaction to the events for a combination CD and book. Joost Korngold (www
.renascent.nl), a new-media artist in the Netherlands, said that a publisher was still being sought and that a charity would be designated to receive the proceeds. Unlike the contributors to Blue Ear's project, the artists will remain anonymous. "This was a touchy point," Mr. Korngold said. "Some artists were questioning the purity of this project as a means for getting their work published. Therefore we have decided no name- or logo-dropping. Only art."

Filling a Rice Bowl
In August I wrote of the demise of The Hunger Site (thehungersite.com), one of the first and most popular sites to let Web users donate to charity by looking at online ads. The concept was simple: If you clicked on a banner ad, a cup of rice was donated to international food programs. 
The site has returned under new management: Tim Kunin and Greg Hesterberg, the owners of EcologyFund.com, which operates in a similar way to buy and protect wilderness lands. They have also acquired and revived The Breast Cancer Site (www
.thebreastcancersite.com), which finances mammograms, and they plan soon to revive The Rainforest Site, which conserves rain-forest acreage.
At its peak, more than 220,000 people visited The Hunger Site daily. Mr. Hesterberg said that traffic now approached half that level. "We're hoping that everyone that dropped us from their bookmarks will come back," he said.

SECTION: Section F; Column 1; House & Home/Style Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1701 words

HEADLINE: STARTING OVER: DISPATCHES FROM CITY AND SUBURB; 
Still on the River, Shifting Views

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
FOR New Yorkers, to stay or to leave, whether in crisis or not, has always been a kind of daily universal question. But with the nation warring, the pressure to make peace with a place, or to secure a sense of safety, seems greater than ever.
 For a young couple with a young child, like Andrew and Gabrielle Bordwin, whose daughter, Tamar, is 2, the move in January from a loft on Broadway, the artery of New York City, to a leafy cul-de-sac in Hastings-on-Hudson, a village of 7,600, raised and has yet to resolve the other big debate, that of living in the suburbs versus the city. 
 The fears and hopes -- the full emotional escort of uncertainty -- accompanied Andrew, 36, a photographer and an artist, and Gaby (as friends and family call her), 34, a graphic designer, when they left.
"It's true -- everybody joked about the 'passport,' " Andrew said, stretched out on the stalky grass, resting on his elbow. "I think it's an illusion, that fear. Once you start looking for it, you find it's not really there." 
"Would you stop philosophizing?" Gaby said, seated next to him. "You hand in your credibility card when you move all the boxes out." Cicadas underscored her voice.
"Half an hour ain't too far," Andrew said, joking defensively about the commute. He keeps a studio in the city. Gaby works on the Upper East Side at a publishing house.
"Half an hour -- I imposed that rule," she said.
The Bordwins' new house, a three-story Georgian Colonial built in 1919 on a quarter-acre of land, rose in a shaggy, shingled stack behind them. Dressed in a high-waisted smock, her red-haired bob a lighter version of her mother's, Tamar spun wide loops on the lawn. She seemed to understand, in her sail forward, that this was now her world to circumnavigate, to the edges of its hill and hedges.
When I saw them as a guest at a going-away party at their loft shortly before they moved out of the city, I told the Bordwins that I would never see them again. Outside their seventh-floor windows, City Hall and the Brooklyn Bridge glittered like a stage set seen from a theater box.
"We thought you were joking," Gaby said last week -- 10 months later -- during my first visit to their new home. Black Gucci sunglasses shaded her eyes, but the dry touch in her tone reprieved me.
The Bordwins moved downtown in 1995, part of the avant-garde few who were living by City Hall, happy with inconveniences in exchange for relatively inexpensive real estate, historical and architectural interest and urban adventure. The dry cleaner was a subway ride; the 1,200-square-foot loft was $220,000. The view was like living inside a postcard.
Six years later, now sleepless new parents worn thin by noise -- five Broadway bus lines once seemed like big-city bustle -- and hemmed in by space that diminished as the baby grew, they moved out, renting a house in Hastings with a six-month lease. Capitalizing on an unsure market that was still strong, the Bordwins sold the loft for $725,000. They bought the home on Fraser Place the next month for $695,000 -- the owners' asking price. They looked in the morning and bid when they finished lunch. As apartment dwellers during 17 years in New York, they had never owned, renovated or maintained a house. Their loft building -- alternative living -- had a superintendent and a porter.
The Bordwins are now experts on their house.
"We replaced 80 percent of the wiring, took out all of the radiators and put in a completely new heating system," Andrew said. "When you do a home renovation, you understand your house really well."
The work, they hope, will end at the end of this month. The Bordwins are living in the living room, like a miniaturized version of their city loft -- with pink-rose carpeting, which was left by the previous owners. Most of their furniture is stacked in the cottagelike garage: slick coffee tables and midcentury-modern dining chairs that look like wealthy travelers shipwrecked in evening dress. They may never reach shore in the quaint new house.
Hastings was at the top of a short list when the Bordwins decided to look for a place to live outside New York. Montclair, N.J., which they visited with good friends who lived in their loft building and had also decided to move, was too large.
"The high school is several thousand children," said Gaby, who had heard of Montclair, as she had Irvington and Hastings, the other communities the Bordwins looked at, in a new mothers' group she attended when Tamar was born, where talk was frequently about "staying or leaving."
The Bordwins liked the idea of being on the Hudson River, in a river town.
"We became really attached to the Hudson, using the parks there, when we lived downtown," Andrew said. "I feel like it's a lifeline to the city -- that we're really not that far away."
It is a Manhattan migratory pattern, for a type of New Yorker.
"People from the Upper West Side and Greenwich Village and downtown tend to come to river towns," said Arthur G. Riolo, an agent with Peter J. Riolo Inc., a Hastings-based real estate company that his father started 65 years ago. The price for a three-bedroom house is $450,000 to $550,000, Mr. Riolo said; there were only six houses for sale last week.
Mr. Riolo said 75 percent of his clients were people leaving New York City, whether buying or renting.
Hastings is a village, incorporated in 1879. The average family size is three. Thirty percent of the population are children; 24 percent are under 18. The largest population group is baby boomers, 45 to 54. The second-largest is 35 to 44. Hastings is a haven of homeowners -- 66 percent of the residents own their houses.
The development of its summer estates and old farms began in 1907, when a group of teachers and other professionals from New York City bought 17 acres and built year-round houses. By the 1920's, Hastings was an industrial town with two waterfront employers: a chemical plant and a cable and wire company. When they closed in the 1970's, the village was as much a bedroom community as it was blue-collar -- a balance in backgrounds that people like the Bordwins, moving to Hastings, consider as much a strength as good schools.
Merchants on Main Street and on Warburton Avenue, the village's downtown shopping district, are largely local -- a carefully guarded vestige of its working-class roots.
"There's a Thomas's Cafe," said Mr. Riolo, whose office is on Main Street. "It's exactly what Starbucks would be, but it's a family-run business. We don't have commercial square footage that would allow commercial chains to come in. Because of parking requirements, chains wouldn't be interested. Zoning would be too restrictive."
Hastings had "a buzz," Gaby recalled, a reputation that has attracted artists and other independently employed people over the years.
Lewis Hine, the photographer and social documentarian, lived in Hastings in the 1930's, a fact that intrigued Fred Charles, an architectural photographer, who moved with his wife, Eileen, a copywriter, to Hastings from Chelsea in 1992. The Charleses, with their two children, are neighbors of the Bordwins.
In 1991, on assignment for Time magazine, Mr. Charles photographed Kentlands, a development in Maryland designed by Andres Duany and Elizabeth Plater-Zyberk, parents and proponents of "new urbanist" suburban planning like Seaside, Fla., which they also designed, the vaguely Victorian town that was used as the location for the 1998 film "The Truman Show."
"Hastings is what Kentlands wants to be," Mr. Charles said. "A mixture of house sizes, not the lock-step single-level suburban homes. There's a porch culture -- you can speak to neighbors from your porch."
The Charleses and the Bordwins also live next to the Old Croton Trailway, a 19th-century aqueduct that is now a 26-mile-long state park. The pedestrian presence of people biking, jogging and strolling next door added a level of villagelike urbanity to suburban life, Mr. Charles said.
Having the option to walk around town, rather than rely on driving, which the Bordwins insisted upon in choosing a new place to live, was a revelation, though.
"It's funny," Gaby said, curled on the grass as the sun set. "You come out here and you think, 'Oh, I'd love to get a little peace and quiet,' and you step outside your house, and there's nobody there."
What sounded like a monstrous bullfrog -- the volunteer fire department's horn -- went off somewhere beyond the tops of the trees, croaking in the dusk.
"I would put Tamar in her snowsuit and take her to the park, and it would be empty," Gaby recalled. "We'd walk in the neighborhood, and she would say, 'People?' "
Diversity was also a problematic surprise for the Bordwins, especially as parents. Though economically and religiously diverse, Hastings is not racially diverse. It is 90 percent white and 2 percent black, according to the 2000 census; 4 percent of the populace is Asian, and 4 percent Hispanic.
"I think by and large that the neighborhoods are pretty segregated in the city," Gaby said. "But the broader community, on the street and in the buses and subways, in public places and at work, are more mixed. I wanted a like-minded community, but I didn't want to move to a place where everybody is like me."
With a hungry child insistently interrupting, Andrew and Gaby got to their feet, making plans to eat at a restaurant by the river. The porch lights shone yellow on the house as we walked to it -- the color of a kind of nostalgic view of suburbia.
"You just make a bargain," Gaby said, pulling a small sweater onto a small body with its arms in the air. "You say, 'I'm willing to move out of the city if I can preserve some of the things that I like.' "
People will say that they move for the children, but I began to suspect that children were often only the excuse for being able to give something up with grace. The Bordwins looked older, not in age, but in maturity, as though they had shifted generations, from growing up to bringing up.
"I never felt like an especially edgy person," Gaby said. "But I felt like New York was what gave me my edge. That was the badge of honor."
"I do think I'm duller now," she said, organizing Tamar for the car and the drive to dinner. "But it's also kind of a relief."

HEADLINE: Slower Growth and Wider Deficit Are Seen for Indonesia 

BYLINE:  By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Oct. 10 

 BODY:
Underscoring how security concerns have clouded Indonesia's economic outlook, the International Monetary Fund agreed today that the country's government would be forced to run a wider budget deficit than planned next year.
 A visiting team of I.M.F. officials, led by the fund's Asia-Pacific assistant director, Daniel Citrin, approved a revised 2002 budget that predicts slower economic growth, higher inflation and a wider budget deficit. 
 Threatened reprisals by fringe militant groups against American interests in Indonesia, the world's most populous Muslim country, have put foreign companies on edge, battering the currency and stock market, and making it harder for the government to raise sorely needed funds.
"The broader concern is what it does to the overall investment climate," said Mark Baird, the Indonesia country director for the World Bank in Jakarta. Investors everywhere are skittish in the wake of the terrorist attacks in the United States, he said, but "the political context here is probably more difficult." 
Indonesia is still struggling to recover from the effects of the Asian financial crisis that began more than four years ago. It still depends on foreign aid, including the $5 billion economic rescue program administered by the fund.
Indonesia's biggest creditors are scheduled to meet in Jakarta early next month to consider the country's request for new loans.
Only last month, the I.M.F. released a $395 million loan to Indonesia after signing a new agreement with the country's new president, Megawati Sukarnoputri. It had withheld that loan since December amid disputes with her predecessor, Abdurrahman Wahid.
A recurring source of friction has been the pace of the government's sales of state-owned companies and assets taken over during the crisis. Many were seized from politically powerful friends and relatives of former President Suharto, who along with some politicians have resisted efforts to sell them at "fire sale" prices to foreigners.
"The broader view is that these assets have to be returned to the private sector and that that should be done as expeditiously as possible," said David Nellor, the senior resident representative for the I.M.F. in Jakarta. But rising anti-American sentiment in the streets may make it more dangerous than ever for Indonesia's financial mangers to sell such assets.
Business confidence is also being tested. Since returning from the United States last month with $530 million in new financial aid promises, Mrs. Megawati has moved to calm the public and reassure foreigners. Most expatriates, many inured to the frequent sight of demonstrations in the capital, seemed willing to wait and see whether she would succeed.
Nonetheless, many foreign offices stayed shut on Monday after forces led by the United States had struck Afghanistan. "We didn't know what the civil situation was going to be like," said William J. Cummings, a spokesman for Exxon Mobil, which shut its office in Jakarta on Monday as a precautionary measure.
Security, meanwhile, has also reportedly been stepped up at oil and gas operations around Indonesia, Asia's only OPEC member. Gas and oil revenues are a crucial source of government income.
But foreign companies like Exxon Mobil, Conoco and Unocal perform most of the drilling. Earlier this year, Exxon Mobil was forced to suspend operations at gas fields in Aceh province, where Muslim rebels are waging a separatist campaign, after repeated attacks on its local employees.
As long as oil and gas keep flowing, Indonesia remains somewhat insulated economically. Unlike many nations, Indonesia does not depend on high-technology exports to the United States, and the prospect of higher oil prices augurs well for it.
Gloom on the securities market is making it more difficult for Indonesia's financial authorities to raise the 33.5 trillion rupiah ($3.35 billion) in asset sales and privatization they have promised the I.M.F. this year.
Indonesia's currency, the rupiah, has fallen 9 percent since Sept. 11 on fears of unrest, prompting the country's central bank to say it would have to sell United States dollars to stem the rupiah's slide. Stocks have also suffered, with Jakarta's benchmark index having lost 17 percent since the attacks in the United States. Last week, Indonesia called off the sale of a chemical company when it said the bids received were too low. It has also delayed the sale of a controlling stake in a cement company to Cemex of Mexico.
Some economists warn that further sales delays could force the I.M.F. to delay its next loan. But the I.M.F.'s statements today seemed to give the government latitude.
"From the I.M.F. there's still a lot of good will toward this government," said James W. Castle, who runs his own consulting firm in Jakarta and serves as president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Indonesia. "The current situation could provide a fig leaf," he said.

HEADLINE: A New Reality Wrapped Up in Silk, Paint and Leather 

BYLINE:  By PILAR GUZMAN 

 BODY:
BACKSTAGE at this year's French Designer Showhouse was like a scene from Luis Bunuel's film "The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie," the surreal 1972 classic that follows a band of friends through a series of outrageous plot twists -- infidelity, assassination attempts, armies of unannounced dinner guests -- that fail to undermine the characters' unflappable self-control. 
 After two weeks of construction and delivery delays, aborted shipments and a crisis of faith over the show's propriety, what is formally the seventh American Hospital of Paris French Designer Showhouse opens its doors today, right on schedule, in a 1906 Beaux Arts mansion at 47 East 68th Street. 
 The show house, which displays the work of more than 25 designers, decorative painters and artisans for a month, benefits the American Hospital of Paris. (Part of the proceeds from admissions will go to the Sept. 11 World Trade Center Relief and Recovery Fund, which the American Hospital of Paris helped set up.)
While many of the rooms recognize the cocooning instinct that follows upheavals, others cling playfully to the notion of the interior as a theatrical escape from times of uncertainty. And at this moment, surreality may be preferable to reality. 
One end of the spectrum is represented by Florence de Dampierre's transformation of a traditional salon living room into an otherworldly universe with floral wall murals and lighting that seems to offer eternal daylight. At the other end is a movie set den (call it "The Old Man and the Sofa") created by Angela Hemingway to honor her late husband, Jack (son of Ernest). The den is jammed with Thomasville Furniture's updated greatest hits of Hemingway machismo, right down to the terra-cotta-colored leather divan.
Whether deliberately theatrical or more practical, the show house registers a time of transition when, as Ms. Hemingway suggests, "everyone just wants to be at home." 
Overall, the most impressive rooms are the subtle ones, where the challenge of marrying the fanciful and relevant comes off effortlessly.
Paul Mathieu's dining room is an adroit balance of city and country, inspired by nature. It's the kind of soothing space you could spend the morning in with a cup of coffee and newspaper or hold a dinner party. "People need a room to do more than one thing these days," Mr. Mathieu said. The walls, which are bisected horizontally -- earthy brown below, a celestial lavender-blue above -- are covered with the designer's own figurative sketches. 
"I wanted to show with the two colors how we are attached to the earth but also that we need this poetry of dancing figures in the sky," said Mr. Mathieu, who added tiny twin towers to the bottom of one of his drawings. "Especially now." 
The space was designed to introduce Air, his new line of walnut furniture for Donghia. The line, a riff on midcentury modern with a French inflection, includes a dining room table and sideboards that seemed ready to leap on elongated, curved legs -- inspired by, Mr. Mathieu said, a surprise encounter with a deer.
Sometimes it's enough for a room to serve as pure retreat. The drawn shades and cork-lined walls in Maureen Wilson Footer's womblike bedroom are homage to her muse, the hypochondriac, neurasthenic and noise-averse Marcel Proust, though many New Yorkers would also appreciate it that way. 
But Ms. Wilson Footer, who did her graduate work in 18th-century French interior architecture and furniture at L'Ecole du Louvre, is careful not to get too mired in the past. Her beloved Louis XVI furniture (signed Pluvinet and Criard) sits easily alongside a starkly minimal concrete mantle. "I don't want to live in a museum period bedroom," she said. 
Even the most efficient spaces can still be romantic. Nathalie du Luart and Delphine Vendel designed a small study with themselves in mind. "We designed a space that we would like to have as women who work from home," Ms. du Luart said. Their prize piece is a sycamore desk that the team designed as a kind of modern secretary -- equipped to handle a computer but with the Old World luxury of inlaid leather -- that folds up neatly to form a sideboard. A fresh vertical stripe fabric by Sanderson hung along one wall, echoed in a tiny green horizontal stripe painted around the upper perimeter of the wall, gives the room an additional layer of crisp texture. 
When you enter Odile de Schietere's bedroom for a "gentilhomme," you feel as if her fantasy patron, an American gentleman living abroad, might walk in at any moment. This character, like its author, isn't afraid to pair a dramatic Federal-style American bed (found in Paris) with a whimsical rhinoceros-shaped table. A minimal tatami-esque border around an animal print rug and spare window treatments by Hunter Douglas behind more ornate ones balance out the antiques. A more contemporary bathroom outfitted by Ann Sacks is cleverly carved out of a closet. 
Some of the show's most inspired touches lie in the decorative painting and wall treatments, and in the lighting designs.
Michael Tyson Murphy's wall motif -- a subtle hand-painted checkerboard and floral pattern inspired by a French Art Deco rug -- adds dimension and an illusion of space to the narrow room. The 60's-influenced cyberbiological abstract mural by John Opella and Roy Steves on the fourth-floor landing and the additional walls painted in faux bronze are also surprising contrasts to the traditional space. 
Robert DeCarlo added an ebonized carved wood ceiling frieze and hand-painted faux wood to a black lacquer Deco kitchen. But he countered the formal touches with inexpensive and artful details: Crate & Barrel glasses and the store's $129 Arts & Crafts-inspired standing lamps only look expensive. The colorful geometric pattern on sheer window shades was actually done with spray paint by Mr. DeCarlo himself. (Check out the 1970's-modern "hutch," from the Hell's Kitchen Salvation Army.)
Stephane Pagani, of Cotule Lighting Design in Brooklyn, created a sleek, intriguing lighting fixture which revolves above the third-floor landing, bringing to mind oars paddling gently through the air.
Even Ms. de Dampierre's decorative wall treatments for the dreamlike salon apply to mortal dwellings. 
Oversized flower murals by Elizabeth Thompson in the overwhelmingly lavender space and one painted on a white Crate & Barrel couch are bold and transforming. And the ceiling effect -- periwinkle at the perimeter molding that diffuses to a faint lavender -- is something a crafty type might pull off at home. Aluminum baseboards that double as light boxes and the tricky white sand on the floor add to the room's almost lunar quality. 
Even in a slowing economy, design as theater has its place. A narrow reception hall plays on the mood shift of a changing season. Pierre Court and Melissa Brown had grayish-blue geometric shapes, supergraphic style, painted over cream-colored walls to suggest the long shadows of autumn light filtered through a dense forest. 
"The idea was to break the boring proportions of the room," Mr. Court said. The primitive forest effect is amplified by an ebony Tucker Robbins pillar from the Philippines. With a giant swath of rust silk suspended diagonally across the ceiling and an oversized flower made of a red feather African headdress hung like a medallion from a mantelpiece mirror, Mr. Court and Ms. Brown prove that bold statements can have subtlety, too. 
Christopher Coleman's masculine turquoise and black study walks a fine line between credible interior and symbolic art installation. Few would have thought that fabric printed with newspaper stock tables, from Stroheim & Romann, would actually make stylish sliding window screens. You could imagine spending a lot of time in this home office, with a day bed at the end of the room and a Lucite desk. The deep turquoise wall paint is not quite the color of money but a tad more cheerful. 
Even more theatrical than viable, Etienne Coffinier's guest bedroom plays up the Lilliputian scale of the room with Nobilis fabrics and textures that cover every square inch of the room. Seriously French on first glance -- Cote France Louis XV-style day bed, Louis XV Dos D'Ane writing desk and red and white toile -- the space also shows the designer's sense of humor with a series of feather-duster wall sconces. 
Even the weirdly wry presence of Louis Vuitton luggage propping Mr. Coffinier's chamber -- when unthinkable tensions are making travel a gargantuan task -- could be an appropriately farcical touch. Happily,the imagination is a realm where one can always roam freely.
The American Hospital of Paris French Designer Showhouse, at 47 East 68th Street (Madison Avenue), is open through Nov. 11, 11-5 daily, Thursdays until 8. Admission $20; (212) 838-0157.

HEADLINE: Broadway Shows Rebound, But With Fewer Tourists 

BYLINE:  By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

 BODY:
One month after being emptied by the World Trade Center attacks, Broadway theaters are showing signs of bouncing back to near normal attendance, according to new figures from the League of American Theaters and Producers. The numbers reflect a stronger than usual turnout by New Yorkers and suburbanites, whose boosterism has helped compensate for a drop in theatergoing tourists from outside the area.
 From a low of $3.5 million during the week that ended Sept. 16, when performances were canceled, gross box office sales jumped to $10.5 million for the week that ended Oct. 7. Sales were $11.6 million for the same period last year, the league reported. 
 Last week's attendance was 183,966 -- not so far removed from the figure for the same period the previous year, 202,789. 
"On the basis of gross and attendance, we have bounced back a very long way," said Jed Bernstein, president of the league, "but that is leavened by the fact that we have four fewer shows." One of them, "The Rocky Horror Show," may reopen; a decision is to be announced next week, said Jordan Roth, the show's producer. 
Some of the biggest attendance increases were for Broadway's longest-running productions. Box office sales for "Beauty and the Beast," in its eighth year, jumped to $543,381 last week from $436,954 for the week that ended Sept. 30.
Until Sept. 11, shows like "Beauty and the Beast" relied heavily on tourists from places like Japan and Ohio. "Now the tourists we are seeing are people from New Jersey, Long Island and Westchester," said Chris Boneau, a partner in a publicity firm that handles several Broadway shows. Last weekend theater managers also noticed an increase in families attending with their children, he said, another sign of normalcy.
"We have been seeing the effects of the marketing promotions, the new ads and, of course, the mayor," said Karen Hauser, director of research at the league. "The mayor has been great. He is our best P.R. person."
A survey of theatergoers by the league confirms a sharp drop in out-of-town tourism, which still has theater producers worried. 
Of those surveyed at Broadway theaters during the two-week period that ended on Sunday, 26 percent were from New York City, 26 percent from neighboring suburbs, 44 percent from other parts of the United States and 4 percent from abroad. A year ago a survey showed that 17 percent of theatergoers were from New York, 22 percent from the suburbs, 50 percent from the rest of the United States and 11 percent from abroad. 
Mr. Bernstein noted that the number of foreigners had fallen off drastically, by 65 to 70 percent since the attacks, while domestic tourism was down by only 11 percent which, he said, was "better than expected." 
He cautioned that Broadway producers were still holding their breath. "Unless these numbers get better, then it bodes ill on a going-forward basis," he said, adding that many producers were waiting before committing to new shows for the spring.
"Everybody is very cautious and putting things on hold," said John Breglio, a prominent entertainment lawyer and chairman of the Theater Development Fund. "This has had a very serious, chilling effect. We need to encourage people not only to come out and see the shows, but to put on the shows the people can see."
The latest figures showed an upturn for new shows that opened recently. For "Hedda Gabler," which opened at the Ambassador Theater on Oct. 4, box office receipts went to $197,188 for the week that ended on Sunday from $148,078 for the week of previews that ended on Sept. 30. Attendance rose by 1,238 during the same period.
Broadway still has one more week before the expiration of concessions granted by unions, royalty holders and theater owners to ease the economic impact of the terrorist attacks. Some shows have already cut back on concessions in response to rising attendance.
"There is no question that every week things are improving," Mr. Breglio said. "But two things are of concern in the long run -- the number of tourists, which are way down, and the environment for bringing in new shows."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Filming of commercials in New York is making a comeback after the disruption of Sept. 11.

BYLINE:  By Allison Fass 

 BODY:
WHEN Jeff Gorman, a commercial director, was making arrangements to shoot a spot for a government agency, he was working out logistical details for the site selected for the production, an emergency call center in Jersey City.
 A day or two before the shoot, Mr. Gorman recalled, "we were told, in the event of a crisis, such as an attack on the World Trade Center, they would of course have to deny us the use of the space." 
The shoot was scheduled for Sept. 12. 
"I thought, 'What are the chances?' " said Mr. Gorman, who owns JGF, a production company in Los Angeles. "It was quite ironic to hear those words being uttered and then to have them fulfilled." After Sept. 11, the shoot was moved to a sound stage at Universal Studios near Los Angeles and was completed last week.
Like virtually all businesses, the commercial production industry was initially rocked by the terrorist attacks. Production on all commercials in New York City was halted immediately. Shoots did not resume in the boroughs outside Manhattan until Sept. 14; in Manhattan, they resumed -- only north of Canal Street -- on Sept. 25.
Now, as the recovery continues, the industry is assessing the effects of the disruptions, which caused many productions to be postponed or moved. The timing could not have been worse for an industry that had already been dealing with the effects of the softening economy, which led to reductions in commercial production schedules, and a six-month strike last year when members of the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists would not perform commercial work.
With the resumption of production, 38 permits have been issued for commercial shoots, said Patricia Reed Scott, commissioner of the mayor's office for film, theater and broadcasting.
"We're now at the level of pre-strike in this very difficult time," Ms. Scott said, "which I must say is encouraging." Commercials are being shot in the city for major advertisers like BMW, Burger King, Crest, Heineken, Mountain Dew and Wrigley's, she added.
To keep that momentum from slowing, there are initiatives by production companies, marketers, agencies, unions and related organizations, cooperating to ensure that commercial production remains in New York.
For instance, a coalition named We Love New York has been formed to bolster advertising, as well as theater, television and film, in the aftermath of the attacks.
The industry is "mounting an ongoing effort to make sure the world knows New York is open for business and New York means business," said Jon Kamen, chief executive of @radical.media in New York, a leading production company, who is active in the We Love New York coalition.
"New York is a very resilient city," he added, "that has bounced back quite beautifully."
Members of We Love New York include, in addition to the actors unions, the Association of Independent Commercial Producers, the American Association of Advertising Agencies, the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees and New York Women in Film and TV.
"Advertisers and agencies are really looking to work with production companies and bring them back here to support the New York economy," said Matt Miller, president at the commercial producers' association. "For jobs to move away, out of whatever reason -- fear, paranoia -- that needs to be squelched."
About 30 percent to 35 percent of commercials shot in the United States are produced in New York, by Mr. Miller's estimate, compared with 50 percent to 60 percent in Los Angeles. New York had been losing shoots because of its higher costs of production, though that is a problem affecting all spots made in the United States; many commercials are being shot in Canada and Europe for that reason.
Some companies now are considering producing commercials in New York that would not have been shot there before Sept. 11 to show support for the city's recovery efforts.
For example, Bob Fisher, executive producer at Celsius Films in New York, said his company had refused to give an estimated price to shoot a commercial in Canada to a client who made the request on Sept. 11.
"There are always commercials that cannot be shot in New York," Mr. Fisher said. "If I'm looking for a desert, Coney Island doesn't work."
"But as far as the ability to do production in New York," he added, "New York crews and equipment are capable of producing any job in the world."
As for Mr. Gorman of JGF, who was stranded in New York through the week of Sept. 11, he said he had an office in New York and worked from there two to four times a year.
"It's either because the advertising agency is a New York-based agency and they want to shoot there," Mr. Gorman said, "or you're looking for a specific New York location -- and there is only one New York."

HEADLINE: Passenger-Screening Companies Lobby for Expanded Role 

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD with MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 

 BODY:
The companies that screen passengers and baggage at the nation's airports readily acknowledge that they do not do their job very well. Yet as Congress debates the future of aviation security, these companies are lobbying hard for an expanded role, arguing they are the only ones who know how to do it right.
 "This is an opportunity to fix what has been wrong for many, many years in the United States," said Thomas Berglund, chief executive of Securitas A.B., the Swedish company that recently purchased Burns International Services of Chicago to become the third-biggest screening company in the United States. Its Globe Security unit screens passengers for American Airlines at Logan International Airport in Boston, the departure point for the first hijacked plane that hit the World Trade Center on Sept. 11. 
 Securitas and two other European companies that have bought the big American providers of airport screening services over the last 18 months contend that the economics of the business are flawed. Because it falls upon the airlines to hire screening contractors and pay them, contracts typically go to the lowest bidder.
"In Europe, we deal with vice presidents of operations, or heads of corporate security; here, we deal with purchasing agents," said Lior Zouker, president and chief executive of ICTS International N.V., the Dutch company that last year purchased the Huntleigh USA Corporation of St. Louis to become the No. 2 American screening company. "What do you want a purchasing agent to do, besides getting a contract for 10 cents per hour less?" Huntleigh did the screening of passengers on the United Airlines flight from Logan that crashed into the second twin tower.
To put the business on what they consider a more rational financial footing, the companies favor the Bush administration's approach -- and the approach favored by House Republicans -- to overhauling airport security. For at least an 18-month period, the federal government would contract with the companies to supply screening services, under tougher standards set and policed by Washington. Any company that flunked would be replaced by federal workers.
"We think we have some pretty good models in NASA, the State Department's embassy protection system, where they hire outside contractors, who are really quite good," Chet Lunner, a spokesman for the Transportation Department, said. "There is some evidence that if you raise the standards, you can get better quality." Administration officials add that it would be easier to fire contract workers who failed to perform than to remove civil service employees.
In the Senate, on the other hand, there is strong sentiment for a federal takeover of airport security, on the ground that only the presence of government security personnel will restore public confidence. The Senate began debate on the issue this evening and is expected to continue on Thursday.
"It's the job of the U.S. government to keep America safe," said Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, Democrat of West Virginia. "We can no longer afford to leave any aspect of our airport security to the lowest bidder among private companies. We need a federal work force with federal training and testing, federal accountability and oversight at every airport in the country -- large and small."
Mr. Berglund of Securitas said that his company bought into the American market expressly to change it. Securitas has also recently purchased security operations from Pinkerton and Loomis Fargo, a business formed by the 1997 combination of Wells Fargo and Loomis Armored Inc. Besides Securitas and ICTS -- which stands for International Consultants on Targeted Security -- the international invasion also includes Securicor P.L.C., a British company that last year acquired Argenbright Security from AHL Services of Atlanta to become the largest airport screening company in the United States.
The security companies have never had a trade group or a lobbying operation, but since Sept. 11 they have hired Burston-Marstellar for public relations; Kenneth Quinn, a former general counsel of the F.A.A., as their lawyer, and Ungaretti & Harris, a lobbying firm led by another former F.A.A. lawyer, to press their cause.
In Europe, passenger screening is the responsibility of governments, not the airlines, and European governments use either civil servants or contractors to do the work. Legislation now under consideration here would create a passenger tax to pay the bill, so that, as in Europe, there would be no commercial incentive to scrimp.
Whether any of the screening companies were lax in their duties in the four hijackings of Sept. 11 is not clear. The planes may have been hijacked with weapons, like small knives and box-cutters, that the Federal Aviation Administration's rules tell screeners to ignore.
But over all, their performance has been poor, according to government investigators. In April 2000, the General Accounting Office reported to Congress on the latest of a series of tests in which investigators set out to slip weapons by airport security.
"Screeners' ability to detect objects during the agency's tests is not improving, and in some cases is worsening," the report said.
Last year, Argenbright pleaded guilty and agreed to pay $1.2 million for falsifying records, performing inadequate background checks and hiring at least 14 airport workers in Philadelphia who had criminal convictions for burglary, firearm possession, drug dealing and other crimes.
David J. Beaton, president of the Global Aviation division of Securicor, said the Philadelphia problem was isolated. Asked if screeners had failed to catch some weapons in carry-on bags, Mr. Beaton said that his employees had confiscated more than 4,000 items last year.
None of the companies have thus far made European-style changes in the United States. Mr. Zouker said that 10 months ago, a major American airline invited him to review security arrangements at one of its hubs and asked if he would take over and improve it. The average pay for screeners at the airport, he said, was $6.75 an hour; when he told the airline that he would have to pay $3 an hour more to upgrade the operation, the airline said it was not ready to take that step.
"We need the federal government to come into the picture, to drop the airlines out of the equation," Mr. Zouker said. "They're not bad guys, but they have a conflict of interest" -- namely, their profits.
Any overhaul of the security system, he said, needs to make it possible to pay screening workers -- who sometimes make less than employees at airport food stands -- at rates that reflect the importance of their work.
"You have to look at the risk behind it, that we will lose an aircraft," Mr. Zouker said. "What is the risk at a fast food restaurant -- that he will put on less mayonnaise?"

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Even in good times, airlines depend on a hairline balancing of supply and demand.

BYLINE:  By Virginia Postrel; Virginia Postrel is the editor at large of Reason Magazine and the author of "The Future and Its Enemies." E-mail: vpostrel@reason.com.

 BODY:
ON a recent flight from Los Angeles to Dallas, the American Airlines pilot thanked the passengers profusely at the beginning and end of the trip.
 The plane was packed, with only a few empty middle seats, and crew members were happy to be back to the world of crowded cabins and potential profits. 
 Before the Sept. 11 attacks, the airlines were struggling to overcome the effects of the economic downturn. Business travel in particular had dropped sharply. After the attacks, planes were grounded for two days, meaning the airlines kept paying their operating costs but had absolutely no revenue. Since then, fears not only of hijackings but of airport security problems and delays have discouraged passengers from flying. 
All in all, it's been a very bad month for the airlines. They've laid off about 80,000 workers and dropped about a fifth of their flights. As Congress rushed to pass a bailout, giving the airlines $5 billion in grants and $10 billion in loan guarantees, the perception grew that airlines are an inherently bad business -- a "failing industry," in the words of Peter G. Fitzgerald, the Illinois Republican who was the sole Senator to vote against the bailout.
Economists who study the industry say it's simplistic to argue that the airlines are always in trouble. The industry isn't exceptionally profitable, but it does make reasonable returns.
Still, even under normal circumstances -- and these aren't normal circumstances -- the business does present definite challenges to managers.
The essential problem is matching capacity with demand, which requires making spending decisions far in advance of ticket sales. That may not sound unusual -- many businesses have to guess how much product to make -- but the problem is harder for airlines than for manufacturers. If they plan for too many passengers, they can't carry the extra seats in inventory.
"Either you sell the seat for this particular flight for this hour or you don't sell it," said Pablo Spiller, an economist at the Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley. "You can't say, 'I'll keep the Thursday, Oct. 4, seat at 5 for next week.' No, it went away, that seat."
If planes fly with few passengers because an airline overestimated demand, those flights tend to lose money. For a given flight, the costs of fuel, labor and the aircraft itself are essentially fixed, regardless of how many passengers the plane is carrying. That's why the airline's "load factor," the percentage of seats filled, is such an important indicator of how well it is doing.
When the load factor drops, airlines tend to get into fare wars. Adding another passenger to a given flight costs almost nothing, so any additional revenue will help cover those fixed costs. If one airline has too much capacity, it will sharply reduce fares to fill up its planes. Competitors will drop their fares to match, lest they lose their passengers.
"It's a very competitive industry," Professor Spiller said. "It's not a fragmented industry -- you have a few large players -- but it's very competitive because in every market you have several players." The hub-and-spoke system means that most travelers can choose among several airlines. This competition means air fares behave almost like agricultural commodities, with airlines having little control over prices. (The exception is for flights starting or ending at "fortress hubs," like Delta's in Atlanta, where one airline controls a great majority of flights.)
In any new industry, managers have to learn how to deal with the particular challenges of the business. Just ask the dot-commers. Airlines aren't a new business, of course, but they operated in a completely different environment from 1938, when the federal government imposed regulation, until 1978.
"They have fundamental challenges matching capacity with demand -- both in getting that capacity and predicting what that demand will be -- and adjusting to business cycles," said Clifford Winston, an economist with the Brookings Institution. Learning how to do that after deregulation, he adds, "was going to take them a while; for 40 years, they had no practice at it and no incentive to do anything about it."
Travel demand fluctuates greatly with overall economic conditions. Since 1978, when federal price and route controls were removed, the airlines have gone through just a couple of full business cycles. "In each successive decade, they were getting better," Dr. Winston said.
After the 1981-82 recession, the airlines bounced back. But during the good times of the mid- and late-1980's, they bought far too many planes. That gave them too much capacity when the economy turned down in the early 90's, leading to fare wars and financial losses.
In the boom of the 1990's, the airlines made plenty of money. To the annoyance of passengers, they not only limited discounts but kept capacity relatively tight. That discipline not only increased profits but made adjustment easier when the downturn came. Before Sept. 11, Dr. Winston argues, "The expectation was, yes, things might slow down for them, but they were gong to come through this part of the business cycle better than they had in the past."
The attacks, however, were a completely different sort of shock. "You have not seen a reduction in demand like this ever," Professor Spiller said. "This is a cataclysm. It's like an earthquake shook a country. The country stops."
Aside from lobbying for the bailout, the airlines have responded by reducing fixed costs. Ordinarily, they wouldn't lay off employees, preferring to cut work hours, because bringing on new people when business improves is complicated and expensive. Similarly, dropping flights can alienate customers, so airlines try to avoid that step. Now, however, they have no choice. "The demand drop is so large that there is no way out," Professor Spiller said.
The attacks created a genuine, but perhaps short-term crisis, for the industry. The continuing crisis that the business is tagged with is less real. With the schedule cuts in place and Americans beginning to travel again, load factors are rising. The problem with this cyclical industry is that its fortunes always upset someone.
"When they're losing money, the airlines are crying; when they're making money, the politicians are crying," Professor Spiller said, noting that not long ago elected officials were accusing the industry of profiteering. "So it's a wonderful business."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Continental, like other big airlines, has announced cutbacks since the terrorist attacks. Airline employees waited for customers at Bush International Airport in Houston on Sept. 15. (Associated Press)
