HEADLINE: Essay; 
On Everyday Bravery

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

 BODY:
"Calm down, relax," advised Mayor Rudy Giuliani at New York's Columbus Day parade. He added: "Be brave." President Bush agrees, urging us to fly again and "enjoy life." 
 That is seemingly contradicted by admonitions from others to "be vigilant." Catch-up alarmists wallow in warnings; as a result, mothers treat their children's every sniffle as incipient anthrax, while hydrated healthniks clutching security-bottles of water are suspected of transporting nitroglycerine. 
 Meanwhile, the act-normally advice of the mayor and the don't-hunker-down message of the president are twisted by the cynical into "splurge at the mall to support your country's economy" or "be a self-sacrificing patriot by dining out and going to a show." 
Coolness under potential fire is thus derided. An ultra-vigilant set that hoards arcane antibiotics and shops for designer gas masks is engaged in "panic chic." Fear is now their fad.
What of other people who are not free-range Chicken Littles but who have been made to feel vulnerable by a war that hits our homeland? We are uncomfortable with national anxiety. We are unfamiliar with a sense of personal danger. Accustomed to rapid response and quick closure, we are especially uneasy about having to wait for the other shoe, or bomb, to drop.
"Be brave." To a service member, or to a cop or firefighter recruited and trained to face a threat to life, that means to act honorably despite natural fear. Such courage is measurable; varying degrees of medals are awarded, sometimes posthumously, to denote its extent beyond the call of duty.
But what does "be brave" mean to those never called, to the person with a paunch -- to the family-centered civilian or the duty-free single citizen? In homeland defense, what used to be called "the home front" is now the actual front, and we have to comport ourselves with a degree of courage on this new front line. 
This is not about fearlessness; only the deranged or the wildly fanatic are fearless. The trick is to shake hands with our worry, get comfortable with our uneasiness, and manage our fear. How? We all have different ways -- religion, meditation, community voluntarism, exercise, meaningless dialogue, escapist novels, three-martini lunches -- but here are a couple that work for me, one negative, one positive:
First, get coldly angry, and not just at the designated villain in a TV studio with a rocky-cave backdrop. I am ticked off at the spooks and feds who failed spectacularly; at catch-up alarmists out to use this war to encroach on civil liberty and citizens' privacy; at Muslim-bashing bigots as well as Muslim clerics too timid to condemn suicide bombing; at Arab leaders who repay our aid and protection with permission to local zealots to fan hatred of America. 
In this regard, fury can be focused on Rihab Taha, the sleazy scientist first named in this space in 1995 as "Dr. Germs," boss of Saddam Hussein's biological warfare buildup. She's been hard at work on the side of deadly disease against the human race. (Read "Germs," by my colleagues Judith Miller, Stephen Engelberg and William Broad; it's the most important book of the year.) Outrage served cold -- the kind that leads to action -- trumps fear.
Flip that to the positive side. A way to deal with the present jitters is to recognize that great good can grow out of combat with evil. 
To build a defense against terrorism's germ arsenal, we are belatedly producing vaccines and awakening to public health needs. Beyond that, government and private foundations are increasing support of basic research into ways to expand the capability of the body's innate immune system without triggering an autoimmune response.
A couple of years ago, I asked an official of the Centers for Disease Control when we might achieve the dream of a "universal vaccine" against all pathogens. He waved it off with "in 50 years, maybe." When he noticed I was a journalist, he cut it to 25 years. Now, under pressure, scientists are seeking "multivalent vaccines" against groups of diseases, which this generation may see. 
Out of crisis comes unexpected bravery. And out of today's threat of biowar may come tomorrow's conquest of infectious disease.

HEADLINE: Pataki Defends $54 Billion Aid Request 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday defended his request for $54 billion from Congress to help New York recover from terrorist attacks, including proposals to use federal aid to balance the state budget and to pay for state transportation projects.
 Mr. Pataki said the federal tax cuts under consideration by Congress, while helpful, would not be enough to save the state's teetering economy if the city and state governments were forced to cut jobs or raise taxes because revenues withered after the attacks. He also called pumping money into transportation infrastructure a fast, effective way to invigorate the economy. 
 In Albany, meanwhile, the debate over what sort of agency will oversee the reconstruction of Lower Manhattan began in earnest as the Assembly speaker began circulating a proposal that would give the State Legislature some influence over how disaster aid was spent.
The governor, a Republican, plans to travel to Washington today to meet with Congressional leaders and aides to President Bush and advocate his proposal. He said he would argue, as in recent days, that New York City played a pivotal role in the nation's economy and that the attack on the World Trade Center was in reality an attack on the entire nation.
Still, he acknowledged that he faced a tough fight in Congress, where representatives and senators from other states with faltering economies were likely to resist bailing out New York "This is going to be difficult, no question," Mr. Pataki said. "We may not get things that we hope to get."
Three weeks ago, Congress and the president approved $17.5 billion in disaster aid to help with cleaning up the devastated zone in Lower Manhattan and restoring public buildings and infrastructure. The Pataki administration now estimates the cost to be about twice that amount.
The governor is also seeking $2 billion in tax-free bonds, tax incentives and grants to encourage companies to stay and rebuild in Lower Manhattan. He is also seeking an additional $3 billion to help families of victims and dislocated workers.
One part of his plan likely to meet resistance is a request for $3 billion to finance transportation projects, including rail, road and bridge upgrades in upstate New York. Mr. Pataki is also seeking up to $12 billion in federal aid to make up for the steep drop in tax revenue both the city and state foresee.
In previous disasters like hurricanes and earthquakes, the federal government has not bailed out local governments for lost revenues, and lawmakers in Washington say Mr. Pataki faces an uphill battle persuading Congressional leaders and President Bush to do so.
"There is a unique impact to New York," the governor said. "I would hope that Washington would recognize that unique impact."
Indeed, the president has said in recent days that any economic stimulus package should consist of tax cuts, not additional spending, a view shared by many conservative Republicans in Congress. Mr. Pataki's proposal has the potential to set up a tug of war between moderates and conservatives within the Republican Party.
Mr. Pataki's request for more federal aid comes as House Republicans are beginning to draft a bill, requested by the president last Friday, that would pump about $75 billion into the nation's stumbling economy in tax cuts. How the governor's proposals mesh with that bill remains to be seen.
Even Mr. Pataki's comrade in arms, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, appeared to distance himself from the governor when he said in his budget address earlier this week that the federal government could best help the city by cutting taxes.
Mr. Pataki sees things a bit differently. "I think tax cuts are an appropriate way to stimulate the national economy, but if at the same time you are saying the state and city must raise taxes it undoes the benefit of the federal tax cut," he said.
The governor said the state was facing a steep loss of revenues that could be as much as $3 billion in the current fiscal year, roughly what his budget-makers say is in the state's emergency reserves. Tomorrow, Mr. Pataki plans to announce several belt-tightening measures in Albany, including a hiring freeze, he said.
Who controls the federal aid flowing to New York is also shaping up to be a potential battle in Albany. The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, has quietly circulated a proposal to create a Lower Manhattan Resurgence Authority, a joint state and city body that would be charged with repairing the damage caused by the Sept. 11 attack, lifting the area's sagging economy and planning a memorial to the victims.
Mr. Pataki has not said how he would handle the reconstruction, and aides say he is undecided about whether to call for a new agency or rely on an existing one that he controls, as well as about how the state should share power with the city, the federal government or New Jersey.
Mr. Silver's plan, dated last Friday and circulated among some of the Assembly's Democratic majority, envisions an authority controlled equally by the state and the city, though many state officials have said that Albany should have the primary role.
The authority's chairman would be named jointly by the governor and the mayor, who would each also appoint three other board members. The Assembly and Senate leaders, the City Council speaker and the city comptroller would each appoint one. There would also be nonvoting members representing organized labor, various public agencies and the State of New Jersey.
The speaker, who was observing a religious holiday, could not be reached for comment yesterday. A spokesman for Mr. Silver, Charles Carrier, said the governor had been given the proposal on Monday. Michael McKeon, Mr. Pataki's communications director, said he did not believe that the governor's office had seen the plans in writing, and declined to comment on them.
Neither the speaker of the House, J. Dennis Hastert, a Republican, nor the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle, a Democrat, has taken a position on the governor's request. Mr. Pataki was scheduled to meet with both today, after meeting with White House aides in the morning.
The New York delegation is supporting Mr. Pataki, though some say parts of the plan will be a tough sell. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said some of the state's proposals, like tax-exempt bonds for developers, might fit in the economic stimulus bill being drafted. 
"New York was severely attacked," she said. "I think you can make a very strong argument that they are stimulative. There are arguments that I think are legitimate."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: MARKET PLACE; 
A Buyer's Market for Autos Is a Tough Development for Chrysler

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP, Mich., Oct. 10 

 BODY:
Dieter Zetsche is holding an arm's length pair of cardboard scissors. The Romeo High School band has played "The Star Spangled Banner." A big American flag is unfurled into a cloudy sky. Veterans salute and a pastor prays. Now it's time for Mr. Zetsche, the chief executive of the Chrysler Group, to cut the big red ribbon stretching over the entrance of Orchard Chrysler, Jeep, Dodge, a new dealership nestled next to a Fashion Bug and a Farmer Jack, several miles north of Detroit. 
 For Mr. Zetsche, 48, an affable, slim German with small, rounded glasses perched over a walrus mustache, cutting the ribbon is the easy part. 
 The hard part is actually selling the cars. 
"There are very few industries that could claim Sept. 11 had no impact," he said later. "It's wise to assume that the market next year will be smaller than we thought six weeks ago." 
Chrysler's problems, however, were well established before Sept. 11. Mr. Zetsche was dispatched by Stuttgart last year to turn around the ailing Chrysler, which was acquired in 1998 by DaimlerBenz, to form DaimlerChrysler. Since taking over, his task has only seemed to get harder, and last week his company conceded that its turnaround goals were "at risk," partly because of a new wave of incentives instituted by the Big Three automakers to revive flagging sales. 
Such deals make it a buyer's market and overall sales for the industry have rebounded, but at a price. Chrysler spent an average of $2,627 a vehicle on incentives through the first nine months of the year, according to a recent report from Merrill Lynch. That is more than any other carmaker and $589 above the industry average, for a company that had an average net loss, per vehicle, of $579 in the first half of the year.
General Motors, the Ford Motor Company and Chrysler were already losing market share to foreign automakers before Sept. 11, but the attacks led to domestic parts shortages because of transportation problems, some production cuts and the new incentives. But analysts see Chrysler as the weakest link. Heading into what is probably a recession, problems are emerging on all fronts -- falling sales, rising marketing costs, a continued abandonment by American investors and a market share that has fallen so far that many wonder when Toyota Motor will oust Chrysler from the Big Three. 
Making matters worse is that Toyota and other foreign automakers, as well as G.M., are flooding the sport utility vehicle and light truck market, Chrysler's bread and butter. At the same time, Chrysler's own cupboard is relatively bare of a major new vehicle introduction until 2004, leaving it exposed at a time when the appetite of car buyers is expected, even by Mr. Zetsche, to shrink next year. He says that Chrysler's recent new vehicles, like the PT Cruiser and the Jeep Liberty S.U.V., can carry the company.
"We are a company with the youngest product lineup of all our competitors," he said. "Yes, there are less launches next year. But we have great, new, competitive products."
Still, some of its old warhorses are fading. Where its Jeep Grand Cherokee was once a flagship among sport utility vehicles, its sales fell 39 percent in September from the month a year ago. Liberty has not picked up enough slack to compensate. 
Eighty-seven stock mutual funds hold DaimlerChrysler, according to recent reports from Morningstar, a fund tracking firm, down from 282 fund holders in mid-1999. By some valuation measures, the stock now looks cheaper than Ford or G.M., but even managers of value funds, which seek out bargains, are wary.
"I'm not quite sure what they're going to market," said James Benson, the manager of the $275 million Oakmark Small Cap fund and the auto analyst for the Oakmark family of funds. 
"The new management of Chrysler is doing many of the right things, but I'm not excited about their products in the near term," he said. "It kind of takes three, four or five years for the new management to make their mark."
Of the Big Three, Mr. Benson favors Ford, which he says has a better balance sheet and more efficient operations. Like many American fund managers, Mr. Benson appears to have sold out of DaimlerChrysler. Harris Associates, the parent of the Oakmark funds group, sold all of its 313,000 shares of DaimlerChrysler in the second quarter of this year, according to bigdough.com, which tracks Securities and Exchange Commission filings. 
Still, Mr. Benson, like many analysts with negative outlooks for DaimlerChrysler, respects Mr. Zetsche, a longtime executive of Mercedes. He also once ran DaimlerChrysler's Freightliner division -- whose current struggles also weigh down its corporate parent. Mr. Zetsche has managed positive relations with the United Auto Workers and is an engineer by training whose knowledge of cars is respected. 
"Ironically, Daimler buying Chrysler, I think at this point, may be working largely in our favor," said Doug Rothwell, the president of the Michigan Economic Development Corporation, which was formed when the state spun off its commerce department.
"If you had asked people three or four years ago, they would have seen it as a sellout, but nobody wants to see Chrysler be successful more than Schrempp and Zetsche," he added, referring also to Jurgen Schrempp, the chief executive of DaimlerChrysler and the architect of the merger. 
Mr. Zetsche's turnaround plan, announced in February, aims to cut 26,000 jobs, or 20 percent of the work force, by 2003, and also idle six plants around the world. The plan called for a modest profit next year, but analysts find that highly unlikely at this point. Saul Rubin of UBS Warburg now projects a $1.4 billion loss for Chrysler next year. 
"The basic premise is that they would be able to trim costs and sustain their market share at 14 percent," Mr. Rubin said. Chrysler's share has lately fallen into the 11 percent range, while interest-free financing actually helped G.M.'s share rise substantially last month.
"Chrysler did the right things, but they didn't go far enough," Mr. Rubin said. "They have to realize that their market share will continue to go down in the future. You have to adjust your cost structure appropriately."
Jack Shnoravorian, sales manager at Star Chrysler Jeep in Glendale, Calif., now has more than a dozen PT Cruisers on his lot. 
"It came out really strong, but its slowed down recently," he said. "It's cooled off." 
"Before, we didn't have any," he added, referring to last year. "We had to order them and people had to wait as much as a year."

HEADLINE: After Month Off, Parties Resume Efforts 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 

 BODY:
Ending a monthlong respite that followed the terrorist attacks, the Democratic and Republican Parties have resumed political events and the soliciting of contributions. And officials of each party suggested today that their counterparts were capitalizing on the tragedy for partisan gain.
 The Democratic National Committee has asked the Federal Election Commission to waive its rules temporarily so that there is a loosening of those governing soft money, contributions that are unlimited and largely unregulated. In a letter to the election commission, Joseph E. Sandler, the party's general counsel, cited the "national emergency." 
 "In these difficult circumstances," Mr. Sandler wrote, "it will likely continue to prove extremely difficult for the D.N.C. to raise funds of all kinds."
The commission is to consider the matter this month. A waiver would give the Democrats 120 days, rather than the current 60, to make a deposit of soft money into a soft-money account after such funds have been pledged by donors. Failure to meet that deadline has occasionally hindered soft-money budgeting.
Terence R. McAuliffe, the Democratic national chairman, said in an interview that by halting fund-raising after the attacks, the party had lost out on millions of dollars, some of which might have been pumped into the races for governor in New Jersey and Virginia.
"We had to cancel five fund-raisers," Mr. McAuliffe said, adding that he was now scrambling to make up for the lost money.
Asked whether he could recoup it before the elections next month, he said that "you just don't have enough time" but that the campaigns would still take in plenty of party money.
The Republican national chairman, Gov. James S. Gilmore III of Virginia, said his party had resisted entreaties from the Democrats to join them in asking the election commission to suspend its rules.
Mr. Gilmore said he would not criticize the Democrats' request. "We're trying to raise the tone of the debate," he said. 
But other Republicans grumbled at Mr. Sandler's citing the attacks of Sept. 11 in an effort to raise more money. And Scott Harshbarger, president of Common Cause, the nonpartisan group that advocates tightening the campaign finance system, said, "For the Democrats to claim that terrorist attacks somehow justify widening the soft-money loophole is simply not credible."
Democratic officials, meanwhile, suggested that it was the Republicans who were invoking the attacks for political advantage. This week Jack Oliver, the Republicans' deputy national chairman, distributed an e-mail message that encouraged recipients to sign "our online petition in support of President Bush and the war on terrorism." Democrats said they suspected that the Republicans would use the message -- which asks for people's home and e-mail addresses and phone numbers -- to build lists of donors.
"It would be totally inappropriate to be using this national-security crisis and to turn it into a fund-raising appeal," Mr. McAuliffe said. "It would be totally inappropriate and outrageous."
Defending his party's efforts, Governor Gilmore said: "It's just an informational e-mail. We're entitled to keep our members informed of what's going on in Washington."
Mr. Gilmore did acknowledge, however, that not all recipients of the e-mail message were party members, though he denied that the message was a fund-raising tool.
In addition to both parties' resumption of political events and telephone soliciting, the Democrats last week distributed their first mailed solicitation since Sept. 11, and the Republicans plan to send their first mailing on Friday.
In their appeal to thousands of prospective donors, the Democrats said their decision to suspend raising money after the attacks had taken a toll. "It was the right thing to do out of respect to the victims and their families," Mr. McAuliffe wrote. "But today, the D.N.C. is in financial trouble. Due to the suspension of our fund-raising efforts, our bank accounts are nearly dry and we have been forced to cut our budget back to the bare bones." 
In the interview, Mr. McAuliffe said he was not so blatantly partisan as before Sept. 11.
"In every speech, I talk about our 100 percent support for President Bush and our efforts fighting terrorism," he said. "I do talk about that there may be differences related to the economic stimulus package."
Mr. Gilmore said his party, which benefits financially from controlling the White House and having a wider network of contributors than the Democrats, was still flush but had nevertheless tried to return to a normal political schedule.
"We're beginning to gradually resume, but we don't intend to go to a harsh-tone situation," he said. "We're not condemning the Democrats. We intend to basically appeal to our members to support us."
He added that he was surprised by the tone of Mr. McAuliffe's fund-raising solicitation, saying, "I'm not sure I'd be quite as pitiful as that."
As part of the resumption of activity, Vice President Dick Cheney, in his first political foray since Sept. 11, is to speak next week at the annual Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation Dinner in New York, a charity fund-raiser that is traditionally one of the city's biggest political pageants.
And tonight Representative Mark Foley, a Florida Republican, collected about $75,000 for his re-election campaign in a reception at his Capitol Hill home. The event, where donors ate marinated flank steak and skewers of grilled tuna, was originally scheduled for Sept. 11.
"Our work goes on," Mr. Foley said. "Our election will happen regardless of the Sept. 11 date."

Court Shields Chirac From Corruption Inquiries
France's highest court of appeal granted President Jacques Chirac broad presidential immunity while in office, agreeing that as head of state he was above the law. The decision derailed efforts by five investigating magistrates to question him on a range of corruption allegations dating from his time as mayor of Paris. A3

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Ads Down, Yahoo Expects a Hard Quarter

BYLINE:  By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
In the face of a dismal market for advertising, Yahoo said yesterday that it barely met its forecasts for revenue and profit in the third quarter, but it sharply cut its sales forecast for the fourth quarter.
 Yahoo, the largest Web portal, lost $24.1 million, in contrast with a profit of $47.7 million in the period a year earlier. Its sales fell to $166.1 million, from $295.6 million in the third quarter last year. 
 Previously, Yahoo had predicted a rebound in its fourth-quarter sales to as much as $250 million, but yesterday it said its revenue would be in the range of the $160 million to $180 million it had forecast for the recent quarter. 
Terry Semel, Yahoo's chief executive, said, "There is no question that the economy and the market for advertising are not only showing no signs of picking up, but both have shown signs of declining."
As a result, he said, Yahoo is considering further staff cuts on top of a round of layoffs earlier this year. He declined to say how many jobs might be eliminated.
Mr. Semel, the former co-head of the Warner Brothers studio, was appointed Yahoo's chief executive in April. 
Still, shares of Yahoo, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., rose 77 cents in regular-session trading yesterday, to $10.93, and as high as $11.75 after the earnings report.
Anthony Noto, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs, said that the slowdown in business would further delay Yahoo's recovery.
"It is a difficult environment that limits the assets they have to invest in new opportunities," he said.
Yahoo, which at one stage had been one of the few profitable Internet companies, said it would seek to break even in the fourth quarter or make a penny a share, at least by its nonstandard pro forma measure of profits. By that measure, the company also earned $8.4 million in the third quarter, or 1 cent a share, about what analysts had estimated. The pro forma results excluded $18 million in investment losses, $1.5 million in costs related to stock options, and $15 million in acquisition-related costs.
The terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 caused the company to forgo $2 million to $3 million in revenue as a result of the cancellation of advertising contracts.
With the demand for online advertising continuing to fall, Yahoo has put much more emphasis on developing services for which businesses or consumers will pay fees. Indeed, revenue from such services increased 3 percent in the quarter, to $34 million, even as advertising revenue declined 11 percent, to $132 million.
Analysts said there was little unexpected in what Yahoo had released. But the lack of anything exciting in itself was a disappointment.
"A lot of people have been looking for a grand new strategy out of the new management team and they certainly didn't get it," said Paul Noglows, an analyst with J. P. Morgan Chase. "I want more specifics, and I don't think they are there yet."
Mr. Semel said, however, that Yahoo's biggest initiative -- creating services that millions of users would pay fees for -- has taken longer than expected.
Part of the delay, Mr. Semel said, came from his review of Yahoo's management. 
"We were organized into 44 business units, and I wanted to sit down with the managers of each of them to talk about their future," he said. "That process took longer than we thought, but there was no reason to rush through it."
The result of that review, he said, would be a more streamlined organization, although he declined to provide details.
At the same time, he said that Yahoo has to develop technology to offer broad-based consumer services. "Yahoo has never had a product for the masses," he said, "and we needed a payment system that would work for millions of people." 
And similarly it had to hire people skilled in direct subscription marketing rather than the sort of brand advertising it has conducted.
More broadly, Mr. Semel said it had taken longer than he had hoped to hire a new group of executives, especially in the critical advertising sales department. Only yesterday did Yahoo fill the essential job of head of advertising sales in North America, hiring Wenda Harris Millard, a former executive at the Internet advertising firm DoubleClick.
Yahoo's vast audience continued to grow slowly in the recent quarter. It reported 210 million users in September, up 5 percent. 
Despite the falling revenue, Yahoo has a strong balance sheet. Its cash on hand declined by $37 million, to $1.71 billion in the quarter, largely because it repurchased $60 million of its stock. Its accounts payable increased by $19 million.
Analysts were concerned that Yahoo's deferred revenue, essentially its backlog of business for the next two quarters, declined $10 million, to $110 million. And the company said this was another sign that the fourth quarter would be slower than it earlier expected.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Yahoo's chief executive, Terry Semel, is considering more staff cuts. (Associated Press)

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Editorial Desk; Pg. 24

HEADLINE: Federal Help for New York City 

 BODY:
With Mayor Rudolph Giuliani at his side, Gov. George Pataki unveiled a broad plan on Tuesday to make New York economically whole in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center. He asked the federal government for $54 billion to carry it out. The plan, which would reimburse the city and state for everything from cleanup costs to lost tax revenues, is undeniably comprehensive. It is also an excessively ambitious wish list that is too diffuse to generate the kind of support that can be realistically expected from Washington. The two politicians should refine the list, focus on recovery and hew closely to the maxim enunciated by the mayor himself: "The federal aid that we ask for should be honestly connected to the World Trade Center." 
 Washington has already approved about $17 billion in federal aid, much of it for clearing the site and rebuilding public infrastructure serving Lower Manhattan. Most experts believe the city will need double that amount and perhaps more to finish these tasks, as well as to provide services to victims' families and to help the many small businesses wiped out by the collapse of the towers. Filling these basic needs -- and setting up a special federal recovery zone for Lower Manhattan, which the plan also envisages -- should be the primary focus. 
 The governor estimated recovery and rebuilding costs at $34 billion and tacked on $20 billion more in various projects that would go forward if President Bush and Congress agree on a national economic stimulus package. Included in the stimulus component was $12 billion in restitution for lost city and state tax revenues, along with a laundry list of transportation and other public projects that had been sitting on the shelf.
Aides said yesterday that Mr. Pataki had intended to make a sharp distinction between the recovery projects and the list. But because this distinction was not clearly drawn, the governor, who is New York's point man in Washington this week, appeared to be invoking a tactic that works better in Albany than in Washington -- laying every possible option on the table as an opening bid. One item on the list, for example, would expedite high-speed rail service from Schenectady to New York City -- hardly the sort of idea to arouse sympathy in Congress. Projects like these can be financed later as part of an overall stimulus package but should not be confused with restoration.
Mr. Giuliani's own announcement of budget cuts sent a clearer signal to Washington that New York City, as he put it, is not running to Congress with a tin cup. The mayor wisely instituted an official hiring freeze and announced that this year's budget would be cut by $1 billion. At the same time, the mayor appealed to New York's Congressional delegation to seek additional money from Medicaid and other federal accounts. These are useful first steps in what is sure to be a protracted struggle to get the city's budget under control.
Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Pataki, never an easy pair, have been working together reasonably well since the attacks. They must continue to cooperate for vital lobbying in Washington to repair the damage to New York City.
